(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: That's a -- that's tap dance, verbal tap dancing. I hear it's - - because listen, they in Washington have been talking about cutting in a contribution limit from $18,000 a year, it's $18,500 next year to $2,400, that's a fact. And now you get this response.

RASMUSSEN: And I think it's something that shouldn't furiate you. It's also a great example though of what the problem is with trying to predict tax reform and what it will end up being.

401(k)s themselves were never intended to be what they became. It was a mistake written to the law, a guy named Ted Benna actually read the law and figured out somehow Congress had made this mistake and we now have tens of millions of people who see this is a cornerstone of retirement.

MCDOWELL: Well because it is. Because they lost --

GABRIELLE: It is. It absolutely is.

RASMUSSEN: That's correct.

GABRIELLE: And they're talking about those pretax contribution limits are going to be huge issue. You say that this has to get done, this tax plan has to be done but the devil's going to be at the details when they hash this out.

And yesterday, we saw 20 noes and that was because of the state and local taxes and those deductions. So I guess my question is, you see it has to get done, how can it get done when we have seen no details yet?

RASMUSSEN: What you will see happening is state and local deductions, there's a big issue for people who live in New York and New Jersey, that affects higher income earners more to lower income people.

And that's where the money is. So that's why these fights will be so intense. The popular support around the country is to get rid of these things that benefit high income people. High income earners are the ones with the most influence.

So I think you'll end up seeing is something will be done on state and local deductions but it will not be a full of a nation. I think you'll see the same thing with 401(k)s, they will trim something back, not as much as they're talking about right now.

And they're going to do it with one goal in mind, it has nothing to do with economics, it will all be, "Where's the 50 first votes?"

She asked him about everything from Artificial Intelligence to investment communities or opportunities. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BARTIROMO: When you first founded PayPal, we were in a different time. Today, we are talking about data, we're talking about the Cloud, we're talking about digitizing our life and technology is the under pending of every industry whether it's driverless cars or collecting data. So zero in for us on industries, where are you finding opportunity to invest in industry?

PETER THIEL, PARTNER OF FOUNDERS FUND: Certainly, you know, for example, Airbnb, SpaceX, Facebook earlier on, you know, investments I made and each of these companies, you can describe them as part of the trends or the sharing economy or social networking for Facebook. But, that's a misleading way to describe it. It was much better to think of them as solving a very specific problem.

Airbnb was, sort of, a hotel room substitute. It's not the sharing economy obstruction. It's the hotel room substitute. It's the only company that's doing that on a worldwide scale and that makes it a one of a kind company. Facebook somehow figured out real identity.

BARTIROMO: One scene that we've been talking about, of course, here, is what his Highness is doing with NEOM and all of the technology that is going to be in this new city of the future. Where do you see the opportunities in terms of starting from scratch? When you have a city, what kind of technologies are going to be most needed?

THIEL: Well, it's -- there's a tremendous amount that one can do when one starts something new from scratch, because one thing that is striking about the great cities of the world, like London, New York, you know, Silicon Valley, very many other places. It is but -- even though there are these incredibly dynamic economic places, it's extremely hard to change things. And so, you know, New York City, it costs $1 billion to build one mile of subway, or something like that.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

THIEL: In San Francisco, you can't -- you can't build new highways or anything new. The transportation grid is set, and so there is -- there is this very weird transportation problem with the big cities where in effect, it becomes incredibly hard to build new transportation once the basic city has been built. If the transportation systems are inadequate and i would say they are badly inadequate in all of our major cities even in the developed world, emerging world, the catastrophic developed world, they are generally inadequate.

The self-driving car trend, it's against the trend. It's a very important trend for the economy, for -- and change consumer behavior tremendously. If you have self-driving cars, maybe you could have a longer commute because you could work in the car or, you know, maybe some things -- some things would change. I'm not sure it's a good investment because there are a lot of companies doing similar technologies in self-driving cars. It's hard to know exactly how to differentiated they are.

BARTIROMO: And people are worried that the more A.I. and machine learning you have, in a situation, the fewer jobs you have. So, are robots going to be taking our jobs?

THIEL: Well, it's -- one of the things -- you know, I'm always nervous about the abstractions, A.I. is one of the greatest abstractions of all because Artificial Intelligence can mean the next generation of computers or the last generation of computers or anything in between. We can mean things that are like a little bit in the future or, you know, very far in the future.

If you had generalized Artificial Intelligence, this, sort of, where you had a computer that was smarter and more able in every way possible, I would say that the problem with that is not economic but political. It'll be like an alien from another planet landing and the question, if aliens landed on earth, would not be, what does this mean for the unemployment rate, the question would be, are they friendly, are they unfriendly, things like that.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's a good point.

THIEL: And so -- and so I think to the extent the economic question is serious, it's much more the political question.

BARTIROMO: What can we do to protect ourselves in this new world where we feel like everyone's getting hacked and data has become so much more powerful?

THIEL: Well, there is a -- there's a tremendous amount that we can do in combining computers with humans. And, you know, a lot of the approaches in crime, defense, areas like this, and security, have been -- we either have all human solutions or all computer solutions and I think the truth is, that there's a lot to be done with these intermediate hybrid solutions.

And what we did at PayPal, and what we've done at pounds here, is figure out a good division of labor between human analysts and automated computer systems. And it turns out that if you get the division of labor right, you can do a lot. One of the challenges with cybersecurity is that it's -- there is something about it where it's very asymmetric. That, you know, in most forms of defense, military technologies, the defense side is pretty good.

But in cybersecurity, it's very hard to defend. It's very easy to attack. And so if you have something where it's incredibly easy to attack, incredibly hard to defend, that creates some very unusual challenges. I think -- I think we haven't quite figured out what to do about them. We certainly are not able to defend as well as we can, we're not willing to take the precautions that are needed and it really calls out for some big - - a lot more work in the decade ahead.

BARTIROMO: You've been really successful in terms of watching where the growth is in the world, and identifying the companies that are, you know, solving important problems, what excites you right now?

THIEL: I do think people are a little bit -- maybe underestimating Bitcoin, specifically, because it is like -- it's like a reserved form of money, it's like gold and it's just a store value, you don't actually need to use make payments, and it's been, you know, there's about $70 billion worth of Bitcoin in the world.

There's $9 trillion worth of gold and if Bitcoin ends up being the cyber equivalent of gold, and it has -- it has a -- it has a great potential left, so that's -- and it's a very different kind of thing from what people in Silicon Valley normally focus on, companies, not, you know, algorithms or protocols but, this may be -- this may be one exception that's very underestimated.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5X8P-KV71-DXH2-63JP-00000-00Earnings in Focus; Hunter Biden Breaks His Silence; Partial U.S.- China Trade Deal; Bank Earnings; Federal Reserve Chairman Jay Powell: We are Watching Global Growth, Trade; Former Russia Adviser Testifies on Impeachment Inquiry; Brexit Deadline Approaches; 737 Max and Southwest Airlines Pilots Don't Expect to Fly Plane until February; Yuengling Celebrates 190 Years of Brewing2019-10-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:41ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTCharles Plosser, Jen Yuengling, Debbie Yuengling, Jack Otter, Cabot Phillips, Ken LeonNEWSDomestic101502cb.231Earnings in Focus; Hunter Biden Breaks His Silence; Partial U.S.- China Trade Deal; Bank Earnings; Federal Reserve Chairman Jay Powell: We are Watching Global Growth, Trade; Former Russia Adviser Testifies on Impeachment Inquiry; Brexit Deadline Approaches; 737 Max and Southwest Airlines Pilots Don't Expect to Fly Plane until February; Yuengling Celebrates 190 Years of BrewingMaria Bartiromo, Lauren Simonetti, Kimberley Strassel

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back.

Good Tuesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. It is a busy one.

I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Tuesday, October 15th.

Your top stories right now 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Earnings season kicking into high gear. JPMorgan out this morning with a beat on revenue. Jamie Dimon saying that the U.S. consumer remains healthy.

Johnson & Johnson also out last hour with a double beat. J&J also raising its full year guidance.

Check out the stocks. JPM up 1.25 percent. Johnson & Johnson up 2.25 percent. We're waiting on other big banks this morning. Gold Sachs, Wells Fargo, Citigroup -- all on tap, ahead of the open.

We're going to have a rock and roll show this morning with all these numbers coming out. We will have the numbers and full analysis as soon as they hit the tape.

Meanwhile markets are higher going into the rest of the earnings period. Dow Industrials right now indicating a gain at the start of trading, up 95 points. The S&P futures are up 8.5. And the Nasdaq futures higher by 18.75 points. That's a quarter of a percent higher pretty much across the board.

There is uncertainty over the deal with China now and that certainly weighed on markets yesterday. Even though the market closed off of the lows of the day yesterday.

Dow Industrials were down about 30 points at the close yesterday. The S&P was down 4 points and the Nasdaq lower by eight and a third at 4:00 on Wall Street.

Global markets this morning are mixed. Take a look at European indices where the FT 100 is down 21 points. But the CAC 40 in Paris is up 30. And the DAX index in Germany is up 57.

In Asia overnight markets were mixed. Take a look. As you see, the best performer was Japan. Nikkei average up 1.87 percent. In China, inflation is surging. The consumer price index hitting 3 percent for September. The outbreak of the swine flu pushing pork prices up 69.3 percent year over year. That is the reason that the Chinese want to buy pork from the U.S. and soybeans.

Hunter Biden breaks his silence, defending his foreign ventures but admitting to making mistakes.

Plus this -- the push for impeachment. Speaker Nancy Pelosi to hold closed door meetings as lawmakers return to Capitol Hill this week. This as more people are testifying. We have all the latest from the impeachment inquiry.

The streaming wars deepen. Disney gives a sneak peek at the massive amount of content coming to its service. This as the major theater chain enters the field. We will tell you all about it.

All those stories coming up this Tuesday morning. And joining me to break it all down: Fox Business' Deirdre Bolton; CampusReform.org editor in chief, Cabot Phillips; and Barron's editor Jack Otter. Great to see everybody this morning.

JACK OTTER, EDITOR, BARRON'S: Good morning. Good to be here.

BARTIROMO: You know, I love earnings season because it gives us that window into really where we are. We have a lot of headlines in terms of where we are but when you actually see the numbers, you get a sense of just how slow the economy is or not slow -- Deirdre.

DEIRDRE BOLTON, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes. And third quarter earnings are expected to drop, if you look at this quarter versus last year at this time, 2.2 percent. But on the upside, sales expected to grow, this is net-net (INAUDIBLE), 3.7 percent.

Personally, I think that's a great sign. It shows competitive advantage. Earnings you can always manage, profitability somehow squeeze some department more than another. But sales are sales.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Look at Johnson & Johnson. Even with 100,000 plaintiffs, they're getting sued all over the place, battling, losing a lot of cases in the court, they actually raised their guidance and had better than expected numbers on J&J. Their stock is up 2.25 percent.

The top story this hour is JPMorgan, we told you the numbers earlier. The markets are reacting to these better than expected earnings on JPMorgan this morning. Still with us this morning -- and the stock is up 2 percent is -- still with us this morning is CFRA director of equity research, Ken Leon.

And Ken -- the numbers were expected to be weak in the third quarter. But are we getting the first signs that we're actually seeing higher than expected from the lowered estimates?

KEN LEON, DIRECTOR OF EQUITY RESEARCH, CFRA: It's all coming on the surprise in the non-net interest income areas. So JPMorgan on leaked cables (ph) usually being number one or two in underwriting, strong in the consumer lending and maybe U.S. commercial lending is still strong too.

But the breaking news from China, one has to pause and say, well, how much revenue is coming outside the U.S. Most of the banks it's about 35 percent. There will be a lot of questions related to Asia. And for Citi, which is also one of four banks reporting, that has a higher sensitivity.

BARTIROMO: You make a really good point, because one of the gives that China made just this the last week of negotiations was that it would lift the limits that foreign companies have faced for a long time in terms of owning your own bank, owning your own insurance company.

And people saw that as a real positive even though it wasn't really new information, by the way. That's been talked about for a long time. But does that represent a nice runway for these banks?

LEON: It's really important. Because when you think about Europe, and it's been the same, it's a slow economy, maybe to recession, and it's not a capital markets-driven market. So for the banks to really grow, you need Asia.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

BOLTON: Can I ask you one quick question? Did you see that move that Maria talked about? Will U.S. institutions open now more now on mainland China and defavorize (ph) Hong Kong which has traditionally been the western -- quote/unquote -- center in the east.

BARTIROMO: Such a good question.

LEON: It's a great question. But it's not in the next few years for sure. And even for the Hong Kong stock exchange to make a bid for the London Stock Exchange, just to be more global that was their hedge -- it didn't work out.

China has inside four major exchanges, but they do need Hong Kong because that's their gateway to more sophisticated derivatives and other instruments.

BARTIROMO: Yes. But's no secret that London doesn't want to go anywhere near the Hong Kong Stock Exchange and merge because they don't want to have China's authoritarian rule.

LEON: And that was done late in the day because London stock exchange already had a major transaction with Thompson Reuters.

BARTIROMO: Can we a bit talk about JPMorgan here for a second. Now Jack - - we know that the consumer has been the best part of this economic recovery.

OTTER: Sure.

BARTIROMO: And once again, the consumer is saving JPM because the corporate side has some holes in it with the Wework situation.

OTTER: Yes. Well, two interesting points that are totally unrelated. Wework -- I think the problem with the Weworks and the Ubers and these other companies is that they were literally giving you a dollar for 90- cents, 80-cents. With Wework they would lease the space and then they would chop it up. But they would lease it to you for less than their cost.

Uber -- you're getting a $15 cab ride for 10 bucks. That is unsustainable and it doesn't scale. The bigger they get, the more they lose. So that's the problem with that segment and we shouldn't say that all IPOs are bad because a software company does scale and they can do well.

So I think somebody referred to the fact that the market was finally getting smart. I think that was Ken. I think we're there.

LEON: And that's the capital markets.

I will say for the large banks thought, they've been conservative on commercial real estate lending. Certainly remembering the great recession, so their credit standards are toughest probably for commercial real estate.

BARTIROMO: Ken -- we're waiting on Goldman Sachs, we're waiting on Citi. Give us your sense of what we should be focused on when the Goldman numbers come out.

LEON: Goldman, obviously still number one, two or three player tables in elite tables for investment banking. What you have to watch is the quality of the results, the quality of the earnings. Last quarter it was a segment which is about 25 percent of revenue called investing and lending. That's their proprietary arm. That made Q2.

Let's see what Q3 is. And then there been, you know, more talk about diversification. This is a really smart management, new management, but its mark is the pathway.

And then, of course, you've got to remember with Goldman or Morgan Stanley, more so than larger banks, trading commission. And last week we had Schwab. Trading commission is still more institutional driven but there's a component that is still retail.

BOLTON: Is it smart --

(CROSSTALKING)

BARTIROMO: -- disrupting the financial services industry now for decades and they did it again two weeks ago -- Deirdre.

BOLTON: Yes. I was going to ask, going from an institutional, somebody who serves institutions versus somebody who is serving now both institutions and retail. How is that going for Goldman? I mean you alluded to markets.

LEON: Absolutely. And bringing it back to Goldman, markets gets a lot of attention. But they're making acquisitions in asset management and areas where they have recurring revenue, cash flow. If you have that consistency, you get a higher valuation.

BARTIROMO: All right. Great stuff.

Goldman Sachs estimate $4.81 a share on revenue of $8.31 billion. That stock is up going into the numbers. We're waiting on that. Ken -- it's great to have you this morning.

LEON: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. Ken Leon joining us there.

Let's slip in a short break.

When we come back, former Philadelphia Federal Reserve president, Charles Plosser on trade uncertainty in the Federal Reserve.

Then the author of "Resistance at All Cost", the "Wall Street Journal's" editorial board member and one of really a hero for this show. Kim Strassl is here on the impeachment inquiry.

Odeon Capitol Group, chief financial strategist, Dick Bove here, is reacting to the bank earnings.

And Kentucky Senator and author of "The Case against Socialism" Rand Paul on the Syrian-Turkey conflict. He's become a real adviser for the president on Syria. We're going to get into that.

Plus, Hunter Biden breaks his silence, we're going to talk about it. Joe Biden's son off on the controversy surrounding him and his father's campaign for president. We'll tell you what he said when we come back.

Plus streaming wars intensifying, Disney rolls out a preview for its new service as other company enters the race for subscribers. Wait until you see how deep and wide the Disney content is. Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Well, Hunter Biden admits he made a mistake.

Lauren Simonetti with the details now and headlines -- Lauren.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: And Maria -- the 49- year-old son of the former vice president and now 2020 hopeful Joe Biden admitting he made a political mistake. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Do you regret being on the board to begin with?

HUNTER BIDEN, JOE BIDEN'S SON: No, I don't regret being on the board. What I regret is not taking into account that there would be a Rudy Giuliani and a president of the United States that would be listening to this ridiculous conspiracy idea.

Did I make a mistake? Well, maybe in the grand scheme of things, yes. But did I make a mistake based upon some unethical lapse? Absolutely not.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: Hunter Biden said he will step down from the board of a Chinese private equity firm at the end of the month as part of a pledge not to work on behalf of any foreign companies should his father win the White House.

A massive recall hits Taco Bell, 2.3 billion pounds of seasoned beef has been removed from restaurants in 21 states because it may have been contaminated with metal shavings. This issue reported Saturday. No reports of injuries.

Disney's new streaming service launch's next month. But the three hour trailer is already out. You can watch it now. It shows all the movies and shows subscribers can look forward to when the service becomes available November 12th.

And competition for streaming is growing. AMC theaters becoming the first movie theater chain to enter the home entertainment business, launching a video on demand service that will be available to members of its customer loyalty program. AMC has a catalog of over 2,000 films that members can buy or rent. And of course you earn loyalty points so this also encourages you to actually go to the movie theater. So it's a win-win. You got to like that.

BARTIROMO: Ok. Yes. No, that's good.

CABOT PHILLIPS, EDITOR IN CHIEF, CAMPUSREFORM.ORG: We have to leave our houses? What?

BARTIROMO: Well, we have such great TV, so it's like, you know -- big set up.

BOLTON: And so many choices.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

Let's talk Hunter Biden for a second. Cabot -- your reaction. I mean just the fact that he says I'm not going to go on any foreign boards or, you know, have foreign relations if my father's president, is this an admission that it's improper.

PHILLIPS: Yes. It's tough to say -- look, there's no law (ph) saying there was nothing wrong with it. However, if my father's the president, I won't do it again. If there's nothing wrong with it then why not continue to do it?

And interesting point also, anything he is saying, Joe Biden, his campaign are giving him directly to say. That's the clear message. He's not saying this of his own will. I think this is clearly a message coming from the campaign.

Also important to point out what this does to Joe Biden as a candidate. This draws more attention to the fact that he and his family have benefited greatly from capitalism, from business. They've made millions of dollars from crony capitalism and that's something that is hugely unpopular right now with the electorate.

So you've got a lot of Democrat voters right now that are trying to run as far away as they can from wealth, from capitalism, saying it's evil to be rich. And now you have your main candidate and his family reaping the benefits of that same system.

This is going to be hurt him in the long run. This will certainly be used not just by President Trump politically speaking but also from other candidates. We're going to see it come up on the debate stage (INAUDIBLE).

BARTIROMO: Well, that's what I was going to ask you. You know, who pokes him about this tonight on the debate stage when they'll all going to be there -- 12 candidates tonight are going to face off for this next debate.

And you know, the fact that he traveled with his father, then a sitting vice president, on Air Force 2 when his father had official business in China and then came home and 10 days later gets this injection of $1 billion which turns into $1.5 billion from a Chinese state bank.

PHILLIPS: Yes. I think Biden's initial reaction was oh, it's just my kid, leave my kid out of it. He's a 49-year-old man. And when he's making this kind of money, it's no longer safe to say, well, there was no reaction there. If you're asking who you think is going to bring it up tonight on the debate stage, you obviously think Elizabeth Warren, given the attacks that she's made against other candidates, accusing them of cronyism, of capitalism also as well.

I don't know if she will. She's kind of gliding right now. I don't know if she wants to make an enemy with Biden because she's the rising, ascendant candidate right now. It might be one of the lower candidates trying to punch up to get Biden to react to them. But it will interesting to see.

BARTIROMO: Well, Bernie yesterday came out and said, you know, Elizabeth Warren is a capitalist. Whoa. Ok.

PHILLIPS: Yes.

BOLTON: Which probably actually is going to help her with Independents.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well, she's handled this campaign really well.

BOLTON: She has. I mean it's become a bit of a joke -- I have a plan for that.

BARTIROMO: Right.

BOLTON: But people are responding to that. I mean I think she's not worth underestimating.

BARTIROMO: I'll tell you one thing, the banks are quaking in their boots this morning if she is the candidate and if she does get the presidency.

BOLTON: Big tech as well.

BARTIROMO: Exactly. Big tech and banks.

Bank earnings this morning is how we're focused on on the sector. Full swing -- Goldman Sachs expected out moments from now. We will have the number when we come. The stock is up 1.25 percent ahead of its quarterly numbers.

Then this, celebrating American made, the country's oldest brewery here on set later this hour. Don't miss it.

Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

We are looking ahead to the opening bell where we are expecting a triple digit rally at the start of trading. Dow futures right now up 103 points. We are getting better than expected earnings this morning.

The markets ended the session slightly lower yesterday. Investors still skeptical about that partial U.S.-China trade deal and whether issues over intellectual property will actually be addressed by the Trump administration.

We are also looking at better than expected earnings in the banking sector this morning. JPMorgan reporting a better than expected number as did Johnson & Johnson and pharmaceuticals.

Joining us right now is the former president of the Philadelphia Federal Reserve, Charles Plosser. And Charles -- it is great to see you this morning. Thanks so much for being here.

Charles Plosser -- can you hear me? Looks like we have an audio problem for Charles Plosser. We're going to get back to him in a second.

And I what I really want to ask the former president of the Philly Fed is where are we in terms of the growth story. How much of this trade uncertainty is impacting overall growth and we know that the consumers is strong but is he seeing it as well? What's your take on where we are?

OTTER: Well, there's an interesting thing happening in markets right now which is that we are lowering interest rates and increasing spending 10 years into an expansion. That's extremely unusual.

Normally you see the deficit shrinking, you would see interest rates rising, and also people say the Fed is what pushes you into recession because the rates go too high.

We're seeing the opposite this time so does that mean we'll have the -- you know, the longest expansion on record will get even longer? Is he here?

So will the longer expansion than ever keep on going? This is what's called -- sorry to get geeky on you, it's called pro-cyclical stimulus. Because the stimulus is coming at the same time that the expansion continues. Very unusual -- it's really an experiment. We'll see how it ends.

BARTIROMO: Yes. We'll see. Charles Plosser -- are you with us, former president of the Philadelphia Federal Reserve? Are you with us -- Charles?

CHARLES PLOSSER, FORMER PRESIDENT OF PHILADELPHIA FEDERAL RESERVE: Yes, I am -- Maria. Good to be with you again.

BARTIROMO: Oh, terrific. Yes -- apologies for that issue with your audio. We're glad you're here.

What's your take on the growth story today for the U.S. economy? Taking into consideration this uncertainty that we're all talking about every day over trade policy.

PLOSSER: Well, I think the basic signs for the economy are still pretty good. Yes, there's been some softening in manufacturing in particular because of the trade issues and the uncertainty. Consumers still seem to be holding up pretty strong. And so I think the economy's still doing ok.

But there remains a lot of uncertainty out there as we've all talked about and I don't think that uncertainty is going to go away very quickly but we'll have to wait and see.

BARTIROMO: Well, in terms of the Federal Reserve and what it can do here, you know, we've had two late summer rate cuts. The Fed expected to put in place yet another cut coming up in the next two weeks amid this potential global slowdown. you know, we're waiting to see if this is actually going to take effect.

I mean this is one criticism that what can the Fed do in the face of the trade uncertainty? Do you think the fed cutting rates is actually going to impact this -- Deirdre?

BOLTON: Honestly, I'd like to hear from our guest on that because I think, you know, the fact is, they're cutting rates at the same time that they're increasing liquidity, right. And that was a reference that our -- or a point that our guest from Stifel had made earlier. And he actually seems pretty optimistic on the next 12 months.

But to Jack's point -- I don't know that we've ever seen this before. An 11-year bull run and expansion at the same time that we're continuing to inject -- I'm not going to call it stimulus, but some flexibility into the system.

OTTER: I would call it stimulus. There's a lot of spending going on. And then the other question with low rates is, does one quarter point really make a big company say ok, now I can afford to build that new factory. Rates are so low right now. How much lower can they go.

BOLTON: I feel like for business leaders it always comes down to confidence, right. If they feel confident, then they spend and they invest and then they hire. And I think a lot of this U.S.-China trade war, what that has done for the past 18 months is just provide another element of instability.

I'm not saying it robs leaders of confidence but it gives them perhaps more pause than they otherwise would have taken. So in that way, I do think the Fed's cutting may mitigate some of those concerns or maybe some of that unwillingness to invest and hire.

BARTIROMO: We're waiting on Goldman Sachs earnings. And that's going to give us a good window in terms of the banking sector. There was an event in London where the St. Louis Federal Reserve president James Bullard, said that the American economy is slowing. He's calling for insurance rate cuts.

So do you want to get rate cuts in place before we actually see this slowdown, you know, deepen?

PLOSSER: So there's Rob Arnott is a really interesting guy. Runs a company that creates models for ETFs. And he makes that point that you can never see the recession coming before it gets there. And then what happens is the Fed always starts cutting when it's too late, like the recession is already on the way.

In fact often, he thinks they caused it by raising rates. So it's possible that maybe we did actually get ahead of it this time. That's the optimistic view.

BOLTON: That's the optimistic view. I'll take the other side just to be devil's advocate. The pessimistic view is we're cutting when we don't need to and when the recession arrives there's no more arrows in the quiver.

PLOSSER: I'm not going to argue with you.

BARTIROMO: We've got a miss on Goldman Sachs. The earnings coming in at $4.79 -- we told earlier that the estimate was $4.81. And there's a lot behind these numbers. Let's go behind the headlines with Susan Li right now as the stock trades down on the Goldman Sachs third quarter earnings -- Susan.

SUSAN LI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Yes, that's right. So it looks like bottom line, they're a bit of a miss. But in terms of revenue numbers, it's pretty much in line. So $8 billion, $8.32 billion is what we got from the quarter, estimates are calling for 8.31. Pretty much in line.

Now, don't forget, that Goldman Sachs is a little bit different from JPM, more of an investment banking, pure play if you want to call it that. And they did see some positives in the quarter with revenues and equities, they say higher due to higher commissions and that reflects increased client activity because for a long time we were looking at stagnant trading in the markets just going one way.

But higher activity means more fees for Goldman Sachs. Tough quarter, though, for GS because they did have to write down their 1.4 percent stake in Wework, down by a quarter of a billion dollars.

They also had to write down according to analysts their stakes in Uber, Avantor (ph), Trade Web, Head Hunter group and those clients total of a quarter of a billion dollars as well

Not good investments so for Goldman Sachs. But I'll be interested to hear what they say about the partnership with the new Apple card. And how that's going on their earnings call.

Maria -- back to you.

BARTIROMO: Yes. We called it at the top of the show, this Wework situation is impacting things at JPMorgan as well as Goldman Sachs. Obviously, you're seeing a bigger hit here on Goldman Sachs with the numbers missing estimates.

BOLTON: And even that partnership that Susan just alluded to, chew with Apple and this Apple card, and our guest from CFRA was talking about Goldman's move, bigger footprint into retail banking for people, not institutions.

And I felt like that deal with Apple was one more way for Goldman to get data, for one.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's true.

BOLTON: And then for two, let itself be a little bit more known among average consumers and average bankers, normal main street people, not institutions.

OTTER: Another move they made in that exact same vein was to buy United Capital, which is an independent advisory firm. It's only $25 billion dollars under management. Not a big move for Goldman.

BOLTON: But part of that diversification.

OTTER: Exactly. And to the man on the street, you know, it's Morgan Stanley, it's not that man on the street -- it's a wealthy individual but they've done a brilliant job of just they decided at the time of the crash I think that was their future was the advisory business -- Goldman taking a little step in that direction.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Stock is down three quarters of a percent right now.

And we're back with Charles Plosser. He is the former president of the Philadelphia Federal Reserve. Charles -- let me get your take on the health of the banking sector today. I mean obviously, these banks have more capital. They're holding more capital than they want to. But it has been a good thing when you look at the stress test.

Do you think we've overdone it in terms of the regulatory environment on the banks with regard to their capital rules?

PLOSSER: Well, I think they clearly are more healthy. I think their capital is up and I think that's a good thing.

However, I do think that the regulatory environment has had some unintended consequences in the side effects of sort of a micro regulation that goes on, for liquidity and other things that the banks have to do.

And I think that regulation is part of the source of the problem we had in the repo market turmoil a couple, few weeks ago. And I think the fed needs to be looking at the plumbing and how their regulatory rules interact with the functioning of the markets, and particularly the money markets in particular.

So I think there's some issues that need to be resolved. I don't think just throwing more reserves at the banking system is going to solve the kind of problems that we have.

BARTIROMO: Yes, you make a good point because that was that one night when, you know, rates in the repo market went from 2 percent to 10 percent overnight. There was not enough liquidity.

I mean a lot of people say that the fed should have seen this, there wasn't enough liquidity there. But you say it's just too stringent rules on the capital.

CHARLES PLOSSER, FORMER PRESIDENT, FEDERAL RESERVE BANK OF PHILADELPHIA: Well, part -- it's partly that. But it's the liquidity requirements and it's the fact that the large balance sheet the Fed's trying to operate in has undermined what used to be the Fed funds market, where banks traded funds with each other.

And that's not functioning much anymore because there's so many Fed funds out there that the banks really don't worry about trading it very much. I think that's contributed to the inability for reserves, which is what the Fed supplies, to move around in the marketplace and meet these shocks that come -- that come in.

So I think it's a combination of factors that are just throwing more reserves isn't going to solve the problem.

BARTIROMO: Yes, it's really great analysis from you on that, Charles. Real quick before you go, we have another Fed meeting in two weeks, it's I think it's 70 percent that the market thinks that we're going to get another rate cut.

Assess the backdrop for us, Charles. Is that warranted right now given the fact that we are looking at a 50 year low in unemployment and the consumer is where it is? But I know that CapEx spending has slowed down quite a bit and there's uncertainties around trade.

PLOSSER: Well, I -- my own sense is that the Fed may very well cut rates again. I'm not convinced of that. I think it's far from a foregone conclusion. I think the problem is, is that, yes, CapEx spending has slowed and softened, partly due to the uncertainty.

But I don't think cutting rates is going to solve that problem. It's not going to make firms more confident about the future. It's not going to make -- get rid of the uncertainty and so I'm not sure it would have much effect, even if they did it.

So I think -- I think -- I don't think another cut is far from -- is far from a foregone conclusion at this point and markets might be surprised at the reaction of the Fed.

BARTIROMO: All right. We will leave it there. Charles, we want to apologize for any audio issues we had this morning. We hope you'll come back soon. Thank you, sir.

PLOSSER: Thanks, Maria.

BARTIROMO: It's good to see you, Charles Plosser. We'll be back with Kim Strassel from the Wall Street Journal. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Our top story this half an hour, the high stakes whistleblower standoff, Congress returns from recess today. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi expected to hold a closed door meeting on the Hill for an update on the impeachment inquiry.

President Trump's former Russia advisor Fiona Hill testifying in front of three House panels for nearly nine hours yesterday. Of course it was all closed doors.

Sources tell Fox News that she had high praise for the ousted U.S. Ambassador to Ukraine and Republican Congressman Matt Gaetz getting the boot from the hearing because he is not on one of those committees that's conducting the investigation. Gaetz slammed the call last night on Hannity, watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. MATT GAETZ (R-FL): Today, Adam Schiff removed me as a member of the Judiciary Committee from the deposition he was taking. This is proof that Democrats can't win a fair election, they can't win a fair debate and they absolutely cannot run a fair impeachment inquiry because they're stacking the deck. They're doing everything they can to limit our access to witnesses and evidence. They're not allowing us to call witnesses.

And by the way, if Republicans had a witness list, it would be Adam Schiff who would be a fact witness because of the collusion that he was -- and his staff were engaged in with the whistleblower that they then lied about.

So look, we're going to keep fighting to get to the facts here.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining me right now is Fox News contributor, the Wall Street Journal editorial board member and the author of Resistance (At All Costs), author Kimberley Strassel. Kim Strassel, it is great to have you on the show this morning.

KIMBERLEY STRASSEL, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: It is great to be here, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us. You have done such an astute and fantastic job covering all of this, we are -- you really are our hero on this program. We talk about your op-ed every day, actually.

Tell me about your reaction to what is taking place now for us before we get into the book, in terms of this inquiry and all of these testimonies that are happening behind closed doors.

STRASSEL: Well, we just saw it today; there are endless stories with leaks about what Fiona Hill said in this testimony yesterday. But we don't really know what she said because it's all being presented, again, behind closed doors and then you see Democrats spinning a narrative. This is really high stakes. It's impeachment. The American people deserve to see transcripts; they deserve to see what's going on so that they can make their own judgment about what happened.

BARTIROMO: You know, you've covered the origins of the Russia investigation so well. This has been a story that I care about deeply.

STRASSEL: You've been great on this.

BARTIROMO: Thank you, because I feel like on any side of the aisle, you have to be upset when you see a cabal of people, whether from the FBI or the CIA, trying to put their finger on the scale and use the tools that we use for terrorists and you're just seeing more of this with this obstruction. What's your reaction to what's taking place?

STRASSEL: You just made a great point, which is that everyone should care about this deeply and there would have been a time when everybody did care about this deeply. Some of us still do.

But just being able to say the FBI started a counter-intelligence investigation into a sitting presidential campaign is an as astonishing statement. And then the more that we find out about how it actually did so and the abuse of power that was going on. We've already heard some of that from the I.G., don't take it from me. The inspector general has already put out a report on Comey and McCabe and made clear.

And this is the kind of damage I'm talking about in the book that people like to say Donald Trump is destroying institutions and democracy, but look at the loss of faith in the FBI and the DOJ. That is a result of folks who abuse their power and Americans say -- because they didn't like this president and it scares Americans.

BARTIROMO: In the book you write that it's not just the left, the media has also jumped on-board and you've got the media driving the bus on this in terms of, you know, focusing on some things but not focusing on other things.

So, the media refuses to look at the origins of the Russia investigation, where we know that they inserted Donald Trump into the story of Russia meddling into the United States.

STRASSEL: Well, no, I have a whole chapter on this, about all the ways that they lowered their standards to using anonymous sources. And you and I both know at least some of those have got to be the people that are accused of wrongdoing at this moment, but they present them as neutral, just running with false accusations. And what bothers me is I think we're seeing a repeat of this now with the Ukrainian story and which is why it's so important.

Look, America suffered through two years of the Mueller investigation, this hyped, what was a hoax in the end. And that was driven in large part by Democrats leaks and media being involved. I think we're seeing a repeat now. And it's why Americans need to be able to see the transcripts and see what's going on.

BARTIROMO: Let's not forget Brett Kavanaugh and what happened there, that's another part of this where you had resistance at all cost as you write so eloquently in the -- in the book, where these Trump haters did not want him to have any victory. And didn't the left spend 30 hours with Christine Blasey Ford to help her carve and shape her hearing and her testimony?

STRASSEL: Well, and to get rid of due process along the way.

BARTIROMO: Bingo.

STRASSEL: You know, and this is the thing, you go through the list. We have a broken Senate confirmation process because of this. We have the lowering and demeaning of impeachment standards because of this. We've got a judiciary that's engaged in all kinds of norm-breakings, national injunctions, right and left. This is a departure from anything we've had. New media standards being lowered and then lack of trust in the media, in our civil bureaucracy, in the FBI and the DOJ.

This is because of the actions of people that got the impression that just because they didn't like Donald Trump that they were allowed to break any rules that they wanted to in their effort to get rid of him. And when you have a mentality like that, that's how you end up breaking like core and important things in the country.

BARTIROMO: And as you write, breaking America. It's just not right. And if you believe in our constitution, you should be outraged by what took place.

Now, we -- I gave an update last night on Twitter to say that the I.G. report now I'm hearing is going to be out at the end of the month, because they are still doing classifications. There's going to be a lot in the I.G. report, I initially thought it was going to come out this Friday, it's not coming out this Friday but -- because they're classifying things.

Do you think we're going to see accountability here? Do you think we'll see actual prosecutions and indictments for those people who tried to take Donald Trump down and used the tools that we use on terrorists like informants and like wiretapping?

STRASSEL: Well, the thing I hope most of all is we simply see most of the report. You just mentioned the classification.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's true.

STRASSEL: Don't forget, when you go back to when House Republicans were doing their investigation, the incredible foot dragging that went into this and how they just would not the -- like DOJ, FBI, all the intelligence agencies, they did not want to give up any information. So I hope we get the information.

And then I am, I am pretty confident we're going to get some accountability.

BARTIROMO: Tell me about this book in terms of the most important piece of information that people need to take away from this book. Because there's so many legs to this story and you write all about it in the book. But give me your sense of what readers should take away with.

STRASSEL: You know, this is a chance to step back and take an objective view at the last three years and then talk about where the real damage is being done. And we all need to know that, especially as we go into an upcoming election season, about the real narrative here and what we risk in this country.

BARTIROMO: And one of the real damages I think is the fact that our leadership, the FBI, the CIA, are not focusing on the real wrongdoing. I mean, when you talk about obstruction, am I wrong to say Hillary Clinton used a hammer and BleachBit to get rid of her e-mails?

STRASSEL: Yes, we have a double standard.

BARTIROMO: Is that obstruction? Hello?

STRASSEL: And I talk to Americans, this is the most frustrating thing for them is that look at the story that we're having right now. Apparently it's perfectly OK for the Hillary Clinton campaign to funnel Russian information to the FBI, to be used against a presidential campaign but the president just calling the Ukraine is an impeachable offense? I mean, you can't have it both ways. And this is the frustration for many Americans.

BARTIROMO: The same thing with Hunter Biden. Now Hunter Biden is breaking his silence, openly admitting to making a mistake in the Ukraine dealings. He was getting $50,000 a month from Ukraine. I mean, $600,000 while his father's a sitting vice president?

STRASSEL: And by the way, you know, people keep using the word corruption. Quite aside from corruption, the fact that Hunter Biden stepped down from that board is an admission that this just smells bad. It's a conflict of interest. He should never have been doing this when his father was vice president.

And I think that the Biden's essentially acknowledged that this week by his decision to step back and say I won't do it if my dad's president.

BARTIROMO: Yes, it's incredible that from the moment Donald Trump was inaugurated, the resistance movement was as strong as it was. But the resistance movement has only gotten worse. How do you think this president's legacy will go down in terms of how we look at this three-year period that you write so well about?

STRASSEL: Well, I mean, again, it depends on how much damage ends up being done. Is there going to be an impeachment vote against him? Is that going to be the asterisk by his name?

But look, we've never seen anything like this before. Again, we all have the ability and the right to disagree with each other in politics. But it doesn't mean that you don't have to follow all of the kind of rules that we've set out about how you handle politics.

And so I think that there's going to be just as many history books written about the reaction to him as his actual governing.

BARTIROMO: This is an important book and it is an important history book. Because this actually happened as extraordinary as it sounds. You write and it's like, you know, you can't -- you can't write this but you did. And in closing, tell me in terms of what you want to see in terms of the wrong doers from the Russia probe. Do you think -- who do you think the mastermind of it was?

STRASSEL: Well, look, all of the leadership of the FBI and then the outside groups too. Fusion GPS, by the way, we just heard they're going to put their own book out here.

BARTIROMO: Unbelievable. And Jim Comey has his own book. I mean, your reaction to him going on T.V. and Andrew McCabe getting a job on CNN. I mean, he's had criminal referrals.

STRASSEL: Well, this is unprecedented as well too. Not just the members of those communities are now acting as analysts, but it's also just one of the reasons people feel frustrated that there's no accountability is because they're being treated as heroes when in fact, you know, this guy was fired from the FBI, he's a disgrace.

BARTIROMO: That's exactly right. Kim Strassel, get the book, the book is Resistance (At All Costs). We'll be right back.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. The E.U.'s Brexit negotiator says a deal with the U.K. is still possible this week. Lauren Simonetti on headlines now, Lauren.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: All right, Maria. Michael Barnier says the main challenge now is to turn British proposals on the Irish border issue into legal text. E.U. leaders are meeting for a two-day summit this week as the October 31st deadline looms, 16 days away.

Britain's chief Brexit minister has also made a last minute trip to Luxembourg to meet with E.U. ministers. We'll see, clocks' ticking.

Pilots of Southwest Airlines don't expect the 737 Max jet to fly again until February at the earliest, that's later than Boeing's projection to return the planes back to the air before the end of this year. Southwest is the largest operator of the grounded jets. Its pilots union sued Boeing last week accusing it of deliberately misleading it about the planes. Maria, back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right, Lauren.

SIMONETTI: Another headache for Boeing.

BARTIROMO: It sure is, it continues to be. Lauren, thank you.

Coming up, America's oldest brewery in business for nearly two centuries. The women behind the brand. Join me on set as we celebrate made in America. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Well, we are toasting America's oldest brewery this morning. Yuengling celebrating 190 years of brewing right here in America. The company is producing 2.6 million barrels of beer every year, becoming America's number one craft brewery.

Joining us right now is Jen Yuengling, vice president of operations and Debbie Yuengling, employee engagement and culture manager. They are the sixth generation running this family business. And ladies, it is great to have you on the program this morning.

DEBBIE YUENGLING, EMPLOYEE ENGAGEMENT AND CULTURE MANAGER, YUENGLING: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: You know, we love family businesses here and we want to hear your story in terms of being of a year generations of being founders. And we also love made in America. Tell us about your business.

JEN YUENGLING, VICE PRESIDENT OF OPERATIONS, YUENGLING: Yes, thank you. So we are celebrating our 190th anniversary this year. Our brewery was founded in 1829 by our great-great-great-grandfather and my sister Debbie and other two sisters and myself; we are sixth generation family members.

BARTIROMO: That's fantastic; you're two of four sisters who are running this operation. How is it Debbie to run -- being women in this male dominated industry and running the family business?

D. YUENGLING: It's very special for us, getting to work alongside your family, but I think also knowing the history that our generations have worked there before us, our grandfather are still there with my dad. The beer industry is typically male dominated. But it's something that we're persevering through.

BARTIROMO: Have you -- how have you broken through in this male dominated industry?

J. YUENGLING: You know, I think what we're seeing is up to a third of brewers in the industry today are women. So we do have a partnership also with Pink Boots Society where they enable and they educate and empower women in the brewing industry. So I think that really resonates with us, a sixth generation.

BARTIROMO: So you -- go ahead, Jack.

JACK OTTER, EDITOR, BARRON'S: So, I'm interested because like Budweiser and Miller and those guys started dominating the industry and put a lot of the smaller guys like you out of business but then in the 80s you surged and you're like the original craft brewer. And now it seems like craft brewing is the thing and you guys are right on top of the wave. How did you start it?

J. YUENGLING: That's really accurate. I think when our father took over the brewery in 1985, he along with Jim Koch with Boston Beer and same items, they were almost the pioneers of that first craft beer revolution.

OTTER: And then now, you're just -- you're riding the wave, right? Are you national or just East Coast or?

J. YUENGLING: We are -- we're in 22 states. So we kind of joke internally. It's taken us 190 years to get in the -- to get into 22 states. But, you know, I think we survived through innovation. Our Lager brand, number one and then also our recent collaboration with Hershey.

BARTIROMO: So, yes, tell us about the collaboration with Hershey's. Because you got a gigantic Hershey's bar here, my favorite chocolate bar by the way and the porter beer with the Hershey's. What is this?

D. YUENGLING: Yes, so we were super excited to partner with Hershey's, an iconic chocolate company. Its 45 minutes from the brewery. We're both in Pennsylvania. So we came up with this collaboration. Our Dark Brewed Porter is one of our original beers, we've -- that's almost 200 years old. So it's a great combination with the dark malt, very delectable taste to it.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

OTTER: Both calories in that glass.

CABOT PHILLIPS, EDITOR-IN-CHIEF, CAMPUSREFORM.ORG: So, the first beer I ever had was a Yuengling. So you guys always have a special place in my heart.

BARTIROMO: Oh, wow.

PHILLIPS: A lot of millennials, upcoming generations maybe a little less like in the past generations to be beer drinkers as a first choice. What are you guys doing to market to them and to shift to their needs?

J. YUENGLING: You know, well, I think the innovation that we have right here with our Yuengling Hershey chocolate porter is you know, it's really hitting millennials. And it's for all legal drinking age consumers. It's more of an upscale, premiumize type beer, so you can see the chalices that we have in front of us here. Great chocolaty malt aroma and overtones in both the flavor and the aroma profile.

BARTIROMO: How cool, a chocolaty aroma. Where do you -- where do you produce?

J. YUENGLING: So we produce -- and we have two breweries in Pottsville, Pennsylvania which is centrally located in P.A. and then we also have a brewery in Tampa, Florida.

BARTIROMO: Fantastic. Ladies, thank you so much. Congratulations to you.

D. YUENGLING: Thanks for having us.

BARTIROMO: Great to have you. Check out Yuengling the new porter beer there. We will see you soon, Jen and Debbie Yuengling.

Stay with us, we've got breaking news, and Hunter Biden's son breaking his silence. We'll talk about that when we come back.

urn:contentItem:5Y32-D6Y1-JCMN-Y37M-00000-00Earnings Outlook: Amazon earnings preview: Antitrust chatter will pick up ahead of presidential election2020-01-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:41ZLexisNexisEarnings Outlook: Amazon earnings preview: Antitrust chatter will pick up ahead of presidential electionfpwire

Jan 28, 2020( Financial Press: https://financialpress.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Amazon.com Inc.'s longstanding antitrust issues could take center stage ahead of the presidential election, say Monness Crespi Hardt analysts. Tech companies are increasingly the focus of Trump administration investigations, with the Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission looking closely at antitrust issues. Perhaps sensing a bigger fight brewing, Amazon AMZN, -1.79%[1] , along with Facebook Inc. FB, -1.41%[2] and Apple Inc.

AAPL, -2.94%[3] , ramped up their lobbying to record levels in 2019, with Amazon spending $16.1 million. Read: Facebook, Amazon and Apple set records for annual spending on lobbying[4] The issue has been a persistent one for Amazon, with GlobalData Retail saying that a 2018 revenue slowdown[5] at the e-commerce giant could poke holes in the talk of a monopoly. Other onlookers as far back as 2017[6] suspected that government intervention could be imminent. But in an election year, the sour relationship between Amazon, Jeff Bezos and President Trump could heighten. #8216;We expect the antitrust rhetoric to reach deafening levels during this presidential election year, while Amazon's relationship with the White House remains the most precarious within Big Tech,#8217; analyst Brian White wrote in a note. Monness Crespi Hardt rates Amazon stock buy with a $2,250 price target. See: Do growing calls for antitrust action threaten the S&P 500 index as the 2020 election nears[7] President Trump has singled out Amazon Chief Executive Jeff Bezos on Twitter because of Bezos' ownership of The Washington Post[8] and with claims that the U.S. Postal Service[9] was losing money on Amazon e-commerce package deliveries. Trump ordered a review of the USPS's finances, but not much has been said on the topic for some time. The Post Office had blamed the U.S. government, and not Amazon, for its losses. More recently, Amazon blames Trump for losing the $10 billion Joint Enterprise Defense Infrastructure plan, or JEDI, contract with the Pentagon. JEDI instead went to Microsoft Corp. MSFT, -1.67%[10] in October[11]. Amazon has filed a lawsuit over the contract. Also: Opinion: What Amazon is really accusing Trump of doing in JEDI deal[12] Amazon is scheduled to announced fourth-quarter earnings on Thursday after the closing bell. D.A. Davidson analysts led by Tom Forte say they'll be listening on the call for comments about this appeal. The JEDI contract is #8216;what we consider to be the company's biggest loss since its inability to secure government support of its New York City HQ2,#8217; analysts said. D.A. Davidson thinks there are two factors that will help Amazon in the antitrust fight: the company's investments in shipping, which would position it to #8216;break the duopoly#8217; between FedEx Corp. FDX, -3.62%[13] and United Parcel Service Inc.UPS, -1.49%[14] in the U.S.; and its growing advertising business, which will snap the stranglehold that Google and Facebook have on that category. #8216;[These are] excellent arguments for Amazon on its efforts to promote more competition, which should provide protection against an increasingly hostile global regulatory environment for big technology, including Amazon,#8217; analysts wrote. D.A. Davidson rates Amazon stock buy with a $2,550 price target. Amazon has an average buy rating and average target price of $2,196.27, according to 50 analysts polled by FactSet. Here are some other things to look for in Amazon earnings: Earnings: FactSet is guiding for earnings per share of $4.05, down from $6.04 last year. Estimize, which crowdsources estimates from sell-side and buy-side analysts, hedge-fund managers, executives, academics and others, expects EPS of $4.53. Amazon has missed the FactSet EPS consensus the last two quarters. Revenue: FactSet is guiding for revenue of $86.03 billion, up from $72.38 billion the previous year. The Estimize outlook is for $85.66 billion. Amazon has beat the FactSet consensus the last four quarters. Stock price: Amazon stock has gained nearly 10% over the last year while the S&P 500 index SPX, -1.57%[15] is up 22.2% and the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -1.57%[16] is up 15.8% for the period. Don't miss: Which tech stock is best? Here's how the #8216;big five' companies stack up as they report earnings[17] Other items: -One-day shipping is going to be bigger than analysts think. #8216;We expect another record revenue holiday quarter, which could eclipse the high end of guidance thanks to share gains from the impressive, aggressive, one-day shipping rollout,#8217; wrote Benchmark analysts in a Monday note. Amazon has already said the holiday season was #8216;record breaking,#8217;[18] though, as usual, it didn't provide sales numbers to back that up. That there will be margin pressure because #8216;let's face it, one-day delivery is expensive,#8217; Benchmark said. But they say, as other analysts have[19], that the pressure is worth it. Amazon has said it would spend more than $800 million[20] to make one-day shipping happen. Benchmark rates Amazon stock buy with a $2,300 price target. Watch: Here's how much speedy delivery really costs[21] -SunTrust Robinson Humphrey analysts think the shift to one-day shipping is #8216;underappreciated#8217; in current estimates. #8216;[W]e believe the company can actually sustain, and potentially accelerate its top-line growth, given the impact to-date on unit growth, and what we observed in 2005 onward following the launch of free two-day shipping,#8217; analysts wrote. Free two-day shipping for Prime members was launched in 2005, and the compound annual growth rate (CAGR) for the next five years was 5%, analysts say. #8216;Overall, we view this set up positively, and believe top-line outperformance in the retail business will drive the stock's outperformance in 2020,#8217; SunTrust said. SunTrust rates Amazon stock buy with a $2,350 price target.The post Earnings Outlook: Amazon earnings preview: Antitrust chatter will pick up ahead of presidential election[22] appeared first on Financial Press - Breaking Stock Market News[23].
