urn:contentItem:5YG0-59B1-F03R-N3XB-00000-00EARN IT: The US Anti-Encryption Bill That Threatens Private Speech Online2020-03-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:41ZLexisNexisEARN IT: The US Anti-Encryption Bill That Threatens Private Speech OnlineDavid Hollerith

Mar 19, 2020( Bitcoin Magazine: https://bitcoinmagazine.com Delivered by Newstex) There's a new bill in the works to fight against child sexual abuse material (CSAM) and other risky services on the internet — but it could come at a cost to online privacy. Eliminating Abusive or Rampant Neglect of Interactive Technologies (EARN IT) was proposed by the Senate Judiciary Committee and sponsored by senators from both sides of the aisle such as Lindsey Graham (R-SC) and Richard Blumenthal (D-CT). The bill is also supported by the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children[1] and the National Center on Sexual Exploitation[2]. However, this bill is problematic for both freedom of speech and privacy online according to Riana Pfefferkorn[3], associate director of Surveillance and Cybersecurity at the Center for Internet and Society. 'This bill is trying to convert your anger at Big Tech into law enforcement's long-desired dream of banning strong encryption,' argued Pfefferkorn in a blog post[4]. Pfefferkorn's detailed explanation says EARN IT appears less like a legitimate way to prevent the spread of child exploitation content and more like a covert attempt to ban end-to-end encryption, without having to ban it outright. At the end of January 2020, a draft of the proposal was leaked and met with similar apprehension not only by Big tech juggernauts (Facebook, Google, etc.)

but also their sometimes opposing counterparts, freedom of speech advocates. 'We're concerned the EARN IT Act may be used to roll back encryption, which protects everyone's safety from hackers and criminals, and may limit the ability of American companies to provide the private and secure services that people expect,' Facebook spokesperson Thomas Richards said in a statement[5] to the Washington Post. Clearly, the issue could not be more sensitive. Patrick A. Trueman, president and CEO of the National Center on Sexual Exploitation, recently voiced[6] this opinion, apparently advocating for EARN IT. 'Right now, Big Tech has no incentive to prevent predators from grooming, recruiting, and trafficking children online and as a result countless children have fallen victim to child abusers on platforms like Instagram, Snapchat, and TikTok,' said Trueman.Section 230: The Most Important Law Protecting Freedom of Speech OnlineWhile everyone who has publicly condemned EARN IT has also stated a universal commitment to child safety online and in the real world, many say the bill's far-reaching approach to content moderation could do more harm than good by essentially eliminating private conversations across the internet, particularly on social media platforms and messaging apps. To fully comprehend what EARN IT proposes, one needs to understand the importance of two bills passed in the '90s. These laid the groundwork for how privacy and free speech are supposed to operate for U.S. citizens. First, Section 230[7] of the Communications Decency Act (CDA), passed in 1996, allows for the continued development of the internet as a free market and universal good for free speech. Section 230 says that online platforms or providers of interactive computer services mostly cannot be held responsible for the things their users say or do on their platforms. It uses the term 'mostly' instead of 'always' because platforms are still liable for exceptions that violate intellectual and federal criminal law. Essentially, this means if someone is defamed for being a fraud, that person can sue their defamer, but they cannot sue the platform for providing the space for free speech. Second, the Communications Assistance for Law Enforcement Act (CALEA[8]), passed in 1994, requires telecom providers to make their networks 'wiretappable' for law enforcement. However, it also ensured a 'carve-out' for encrypted messages and information services where websites, email, social media, messaging apps and cloud storage fall out of CALEA's jurisdiction. The purpose of these carve-outs was to reach a compromise between the competing interests of network security providers, privacy advocates, civil liberties, technological growth and law enforcement. In combination, Section 230 and CALEA prevent regulation from suffocating growth and development of the U.S. information economy.Weakening ProtectionsSince the '90s, more regulation has passed to undo Section 230. 'Section 230 has been amended since it was passed: SESTA/FOSTA[9], enacted in 2018, pierces providers' immunity from civil and state-law claims about sex trafficking,' wrote Pfefferkorn. SESTA/FOSTA is currently being challenged[10] in federal court being unconstitutional and doing more harm than good. There is also already a regulatory reporting scheme[11] for online providers combatting CSAM. Also, Section 230 does not keep federal prosecutors from holding providers accountable for CSAM on their services. While the current reporting scheme's success is questionable, there is reasonable evidence to believe that EARN IT is an attempt to regulate communication on the internet more broadly. 'The so-called EARN IT bill will strip Section 230 protections away from any website that doesn't follow a list of 'best practices,' meaning those sites can be sued into bankruptcy,' writes[12] Joe Mullin, a policy analyst with the Electronic Freedom Foundation. Mullin is referring to how EARN IT would target CSAM. It proposes to do this by creating a federal commission to develop a list of best practices for preventing CSAM that online platform providers would have to follow or else lose their immunity under Section 230 — meaning they could be sued into bankruptcy. This commission would largely be made up of law enforcement and allied groups such as the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children (NCMEC). According to Mullin, 'The 'best practices' list will be created by a government commission, headed by Attorney General Barr, who has made it very clear he would like to ban encryption and guarantee law enforcement 'legal access' to any digital message.' Although the word 'encryption' does not appear anywhere in the EARN IT bill, Mullin is suspicious of how the federal commission might design best practices. For instance, in an earlier draft of the bill, the NCMEC Vice-President stated that online services should be made to screen all messages using screening technology approved by themselves and law enforcement, report what they find in messages to the NCMEC and be held legally responsible for the content of the messages sent by others.See Alsohttps://bitcoinmagazine.com/articles/freedom-of-speech-in-financial-commerce-1369969664 In short, the commission could quietly give backdoor access to all U.S. hosted information services, undoing encrypted messages altogether.Centralized Control and 'Techlash'Mullin, Pfefferkorn and other outspoken critics of EARN IT all agree that the bill's proposed execution is opening the door for the elimination of encryption: the fact that it is never explicitly addressed is especially concerning.. According to Mullin, it's also possible that the current draft of EARN IT will be amended to undo the damage it could do to online privacy. 'Could be as straightforward as putting a clause in[,] saying the bill doesn't apply to encryption,' he writes. However, until some amendment occurs, critics are wary of a federal commission consisting of fewer than twenty people, according to the latest reports, who would be making large-scale privacy and security decisions for the entire U.S. population. Such a potentially big power grab would seem a bit ridiculous, but Pfefferkorn also acknowledged that EARN IT rides on a wave of resentment or 'techlash' the U.S. population has begun to harbor against many internet-based companies. This animosity is directed toward both U.S. tech juggernauts, whose business models run off of surveillance capitalism and online free speech platforms which, for the average person, can feel like the 'concentrated font of human venality every time we open our phones,' according to Pfefferkorn.Private Messaging: A Prerequisite to DemocracyIn general, free speech on social media platforms is already a nuanced and complicated topic. Even under Section 230, social media platforms can still censor content when they deem it inappropriate internally. For example, Twitter has a keyword blacklist[13] and the protocol for how it works can change on a dime. For Nozomi Hayase[14], social psychologist and writer, surveillance of encrypted messaging is a movement toward forfeiting democracy. By Hayase's reasoning, privacy is a prerequisite for a kind of solitude that allows people to think and act independently and is, therefore, essential to a functioning democratic society. 'Democracy requires sovereign individuals who are able to communicate with one another freely. This freedom comes with great responsibility,' said Hayase, who recognized EARN IT as the newest installment of a dangerous trend toward online censorship. 'If we really want to have a truly democratic society, we have to accept the fact that it is the duty of each person to develop his or her own moral capacity to determine what is right and wrong, instead of depending on an external authority to tell us what we should or should not do.' Currently, EARN IT has been referred to the Senate Judiciary Committee. Citizens can contact their congressmen directly or take action[15] through the Electronic Frontier Foundation's website. [ 1]:   https://www.missingkids.org/content/ncmec/en/blog/2020/earn-it-act-2020.html [ 2]:   https://endsexualexploitation.org/articles/the-earn-it-act-will-protect-children-from-online-sexual-exploitation/ [ 3]:   https://twitter.com/Riana_Crypto [ 4]:   https://cyberlaw.stanford.edu/blog/2020/01/earn-it-act-how-ban-end-end-encryption-without-actually-banning-it [ 5]:   https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2020/03/03/section-230-justice-department-congress/ [ 6]:   https://endsexualexploitation.org/articles/the-earn-it-act-will-protect-children-from-online-sexual-exploitation/ [ 7]:   https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/47/230 [ 8]:   https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/47/1002 [ 9]:   https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/qvxeyq/trump-signed-fosta-sesta-into-law-sex-work [ 10]:   https://stopsesta.org/ [ 11]:   https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/18/2258A [ 12]:   https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2020/03/earn-it-bill-governments-not-so-secret-plan-scan-every-message-online [ 13]:   https://twitter.com/taiberg/status/1240311957644816384 [ 14]:   https://twitter.com/nozomimagine [ 15]:   https://act.eff.org/action/protect-our-speech-and-security-online-reject-the-graham-blumenthal-bill

urn:contentItem:5RYN-VV81-DXH2-63FX-00000-00Easing Trade Tensions; Deadly Russian Mall Fire; Remington Filing for Bankruptcy; Apology Status2018-03-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:41ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTMitch Roschelle, Lee Carter, Mark Walker, Larry HavertyNEWSFinancial032602cb.231Easing Trade Tensions; Deadly Russian Mall Fire; Remington Filing for Bankruptcy; Apology StatusMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Cheryl Casone

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Welcome back. Good Monday morning everybody. Thanks so much for joining us.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. Happy Monday to you. And it is Monday, March 26.

Your top stories right now at 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Averting a trade war -- "The Wall Street Journal" this morning is reporting that the White House and China have held behind the scenes negotiations in an effort to ease rising tensions following the administration's move to impose strict tariffs.

As a result markets are rallying. Dow industrials expected to be up almost 300 points right at the start of trading this morning. That's better than 1 percent. Nasdaq up 1.5 percent right now, 97 points higher. And the S&P is up 31; that's 1.25 percent.

The news comes after a rough week at the office last week. Dow Industrials down yet again Friday capping a week which saw all three major indices fall roughly 6 percent.

In Europe this morning, slight gains across the board -- take a look. The FT 100 is up half a percent. The CAC 40 up a third of a percent. And the DAX index up two thirds of 1 percent.

In Asia overnight, stocks were mostly higher with the exception of China. Best performers there Kospi index in Korea up almost 1 percent.

Well, apology status -- Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg taking out a full-page ad in newspapers across the globe promising to do better following the Cambridge Analytica scandal. Is it enough? The very latest and the new questions over the company's access to your data.

And then gaining ground, new Fox News poll show Republicans are tightening the gap with Democrats. What you need to know ahead of the important 2018 midterm elections.

After more than 200 years in business, America's oldest gun maker has filed for bankruptcy -- the details behind Remington's decision.

Plus a good move ore tunnel vision -- Elon Musk debuting the boring company's latest swag -- life-sized Legos. Why he plans to build on the company's flame thrower success.

All those stories this morning coming up and joining me to talk all about it -- Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell; PWC partner Mitch Roschelle; and pollster and the president of Maslansky and Partners Lee Carter.

Great to see everybody.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY AND PARTNERS: Great to be here.

BARTIROMO: Good morning -- every Monday.

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PWC PARTNERS: We've got a lot of news.

BARTIROMO: Yes, we do. We see a market that's completely turning around this morning.

ROSCHELLE: And the market did a complete reversal from where it was Thursday and Friday.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

CARTER: No, it's so interesting. Last week initially we were talking about the China tariffs. We're saying I wonder if this is a negotiating strategy, if he's going to throw this out and then China connects on the cable and that's what we are seeing maybe it's happening.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ROSCHELLE: And trying to maybe into the table the whole time but backdoor negotiations.

BARTIROMO: I'll tell you -- after looking at this subject I have learned so much about what China is doing. It's not just about transferring technology to China and acquiring some of the best and most important sectors that we are or trying to acquire, the most important sectors like robotics and AI that China is doing.

They are also trying hard to be number one in terms of military. They're acquiring infrastructure all across the world, owning that infrastructure and then getting a spot on the sea level -- on the sea lane in different parts of the world and setting up military bases there.

Very interesting. That's what Devin Nunes from the intel committee told me yesterday.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN HOST: But that's one of the reasons that the spending bill in the runaway spending and the debt dovetails with what we're trying to do with China because we lose some valuable ammunition the more that we run up our national debt and the more that we basically are running $1 trillion budget deficits every year because then we have to lien on China even more to continue to buy that debt. And surely not sell what they already own being the largest foreign holder of U.S. Treasury.

BARTIROMO: Which is why every time we hear a rumor that China's starting to sell treasuries or buying lesser than what people expect -- you see massive selloff in the stock market.

MCDOWELL: And quite -- my opinion, but if you wanted to really have your allies lock arms with you to take on in China, it's not just the United States intellectual property and abuse and its motives. We need to lock arms with our allies so then you don't throw on those steel and aluminum tariffs and basically kind of shock those very allies ahead of wanting to take a harder stance with China.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ROSCHELLE: The 10 industries that they want to, by 2025 be the world leader in --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ROSCHELLE: -- aerospace, next gen technology, robotics, agriculture, rail advancements --

BARTIROMO: -- shipping and bio-tech.

ROSCHELLE: Yes. These are things that we also want to be leaders in.

BARTIROMO: I love that list and I will focus on that list. We're going to talk about that list coming up this morning.

And joining the conversation Fox News senior judicial analyst Judge Andrew Napolitano is here; Major League Baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred making an appearance today, he will be in studio with us; former U.S. Ambassador to China and former Commerce Secretary Gary Locke is with us as well. A lot to talk about with him.

Don't miss a moment of it. We've got a big two hours coming up.

And we kick it off right now with this. Markets -- futures are indicating a big rally at the start of trading this morning. Markets are on a tear as "The Journal" is reporting that Washington and Beijing has begun negotiations on improving U.S. access to Chinese markets.

This comes as House intel committee chairman Devin Nunes told me yesterday on "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES", "congressional investigators have been looking into Chinese practices.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. DEVIN NUNES (R-CA), HOUSE INTELLIGENCE COMMITTEE: They are stealing our intellectual property. So either it's through the internet or it's through investing in educational systems here or think tanks. They are bringing people here. I believe that they are still in Silicon Valley blind.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining us right now is the chairman of the Republican Study Committee and North Carolina Congressman Mark Walker. Chairman Walker -- good to see you. Thanks so much for joining us this morning.

REP. MARK WALKER (R-NC), REPUBLICAN STUDY COMMITTEE: Thanks-- Maria.

BARTIROMO: So Devin Nunes just said that his committee is investigating this. What should be investigated?

WALKER: Well, if you look, my first two years in Congress, it was an eye- opener for me serving on the homeland security, realizing how many times per day, tens of thousands of times per day that China literally hacks every industry that we have. They are the biggest stealers of our intellectual property and have been doing it for decades.

So the Trump body language and the movement to throw down some for warning shots I think is very important and sends a very clear message.

BARTIROMO: So you like what the President has done here then?

WALKER: I do. Obviously we want to make sure that the tariffs ultimately do not get to the place where there is an increase in consumer costs or ultimately even jobs. But I believe going after bad actors and communicating very clearly what the Chinese have been doing, specifically their leadership, I think is a very educational moment for Americans.

MCDOWELL: Congressman -- it's Dagen McDowell -- though if China retaliates, they've already started talking about tariffs on pork but then what about hogs. That would hammer the very people in your state. And if they do retaliate, they will go after those states in those places who voted for President Trump.

WALKER: Absolutely. There's no question. And this will just impact theirs, even has ties to the E.U. the F Corp located here in Greensboro, very concerned, even things about Wrangler jeans -- a 25 percent hike across Europe.

This -- ultimately we know that free trade is very important. We have to be careful here but sending a shot across the bow, I am glad to see that these -- what we thought was very wide scope tariffs have been narrowing. And we want to make sure that it doesn't unroll or disembark the good work from regulatory relief and tax reform that we've seen already.

BARTIROMO: But I mean do you think that $3 billion in tariffs that China has promised last week -- was that just a gesture? I mean obviously it's not commensurate with $60 billion in tariffs that the U.S. is talking about. It's $3 billion.

So is China just saying we are not rolling over, but we're also not going to do anything to mess with this $375 billion surplus that we have?

WALKER: I think at this point, Maria, that is correct. Maybe more a gesture than anything else but ultimately, as most of your panelists would know, we certainly don't want to let it devolve into a trade war.

BARTIROMO: Right.

WALKER: So one of the reasons that the spending bill is so important that we make sure -- I think Dagen hit it out of the park just a few minutes ago, breaking that down. It's very important that we keep our fiscal house in order as well.

BARTIROMO: Well, ok. You said that. That's what we were talking about all morning but fiscal has an order $1.3 trillion spending bill, I don't know. It doesn't add up, sir.

You know, we've got brand new Fox News polls show this morning that Republicans are narrowing the gap with Democrats ahead of the 2018 midterm elections. Democrats had have a five-point lead over the GOP but this comes as Republican Pennsylvania Congressman Ryan Costello confirmed yesterday that he will drop his bid for reelection and retire at the end of his term.

So Chairman Walker -- are you worried that the Republicans are going to lose the majority in the House and how does the spending bill play into that?

WALKER: Well, I think that is secondary. I think ultimately what we need to be doing as members of Congress is fulfilling our promises and let the chips fall where they may. Do I believe that we have much to run off in 2017? We do -- ANWR, regulatory relief, tax reform, pro-life legislation. But if Republicans get to the mindset that we can spend like the Democrats do and not doing anything from here to November, I think that would be cataclysmic.

I think it's very important to continue to build on those promises. The Republican Study Committee is coming back with the great fervor pushing for a balanced budget amendment. We'll also develop our own Republican Study Committee budget that's going to be much more in tune in balancing intense come elected and very important we communicate. Hopefully in 10 and 11 -- at the most 12 years, it's very important that we communicate these principles to the American public --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

WALKER: -- if Republicans want to keep the majority.

BARTIROMO: Well, we want to talk about this because we all have problems with the spending bill -- sir. I mean the economy will obviously be a big issue in the midterms and the President is tweeting about this, this morning.

Here's what the President said just a few minutes ago. "The economy is looking really good. It has been many years that we have seen these kinds of numbers. The underlying strength of companies has perhaps never been better."

Do you agree with that? And do you believe that if we keep running up all of this deficit, that that is going to cut into the growth?

WALKER: I believe temporarily we are seeing some wonderful economic recovery news. However, if you look out just a few years, our mandatory spending had gone from about a third of our budget to closing in to 75 percent, 76 percent of our budget. We simply can't sustain that.

In this specific omnibus, it increased nondiscretionary spending -- or discretionary spending 13 percent in one year. As a fiscal conservative, some people like to say a fiscal hawk. Sometimes we feel like we're the adults in the room trying to say or trying to put out some warning signs. We are the only group that doesn't have a special interest that we are advocating for.

Where Defense needs massive, they were out, stood in the empty silos in Alaska where this previous administration depleted our military defense. But at the same time we have to understand that unless we're willing to go after this mandatory reforms, we will not leave the next generation very much to work with.

CARTER: So Congressman -- you guys have the House, you have the Senate, you have the White House. And if you can't get this through now, when are you going to get it through and how is it going to be different eight months from now than it is right now.

Because it seems to me, that if you couldn't have gotten it done this time, how are you going to get it done?

WALKER: That's a very fair question. I remember sitting in the room with the Majority Leader when Congressman Tom Graves came up with the idea almost a year ago that we would get all 12 appropriations bills done through the house for the first time in 13 years.

We have met that goal, sent it to the Senate. The senate never took up a single appropriation. We then tried again in package 4 props bills, budgetary bills and put into one particular piece of legislation. They still didn't take it up.

So there has been some talk. Does the Senate eventually move to a 51 simple majority when it comes to any kind of budgeting idea or appropriations? I don't know the solution, but we're going to keep the pressure, keep the press on, really exposing those who are putting a stop in the progress.

MCDOWELL: And clearly there's some politicking going on with the pushback on President Trump signing the spending bill on Friday because Secretary Mnuchin of the Treasury Department was on with Chris Wallace yesterday. And Chris Wallace had to remind him when he brought up the idea of a line- item veto, he wanted Congress to pass the rule for a line-item veto so the President could go through and veto line items in the spending bill.

And Chris Wallace had to remind him well, that was ruled some years ago unconstitutional.

BARTIROMO: There will be a constitutional amendment.

MCDOWELL: So again, you know, you can pass a constitutional amendment but that requires a two-thirds vote in the House and Senate.

WALKER: It does -- Dagen. But let's not just talk about the policy. Let's talk about the process of getting a nearly 2,300 page bill on the evening of the next day you're supposed to be voting for it.

We have eight full-time people, staffers on the Republican Study Committee. Two stayed up all night, trying to get through the bill. They weren't able to complete. I think it is preposterous to ask us to vote on something so lengthy with the amount of pork and level that was in the specific piece of legislation.

BARTIROMO: But YOU did it.

WALKER: No, I didn't. I was one of 90 that voted against it. And we're going to continue to rule against it.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well, this is an important point that you bring up. You voted against it so you weren't one of those people who said all right, look, I'm just going to throw in the towel here just to get the spending for the military.

What are you supposed to do the next time? The President said he's never spending something like this -- he's never signing something like this again.

WALKER: Well, this bill should've never reached the President's desk. It did not even have some of the specifics that he had asked for, for wall funding. I think we acquiesced a little bit too much. I've got to give the speaker a little bit of props here because I understood some of the talks and some of the battles that he was facing trying to get at least some of the things across the finish line.

But this bill is really not good. You're talking about an increase of 13 percent in one year in discretionary funding. That is ridiculous.

I believe it's very important that not just 90 of us but more and more members of Congress have to draw the line somewhere when it comes to being fiscally conscious.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

WALKER: This is preposterous that we would increase this kind of debt. We are now matching levels -- think about this - -we are now matching levels if not even more of a deficit than Obama's last three, maybe four years in office.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

WALKER: We promise to do better and I hope that -- I hope more members will wake up to that cause.

BARTIROMO: Mr. Chairman -- thank you. Thanks so much. Mark Walker joining us there.

WALKER: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: We'll be right back.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Dozens of people including children killed in a fire in a Russian mall.

Cheryl Casone with the details and headlines now -- Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: That's right -- Maria.

Reports say at least 64 people been killed, another 16 are still missing -- dozens of children are among the victims. The blaze started on the upper floor of the Winter Cherry Complex in Siberia while many of the victims were at the movies. The cause of the fire is still under investigation.

The shopping mall which opened in 2013 has a cinema, a petting zoo, a children's center and a bowling alley.

Well, America's oldest gun maker is filing for bankruptcy protection. Remington -- taking that step due to a heavy debt load, falling sales and lawsuits following the Sandy Hook school shooting in 2012.

Under the bankruptcy plan, control of Remington would shift to its creditors which include Franklin Resources and JPMorgan Chase. Much of the company's debt will be erased and its filing also means that Surplus Capital Management will no longer own Remington.

Elon Musk unveiling his plan to sell rocks that are carved out by his tunneling venture. Here is his tweet and how he announced it. "New boring company merch" -- which is merchandise" -- "coming soon. Life-size Lego- like interlocking bricks made from tunneling rock that you can use to create sculptures and buildings. Rated for California seismic loads, so super strong, but bored -- like an aircraft wing span so not heavy."

The boring company's main (INAUDIBLE) project is a network of tunnels under the city of Los Angeles. Of course, Maria, this is Elon Musk's big, you know, dream to make these hyper loops so that we can get from city to city a lot quicker. That's the idea.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Good stuff.

CASONE: Yes.

BARTIROMO: All right. Thank you -- Cheryl.

Coming up -- Facebook is saying sorry again. The reaction to the social media company's new apology in print, following its breach of trust, next.

And then Uber selling its Southeast Asia business to a rival company -- we break down that deal coming up. Back in a moment right here.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Facebook's mea culpa -- CEO Mark Zuckerberg is apologizing for the company's breach of trust in a full-page ad in six U.K. and three U.S. newspapers following the scandal. Facebook shares are looking like this, this morning after a tough week last week where the company gave up more then 10 percent of its value. That stock is up fractionally right now.

Joining us right now is Gabelli multimedia trust portfolio manager Larry Haverty who owns Facebook and many other companies.

Do you think it's done enough -- Larry? Good to see you.

LARRY HAVERTY, GABELLI MULTIMEDIA TRUST PORTFOLIO MANAGER: Yes, I think basically, Maria, the crisis could have been addressed earlier by Zuckerberg. My big rant on the company, if you will, is that Zuckerberg is the captain of the ship and he should have been at that all-hands meeting that they had on Tuesday rather than sending a lawyer.

But after Wednesday, I think somebody got into his ear or there are a lot of smart people at Facebook and since then in my opinion they've done all the right things. They've hit all the boxes including the advertisement, which I think should've been earlier but in my opinion was very effective.

ROSCHELLE: Larry -- looking more broadly at the tech sector and the fact that the big run-up in the market, a lot of it was the big tech names in terms of the S&P. How -- does this really impact the broader technology sector, investors are going to start shying away a bit?

HAVERTY: I don't really think so. I look at the tech sector versus other consumer equities. And you look at the tech company like Google or Facebook on current cash flow around 17 times and you look at a consumer product company that has maybe a 1 percent growth rate and it's 12 times.

So tech is really very, very underpriced. The only reason that tech would I think have big problems is if you had a very significant increase in interest rates and/or an acceleration in inflation and that would have to be energy driven and I don't see any chance of that. It's going to happen any time soon.

BARTIROMO: What about an increase in regulation? What if we have a whole new rule book now for Facebook and all of these other companies that have an incredible amount of data? Does that cut into earnings and change the reason to own these stocks?

Haverty: I think for sure it does and for sure we're going to see something like that particularly in Europe and the U.K. where the new regulations are really pretty stringent on what they can do. And the U.K. people are very, very conservative about this, at least as far as my understanding is.

And you know, what you're looking at is a slowing in the rate of birth. Say, if you thought Google was going to grow at 20 percent. Maybe it's growing at 18. If you thought Facebook was growing at 30 percent. May be it's 25. I don't really think it's any lower than that Maria, because you have so much growth in, you know, -- I was just in Australia and New Zealand last week and they are growing like weed over there.

I think with this it's unlikely that they are going to get into China. That would be the big bonanza. But there's a lot of growth in the world and the thing about these companies is at the end of the day they don't give you anything. They are not giving you Colgate toothpaste; they're not giving you soap. Their cost to good sold is virtually nothing. So if they get any revenue, they can't spend the money really fast enough so it goes to free clash flow.

MCDOWELL: But with Facebook, we talked about regulation and the addict calls. And even if they choose, even if it's not through regulation, is they choose to dial their business back -- that potentially reduces revenue and profit.

However, you do have a rising tide to people basically getting rid of their Facebook account. And it might -- maybe it's temporary. Maybe it's not but which companies also benefit from this backlash like an Apple -- again, you can use Apple messenger, you can use your iCloud e-mail because they certainly are more principled and their primary source of revenue and income is not selling people's data unbeknownst to them.

HAVERTY: Well, I think one of the beneficiaries is maybe what we now call old media. And you look at one of the companies in the news, Unilever. And Unilever is apparently very irritated at Facebook. And of course, Unilever is a British and a Dutch company and that goes in line with what I was saying about the regulation over there.

Well, Unilever is not going to stop advertising so some of some of it is probably going to filter down to the old guys. But importantly, my training as in economics; and in economics, you learn to talk and think about the margin.

And what you're talking about is the margin, it's not the mass. Could they lose three, four, five percent of their subscribers? Absolutely. Do I expect that they're going to lose that? Absolutely I do.

Is it discounted in the market? I think a lot of it is discounted because Facebook already lost -- pick a number -- $60 billion, $70 billion in market value. That's not a casual number.

MCDOWELL: They could maintain their profit margin by laying people off.

HAVERTY: You are talking about a 40 percent profit margin. This isn't a supermarket company with a 6 percent margin.

MCDOWELL: Right. What's their annual income, net income -- $50 billion?

HAVERTY: I look at in on operating cash flows so it's $23 billion. Google's around $32 billion.

BARTIROMO: That's incredible. It's their income number, not revenue -- that's incredible.

ROSCHELLE: The numbers are really staggering -- yes, sir.

MCDOWELL: I don't think we'll look at those numbers and realize that they're your personal information that they were basically not protecting and handing off to other companies. That's how they make that much.

ROSCHELLE: And monetizing it -- right.

MCDOWELL: Right.

CARTER: I'm curious though because it used to be that Facebook was like the thing in town. And now there's so many alternatives. You've got Snapshot, you've got Instagram. There's all these other things that are rising in popularity. So if Facebook doesn't do the right thing, don't you think they could go the way of Kodak and Blackberry? And these other --

(CROSSTALK)

HAVERTY: Oh, no, no, no.

CARTER: We don't. Tell me why. Tell me why.

HAVERTY: Because basically these applications have really changed your life.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

HAVERTY: No one in our business can get along without Google. I mean I can't tell you how many times --

BARTIROMO: But there's a prize to be paid -- Larry.

HAVERTY: of course there is, and that's -- you know, that's for the market -- that's for the market to decide. And the market sets its price, I think, based upon interest rates and alternatives. And if interest rates stay anywhere near where they are and I think that is the best bet, the price is not unreasonable.

You're paying -- For Google, 17 times cash flow. That's a six percent return. Google is growing 20 percent. You get 3 percent if you invest with the government for 30 years; 6 percent from Google versus 3 percent from the government, I'm going to go with Google.

BARTIROMO: What's Facebook trading out right now?

HAVERTY: Facebook right now is about 18 times -- running rate casual.

BARTIROMO: And Amazon?

HAVERTY: Amazon -- that's another story. On operating cash flow it's around 34.

BARTIROMO: Ok.

HAVERTY: But the reality is --

BARTIROMO: But next year's earning is the a hundred. There's really virtually no earnings and with what he's planning to do. I can see that there's going to be any earnings any time soon.

I have a lot of trouble with Amazon -- Maria. I think it's going to sooner or later run into the antitrust people. I don't know when or why or how, but I've been reading about Rockefeller. Amazon to me looks an awful lot like standard oil and Standard Doyle who got broken up into many, many pieces. So you think they're going to break it up.

HAVERTY: I think they will break up Amazon web services and that other Amazon businesses; and the other Amazon businesses then will not have any cash flow to support them (INAUDIBLE)

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: Ways to watch Amazon try to buy Microsoft and then all of a sudden Washington wakes up. He said wait a minute.

BARTIROMO: Right. No, I think they are on tour right now. I think they're on tour right now, you know, even without a big acquisition like that. But we will see. That's a big statement you just made. You think Amazon Web services gets broken up.

HAVERTY: I think that it's the fuel for anti-social behavior. The parallels to standard oil are pretty strong.

BARTIROMO: Wow. All right. We're going to look at that. Larry -- thank you.

HAVERTY: Thanks -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: Larry Haverty joining us from Gabelli.

Coming up -- the House Judiciary committee has subpoenaed the Justice Department for records tied to Hillary Clinton's private e-mail server. Now the House intelligence committee is looking to raise the stakes. What Chairman Nunes has to say on the issue -- next.

And then Disney World says kids will eat for free. How the company will help you save at the happiest place on earth.

Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL)

BARTIROMO: It is Monday, March 26th, the stories right now 7:30 a.m. on the east coast. Easing fears of a trade war this morning, we've got a big really underway right now. Futures indicating big gains at the start of trading after a new report from the Wall Street journal this morning, reviles that the US and China have been holding behind the scenes negotiations to solve trade concerns.

The talks follow a brutal week for stocks last. All three major industries down about six percent on the week as you can see right there, looking at the global markets this morning, taking a queue from the US's rally. Most of the major industries in Europe are higher across the board. The F2 100 up a half of a percent,(CAX) and Paris up a third of a percent, DAX index in German up two thirds of a percent.

And overnight in Asia most agencies we're higher with the exception of Shanghai Composite in China, Nikkei average in Japan up three quarters of one percent. Digging into the DOJ, the House Judiciary Committee subpoenaed the Department Of Justice for all the documents regarding the Clinton e-mail scandal and more, the very latest twist in this search for answers coming up.

And Uber puts South East Asia in the rearview mirror. Why the ride sharing giant is selling its entire business for that region. Plus the happiest meal on earth, how your kids can eat for free at Disney World this summer. And then pack - back in the swing of things. Get excited baseball fans opening day is this Thursday. I'm talking to MLB Commissioner Rob Manfred about the big changes coming this season both on and off the field. Yes it is baseball season once again.

But first our top story this half hour investigating the investigators, House Judiciary Committee Chairman Bob Goodlatte sent a subpoena to the Department Of Justice last week as you know. Demanding all the documents related to the Clinton e-mail scandal. The Subpoena also seeks access to any files on alleged abuses to the foreign intelligence surveillance act, the FISA Court. I spoke about that with House Intel Chairman Devin Nunes yesterday on Sunday morning Futures.

DEVIN NUNES, HOUSE INTEL CHAIRMAN: As we're still looking into FISA abuse and other matters, we still have a lot of witnesses to bring in from the State Department and from the FBI and DOJ. To try to get to the bottom of, was there a conspiracy to go after the Trump Campaign? Did people purposely obstruct Congresses investigation? We still need to get those answers that what we continue to look at.

BARTIROMO: He said if all of the documents requested are not on his desk and Bob Goodlatte's by the time they get back from their Easter break which is in two weeks. He is going to call them in contempt of Congress. Joining us right now is FOX News Senior Judicial Analyst Judge Andrew Napolitano, Judge good to see you.

JUDGE ANDREW NAPOLITANO, FOX NEWS SENIOR JUDICIAL ANAYLST: Good Morning.

BARTIROMO: What is the fall out of contempt of Congress? What is the fall out if the Department Of Justice doesn't turn over these documents? Because we know they've been stonewalled for six months already.

NAPOLITANO: Well former Attorney General Eric Holder was personally held in contempt of Congress and nothing happened. They didn't prosecute it. They didn't sue him. It didn't affect his license to practice law. Absolutely nothing happened. So it depends upon how serious they want to be. They obviously were not serious with Eric Holder.

Now a couple of basics, you can't hold the FBI in contempt. You can hold the Custodian of Documents, who's refusing to surrender them in contempt. You can hold the Director of the FBI, who's stonewalling the surrender, same thing with the DOJ. So we have a Republican Congress now trying to examine what a Democratic DOJ, Department Of Justice did in the investigation of Hillary Clinton.

Was there a conspiracy to exonerate her no matter what the evidence said? And those documents and that information is now in the hands of a Republican DOJ, which is resisting cooperating with a Republican congress. Why would Republicans in the Department Of Justice resist cooperating with Republicans in the House of Representatives about how Democrats in the Department Of Justice, follow me here, exonerated Mrs. Clinton?

Because there is an institutional attitude, if we don't defend our predecessors, who will defend us when someone is examining why we're making our decisions now?

BARTIROMO: That's not a reason to blow off the law.

NAPOLITANO: Absolutely. My view is if you have that attitude you don't belong in the government.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

NAPOLITANO: Because the government's job especially the Department Of Justice is to find crimes, examine them, and prosecute them. Not look the other way. So I don't know where this is going to go.

BARTIROMO: Which is why so many people are calling for a second Special Counsel, just as Lindsey Graham did yesterday, watch this.

(START VIDEO CLIP)

LINDSEY GRAHAM, US SENATOR FROM SOUTH CAROLIA: Well I want more information. I want to be able to prove that the FBI investigation of the Clinton e-mail scandal was a sham. That the lead investigator, the lead FBI agent hated Trump, supportive of Clinton, they whitewashed the e-mail scandal. If you had done what she had done you'd probably be in jail now, and to hold the FBI accountable for not doing their job correctly.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

NAPOLITANO: I could not agree more. I don't agree on calling for a special counsel.

BARTIROMO: You don't?

NAPOLITANO: But I agree on everything he just said.

BARTIROMO: You don't like special counsels.

NAPOLITANO: No I don't like special counsels for a couple of reasons. One they tend to go off course in order to justify their existence. They've invited our prosecuting manifest for events that occurred - financial events as we all know that occurred long before Donald Trump was running.

BARTIROMO: And which have nothing to do with any collusion?

NAPOLITANO: Correct, correct. But second, think about this. Bob Mueller is the Special Council. Who works for him? 13 lawyers from the Justice Department, 2000 --excuse me two dozen, three dozen FBI agents. So it's basically the same people in a revolving door. If you picked the most perfect special council, if you let Lindsey Graham pick the person he wanted to be Special Council. Let Trey Gowdy when he leaves Congress become Special Council.

His prosecutors will come from the DOJ. His investigators will come from the FBI. It's basically the same thing as if the DOJ investigated. And then you have this institutional reluctance about people that don't want to investigate their predecessors. I think it's a conundrum. But I do believe that we need to get to the truth. The evidence of Mrs. Clinton's guilt. Forget about Republican or Democrat. The evidence of her guilt was overwhelming.

Did they even present it to a Grand Jury? No. Did Senior and people in the DOJ make an evaluation of it? No. Jim Comey the day after the Fourth of July held a press conference that said I've decided that no rational prosecutor, no reasonable prosecutor would take the case. There for no one's going to take the case.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: And a statement that was drafted even before they interview her.

NAPOLITANO: Yes.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: A statement that was authored in part or vetted verbally by Peter Strzok, the conflicted FBI agent that we only know is conflicted.

NAPOLITANO: One of the reasons --

BARTIROMO: And by the way no notes. No notes from that FBI interview. No notes from any meetings with Hillary Clinton.

NAPOLITANO: There we're so many absurdities.

BARTIROMO: No notes. Only notes on Donald Trump.

NAPOLITANO: They permitted her former lawyer who was a - herself a target of the investigation to be there and whisper in her ear to help her answer their questions. Something the FBI never permits.

BARTIROMO: Well, by the way, I reported it earlier, I'm expecting more texts to be revealed in the next two weeks something about a White House meeting between those two, Peter Strzok and Lisa Page.

NAPOLITANO: Can we discuss something -

BARTIROMO: Talking about a White House meeting.

NAPOLITANO: Can we discuss something happy like baseball?

BARTIROMO: Hey, it's Opening Day on Thursday. Thank you so much because we've got Rob Manfred in the studio coming up. Judge, good to see you.

NAPOLITANO: Pleasure.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much Judge Andrew Napalitano. It is Opening Day and we are on it this week on Thursday. Coming up next Uber exits from Southeast Asia why the ride handling (ph) company sold its operations to its main competitor. Plus a more affordable way to visit the happiest place on Earth, Disney World's new plans for kids to eat for free. Next.

(COMMERICAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Well, while the Saudi leadership is in New York this week, the Crown Prince Saudi Arabia has been the target of a missile strike from Yemen. Cheryl Casone with the details. Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NEW ANCHOR: Yes, he's in New York today, by the way, Maria. Saudi Arabia says that it has shot down seven ballistic missiles fired by Yemen's Houthis milita. Three missiles were aimed at the Saudi capital of Riyadh. Officials say the debris from the incoming missiles killed one man in what was the first death in Riyadh during the Saudi led three year war in Yemen.

Well, Uber is getting our of Southeast Asia. They've agreed to sell the business in the region to rival Grab. Uber is going to take a 27 percent stake in Grab. This is the second retreat from Asia for Uber after it sold its China business also to a local rival there. Well, Walt Disney is giving families a way to cut the cost of visiting Disney World for the summer.

It's offering free meals to kids between the ages of three and nine when parents book a Magic Your Way package. This is between May 28th through August 30th, so the summer. There's a few blackout dates and limitations and families must reserve a package by August 1st. Share of Walt Disney are down eight percent so far this year.

All I know is it was free and Disney in the same sentence so I had to do the story, Maria. And those are your headlines.

BARTIROMO: All right, Cheryl. Thank you so much. Coming up, Major League Baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred in the studio here. I had him Opening Day. He'll weigh in on Thursday's big day, big changes coming on and off the field. That's next.

(COMMERICAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. All right it is that time of the year. America's favorite pastime back. Thursday is Opening Day for baseball. For the first time in 50 years every single MLB team will play on Opening Day. All 30 clubs. It is also the earliest Opening Day in league history. Kicking off with the Cubs versus the Marlins on Thursday.

Other must watch games include defending champs the Astros facing off against the Rangers and the Yankees will take on the Blue Jays in Toronto. Joining me right now and a first on Fox Business Interview MLB Commissioner Rob Manfred. Commissioner, it's great to see you.

ROB MANFRED, MLB COMMISSIONER: Great to see you, too, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us. I got to tell you, I've seen a lot and done a lot of stuff over my career. The most exciting day of my life was when I threw out the first pitch at Yankee Stadium. I mean, it's incredible. Baseball really is exciting and what do you think about this Opening Day with all 30 clubs opening at once?

MANFRED: Well, we're thrilled about the idea. We think getting back to the tradition of everybody playing on Opening Day is an exciting thing for the sport. I think it give and opportunity to own Thursday, make opening day into the national holiday that it should be.

BARTIROMO: Can the Astro's do a repeat?

MANFRED: Hey, look. The Astro's are really talented, but there are a lot of good teams out there, a lot of buzz around the one team here in New York, the Yankees. Same thing with the Cubs. The Dodgers were great last year, so I think we're going to have a really competitive season.

BARTIROMO: Well, you've got a competitive season, but also because of all of these new rule changes, right? Let's talk about that. Speeding up the game is one of them. You're testing new pace of play rules in the minor leagues teams. You'll start with a runner on second base if the game goes into extra innings. Does this expand to the major leagues, and tell me about the rule changes and the impact.

MANFRED: Well the rule changes in the major leagues this year are really speeding up inning breaks. There's a clock. Batters have to be ready to go at 2:05. That should save us about 25 seconds on every inning break, which adds up to be a lot of time. We're limiting mound visits, six per game. The idea there is to take dead time out of the game. We're trying to proceed slowly at the major league level.

We've been more aggressive in the minor leagues. We have pitch clocks. We've had them for a number of years. We feel like they're successful. Those could come to the major leagues. The extra inning rule, I don't see that at the major league level. Some people really like it. It does make for excitement, but I think breaking the tradition of the extra inning game at the big league level is not likely to happen.

BARTIROMO: So the whole idea of speeding up the game and pacing differently, is that to make sure that it doesn't impact engagement, get the engagement (inaudible) because we've watched what has happened at the NFL. The NFL has been seeing a drop in viewership over the last couple of years. Are you watching this? What are doing in terms of game viewership and is that part of it?

MANFRED: Oh, it's a huge issue. In the ballpark, pace of game is not a big issue because during the breaks there's a lot going on, there's entertainment.

BARTIROMO: Exactly.

MANFRED: . there's things to do.

BARTIROMO: It's when you're at home watching.

MANFRED: Home, and every one of those breaks is an opportunity to tune away. We pay a lot of attention to what's going on in other sports. We've been fortunate, however. Our last two World Series have been really successful in terms of our ratings. And during the summer in 25 markets on game days, we're the number one programming on television, so we've been.

BARTIROMO: Still?

MANFRED: . very fortunate in that regard.

BARTIROMO: That's incredible.

MANFRED: Yes, it's - look, in the summer time, people remember that baseball is a national pastime and they tune into their local team.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's a good point. So a lot of big moves there. The big Yankees move, obviously, the off season. Tell me about that because you've got the Yankees acquiring arguably the two best sluggers, right, Judge and Stanton. How were they able to pull off that trade?

MANFRED: Well, it was, I think, one of those things where the Marlins felt that, with their new ownership, they wanted to go down a slightly different path. The Yankees were there as willing buyers on what's a very large contract, but it's exciting in New York. The two players together last year hit 111 home runs. I think it's only four short of what Mantle and Maris did in their historic season, so a lot of buzz around that team this year.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I'm glad you mentioned the Marlins because you've got the former shortstop, Derek Jeter, now owning the Marlins or part of the Marlins. What does that do for the game? Are former players becoming office executives good for the sport? What's the impact?

MANFRED: Oh, I think it's great for the sport. I'll tell you, it's difficult at the beginning, you take over a team, you haven't been an owner before, it's obviously difficult to get your footing, but I was down and saw an Marlins spring training game recently, talked to a bunch of people in the organization. Derek's done a phenomenal job. The organization is very positive. They've got a lot of great, young talent that they brought back in these trades, and I have every, every expectation that Derek's going to be really successful.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I would imagine when somebody who knows the games, knows the tricks, just knows how to get around the field as an owner, it could be real positive.

MANFRED: Look, I think it's a huge positive to have former players, particularly a player of Derek's stature, involved on the ownership side of the game.

BARTIROMO: Let me ask you about the new tax law because we were talking about this earlier. The new tax law seems to be throwing some of the players and owners a curve ball, if you will. It could make it so that clubs face higher capital gains taxes for trading highly paid players. This is something that I didn't think about initially when we were looking at the tax plan, but how does this impact the teams and the players?

MANFRED: Well, it could really be an impediment to trades taking place.

BARTIROMO: Exactly.

MANFRED: . particularly trades that happened quickly because of the requirement evaluation. We think it was a mistake, that it really was not intended to apply to trades of baseball players, and we're hopeful that when things get clarified in the technical corrections that we'll deal with that issue.

BARTIROMO: Yes, because it's not - I mean, you don't think of a trade of a player being the same as capital gains trading stocks.

MANFRED: Well, if you think about the economics of it, right, I'm trading you something in return for something else. There's a very good argument that they should be treated of equal value, otherwise somebody's not acting rationally, which I don't think is the case with most of our clubs.

BARTIROMO: Have you been in touch with lawmakers on this issue?

MANFRED: We have.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MANFRED: We have.

BARTIROMO: So they're looking at it. They're aware that maybe there were unintended consequences.

MANFRED: Yes, there's a large list of things. Obviously, we have a couple of issues in the tax bill that we have been in touch with lawmakers about and hope they get clarified.

BARTIROMO: Rob, the league is working to finalize a two-game series between the Yankees and the Red Sox at London's Olympic Stadium. Let's talk about that. This would be the American baseball's first regular season games in Europe. Pretty exciting stuff.

MANFRED: Very exciting for us. We feel that Europe's a frontier that we need to get to. We want to get there with our very best. We think a Yankee-Red Sox series will be very exciting and give us a foothold in Europe.

BARTIROMO: What about the streaming deals? This is an important piece of business right now for the league. You've got streaming deals with Twitter, ESPN, Intel, YouTube, Facebook Watch also stepping up to the plate with a deal with the league. The exclusive stream, 25 games. Tell us about this.

MANFRED: Well, being on the cutting edge of technology has been really good for our business on the development of Bantech (ph), the sale of that asset to Disney, and we feel that these streaming deals are really important in terms of capturing the next generation of fans.

BARTIROMO: You have to because that's where a lot of people watch the game, on their phone.

MANFRED: Absolutely. Look, the next generation wants to see their favorite sport, and we hope it's baseball, on a variety of different platforms, and our strategy has been to make the game available on those platforms.

BARTIROMO: Yes, but you said it earlier, you see more people in the stands that before, right? Are you having a hard time getting people in their seats because they're watching it on streaming?

MANFRED: Well, it's amazing. We had 114 million people went to see baseball live last year, minor league and major league baseball. That's a phenomenal number for us. Our ballpark experience is a little different than our broadcast experience. There's a certain commradery to it. There's all the entertainment that goes on in the ballpark, and fortunately our attendance has remained really stable.

BARTIROMO: And lots of giveaways when you're in the field.

MANFRED: That's right. Those promotional nights are very popular with our fans.

BARTIROMO: Rob, it's great to see you. Thanks so much.

MANFRED: It's great to see you, too, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Good luck with opening day. We will be watching.

MANFRED: All right, thank you.

BARTIROMO: MLB Commissioner, Rob Manfred, there. We'll be right back. Stay with us.

urn:contentItem:5FDN-HNV1-JB20-G426-00000-00Eaton Corporation PLC Corporate Analyst Meeting - Final2015-02-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:41ZLexisNexis022715a5620690.790Eaton CorporationPLC Corporate Analyst Meeting - Final

Corporate Participants

* Don Bullock

Eaton CorporationPLC - SVP, IR

* Sandy Cutler

Eaton CorporationPLC - CEO & President

* Rick Fearon

Eaton CorporationPLC - Vice Chairman & CFO & Chief Planning Officer

* Craig Arnold

Eaton CorporationPLC - Vice Chairman & COO, Industrial Sector

* Uday Yadav

Eaton CorporationPLC - President, Aerospace Group

* Tom Gross

Eaton CorporationPLC - Vice Chairman & COO, Electrical Sector

* Revathi Advaithi

Eaton CorporationPLC - President, Americas Region, Electrical

* Frank Campbell

Eaton CorporationPLC - President, Europe, Middle East and Africa Region, Electrical

* Mark Eubanks

Eaton CorporationPLC - President, Cooper Lighting Division

Conference Call Participants

* Deane Dray

RBC Capital Markets - Analyst

* Nigel Coe

Morgan Stanley - Analyst

* Ann Duignan

JPMorgan Chase - Analyst

Presentation

DON BULLOCK, SVP, IR, EATON CORPORATIONPLC: Good morning. I am Don Bullock, Eaton's Senior Vice President of Investor Relations. I'd like to welcome all of you here in New York and those of you joining us by webcast to Eaton's 2015 Investor Conference. I'd like to draw your attention to a couple of items before we start, before I turn the podium over to our speakers. The first thing I'd like to do is talk a little bit about the agenda. As you can see, we have a robust agenda today and we are confident that you will find it both informative and insightful. Today, we start with comments from Sandy Cutler, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer and Rick Fearon, our Vice Chairman and CFO, on some corporate items and those are followed by the industrial sector presentations and our electrical sector presentations.

You'll have three opportunities during today's meeting to be able to pose questions. At the end of both the industrial sector presentations and the electrical sector presentations, we will open the floor for questions. In addition, after lunch, we will be taking questions after the lunch session. We will be breaking at 10:15 for a short break. For those of you joining us by Webcast, when we break for lunch, we will readjourn for the question-and-answer session via the webcast approximately 30 minutes after we break.

Finally, I'd like to draw your attention to our comments on both our forward-looking statements and our use of any non-GAAP measures. Take a moment to read it; it is in your packet. It's also on the website and the materials are covered in more depth on our 10-K filed on February 26, 2015. With that, I'll turn the floor over to Sandy.

SANDY CUTLER, CEO & PRESIDENT, EATON CORPORATIONPLC: Thanks, Don. Let me add my own welcome to all of you who are here this morning, as well as those of you who are on the webcast. We appreciate the time you are going to spend with us this morning. We think we've got a really exciting morning to give you insights both on our current performance and our future-looking prospects. So I once again appreciate your commitment of time.

I want to cover four themes with you to kick things off and as you saw from the agenda that Don shared with you, we are going to put the primary time this morning on helping you gain some additional insights into both businesses and market conditions that you've had a number of questions about over the last several months. So let me hop right in on the first one here talking about our power management strategy. For those of you who have followed our Company for some time, you know that we have really aligned our Company around the issue of power. And we are able to supply power using three important technologies -- electrical, fluid or Hydraulics and mechanical technologies -- to serve a series of high power consuming industries.

The reason we think that is important is that regulations and sustainability continue to drive adoption of advanced technologies. Those advanced technologies require a very active R&D stream and I'll share more with you on that and it gives to us the opportunity really to maintain very strong margins through the cycle. At a time when oil prices have backed off, what is interesting to see is that customers are still looking for sustainable solutions that over the long term offer them the opportunity to reduce their energy costs and utilize energy and power safely.

I think you are all aware that we organize our Company into two sectors -- our electrical sector led by Tom Gross, our industrial sector led by Craig Arnold -- and within those businesses maybe just a couple quick introductory comments. You will hear much more about them as we go through the morning's agenda. In our electrical business, post our acquisition of Cooper, we now offer complex solutions all the way from generation onto end-user applications. We can compete head-up with anyone around the world and we are really delighted with the increased breadth of that operation.

Within our industrial sector three businesses, Hydraulics serving a broad array of activities and end markets. We'll talk more about those this morning. Our Aerospace business serving virtually every commercial aircraft manufacturer in all NATO-aligned countries in terms of their military operations and our Vehicle business serving that complex array of solutions that help fuel economy, as well as uptime and safety across both commercial vehicles and passenger or light vehicles.

We have been fairly clear about our strategy since 2000. I just want to do a very quick reprise of what that strategy was, what our goals were, what the strategy was and what we've done to execute that has really brought us today and another record year this last year with our earnings up some 13% in spite of relatively slow growth end markets. We said we had three goals when we started in on the transformation of the Company. The first was higher earnings growth, the second was reduced volatility in those earnings through the cycle and the third was while we were doing that to maintain a high return on capital, that we weren't simply going to take moves that diluted the return on our investors' money.

Our strategy was first to start by changing the mix fairly aggressively. Our portfolio today is very different than it was and within that portfolio, just as important, every year, we continue to make changes to move our assets toward higher return, higher growth businesses. We wanted to upgrade the talent significantly. You saw this was particularly a sharp change in the early 2000s. We brought a lot of people into Eaton to bring us to the opportunity to really run what we called an integrated operating company model. I'll talk more about that in just a minute.

But what you would see if you were inside Eaton today, you would Eaton University with over 30,000 people going through Eaton University every year. It is critical to how we train people for their careers, train additional competencies, certify people on being able to use the Eaton Business System, which is the third piece of the strategy, which was to run our business better. We were convinced we could run the Company again higher growth, reduced volatility, lower level of assets, but we needed to do so capturing the scale of what had become a bigger company. It is particularly true for companies who do a lot of acquisitions and as you can see if you move to the right side of this chart, we have done some 66 acquisitions. They are integrated; they operate on one model. We do not run what I will call a loosely affiliated holding company and we think that is how you capture scale in large-sized businesses.

We've also invested CAD5.5 billion in research over this time period. You will hear this morning again I think a really impressive array of new products being launched again this year that really bring to us again that opportunity for high margin, high growth and bringing those complex solutions to our customers that are really necessary to deliver on our promise of utilizing energy and power efficiently, safely and reliably and sustainably. And during this period of time, you can see with those 66 acquisitions we've spent some $20 billion of capital and we have successfully integrated those 66 acquisitions.

Let me turn a little bit to the issue of stability. I think as we all talk and you know very well right now, these are pretty volatile times. Whether you are looking at currency, whether you're looking at differential growth rates between countries or whether you are looking at the challenge of relatively low global growth, it becomes important that the portfolio of companies are one that can grow right through the economic cycle and not be dented by a change in one end market, but not be dented by a change in one geographic area and not be dented by the normal cycle that might go on if you were just in one business. That has been a hallmark of our strategy and we think it is continuing to prove to be an effective one for our investors.

If you look at this chart, we have talked to you quite a bit about wanting to get balance in our segment businesses and you can see we've got really quite a nice array of businesses that participate at different times of the economic cycle. You can see in that second one, we are just about perfectly balanced now, which was one of our objectives in terms of early, mid, late and then those businesses that tend to have a very strong aftermarket stream that tend not to have much of a cycle. That is critical when you are going through the economic cycle, so we are no longer an early cycle bet or a late cycle bet.

The lower one is one that has become particularly true and important to observe really since 2008. For all of you who were investing on the theme of emerging nations in the period of 2000 to 2007, clearly that has not been the winner since that period of time. Our strategy has been to get ourselves to 60% of our revenues outside of the US with the last 40% equally balanced between developed and emerging international economies.

What we have been able to do is in spite of the fact that the so-called BRIC have been a really disappointing story over the last couple of years, we have been able to still maintain very strong growth because of our balance. There will be a time driven again by the demographics and more political stability where a lot of the emerging nations' story will be a lot more attractive. That is not right now, but it will be in the feature and we continue to put down the important cornerstone investments in those economies to allow us to grow and take advantage of that.

And last but not least, certainly oil and gas is on everyone's mind today. A number of years ago, it was construction equipment, it was mining. You can think about different markets over time that fall into disfavor and others that are in favor. One of the advantages of Eaton is we are spread across a lot of end markets. We're not beholding to any one end market. That is a specific construct of our portfolio and our strategy. We again want to be able to move assets and move resources to advantaged end markets during the cycle and that is how we continue to have the opportunity to outgrow our end markets.

This chart is just a quick look at another cut at that issue. On the left side of the chart, what we've tried to do is simply by showing you a bright green or a plus or a minus for a market condition is to show you if you go through the businesses that we report externally and think about what had been the market conditions in individual years for these businesses, you will see that in every year there is some business that maybe isn't as strong as others, but the important piece of this is the balance by being represented across many businesses and across many end markets is what has allowed us on the right-hand side to drive 14% compound annual growth rate in terms of our operating earnings per share during this same time period. We think very strong earnings growth in a period of reduced end market growth, more currency volatility and clearly very differential results by end markets.

And then again if you ask the question of how that compares to our peers, our 13% increase in our operating earnings per share last year obviously compares very advantageously to the 7% to 8% of our peers and when we look again at that 2010 to 2015 time period, you can see we've outpaced our peers again. The strategy of breadth is working.

This is, of course, the long-term chart that we have shared with you on numerous occasions in terms of what our total shareholder return -- this obviously includes dividend reinvestment -- in this process has worked. Clearly we did not have as good a year last year. It is the first year of negative return except during the recession we've had. We are pleased that we are off recovering most of that already this year and we think the strategy over this time period really is working.

Let me turn to the third segment in terms of what I wanted to highlight for you this morning. It's our view on the economy. Not much new here and not much that you don't already appreciate. This post-2008 period of time burdened by the recovery from a liquidity-driven recession and the instability and high interest rate environments in many of the emerging nations is leading to a lower growth market. A fundamental reset has occurred. For the companies who have not put the strategy in place to deal with a reset, this becomes a very difficult environment.

You heard us coming out of the recession that our game plan for the five years forward after that was that we thought things would grow slower. In fact, it has grown a little slower than even we thought. We do think that this is the new normal. It is one that we've got to adjust to and we do believe we've got the plan put in place and that is fully reflected in our guidance for this year. The piece that I think is different and if you recall that we talked about it, if I could just hearken back to that previous chart, is we said that we thought we would see more currency instability. We thought it would occur earlier as you had differential rates of growth around the world.

That reset is clearly in full flow at this point and if you look at what happened in the fourth quarter and obviously what has happened in the first quarter, while it may have been a year or two later than we thought, we are in a period of really differential what I will call disintermediation of currency rates that are starting to make the growth rates around the country -- around the world -- make more sense. There will be more of this. We've taken about a 4% hit is on our forecast for this year in terms of impact on the top line from currency valuation. This is another issue that companies need to learn to deal with and still create earnings growth.

One of the fundamental ways we are doing that is what we've often called our self-help story. Our view if you go back to 2011 and 2012 was that these next couple of years were going to be a period of slow growth and if you grow your top line say at 3%, you can grow your bottom line at 6%, while that was attractive performance, that wasn't really attractive in the minds of investors and you needed to have another piece of your strategy, which would allow you to supercharge your earnings to get more toward that 10% type growth per year.

That strategy was the Cooper acquisition for us. Not only did it strengthen our electrical business and give us breadth and put us into new applications and strengthen us around the world, but it also supplied to us four successive years of substantial synergy savings. You can see them arrayed on this chart. The first year, $115 million; the next year, an incremental $95 million; the next year, an incremental $150 million. That's this year. And remember, next year, there's another $115 million incremental coming in 2016. A really successful acquisition. You will hear more about some of the key elements of that integration. We are absolutely on track or slightly ahead of schedule and it is producing all the results that we hoped that it would.

Now in the meantime, organic growth remains very important. It is the majority of our long-term growth plan. While we can have acquisitions, they are not the main feed at the table. They are a portion of our overall growth strategy and the investments we've been making through this period of time, even though it has been relatively slow growth, are important. If you go back to 2000, we had two global innovation centers. These are big R&D and innovation centers in the world, both in the US. Today, we have six with two in the US. Clearly, we are accessing talent around the world and we are developing product and innovation for local markets and the configurations and the functions and the cost base you need to succeed in those individual marketplaces.

You can see we are spending nearly $700 million on R&D, but more important than the dollars is really just -- I'll give you a quick capsule of kind of the results on the right-hand side. Over 10,000 engineering professionals around the world for Eaton now. That is a real army of highly creative talented men and women who are really making a difference for us in the front end of our businesses. Patent applications last year up 13% again. First issue patents up 27%. Eaton is doing important work in the area of power management and our customers feel it.

This is just a very quick look at just four of the recent introductions in this area. You're going to hear a lot more about many others here today. In our electrical sector, our variable frequency drives, and for those of you who know the characteristics when one starts an electric motor, there's a huge inrush; energy utilization is ineffective at that point. We've got now a complete line of variable frequency drives. You'll hear a little bit more about it this morning, really exciting. We took advantage of our Powerware acquisition to utilize the power semiconductor knowledge that came out of all the engineers working on UPS to be able to redeploy people in addition to doing UPS to develop a whole line of drives. That's an example of an integrated operating company being able to build on strength in one area and take it into another.

You've heard Tom Gross speak the last couple of years about when we did the Moeller acquisition in 2008. We acquired a very complete array of IEC components. What we didn't get were IEC assemblies. And what we've been working very hard on is bringing out the assemblies. These are the large structures and integrated capabilities to serve big jobs, if you will, in the market whether industrial or commercial. We now have those products and are really starting to push that around the world.

If I switch to our industrial side, many of you know Eaton has traditionally been much stronger in the heavy-duty application Class 8 truck market. Our relative participation in the medium-duty market has been lower in that regard. You'll hear Craig talk today about our Procision dual clutch technology that we are taking this year into the medium-duty North American market to allow us to significantly increase our marketshare and really make a difference for our customers in terms of performance. We're really excited about this product.

And in our Aerospace business, you will hear Uday Yadav this morning talk a little bit about here is just an example of the kind of technology we have in our seals capability that is allowing people to develop engines that deal with lower friction, higher heat and obviously better operating performance over time.

But it's not just about products. It's also got to be serving the right customers and how we go about serving them.
