Our channel partnerships are incredibly important to us and you're going to hear from Revathi Advaithi this morning about what we are doing in a relatively unique way to significantly improve our sales through our North American electrical channel process. It's not really in our electrical business. Real success is in Hydraulics in Asia this last year. We've talked to you about the volatility that occurs on the OEM side of the business. One of the important things is to build the stationary and distributor-oriented side of the business. As you can see, some 100 new distributors in Asia just in the last year in that respect.

Customers want to deal in a digital environment today. Every one of us who buys clothes or any other retail product are very used to click and order. That's not generally how the industrial markets work today. What we have launched across Eaton and will be rolling out the next three years we think sets the standard in the industry in terms of a digital contemporary experience for engineers that are a whole other generation than the ones that used to look at books and charts and specifications. This is a fundamental investment in doing business differently and it goes across all of our businesses.

Then last but not least, as markets ebb and get stronger, all these individual small markets, we want the ability to be able to move people to key segments that are strong. Let me give you a current example of being able to focus in that regard. The machine-building marketplace is getting stronger again. It's an area where we have electrical and hydraulic applications. It is unique within an integrated operating company that we can move people quickly and we can bring people from different franchises to emphasize where points of opportunity are that are stronger than others during the cycle.

Now all that comes together in terms as we think about our 2015 guidance. Clearly, if you were listening to companies in the December time period, many multinationals were talking about FX guidance for the year of 2015 maybe denting the top line by 1% or 2%. As we got into January, you started to hear people talk early in the month about 2%, 3%. By the end of the month, most people were in the 4% to 5% and we think it will impact us by 4% this year. That's about $900 million on the top line that it impacts us this year. But we have to find a way to create operating earnings.

What you can see on that lower chart is that our operating earnings-per-share guidance this year at the midpoint is up 5% compared to last year. Without the FX and then, of course, we told you in our gardens that our tax rate is going to be approximately 9% to 11% this year. Last year without the special items it was approximately 6%. That increase obviously is a drag this year as well and has been consistent with what we had indicated all through the second half of last year, really no change as we got to our guidance this year. Without those two items, we are driving 13%.

What makes that possible? What makes that possible is that additional $150 million of synergy savings plus the $35 million of additional benefits that came out of the restructuring that we did last year in the industrial sector. That's the self-help story that is allowing us to continue to drive strong earnings during a period of weak end-market demand, substantial FX currency valuation change and the fact that our tax rate is moving up through this time period.

Let me talk about maybe the big news I think for 2015. In 2012, when we announced at EPG in late May that we are acquiring Cooper, we said we would be out of the M&A market for probably about three years. And we thought it would be about the middle of 2015 until we had completed most of the decisions and most of the integration for the Cooper business and had made the biggest portion of the progress to paying down our debt. So we call that sort of the financial capacity. Once we are fishing up the integration, our management capacity would return to again potentially enter the M&A market.

As you can see, we've had very strong growth in cash from operations during this time period, 23% compound growth rate. That has been primarily applied to paying down the $2.1 million of the $4.9 million of the debt that we took on to acquire Cooper. You can see on the right side our free cash flow has really improved as well. We continue to spend on R&D. We continue to spend on CapEx. We are not cutting any of those things back, but you are starting to see the scale and the profitability of the Company that really is making this happen.

As a result, as we look forward I have shared with you the middle of 2015 becomes a pretty important decision time for the Company. I think that's really good news for investors. We are now just four or five months away from that. We were 2.5 years away from it when we talked in May, so it felt -- in May 2012 -- so it felt relatively inapplicable at that time and what we've tried to show you just on the left-hand side is a representation of rough approximations -- this is not guidance -- this is a rough approximation of the second half of 2015 and an early look at 2016 in terms of cash flows to give you some dimension as to what is going to be the amount of cash that we might apply in terms of optionality. And if you go to that right-hand column that says capital optionality, approximately $1.5 billion to maybe $1.65 billion of cash that we're going to need to apply to something during that time period.

What are we going to apply it to? You saw us buy back $650 million of shares in the second half of this last year. We had not planned on doing that originally. We were able to do that earlier than we thought. But we think it is likely to be a mixture of you saw us increase the dividend early this week, 12%. We think going forward it is likely to be a mixture again of these three things -- of continued strong dividend increases, some mixture of share buyback and potentially M&A if we find the right particular transactions. We will be able to share more with you as we get to the middle of this year. So by conclusion, we really think the power management strategy is working; it's effective. It provides the stability we are looking for. It is allowing us to drive earnings during a difficult set of end conditions and we are positioned now I think for that next step for the Company around cash deployment.

The balance of this morning, Rick is going to give you a quick update on 2014 highlights, a look into more detail in terms of our guidance for this year. We are then going to switch to what we would all call kind of the meat of the morning. Craig is going to give you a view overall for the industrial sector and then Uday Yadav is going to join you and talk a little bit about our Aerospace business. Then the electrical business, Tom is going to set the sort of overall summary and then you are going to hear about the sales channel integration and strategy, such an important part of the Cooper business by Revathi Advaithi, who runs our Americas area for our overall electrical business. Frank Campbell is going to tell you about some of the new product innovation and reasons for real excitement around the vitality. Frank runs our EMEA region for our electrical business and then Mark Eubanks, who runs our lighting business, is going to share with you some really exciting insights around the LED revolution that is going on in the marketplace today and how we are really very advantageously positioned. So with that, let me turn things over to Rick and we will continue the morning. Thanks again for being here this morning.

RICK FEARON, VICE CHAIRMAN & CFO & CHIEF PLANNING OFFICER, EATON CORPORATIONPLC: Thanks, Sandy. I'm going to spend 20 minutes and take you quickly through a recap of 2014, talk a little bit, as well as some of the longer term trends. Then talk in some more detail about the cash optionality decision and some of the options that we are going to face in the middle of the year and then give you a little more granularity on some aspects of our 2015 guidance.

This shows you over the last decade three key measures of the growth that we have had -- sales growth 9%, cash from operations 12%, operating EPS 8%. This is in an environment that has been incredibly volatile. If you look at the average of GDP growth over this 10 years, it's actually been 2.8% globally. Now, obviously, a lot faster prior to the Great Recession. Then you took a step backwards in the Great Recession and since then, we are in this new normal period and unfortunately, it appears that that is what we are likely to see over the next few years, which makes generating your own growth ever more important.

One of the things that we have been focused on as part of Cooper is, and one of the reasons we are interested in Cooper as an acquisition candidate was we believed that it would provide greater earnings stability, one of the goals that Sandy talked about. I thought I would share a couple of measures of that to give you some insight into this earnings stability.

On the left side, I'm looking at the range of EBIT margin over this ten-year time period and what we've done is looked at Eaton and Cooper pro forma together over that 10-year time period. And as you see, we have one of the more stable EBIT margins compared to our peers and in fact, if I were to show you Eaton standalone, we would have been, as a standalone entity, in the half to a little bit above half towards the higher end of that chart. So Cooper has definitely given us more margin stability.

Another way to look at it would be to look at EBIT growth. And so what we've done here is looked at EBIT growth over the time period prior to the acquisition of Cooper, looked at Eaton standalone, looked at Eaton and Cooper together and as you see, the volatility of the growth of EBIT is about 20% less Eaton/Cooper combined. So Cooper definitely has given us more earnings stability and you are seeing that.

2014 was a record year and sometimes it is hard as all of you do focusing mainly upon quarters to step back and look at that. But if you look at just a few parameters, I think it will show what a strong year it was. 13% operating EPS growth, $4.67. Now that was almost exactly the midpoint of the guidance that we gave at the start of 2014. That midpoint was $4.70. 15.3% segment operating margin, up 40 basis points from the prior year and $2.53 billion cash from operations and that compares to $2.28 billion in the year prior. And we closed in a strong way with core growth of 5%, our strongest quarter of core sales growth since 2011.

If you look at the cash that we gave back to shareholders, $650 million of repurchases, $929 million of dividends paid and of course, the 12% dividend increase our Board enacted on Wednesday bringing our dividend to $0.55 a quarter. And I would also point out that we have taken away risk from future growth. We have paid down debt to the tune of $582 million. We are approaching our target capital structure, not yet there, but we will be there in about a year from now. And then, lastly, we resolved some long-standing litigation, the Meritor, the Frisby suits and that took nonbusiness risk off the table. So a year of great accomplishment, one that we are very proud of.

Turning to cash optionality, Sandy showed you the growth in cash from operations over the last five years. That was, of course, void by coming out of the Great Recession. If you look over this longer period of time though, it has grown about 10%. So a strong rate of cash from operations growth. We have grown the dividend during that same time period at 14%. Quite an attractive rate I think if you compare the rate of our dividend increase compared to most of our peers. And as you see, that has been a pretty steady progression over this ten-year period.

That dividend increase has allowed us to pay a good yield, a high yield on our shares. Our yield prior to the increase last Wednesday was about 2.7%. Today, it is over 3%, so a strong running dividend yield. The middle chart shows you the repurchases. We ramped them up across last year as we saw opportunities to use some excess cash to take advantage of weakness in our share price and in total, we returned $1.6 billion of cash to our shareholders last year. That is 4.4% of the market cap of Eaton at the start of 2014. I think that's a real testament to the shareholder orientation of the Company.

This shows you our remaining debt paydown schedule connected to the Cooper transaction. When we did the transaction, met with credit providers, met with the rating agencies, we made a commitment that we would reduce our long-term debt from the close of the transaction by $2.1 billion. We have $1.2 billion left to pay down, $400 million in the second quarter and that is $300 million in April and $100 million in June. And then another $600 million in early November. And we will then close off this debt paydown schedule with $240 million maturity in the middle of January.

So we are actually only about 11 months away from having completed this paydown and what that will do is that that leaves us with an amount of long-term debt that we believe, at our present size, is appropriate for the long-term capital structure of the Company. Obviously, as the Company grows, there potentially is the ability to have a bit more long-term debt, but we will be in what we regard as a stable situation by January of next year.

And if you step back and think about our capital deployment over the last -- or since the start of this decade, since 2010, this is I think a useful way to think about it. In the 2010 through 2012 time period, we deployed about $17.5 billion of capital. And the majority, the great majority of that deployment was in acquisitions. We spent over $14 billion on acquisitions; Cooper, of course, being the largest at about $13 billion. And then other deployment to CapEx, dividends, etc. and a tiny bit of debt paydown.

If you look at what we have been doing in 2013, 2014 and will be doing in 2015, it is largely a balance sheet repair period. We will have devoted the largest portion of our money to paying down debt, but we also will have maintained attractive dividend and fully funded all of the capital spending needs of the business, as well as opportunities to pursue new product introductions.

Looking into 2016 to 2018 then, that large amount of money that has been spent on debt paydown is no longer going to be needed for such and so we're going to have the ability to change focus and redeploy that for growth -- shareholder growth-enhancing activities whether it be repurchase, whether it be M&A and we are actively giving thought to just what our strategy should be over the next year and a half from the middle of this year and we will update you on that when we get to the middle of the year.

Let me talk a little bit more about our 2015 guidance just to give you some understanding of how we see this year turning out. As Sandy talked about, global growth has definitely downshifted to a lower trajectory. So-called new normal. The growth of global GDP this year we estimate to be about 2.8%, so very much typical of the kind of growth that we are likely to see. And with that global number that is fairly moderate, you're going to see a fair amount of variation around the world. The United States we think will be one of the higher growing parts of the world, certainly the highest growing developed part of the world at 2.9% and that compares to 2014 GDP in the US of 2.4%. You may have seen they just revised down the Q4 US GDP number at 8:30 this morning to 2.2% for the fourth quarter of last year.

Brazil, we had thought as we were coming into our planning for the year that it might have modest growth, but with the issues that Brazil is confronting, the issues around commodity prices, some of the political issues that they are dealing with, we now think that you are looking at a modest decline in Brazil of 1% to 1.5%. Europe, 1.5% will be the best year in many years for Europe and it is really a reflection of several things. It's a reflection of the euro having declined about 20% and we are definitely seeing that in export orders out of Europe. In fact, if you looked at German export orders for Germany as a whole in January, that was the highest month ever for export orders from Germany. So you are definitely seeing some rebound in Europe. China downshifting growth a bit. Still a very high rate of growth, but certainly not what it was five, six years ago. And in India, growth seems to be picking up, which is a good thing and definitely an opportunity for us.

So that's the world that we are living in and within that world, we believe that we will be able to generate core or organic growth -- we use those words somewhat interchangeably -- of 3% to 4%. And I have arrayed for you the core growth differences between the segments. Hydraulics will have the lowest core growth or perhaps a slight core decline related to the downturns in some of its markets, namely large ag and Chinese construction equipment. Vehicle will have the highest growth we believe and the rest are in between.

And then on the right side, and I'm not going to go through each of these individual bullet points, but I've tried to array the growth expectations we have for some of the key markets that affect the core growth in each of our segments. So at your leisure, you can take a look at that. We expect good margin improvement in 2015 and that is consistent really with the long-term trend. So if you look at our segment margins starting back in 2000, and you see it has been on a nicely uptrend over this 15-year period, we expect our margins at the segment level to increase 60 to 120 basis points in 2015 and that is from the 15.3% margin that we had in 2014.

Now our cash earnings are even stronger than our GAAP earnings. And so I thought I would show you a comparison just to give you some insight into that. On the left side, with operating EPS in 2014 of $4.67, we had EBITDA per share of $7.52. And with a midpoint of $4.90 per share operating earnings in 2015, we expect that you are going to have a number for EBITDA per share that is going to be between $8 and $8.05. So a very attractive cash profile.

One of the questions we sometimes get is cash conversion ratios, how does free cash flow compare to GAAP earnings and I thought I would give you some insight into that. In general for 2015, we think cash conversion is likely to be about 100% and in 2014, it was a little less than that at about 90% and a simple way to think about that is that our non-cash amortization of intangibles is a little over $400 million a year. If you think about what happens to that non-cash amortization, it gets whittled down quite a bit by several factors. First of all, in 2015, we are planning to spend about $110 million more on CapEx than is our depreciation. And the reason for that is capacitizing new facilities, capacitizing new programs so that we can take advantage of growth opportunities.

Secondly, our pension contribution is going to be a bit higher than pension expense this year. Now compared to 2014, there was a bigger gap in 2014, but there still will be some gap in 2015 and as I'll show you in a second, however, that gap is likely to be eliminated pretty quickly given how well-funded our pension plan is right now.

And then, lastly, we think there will still be a little bit of gap between cash taxes and book taxes in 2015. We think that gap will be less than the gap was in 2014 and then there are a few other very small items where you will have a little bit of an imbalance between cash and book. That is how you walk from this non-cash amortization over to roughly around 100% free cash flow of GAAP earnings.

In terms of our pension plan, our US qualified plan, that is about two-thirds of our pension liability and it's about 90% of the liability that has to be funded. We have liabilities and many countries, there are no funding requirements and so you pay as you go. If I look at where we were at the end of 2014 and I've taken a little bit of liberty. We made a $200 million contribution the second day in January, so I have added that in and we are 85% funded then at the end of 2014, $570 million underfunded. And that reflects two negatives in that calculation. First, the new mortality tables and those mortality tables reduced or increased our underfunded status by $143 million just from the mortality tables and secondly, the discount rate going from 4.7% to 4.0%. So even with those two fairly significant negatives, still 85% funded and as a sensitivity, I think it is helpful to note that a 50 basis point increase in the discount rate improves the fund-in level by 5 percentage points. So if you had a 150 basis point increase in the discount rate, you would be fully funded.

And the bottom shows you how the discount rates changed over time. It was 7.75% in 2000. As recently as 2010, it was at that 5.5% that would allow us to be fully funded. Then if you look over on the right side, I've tried to show US qualified plan funding as a percentage of cash flow and you see how that has dropped dramatically from 16% down to 7% this year.

One other comment I thought you might find helpful is if indeed you had a 100 basis point increase in the discount rate, just to give you a sensitivity to earnings, a 100 basis point increase in the discount rate would increase our earnings by $75 million. That's essentially a reduction in pension expense of $75 million, so it would also impact the P&L.

This is our guidance slide. It has not changed from what we went over with you in January. The 3% to 4% organic revenue growth, negative 4% ForEx and the segment margins are all the same as we talked with you in January. What I thought I would do though would be to give you a little color on the first quarter because I think you all might find that helpful. Generally, we find on the revenue side in the first quarter that first-quarter revenues are the weakest revenues of the year just for seasonality reasons, some of which are related to weather. But this year, we are also finding that there's a significant foreign exchange negative from the fourth quarter to the first quarter.

So if you think about the normal downturn from Q4 to Q1, you add on the FX negative because exchange rates really accelerated all throughout Q4 so you didn't really see the full impact by any means of this exchange rate slide in Q4. In total, we think that revenues in Q1 are going to be about 5% under revenues in Q4, so that is a good way to think about that as you model that out. If you look at our margins in Q1, we believe that at the segment level they will be between 14.5% and 15.0% and the reason they will be suppressed a little bit is that, as Craig will talk about, we are doing some restructuring actions in Hydraulics and those restructuring costs are reducing in particular the Hydraulics margins in the first quarter.

And so in summary, we have had solid results over a long period and are very well-positioned for the future. Strong and predictable earnings growth. We've got a lot of cash optionality. We are returning a lot of cash to shareholders and the self-help strategy that Sandy described and we've been pursuing is delivering solid growth in what I think we all agree is a slowing global environment.

With that, let me turn it over to Craig and I'd be happy to answer any questions at the break.

CRAIG ARNOLD, VICE CHAIRMAN & COO, INDUSTRIAL SECTOR, EATON CORPORATIONPLC: Thanks, Rick. Appreciate it. So I guess I should say welcome to the meat of the morning, which is the expression my boss used. I'm not sure if I like the analogy of being considered the meat of the morning. It conjures up images of a bunch of lions and tigers and bears in the audience, but, oh my, yes. But a couple of the other things that he said that certainly resonate with me and are consistent with kind of the story that you are going to hear from us in our industrial businesses is that Sandy said our power management strategy is working. He also said that the stability that we have and the balance that we have in our Company has essentially allowed us to grow our earnings as a company through the cycle and to outperform our peers.

And so my job today and Uday's job today and when he comes up behind me is to show you how the industrial businesses are an important part of that success. And in fact, we strongly believe that if you take a look at each of our businesses, each of our businesses do have the ability and have historically been the engine of earnings growth inside of the Company at some point in the cycle. You are certainly seeing that today quite frankly in our Vehicle business if you take a look at how they performed in 2014 and our guidance in 2015.

So that's essentially what we're going to try to take you through and what we're going to try to do in our presentations is anticipate mainly the questions that you have written about and that we think you have about our business. But first just a quick level set, if you will. As a power management company, as Sandy talked about, we are on the side of fluid and mechanical power. But if you step back from that, the way to think about our business is that really we do tough stuff. We take on difficult tasks that need to be safe and that need to be reliable and that is really one of the key themes that really cuts through all of our businesses both on the industrial side and certainly on the electrical side as well.

If you think about our Hydraulics business in an application like a wind turbine, for example, where we are doing the control of the blades, pitch control and directional control, 300 feet in the air, 24 hours a day, 7 days a week and it absolutely needs to be reliable. If you look at our Vehicle business, certainly a key supplier to the transportation industry, but I would tell you more than that, we make engineer management products and inside of the engine, our valves see temperatures that exceed 700 degrees Fahrenheit and millions of cycles and have to be reliable and can't fail.

Many of you have been on the road behind one of these big Class 8 trucks, probably a little frustrated. We like those things. But these trucks, we actually warrantee them for about 750,000 miles. By the way, and there is no maintenance required. They have to be reliable. And to say that our Aerospace business is mission-critical maybe is a little bit of an understatement, but on everything that flies, our hydraulic systems and our fuel systems are essentially there through takeoff, cruise at landing and absolutely have to be safe and have to be reliable.

Anybody ever been on a plane that was delayed due to a mechanical? Probably most of us. So dispatch reliability is obviously one of the keys in that industry and certainly if you think about what makes our Company unique, it is in fact that we bring value, we bring unique technology to all of these big challenges.

And we do think there's some tailwinds that we have if you think about some of the big megatrends that will help our businesses. But we will in fact see different patterns in 2015 and have different expectations for our businesses during the course of the year. We will have a year in 2015 where Vehicle will be strong again. Aerospace will see modest growth and we'll have some challenges in Hydraulics and we will talk about that. So we don't expect all of these businesses to perform consistently in the same, but the balance that they bring to the Company through the cycle is in fact one of the key strengths of this portfolio.

Sandy talked about our formula for creating value and our formula for creating value really hasn't changed. It really is centered on these three things. It's about being in the right markets not only as a company but within each of our businesses. We consistently look at our portfolio and make sure that within the segments that we serve that we are focused on those aspects and segments and applications that are growing faster. And we are investing to outgrowth, we're making tough trade-offs and differentiated decisions around the portfolio and where we invest, which markets, which applications, which regions of the world.

And we are focused on running the business better. And in this period of slow growth, perhaps the most important thing that we can do is in this area of self-help, the things that we are doing, things that are inside of our control, things that we have today in our hand that we can do to grow revenue, to improve earnings, all built on the back of the Eaton Business System, the standard system that we use for running each of our businesses and running each of our functions and the way we create value inside of our organization.

But maybe just a couple more slides to talk about the Eaton Business System and how we apply it inside of our business. And I do think you can think about the Eaton Business System really as Eaton's self-help story. The things that we can do that are in our control that allow us to both improve the efficiency, the way we run our Company and to help us grow. And we think about it typically in these three buckets. It's about costs and improving efficiency for sure. It's about operational excellence. It's also about functional excellence and it's about the way we work with customers and getting more out of our existing relationships.

Now inside of these three buckets, I'll drop you down just to one particular example in one of our manufacturing plants to give you a sense for the way it works. Every one of our manufacturing plants are essentially run the same way. We have a common set of measures, a common set of tools, a common set of processes and essentially a common set of goals for each of our businesses. All of this built on a culture and a foundation of continuous improvement, something that we expect every one of our facilities to do day in and day out. And we have at least five key metrics in every plant and it's about safety and quality and on-time delivery and getting costs out for our customers and quality. And every one of our facilities is actually benchmarked against what does world-class look like, what does best in breed look like. And so every facility that you would go to would actually have a benchmark that says here is where you are performing today, here is what best-in-class looks like and that is the goal, to get every one of our facilities to perform as good as the best of our facilities.

And we're certainly proud of the fact that we had 14 sites in 2014 make world-class metrics in the industrial sector and a number of others on the electrical side, but we are even more excited about the opportunity that it represents for our Company. If we can simply get each of our facilities to perform as good as our best facilities, the amount of self-help, the amount of value that we can create for our Company and for shareholders is tremendous. And I just cited one small example here in quality, the cost of quality. We are not perfect today. We are good, but we are not perfect. But by simply getting each of our facilities on the industrial sector to perform as good as our better facilities, not perfect, we unlock at least a $60 million opportunity to improve margin. So it is self-help. It's the Eaton Business System. It's the things that we can do to control our own destiny.

Now it's also about the way we run our Company. It's about the things that we do to improve efficiency in our plants, in our support functions and it's also about the things that we have to do from time to time to reset our business based upon changes in our market. And you certainly saw in the course of 2014 we took some restructuring actions. And in hindsight, we are pleased that we did. We made the right early call that we were going to, in fact, see some challenges in a number of our end markets and so we will deliver the $35 million of benefits that we promised in 2014 based upon the restructuring actions that we took.

But we have to do more. I specifically have to do more and it probably doesn't come as a surprise to anyone here that it will in fact be centered in the Hydraulics business. If you take a look at what is happening in some of their big end markets, whether it is global ag, whether it is mining, whether it is China construction or recently oil and gas, clearly, we have to do some work to reset that business in terms of the current realities that we are dealing with in our marketplace. And so we will be taking some charges in the first half of this year. A lot of that will be centered and as Rick indicated in the first quarter, but the good news is there will be about 70 basis points of margin improvement that will roll into 2016. So even at these very low levels of economic activity and really in some cases awful end markets, our margins will expand by order of magnitude of 70 basis points in 2016 in Hydraulics with no lift in revenue.

So let's move directly into Hydraulics. And I won't spend a lot of time on this chart; I think you can read it. It's pretty much self-explanatory. But I will say maybe as a way of thinking about the business, we see our Hydraulics business today as a good business. It's a good business today dealing with some pretty awful markets, but recognizing that, we understand also that there are elements of this business that are volatile. And I'll talk about in a subsequent slide, we think about 30% of the business tends to serve volatile markets.

So we have to be proactive. We have to deal with the element of volatility and flexing our business, but we also have to grow the piece of the business that is not volatile and about 70% of the business is in a category that we call stable. So we are focused on doing the things that we know we need to do to restructure the business where needed, to grow the stable side of the business and to make sure that we are doing the things that are in the category of self-help to essentially make this a business that we can continue to be very proud of.

Many of you probably are thinking about this business also in the context of the Great Recession and you'll recall I used this same exact chart last year. And so what happened in the Hydraulics business, if you go back to the Great Recession, essentially all of the end markets basically fell at the same time and markets fell quite hard. And in hindsight, we saw a very steep V-shaped recovery and probably markets came back too fast. A lot of that was driven by stimulus spending around the world and in the US, but principally in places like China and China was the engine really that drove a lot of markets around the world.

On top of that, you clearly had commodity prices and mining that was on a ramp and it eventually fell over. You saw a super cycle in ag essentially crack during the course of 2014 and that market fell. And so without a doubt, we are dealing with, in this piece of the Hydraulics business, some really challenging market dynamics. But I will tell you that as we think about this business and where we are at this point in the cycle, we think a lot of the bad news around this volatile piece of the business is in fact behind us and as we look forward, we are not sure exactly when it is going to turn. It could be 2016, it could be into 2017, but clearly these markets are either at or approaching the bottom of the cycle and we think long term it continues to be an industry that grows at about 3% a year.

And so once again, a way to think about the business, it's a large market and in fact, there is a piece of the market that is volatile. And we think it's about 3% of the portfolio that is in fact exposed to large ag, China construction, a piece of oil and gas and that piece of the business is volatile. But I don't want to lose sight either of the other 70% of the business that is not volatile. It's a very big piece of this business whether it is material handling, it's industrial markets, it's stationary applications, it's a very big piece of aftermarket that is not volatile. And so we're going to be busy focusing on what we can do to grow naturally in this 70% of the business that is in fact more predictable and more stable. So it's really this 70% and the things that we're doing in the area of self-help that give us the confidence to say that we think this business, despite the headlines and what is going on in some of these markets, will essentially be anywhere from flat to down 2% during the course of 2015.

Now before we leave these volatile markets, I don't want to lose sight of the fact either that there is good news coming. Here are just three markets that we have modeled to give you a sense for where they are at today versus their peak. And as I noted, they may be at bottom today. If they are not at bottom, they are certainly approaching the bottom of the market and at some point these markets will turn. And they are likely not going to all turn at the same time, but when they do turn, there is significant revenue growth and earnings growth that will help power the top line and the bottom line of Hydraulics business. So you really are in fact approaching the bottom of a lot of these key markets and that is essentially good news as we look out into 2016 and 2017 inside of this business.

So as we think about our Hydraulics business, maybe the way to think about it is that, yes, we recognize the fact that there is a piece of the business that is volatile. It is some 30% of the business. But we are taking the steps that we need to take to essentially fix the business and ensure that we can operate effectively through these economic cycles, through these downturns and it's really a three-point strategy. It's about really growing the 70% of the business that is in fact stable. It's about improving the product mix and it's about taking the steps that we took last year and we will continue to take this year around getting the cost base right in the business.

And so here is the way we think about the business and think you should. At this point in the cycle, which we think is close to the bottom, it will be about a 13% to 14% business. At the midpoint in the cycle, we think that's roughly 15% to 16% and at the peak of the cycle, it is roughly 17% plus. And so we think a business that will continue to be a key contributor to Eaton's ability to grow earnings through the economic cycle.

One of the things that we are doing, we talked about growing the 70% is in fact focusing on one of the key markets here, which we call machinery OEMs and it is something that Sandy referenced in his presentation as well. Today, the hydraulics market is about a $40 billion global market, $15 billion of which is in what we call stationary equipment. $4 billion of that is in this segment, what we call machine-builders where we sell into the OEM market. This is a market that requires a lot of hydraulic equipment. It's a market that we serve today. Hydraulic pumps and motors and valves and fluid conveyance products, it's an important hydraulic market.

What's also unique about this market, it's also a market today that we are also serving on the electrical side of our business. And so we have a really unique capability. We are the only company who has the ability under one roof to bring both hydraulic and electrical solutions to these types of applications. And here is one small example here. As Sandy mentioned, the electrical variable speed drives that we have developed. So what we are doing here is we are taking all of our hydraulic equipment, we are marrying it up with an electric motor and a variable speed drive in our electrical business and we now have the ability to go to market and offer something that nobody else has and deliver a solution that is 70% more energy-efficient than other applications available in the marketplace. So a really unique opportunity that we have based upon our core strengths in Hydraulics and partnering with our electrical businesses to grow the stable 70% of the business in a really important market.

The other piece of growing the 70% is really a more keen focus on aftermarket. Aftermarket today is a large market. It's about a $12 billion market. It's very predictable. It grows at about 3% a year. We have an enormous installed base of equipment, some $18 billion of equipment out there with our Hydraulics components on it and it is a profitable business. It accounts for about a third of our revenue today and so we will continue to focus on growing our aftermarket, expanding our points of distribution. A lot of initiatives there in the US and around the world, building unique service capabilities and in many ways also localizing capabilities so that we can serve aftermarket opportunities around the world. So we think there's an opportunity here and we have good line of sight to actually growing the aftermarket business inside of our portfolio at a compounded rate of about 5% a year.

So in summary, I would tell you that the Hydraulics business today, we understand the business. We have been in it for a long time and we understand the uniqueness of the piece of the business that is volatile and we know how to manage and flex our business to deal with those ups and downs. We will in fact continue to focus on growing the stable 70% with new technology and new products and applications and most importantly we will continue to drive our self-help story around running our businesses better.

So, as you saw in the guidance, clearly it's a business where the margins will be down slightly in 2015 principally due to the restructuring charges that we are going to take and as Rick noted, we will take most of those restructuring charges in the first half of the year with a bigger concentration in Q1. So a way to think about the business is the first-half margins will be anywhere from 10.5% to 12.5% and then the second half anywhere from 13% to 13.6%.

So if we can just turn to Vehicle for a second, this is a business once again that I think this group knows well. It is a really strong franchise that is well-positioned in both automotive and truck markets. It's a business that today really wins due to technology, wins due to the fact that it is in fact a highly regulated market and so if it's about fuel economy or it's about emissions, if it's about safety, it really does play to the sweet spot of our Vehicle business.

And here too we say we're in the right markets and certainly at this point in the cycle being in a short cycle Vehicle business is in fact the right market and I won't cover these numbers here because Rick already covered a number of them, but certainly we look at North America truck to be a strong market again this year that global automotive markets around the world continue to be strong and Europe is actually on the positive side. So a really good set of markets that we are exposed to here in Vehicle and as a result, we think we are confident that our business will grow some 5% to 7% a year.

The other thing I talked about is the fact that this is a business that wins with new regulations. And if you take a look at what you see on this chart here, some of the more high-profile examples of regulation and it tends to be around fuel economy and reduced emissions, it's around safety, you see what is going to happen is they put fuel economy standards in for heavy-duty trucks, the piece on the automotive market is well known to this group. So when you see new regulations and requirements around the world, it is always a good thing for our Vehicle business because it does in fact play to the unique advantages of our technology.

One small example here in China in what we call here this on road vapor recovery system. In the US, for some time now, when you actually fill up your car, you've actually had to recover the fuel vapor that would be lost and would go into the atmosphere. China did not have a similar requirement, but in the course of 2014, they have adopted the US requirement and that is a great thing for Eaton because we have the leading technology in the US, we have the number one share position in the US and now overnight what opens up due to regulations is a $135 million market opportunity for us in the China market. So once again regulations driving opportunities for us to grow our Vehicle business.

The other big market for us is obviously NAFTA and specifically what is happening today in the area of automation. The heavy-duty truck market is rapidly converting to automation and it's driven by a lot of factors, including in some cases better fuel economy, in some cases safety, in many cases quite frankly, driver availability and automated transmissions that's simply easier to drive. But also we will acknowledge here that some of this shift is also being driven by vertical integration that many of you are aware of and have written about that is taking place in the North America Class 8 market.

As the market moves from manual to automation, yes, there comes some risk, but, yes, there also comes some opportunities and the big opportunity for us is the fact that an automated transmission actually sells for 40% to 50% more than a manual transmission. So as this market moves and we think the market moved about 8 points during the course of 2014, there is an element of this that is good for Eaton.

But the way to think about perhaps this whole vertical integration threat that we are dealing with in North America is that, yes, we probably on unit volume will give up some share to some of the vertically integrated OEMs, but offsetting that are a lot of positives, one of which is in fact the fact that an AMT is a good thing for us because we sell it at a much higher price and a number of the other initiatives that I'm going to talk about in subsequent slides.

Transmissions, it's a big market today. It's a $12 billion market. It's growing by 3% a year and we are not sitting still. We've done a lot of work over the last couple years to refresh our entire productline. Our heavy-duty transmission line has been essentially redone both in manual transmissions and in automated transmissions to the point that they are lighter weight now, they are delivering better fuel economy.

Many of you have read and seen articles on our Smart Advantage Transmission in partnership with Cummins and we'll talk about that, but perhaps most excitingly and Sandy mentioned this in his presentation is what is going on in the medium-duty space. This new transmission that uses our proprietary dual clutch technology and what that means in simple terms is you get the same driving experience that you would in driving your family car with an automatic transmission with the fuel economy advantages that you would get with a manual. And it is because we have this proprietary technology, we call it dual clutch, we call it Procision, that gives us an opportunity to enter a market that historically we have not played in. So we think this is about a $120 million revenue opportunity at maturity and one of the key things that we're going to do to continue to grow our North America truck business despite some of the pressures that we are seeing in other areas.

The other thing is what we are doing in the area of alliances. Many of you are probably aware if you follow the Company over the years is that we have had a long-standing joint venture with a company called Nittan Valve out of Japan and this particular joint venture essentially pursues the Japanese and Korean transplants around the world and it has been tremendously successful. This business has more than doubled over the last five years.

During the course of 2014, we also signed a joint venture, a clutch joint venture with the largest transmission manufacturer in China. We have the clutch product. We have the technology. They have the market. And so it's a unique venture that will allow us to penetrate the Chinese market in the space of clutches. And then our alliance with Cummins, and we have been working with Cummins now for many years, but the example that you see here is what we called Smart Advantage. It is basically taking a Cummins engine, putting an Eaton transmission behind it, but it's an optimized drivetrain and we belief that the Cummins/Eaton combination is as good as any drivetrain in the market. And as you can see here delivering anywhere from 3% to 6% improvement in fuel economy over other alternatives.

And I don't want to leave the stage without at least saying a word or two about our automotive business. It's clearly the leader in engineer management and has been for a long time. It's certainly a business that continues to benefit from regulations, continues to benefit as our customers try to deliver better fuel economy to reduce emissions and the way I would think about this business really is in really three technology buckets. It's what we are doing in the area of valves. And as the industry downsizes engines, downspeeds engines and engines run hotter, in comes a technology called hollow valves, and hollow valve is important for us because it's a valve that sells at a much higher selling price than a standard valve.

Or you move to variable valve actuation, varying the lift of the ignition event inside of an engine and once again we have technology that delivers fuel economy and reduced emissions or some of the newer solutions in cylinder deactivation where you basically take a six-cylinder engine car and you turn it into a four cylinder at various points in the driving process. So you've got a six cylinder where you need the power and it turns it into a four cylinder at cruise when you don't need the power. And in every case delivering improvements in fuel economy, reduction in emissions and quite frankly significant growth opportunities for our business.

And lastly, in Vehicle, something we don't spend a lot of time talking about is aftermarket. Today, we have a fairly sizable aftermarket business inside of our Vehicle business. It's about 15% of the total business today. We have an enormous installed base, more than 4.7 million vehicles out there on the road today and so we are working hard to grow this piece of our business. We're putting ignitions in place to really capture a secondary market with fleets, with developing channel programs, unique products to serve the aftermarket and so we think as well aftermarket is an important piece of what we're doing to continue to grow the business to control our own destiny and offset some of the headwinds that we face.

So I think we would stop here and say that our Vehicle business is a strong business. It's without a doubt a leader in its respective industries. We have great technology and quite frankly, we have a bit of a tailwind. Fuel economy, emissions, regulations are all very important elements of what drive our business and we have the technology to answer those challenges.

We are not resting on our laurels. We recognize hereto there's a lot of opportunities that we have internally to run the business better and control our own destiny. But I think you will agree with me when I say that the Vehicle business today is delivering. In fact, when we were here last year, we talked about the business getting to 17% return on sales. As you can see this year, the midpoint of our guidance is already in excess of 17%, so the business is in fact doing exactly what we expect it to do inside of our portfolio as a short cycle business at this point in the cycle.

So I'm going to stop here and I'm going to turn it over to Uday Yadav, who is going to take you through Aerospace and then I will come back later for the wrapup and the Q&A. Thank you.

UDAY YADAV, PRESIDENT, AEROSPACE GROUP, EATON CORPORATIONPLC: Good morning. There are three main messages I want to share with you today about our Aerospace business. First, we are a strong dynamic enterprise within a growth industry, an industry whose actual advanced technology needs are right in our sweet spot of improving fuel efficiency and power consumption.

Second, there is a convergence of powerful forces. We are winning increased content on next-generation platforms. We are profiting from the rate increases on legacy platforms and we are gaining in the aftermarket. And these forces have combined to create a robust organic growth engine for the future.

And third, we are constantly focused on running the business better and we leverage the Eaton Business System to improve productivity and drive margin expansion. So the Aerospace business in 2014 closed with all-time high revenues of $1.9 billion. And just to give you some context, that's about 26% higher than the 2010 recession low. Our business mix is commercial 65% and military 35% with OE and aftermarket being very similar. But as you can see, the single largest segment is commercial OEM, three-quarters of which is large jet transport, which is very much representative of the broader market.

And aerospace is a very attractive market on a number of dimensions. It provides steady and exciting future growth I'm actually going to expand upon later. It's a long cycle industry where you make major upfront investments that generate really rewarding revenue streams for 25 to 40 years, including a profitable aftermarket. And we have a great technology position that because of large customer investment and certification requirements often leads to sole sourcing. And when you are an incumbent on an existing platform and you are performing, customers really value that pedigree for the future.

So in 2015, we will be operating in an $11 billion global market and we expect the weighted average of those markets to increase with strong growth in commercial OEM driven by new large transport new launches and rate increases with commercial aftermarket also being up. This is offset though by declines in military due to lower defense spending. Now our own organic growth in 2015 will be in the 2% to 4% range.

If I can pivot for a minute though and look out five years and frankly beyond, Aerospace really does provide very steady growth. In the next 15 years, air traffic is going to double due to the expanding global middle class. So for example, in China, the number of trips per capita per year is 0.3. That is going to triple in the coming years. So this factor and many other factors are going to lead to the introduction of thousands of new aircraft in the coming years. Our own growth over the next four to five years is going to be a very healthy 6% compound annual growth rate.

Now our customers are also demanding new forms of technology adoption. They are favoring incremental innovation on existing platforms versus brand-new designs. So what does this do? It shortens the product lifecycle and it creates growth opportunities for companies like ours. So we are in the right markets at the right time with the right portfolio. And as you can see, we participate in four systems on the aircraft and all of these systems are focused on addressing two very critical customer needs -- conserving fuel when you don't need it and using the right amount of power when you do.

So hydraulic systems on the top left, our industry-leading products generate and distribute power to enable really critical functions on the aircraft, so the lowering and the retraction of landing gear, the movement of wings and the tail to allow the plane to move, the delivery of emergency power when engine power is not available. On the top right, motion control systems. We deliver the steering that allows the plane to taxi on the runway or to stabilize the wings when they are in flight or slow the plane as it approaches landing.

Fuel management systems, so a typical large commercial jet will carry 30,000 gallons of fuel. We design systems that manage the flow of that fuel to the engine and around the aircraft ensuring at all times there is balance, it is done efficiently and of course safely. And then finally on the bottom right, engine solutions, which is where a lot of innovation is taking place on the engine. We support the engine through our main fuel engine pump. We protect the engine with our oil debris monitoring systems and we connect the engine with other systems on the aircraft through our engine buildup unit. And it is this very strong portfolio that has allowed us to win and grow on the next generation of platforms across almost every single market segment.

And as you can see on this chart, this ranges from anything from 2 times up to 8 times the content versus previous platforms. For the six examples shown here, they represent about $6.5 billion life-of-program revenue. Three of these planes are actually flying today. Two have entered service and two are getting ready for first flight. The first two examples, military rotocraft, the C853K is a next-generation heavy lift helicopter from the Marines. We are providing the complete hydraulic system, the complete fuel system and the chip detection system for 7 times the content of the previous platform.

In commercial transport, the recently introduced fuel-efficient long-range 787 that you are all probably familiar with, we've increased our content by a factor of 4 due to our fuel systems and engine solutions. So all of these wins are at different points of development where they clearly translate into real revenue gains for the future. In fact, if you look at the nine new OE wins on this chart that are evenly balanced by the way between commercial and military, and as you can see are at different points in the product lifecycle, they all combine over the next four years to deliver $170 million of incremental sales by 2018. The A350 and the F35 will deliver 70% of that revenue. Both are flying today and annual volumes are expected to triple in 2018 versus the 2015 base.

Now a large portion of our revenue is derived from our position on legacy platforms. These legacy platforms are very high volume. And because of the growth I described earlier, we expect to have a net gain due to the production rate increases and us winning additional content. More specifically, more specifically, the growth is actually fueled by the large commercial single aisle and these are planes you will typically fly on from coast to coast domestically. And we have one due to additional content. In fact, we have won 20% and 10% more additional content on the 737 Max and the A320 Neo and then we also benefit from the 787 rate increases. These will be offset by OE military declines. All in all though, our legacy OE will grow at about 3.5% compound annual growth rate and deliver $115 million of incremental sales in 2018.

Aftermarket, aftermarket represents -- we'll be very aggressive in the aftermarket. We expect to grow at a 7% compound annual growth rate, almost twice the market. And this is from the actions that we have been taking, very aggressive actions in the commercial and military segments of the aftermarket. These actions include improving our operational performance by reducing repair turnaround times, focusing and reinforcing our dedicated aftermarket organization, of course, capturing our entitlement and then driving modern upgrades on our products. And we believe these combined actions will come together to deliver $120 million of outgrowth by 2018.

So big pictures on outgrowth, we expect to deliver slightly north of $400 million of incremental revenue growing at 6% compounded annual growth rate by 2018 with 60% of that growth coming from the OEM side of our business and 40% coming from the aftermarket.

Turning to technology, if I may and why we are winning. Just in the last two years, we have generated $3 billion life-of-program wins across our entire product portfolio and with balanced wins across multiple market segments. So we will be delivering unprecedented levels of high pressure fuel flow from our fuel engine pumps to the engine to help improve engine efficiency. We are optimizing the weight on the engine buildup units that connect the engine with other systems on the aircraft. We are bringing a higher reliability hydraulic equipment to the next reengine regional jets and we are supporting and providing increased refueling flow for the next generation military tanker. And then a few months ago, we won the fuel and inerting on the regional turboprop.

Turning to a quick case study, if I may, and why our technology is allowing us to win in the $5 billion commercial OE market. On the right-hand side, you see an example of how a seemingly simple component -- sorry -- how innovation apply to a seemingly simple component can dramatically improve uptime by a factor of 4 on emission-critical jet engine. So sitting there for a minute, if you can imagine a large jet engine with a main shaft running through and connecting the five main modules of the engine that generate power for the aircraft, each of which has bearings that allow the shaft to rotate.

Now traditionally the bearings on the shaft in the module have seals that contain fluid where they physically touch each other. This causes wear, friction, wear and eventual replacement after 10,000 hours. Now our hydrodynamically designed seals uniquely create an air barrier between these two seals, eliminating physical contact and therefore increasing life. And as you can imagine, that creates tremendous value for our customers. They have greater uptime, lower maintenance costs and obviously we can command a premium for that product.

Moving to the military market where our innovative technology has allowed us to win on the next-generation tanker and the next-generation transportation claims. So if you can imagine for a minute the KC-46A, which is the US Air Force's next-generation tanker, flying at altitudes up to 40,000 feet at speeds of up to 500 miles an hour, simultaneously by the way refueling another plane, doing it very, very quickly and of course safely in a highly variable environment up there, that's where our technology comes in.

And just to give you some context of what that means, in a typical jet engine, fuel flows to the engine at about 25 gallons per minute. When you are refueling in the air, that increases by a factor of 50 to 1200 gallons per minute. Big numbers. And that is where our technology really comes in. So our uniquely designed, high-capacity pump and redesigned boom refueling nozzles are going to improve the fuel flow on this platform by 10% to 30% versus the prior platform and improve life of the pump by about 30%. And as you can imagine for our customers, end customers, that creates tremendous value. And so here are a couple of examples around our technology, where we have won in the past, where we are investing today and why we will continue to drive to win in the future around this technology investment.

Craig talked a little bit earlier around how each of the groups is focused on running the business better by leveraging the Eaton Business System. Within the Aerospace group, we have aggressive plans to improve our overall cost structure through optimizing our manufacturing footprint and transitioning product to best cost countries. In this example from Tijuana, Mexico, which is one of our model plants, over the next five years, we will be doubling our sales or doubling our output from this plant and obviously expanding the factory, helping to improve our overall cost structure and obviously asset utilization.

Another example, this time from Batam, Indonesia, which is one of the world-class manufacturing sites of the 14 that Craig referenced earlier in his presentation, here we are deploying, as Craig described earlier, the continuous improvement framework across all of our factories, including this one in Batam. Then our local team took four very complex productlines, did a lot of work to simplify those lines into one continuous flow for mixed model assembly that resulted in the results that you see, improvements in manufacturing leadtime, improvement in inventory days and most importantly, improvements in productivity.

So why am I sharing this one example with you? It's because, as Craig shared earlier, we are doing and driving this every day in every factory across all of the Aerospace plants and over time this is going to result in us increasing our margins and we see a direct link between improving our manufacturing performance, improving our productivity and expanding our margin. A lot of work to do in the aerospace industry and specifically in our business.

So we believe the Aerospace business is positioned very well for profitable growth. We are clearly in the right market and a very exciting time of growth for our industry. We have a strong presence on platforms, on many platforms, platforms that will definitely be growing in the future. We have invested for outgrowth and I think you have seen evidence of that in our new OEM wins and our gains in the aftermarket. And we are absolutely relentlessly focused on execution, on running our business better by leveraging the Eaton Business System.

So in 2015, we expect our operating margins to be in the 15.1% to 15.7% range, a rise of 40 to 100 basis points from our 2014 performance. With that, I'd like to thank you and hand back to Craig to help summarize for the sector.

CRAIG ARNOLD: Thanks, Uday.
