TOM GROSS, VICE CHAIRMAN & COO, ELECTRICAL SECTOR, EATON CORPORATIONPLC: Okay, well, please grab a seat. Good morning. It's my pleasure to take you through the next -- kick off actually four presentations that will take you through an update on the Electrical Sector.

Let me just start by saying the obvious: we're in a terrific business because of what's written on the upper left of this slide, these megatrends, and I suspect they are playing out across the electrical industry. I can say for certain they are playing out in an accelerated fashion in the markets that we serve, on the bottom right of this.

We are in a really good position to provide answers to those four megatrends. We've used to this chart before to summarize our capabilities into seven core competencies. And the secret to understanding the power of that portfolio is the fact that each one of the target segments on the bottom, typically one of those seven is a lot more important than the other six; and yet every one of them buys at least four or five of the seven; and some of those segments buy all seven.

So that's really a secret to understanding the portfolio and, frankly, the secret to understanding the basic nature of the sales synergies that we talk so much about with Cooper, because three of the seven came to us to via the Cooper acquisition; four were traditional Eaton. You can see that in a little more detail here: as I said, at least four, but typically five or more are required. These technology platforms really are important to each and every one of our segments.

One of the important aspects of this chart, however, is the fact that it's not just about having stuff, whether it's from us directly or through our channel; it's really about application and industry relevance. So one of the big things we took on and accomplished -- globally, by the way -- through 2013 and 2014, is we changed, frankly, a large number of independent salesforces that were chartered to sell horizontally. In other words, they were behind one of these technologies; so they were the power distribution salesforce, or the power quality salesforce, or the fusing and disconnect salesforce. We took all of those and we flipped them vertically.

That was a big change, and what we were trying to accomplish, obviously, was to unlock application and industry relevance. Because you cannot possibly be an industry expert across five or six segments and hundreds of thousands of products.

So we made it simple for them. They are jerseyed on one of these and they're now in a position to know what to lead with and then how to pull through the other four, five, or six technologies that would go too.

So we're very excited about that change. We think that's a five or more year transition. It's paying off already, but it's going to have legs to really fuel unleashing the power of that portfolio.

We have a very good scale today both geographically. You can see we're approaching 50-50 US and non-US revenues.

Probably more important, look at the industry segment diversity that we have today. For those of you who have followed us a long time you know that you don't have to go back very far to remember that the left side of this was mostly orange and the right side of this was mostly blue. In fact the right side of this, there wasn't even a green not that long ago; and the red, the utility, was so small you could barely read it.

So we've diversified our end market mix. That's led to better balance; it's led to better solution content and, again, just greater relevance to those segments and the applications within them.

So we are quite happy with that. A ways to go yet, obviously, geographically, because the market is really a third, a third, a third when you think about Europe, APAC, and Americas. So we have some more work to do, but we are pleased with the progress.

Let's jump into the two reporting segments, products first. This is a very attractive $7.3 billion segment, we think today with the scale to compete globally.

On the left, in case you're not familiar with what all rolls up into this segment, you can see the big capabilities. These are actually big business units within Electrical Sector that roll up into the Products reporting segment.

Our growth drivers are many. I've captured a few here, but the big ones for us are the conversion to LED technology and what used to be called the Cooper lighting business.

And you'll see later today that's just the start of it. There's an awful lot more technology and a technology play that's going to go into lighting and lighting control that we think we're advantaged towards. That's driving a lot of growth.

Our new relevance in distribution channels is really terrific. We're going to go into some detail.

We're going to show you the North American example of that here in a few minutes. It's just an example of greater distribution relevance around the world.

And if, let's say in the past, we might have been number six at a distributor, and Cooper might have been six or seven, or five or six, together we're typically now number three or four at the distributors. And that's interesting because wiring is always number one, right, and we sell a lot of wire.

So we're typically number one, two, or three in terms of our revenues as a percentage of the channel. So we're a lot more relevant; that's driving some very interesting growth for us.

I'd also want to highlight the smaller end of our power quality market. We have today arguably the best single-phase product lineup in the world, and we are driving market share gains year in and year out. That's been a good source of growth for us and, of course, just leveraging our total portfolio, as I mentioned.

So as you can see in 2014, a very handsome business at 17.2%. We think 2015 that expands to somewhere in the mid-17%s to low 18%s.

A quick look at Systems and Service, a $6.5 billion segment for us in 2014. High-value systems and services across all aspects of the value chain. Big capabilities; on the left here you can see is where we put all of our services as well.

Growth drivers for us. We're, without question, the leader in safety in terms of electrical systems.

Arc flash is an Eaton heritage; and explosionproof is definitely a Cooper heritage. We put that together and we market ourselves now as the provider of the safest electrical solutions. And that applies to all of our segments because arcs and explosions obviously are catastrophic events, and we're in a position to eliminate them.

Our energy-efficient UPS strategy and our products continue to resonate with data center owners and operators everywhere. It's a great example of when we win there we pull through just a juggernaut of other equipment.

IEC assemblies. Sandy had mentioned we are in the fifth year of deployment of capabilities that we just have very terrific share and capabilities in, in North America. We've wrapped to that into assemblies and systems that meet global standards, and we're in the fifth year of executing a growth strategy in those IEC markets.

Then finally a way to think about growth and margin in Systems and Services is you have to have the capabilities, and you have to have the ability to engineer to order and the manufacturing facilities that can build flexible systems. But to a large degree, growth and margin is driven by your ability to manage projects on behalf of your customers and hook services, value-add services, during the project. And we think we're very good at that.

Margins in Systems and Services, 13.8% in 2014. We believe that expands to mid-14%s to low 15% in 2015.

Sandy mentioned we are on track to deliver the Cooper integration savings, a $150 million step-up in 2015. The integration finishes in 2015, and that allows us to essentially capture the full-year effect of all of the projects in 2016. And that adds another incremental $115 million of profit.

I thought I'd go back to the format we've used a couple times now. I hope you're not getting tired of it, but it's a good way to give you an update.

We are meeting our upwardly revised sales synergy targets. We have always broken these into these four buckets.

And let me start with the second because that's -- larger package to common customers is basically what I just talked about, where we have the seven key capabilities. Figure out what's important and then sell the rest, so don't stop after we get one of the seven. And then a channel program that aligns with that and takes -- allows us to capture the increased relevance and allow distributors to opt into a bigger Eaton package to go along with that.

When we look at 2016, by the way, we think about 75% of the sales synergies will come from the first two. The other two are very important, though.

We had identified that former Cooper did not have a service business, yet they have a lot of business units that services are required. So we wanted to provide those services on top of their solutions.

Then the fourth one was geographic expansion, not broadly speaking but limited to certain countries where we were both real small fries. We thought if we put them together, we're a little more relevant and we can get higher growth rates.

We view those two as about 25% of the total. Now that's probably a little more lopsided than we've explained it in the past, and a way to think about it is that the first two tend to happen quicker, and the last two tend to take a little more time. Because it's hard to build a service business that's profitable, and it's a little bit harder to be in countries where your brands aren't recognized.

So this is a 2016 view. We think over time that we probably go back to the balance that we explained before, which was closer to 65/35. So we think the right will -- all four will continue to play out after the acquisition, with a little bit more emphasis on the right.

We are also meeting our revised cost targets. We had identified these five areas, and you can see our view of where we are as of January 1 of this year in terms of complete.

Let me start on the right. 100% done with all the corporate integration tasks. The second one was really the SG&A part of the savings, where we have integrated certain similar groups and taken advantage of Eaton's investments in shared service centers.

We're about 90% complete there, with some follow-on project still remaining in Europe. Just takes a little longer, given the works councils, to get through some of that. But largely complete there.

Supply chain, a big source of P&L benefit. We're about 70% complete. We're higher than that if you look at the original list of projects we had; but as we have gone through this integration we keep finding new projects, so we've got about 30% more economic value to capture there.

EBS: a good story. The Cooper facilities fully absorbing Eaton Lean system, Eaton quality system, production planning, processes, and the like. I would say with pretty high degree of confidence if you walked into a former Cooper plant or an Eaton plant, you couldn't tell the difference today. But there's still probably 30% economic value to capture up against the goal we had set.

Finally, plant and distribution center, about 60% done with the projects.

So just as a summary and then I'll let the next three presenters come up, we really think we're in a great position for our current reality in 2015 and beyond. Just a terrific portfolio of brands. We use the term anchor brands; these mean a lot to our customer and our channel: Crouse-Hinds, Cutler-Hammer, Moeller, Phoenixtec, and so on.

Growing strength in the channel; an array of customer and application experts and increased relevance due to the unlocking of that salesforce; leading positions in some key markets such as data centers, lighting, and key industrials. Just a terrific broad basket of solutions, and an ability to continue to innovate.

The next three presenters are going to cover these highlights in blue. Sandy had showed you the agenda, so I'm going to pass the podium over to Revathi Advaithi, our regional President of Americas, who's going to give you a good summary of the channel. And by the way, all four of us will be up here at the end to answer any of your questions, okay? Thanks.

REVATHI ADVAITHI, PRESIDENT, AMERICAS REGION, ELECTRICAL, EATON CORPORATIONPLC: Thank you. Good morning. My role here today is to connect the dots with what Tom had talked about, which is a significant portion of the Cooper sales synergy came from channel and the package to common customers, and how did we get that sales synergy, and how are we positioned in the future with that sales synergy.

Now, most of you know the story well. The electrical value chain is a complex one. Everybody who buys power is our customer, and we get to touch all of them in some shape or form, so we have to be well positioned to take this from an individual consumer who's in a residence all the way to a large industrial customer of some kind.

And we do this extremely well. Our salesforce, which I will talk about later, is really positioned very well to do this.

A good example would be to talk about this with a project that we recently won, and this is here in your neck of the woods, in the Tappan Zee project that was announced, the reconstruction of that project here across the Hudson. In a project like that, typically you would start a project like that with a consulting engineer of some kind, a company that is basically designing how the rebuild is going to happen.

Our Eaton application engineer would work with the consulting engineer to help design that project and bring in the utility expertise and the local expertise that the application engineer has. So that puts Eaton in a really good specification advantage when you start a project like that.

And then as you move through the phases, you get to the general contractor phase, where there will be a general contractor. The Eaton sales engineer at that point in time will be working with the general contractor to make sure that plant schedules are lined up; that any changes in the design are going through the plant, and that is well positioned.

Then it goes to an electrical contractor, where our distributor sales specialist will work with a local distributor to take that project and make sure inventory is positioned, project management is well positioned. And then on the completion of the project, then we'll go to the end-user and our service team will work with the owner/operator to make sure there's lifecycle support through that whole project.

So a typical project -- you can do this in a grand scale or you can do this for a $50,000 project -- but it has at least four to five touch points across this project. What Eaton does extremely well is position ourselves across all these touch points.

So we are very good at creating pull with our customers. We know how to do that extremely well. What this helps do for our partners and our distributors is then they push our product and position our product in the marketplace.

Most of my talk today is about distributors and how Eaton positions ourselves with distributors. You know this well. You know distributors are important because the Electrical franchise, our go-to-market model is complex, thousands of customers, distributors. Varied geographic footprint is important in this case.

Dealing with many transactions is really important in this. 70% of Eaton's Electrical revenue goes through our distributor partner network. It's really, really important for us to do this well. Then you combine that with local inventory, good project management support, it really makes for a strong story.

The distribution segment here in North America is very fragmented. Many, many thousands of distributors here in this part of the world, tens of thousands of branches.

A good way to think about this group of our customers is they fall into three major categories. I think about them as the big nationals; you know who are they are. They are fairly well known.

They have hundreds of employees, many branches. Typically they'll go across probably four or five segments across that footprint.

Then you have the super-regionals, who are really very important in this mix, too, who will be across multi-states. In a case like here in the Northeast, they may be a New England, they may be in New York, they may be in New Jersey. Maybe going into Washington, DC; that would be a super-regional.

Smaller number of branches, less employees. Could be in one or two segments, sometime could go to more than that.

And then we have many, many local distributors who could be in small towns across the United States. All they are serving is that particular city or county in one or two segments.

What we have to get right is how do you weave this network of not only the right distributor at the right point but in the right segment. Because you have to do that well, too.

In a project like the Tappan Zee project I talked about, we would be partnering with a certain distributor in a project like that. But if you have a residential renovation coming up in this part of the country, there would probably be a different distributor we would be partnering up with.

So we have to weave that web really correctly. We've been doing that for a while, and with the Cooper integration we really enhanced that. But once you get it right, it creates a sustained growth platform for us across this part of the world.

We have spent a lot of time with distributor; obviously, 70% of our overall revenue. We know what they want from us, and we are very focused on making sure that we deliver that well.

Distributors have told us consistently that for us to be valued we have to do well in these six categories; and I'll talk about them in a second. You combine a strong portfolio with the best salesforce in the industry, and we have to make sure that you have service when you do projects, or in an aftermarket environment. In the power industry, service is critical.

If you don't have the best service capability, that is a difficult way to do business. Eaton has built up its service portfolio over a long period of time, and now we're enhancing that with the capability that we get to deliver for all the Cooper projects.

An example that recently happened here, just for you to envision how the service structure works for us, is a pretty significant hospital chain in Ohio recently had three of their transformers blow up in one of their main research labs. Pretty significant, right, because you have very expensive mice there, and you have all this research capability there, and every minute counts.

The first place they called was Eaton. And Eaton went in and -- remember, now we have a transformer portfolio with Cooper, so that really also adds to this story in a big way. And a change like this would take weeks to be able to put together. Eaton was able to go in, make sure there was backup power there in a matter of hours, but also bring back the entire facility within a week; and that meant brand-new transformers, brand-new grounding systems, and was able to manufacture, deliver, install in what could've been a 12- to 18-week project.

So, portfolio, large salesforce, strong service. You have to have innovation. Frank Campbell is going to come after me and talk about innovation and why Eaton is known as an innovation leader, so that's expected of us and we have that.

You combine these with our brand portfolio. We have strong anchor brands which only got enhanced with the Cooper acquisition.

You combine all that with ease of doing business. Tom talked about -- Sandy talked about that. Important for transaction efficiency.

I'll give you a small example here. We do hundreds and thousands of projects every day. You think, well, that sounds like a big number. Well, a $5,000 project is also a project.

So it could be that there is a small retail shop that is getting set up in Shawnee, Oklahoma. Okay, so distributors tell you you have to be best-in-class in the six areas I talked about. But you have to provide great incentives. We all know that, right? Makes people happy when you have good incentives.

We were able to, post-Cooper acquisition, look at the Cooper program, the Eaton program, what really works well, and put that together to come up with a best-in-class program. We call that the Eaton Distributor Advantage program.

What this program does is it incentivizes distributors on growth -- very, very important. It incentivizes distributors on loyalty -- loyalty to our products. So we combine this really strong financial reward package, we launched a combined channel organization across our teams, and then a very in-depth goalsetting marketing program process that has taken us to the next level of performance. I don't have to say much. You just have to read the quote to know what one of our top super-regional distributors thinks about Eaton. You bring together the best-in-class in these six areas, combined with a strong incentive program, deliver strong goalsetting and marketing programs together with a distributor, it creates a winning proposition for them and for us.

I'm going to talk about a few examples here. It brings it home. It's always good to have examples to envision how all this comes together, and I have some really fun ones.

This one is for our Bussmann fuse brand. All of you know Bussmann fuses; well-known for reliability, innovation, product portfolio.

A big national distributor looked across their national footprint and had a variety of different fuse brands, came to Eaton and said: Hey, I would like to look at not only inventory rationalization but it will provide better training for our teams. The second example is in our lighting segment. As most of you know, distributors tend to carry maybe a few lighting lines, and they will do that just to make sure that they have something for everyone. We have such a wide portfolio today that there really isn't a significant need to do that.

It's really strong story in terms of these examples. You see how all this comes together.

I want to close with this, is that I told you in the beginning the distribution channel was important. When a 70% of our revenue goes through this distribution channel, they are really important to us.

FRANK CAMPBELL, PRESIDENT, EUROPE, MIDDLE EAST AND AFRICA REGION, ELECTRICAL, EATON CORPORATIONPLC: Okay. Thanks, Revathi. Good morning, everybody. You've heard Tom and Sandy both talk about how critical innovation is to the success of our Electrical business, and it really is. And then I have several examples of how we've used those assets to actually create something innovative for a customer, so I'll share some examples of innovation that we are delivering today that have come from that process.

I'm particular happy to be able to do it, because it's a subject that I have an intense amount of passion about and I really enjoy. I think a great place to start the discussion is to first think about the incredible opportunity that we have as an innovator in the electrical space.

I think there's three dimensions we should consider here. First is just the demand, the base demand, the base need around the world for electricity.

Cities, giant cities are being developed around the world; an incredible there. The digitization of our economy -- obviously, as more digital things are put in place the demand for electricity grows.

And then the fact of the matter is that there's billions of people on the planet today that don't have power. So it is an incredible opportunity for innovators like Eaton to provide solutions.

Second dimension I think we should think about is the issues with electricity. There's some of them shown on the board here. It's a complex subject, right?

It is really, really fraught with issues that customers have to deal with. Clearly as an innovator, those aren't issues to us; those are opportunities.

And then I think last and most importantly is -- the real force multiplier of the opportunity is the incredible diversity of the applications, the customers, and the segments that we serve. Because each of those customers has each of those problems; but each of those customers views each of those problems differently.

One is more important than the next. So matching up a customer to a problem is sort of an infinite set of combinations that you get there, and you have an incredible opportunity to innovate. So clearly a target-rich environment.

The fact of the matter is, though, that as significant as the opportunity is, as significant as the number of things we have to work on, innovation doesn't just happen. It's not an automatic thing. It is a purposeful and intentional activity.

I think you need -- we think we need and we think we have some distinctive capabilities in really three areas. First one is customer engagement. Obviously, innovation starts with a customer.

Being able to understand what keeps customers awake at night, critically important. So you need to have a very capable engagement mechanism, and we believe we do in the Electrical Sector.

Clearly electricity is technical. Most of the solutions we offer are technologically based; and therefore you need to have some smart people, and those people need to have the assets and tools required to do their job.

And last but not least, clearly with all the things that are going on, you need a process in place to govern the innovation that we are working on.

So let me start with probably the single most important aspect of our ability to innovate, and that's understanding what our customers' problems really are. You heard Revathi talk about this; you heard Tom talk about this, as well as vertical market segments.

We are increasingly aligning our resources in the organization around vertical markets. We're increasingly specializing, putting people in place that have either come from or have worked very closely with these industries for a long period of time.

They are thought leaders in the industry and they position Eaton as thought leaders in the industry. We have people that really, truly understand what keeps these customers awake at night and what drives their business.

Revathi talked about channel. Really, really important. We have 10,000-some channel partners around the globe. If just a couple -- if each one of those channel partners just has a couple of folks out there calling on customers representing Eaton, you can imagine the amount of opportunity that we get generated in terms of understanding what keeps our customers awake.

Our own commercial enterprise. Revathi mentioned some 1,700 sales resources in North America; we have some 8,800 around the world. That's both outside and inside and customer support people -- it's not just salespeople -- but a very large presence with people out there talking to customers every day.

I think Revathi mentioned this, a significant service presence around the world. What better way to understand what keeps your customers awake and what their real problems are than to be out there in the trenches with them every day, arm in arm, solving problems.

Clearly it's not just a great revenue-generation engine for the Company and a margin generator; it's an opportunity generator. It really helps us understand our customers.

I'll skip one and go to the last. One there I'm pretty truly passionate about because I used to run one of them. Here in North America we have a network of geographically located solution centers. They're little manufacturing sites that are located around the country.

They're there to do things quick and special for customers. Often, and very often, customers walk in; they've got a difficult problem. And we have the manufacturing capability right there in the region with technical people to support them and actually create a solution, deliver that solution to the customer in an hour or in a day or in a week.

And oftentimes the problem we solve in one part of the country customers have all over the place. It gives us the chance to quickly scale that thing around the country.

So critical here -- probably the most critical innovation starts with the customer, our ability to understand what they need. And we think we have -- we are well positioned in this area.

Yes. Okay, second. As I said, technology, technical solutions in Electrical -- important. You need to have a bunch of smart people, and those smart people need to have the tools to do their job.

So 10,000 people around the world doing R&D. And, by the way, those are electrical engineers, those are electrical folks, obviously a significant number of those with advanced degrees.

We divide them into two areas, right? So we get R and D, the left being research. We've got groups of people; Sandy mentioned our innovation centers.

Those people are doing research, real science. They're advancing the state-of-the-art. They're solving really difficult technical problems and creating things that we can use to solve problems for customers.

They work on significant areas of expertise. The ones that are important to Electrical are shown here.

And then the development work, right? So this is the people that are sitting in our business unit headquarters around the world, that are taking the technology, matching it up to the customer needs that we've identified, and actually launching real products in the marketplace.

Critical asset for them is this stability to test, right? We have a highly regulated industry, serious need to certify and test our products.

So we maintain a network, a very, very robust network of laboratories around the world that allow us to certify our products. And when we have extra capacity we actually can certify competitive products.

Clearly, as many smart people as we have, we don't have all the answers. So we need to maintain partnerships and relationships with universities and government agencies around the world so that we have access to the best and brightest and the latest thinking in technologies around the world. So clearly that's a big technical asset for us.

We also cooperate with other industrial partners. An example is shown here. For the sake of time I won't go through details.

Then something that's often overlooked is our need as a technical innovator -- so somebody that's involved in these technical things -- is to maintain our relationships and to help the standards organizations around the world; quite a few of them -- that's only a small list -- but quite a few of these standards organizations, to help them. Help ourselves understand what they are doing and help them evolve the safety standards around the world.

Last but not least, as all good things at Eaton, you need to have a process. You heard about Eaton Business System, and this is our innovation process. We call this the growth and innovation funnel.

It's not a difficult process, but it is a process. It allows us to sort through the opportunities. We understand what's important, which ones we should be working on next.

You can see for us in the Electrical Sector, a fairly sizable amount of stuff sitting in that funnel. There's $8 billion to $12 billion worth of ideas, worth of opportunities at some stage -- that's measured as mature year revenues -- that is in that funnel at any one time.

Really two important stages here prelaunch and PROLaunch. Prelaunch is where we are working through experimenting and understanding whether we have the technical readiness, the commercial readiness and the manufacturing capability to build something, right?

If we don't, we're working through a series of experiments to get that technology in place, and we're working hard on understanding the commercial readiness. Do we have the right go-to-market channel? Do we have the right sales team, right? You can clearly out-innovate your ability to sell.

Oh, by the way, the more important thing is, will customers value, will customers pay for, and are we going to be able to grow with the innovation out in the marketplace? So critical part of prelaunch.

Clearly when we're done and we think we've got -- look, we can technically do it, we can commercially do it, and we can build it, we'll run it through a disciplined execution process we call PROLaunch. And that's nothing more than making sure we deliver what we said we were going to deliver on time, on budget, and on spec and get a product launched from concept to actual launch.

Quick peek inside that green slice there, just give you an idea of the kind of projects we're working on. We classify them in a different set of rating range, and about a quarter of those we call breakthroughs. Breakthrough for us is a technology that the customer has never seen, or technology that we have that we have never applied in a way that we are going to apply it in this particular area.

Clearly a third of the stuff we work on, feature, function, additions to existing product lines, enhancement sort of things. And the rest, that big group in the middle, doesn't rise to the level of one, but it's clearly a significant innovation for customers, and that's clearly the bulk of what we're working on.

What does all that bring to us? Clearly Sandy mentioned these numbers: a significant intellectual property portfolio and a portfolio that continues to grow and grow nicely. Recognition from the industry, industrial associations around the world, as a global innovator. And we think some distinctive expertise in solving difficult technical problems for customers.

In the next few slides I'll share with you how those, how that expertise manifests itself in solutions for customers. A series of examples.

First one, this one is from our lighting business. I just want you to envision this application: you've got a mining shovel.

This mining shovel is running 24/7/365. And mines are not in garden spots, so they are in difficult environments. They are dirty, they're dusty, they're grimy. And they are oftentimes pretty hot in the summer, pretty cold in the winter.

And this big shovel is run by a diesel engine. Clearly diesel engines have lots of vibration. So since they run 24/7, you have to have a light on the outside, and you have to have a light underneath.

So there's about a dozen lights, 10 to 15 lights on this shovel. And lo and behold -- I didn't realize this until I actually started putting this presentation together -- the light technology, the light source technology on these shovels until recently was incandescent lamps. Incandescent lamps have a problem: they are a filament-based kind of lamp, and filaments under heat don't like something called vibration.

You can imagine this incandescent light on the shovel sitting out there under vibration in these terrible temperatures. No surprise those lights needed to be replaced quite often. You can see, every two weeks you've got to replace a light.

Clearly huge downtime problem for the shovel operator. And clearly if they are not running there's issues with fines.

Obviously, LED came along, so great technology here, because it's not filament-based. But the innovation here is not about LED. The innovation here is about taking LED and all the electronics associated with LED, putting it into a package, a very small package, a very robust package that can withstand terrible cold, terrible heat, terrible environment, and provide long life.

Clearly this luminaire we've put out works quite well and delivers 60,000 hours of service to a customer. And by the way, a better quality of light, okay?

So think about what I said about solving a customer problem, what's important to each customer and its being different: same fixture, same exact fixture, very different value proposition. Take that same fixture and put it in a mine shaft; or take that same fixture and put it on an oil rig; or take that same fixture and put it in a refinery. Now instead of just 10 you might have 100 or 1,000 or 10,000 fixtures.

What's important to those customers is energy efficiency. If you take the same solution, 85% energy efficiency, very meaningful to those customers. Very different value prop with the same solution.

This one is probably close to home for many people these days on the East Coast, with all the power outages we've been having. This is about utilities. Clearly power outages are a significant drain on the economy.

Where do power outages typically happen? When the power is out, it's not because the power station is out; it's not because the transmission lines were down. It's because the distribution utility network has a problem.

The distribution utility network is that thing you see when you're driving around your neighborhood or you're driving down a road near the shopping center. It's those lines you see on the wooden poles.

It's not the lines you see on the big transmission towers; those don't typically have any problem. It's those lines that are on the telephone pole. It's those green boxes in your neighborhood.

The distribution utility network is the most susceptible to problems. The ice goes on the lines and pulls them down; that doesn't happen on transmission networks. Cars hit the wooden pole and drop the lines. A backhoe digs up the line in an neighborhood.

Really it's a complex environment, getting more complex with intermittent loads connected to the grid, things like solar and wind. So a distribution network engineer's life is difficult.

Two innovative solutions here by Eaton to allow distribution network engineers to do an effective job of, number one, designing the most robust network they can possibly put out there. Software tool allows a distribution utility network engineer to configure a network and see what's going to happen, and play what-if games, to put the most robust and most power quality-oriented utility network in place.

And the second software package is one that actually helps the utility run the network. It's a tool, it sits out there, runs on their networks, constantly sensing what's going on. And says: if this happens, if I lose service here, how do I quickly isolate -- how do we quickly locate, quickly isolate that fault and restore service quickly and automatically?

Again the network engineer puts together scenarios with switches that are automated. So when something happens, boom, they can put the network online. So fault location isolation and service restoration. One utility, partial deployment on a number of feeders in their network, obviously saves significant, very significant number of outage minutes and improves customer service.

This one, I use a metaphor here; I think it's a good one. Think about this as: why use a sledgehammer when a ballpeen hammer will actually do the job?

What we're talking about is energy efficiency directives in Europe. What they said was, you have two issues.

Number one, all motors have got to be energy efficient; and if you're not going to use a really energy-efficient motor, you've got to put a variable frequency drive on it. And the other thing they said was: all applications where you're using mechanically dampened solutions to control things like airflow, or water or fluid flow -- so imagine, the motor goes on, it blows air. And the way they control the volume is they turn a damper; or the way -- turn a motor on, let it run 100%; and they want to control the fluid flow, they turn a valve. Those are mechanically dampened applications.

The EU said: all mechanically dampened applications you must put a variable frequency drive on. So that's great; we love variable frequency drives, by the way. You heard Sandy talk about this.

Two pictures on the board here in the middle, those are the two variable frequency drive platforms we launched in 2014. That story would be yet another slide and talk about innovation; and that's not what I want to talk about.

That's the sledgehammer. Because think about a variable frequency drive is, it's really complicated. Just look at it. It's got lots of buttons, lots of screens, and it takes a technician to go start those things up.

To meet the European energy regulations, you don't need a sledgehammer. What you need is a ballpeen hammer.

The issue here is energy efficiency. So why not design an optimal-cost energy efficiency device, not a drive -- which is exactly what we did.

We launched in January what we think is a very innovative product. It's aimed at energy efficiency and it's aimed to do it in the most cost-effective way possible.

It takes the place of what we called a motor starter. A motor starter is what you used to use; it just started the motor.

We've put drive technology into a different form factor, so that drive technology is in a device that mounts like a motor starter, wires like a motor starter, and is really familiar to the electrician that is doing the work. So it's very comfortable for them.

By the way, you take it out of the box, you click it where it goes, and in many, many cases zero startup. It just runs.

You connect your mechanical damper actuation system, and the thing will run. So really simple right out of the box. Very, very different approach -- again, use the ballpeen hammer -- and you can see the savings: some 60% less installed cost versus a variable frequency drive.

Don't get me wrong. We love variable frequency drives; we have them, and we sell them. But this is just an example of taking a little bit of a different approach to solving what I think is the right problem with the right product.

Okay, this is an example of innovation isn't always about product and innovation isn't always complicated. This is an oil rig or an FPSO. You guys may have seen these, right?

These are gigantic structures. They look like small cities, and in those structures there is an enormous amount of electrical wiring.

With Eaton's acquisition of Cooper and the B-Line business, we make a whole family of cable support structure products. No offense to my friends listening in Highland, Illinois, that are in the B-Line business; but at the end of the day, our cable management business is bent metal. It's bent and welded metal, okay?

So that's not the most complicated thing in the world, but obviously is some innovation to reduce the weight and increase the strength of that offering, so that we could hold more cable. The interesting thing here is that the value proposition isn't anything to do about cable. The value proposition here is for the rig builder, the guy that builds the rig.

If you can reduce the weight of your cable management system that sits above the waterline, you can reduce times a factor of 4 -- well, 3 times more, because for every unit of weight above you've got to have another unit of weight to support it and two units of weight below. So for every unit of weight you take out above the waterline, you take three more out of that rig.

So instead of selling to an electrician or selling to the electrical installer, what we're doing is we're selling the weight-reduction technology, the weight-reduction capability to the rig builder. So clearly innovation here.

Yes, there is some innovation in product, but more innovation about who we're selling to, how we approach the sale, and when we approach the sale. Because typically now you've got to go to the rig builder before he designs the rig, because he's got to design the product into the system. So again, very different innovation, not about product necessarily, more about process.

This one is about machine builders. This is something we called SmartWire; I believe you saw it on Revathi's slide as well. This is an example of what I'll call very disruptive and transformative innovation.

It's transformative because it is transforming the way machine builders build machines. If you are a machine builder, the number-one issue -- or the guy that wires the machine, the number-one issue you've got in your manufacturing process is wiring. Wiring by its very nature is complicated.

Think about a panel going down a manufacturing line, one of these panels, the one on the left. You've got a technician on the floor who's got to run the wires here.

What is he typically doing? He's typically looking at a wiring diagram. He's having to figure out: okay, I got to cut the wire so long; I got to mark it on both ends; I got to strip it; I got to route it. And by the way, I got to make sure it's connected to the right terminals on both sides.

Then it goes through all the rest of the process and it ends up at the factory at the test line, and hopefully it's all done right. Very significant costs, very significant time. Typically the largest single bottleneck in any factory is right here in wiring.

This is a really revolutionary way of thinking about wiring differently. What we've done is we've embedded a small microprocessor in a very small connector; and that connector clips onto a ribbon cable.

What it allows a machine builder to do is not even have a wiring diagram on the factory floor to run wiring. He literally just snakes that green ribbon cable in the most mechanically effective way through the panel; clips the microprocessor base connector. Very inexpensive, connects it to things as simple as pushbuttons.

And it allows at the end of the line, you plug a computer in. And because of there is patented technology in the chip, which does autoaddressing and autodiscovery, you don't need to do -- you don't even need to have a wiring diagram on the floor. Incredible value for machine builders.

You might also notice -- again, we could talk about three or four more innovations here; I'll just point one more out, is -- notice in the top row here, the panel to the right, there is no more I/O. You don't need I/O anymore when you use this intelligent microprocessor chip. You completely eliminate an entire category of product in these things.

Really, this has been around for a couple, three years. But I think the interesting thing we've done with this is we now expanded it to our entire range of control products. You even heard Craig talk about how we're taking this product now and putting it outside these control panels.

So we are connecting that little chip into things like sensors, machine sensors, and things that are running around on a machine, as well as even to things that aren't even really electrical and are hydraulic valves. It allows the machine builder to not only do better in the box but a lot of reduction outside the box as he runs around his machine.

Last example, and this is example I think I would call this the two ways to skin a cat. So the same problem, safety. You heard Tom talk about us being an industry leader in safety, and I think we really are. We have a complete portfolio of safety products.

So dealing with arc flashes -- so arc flashes are very violent events. You can see that they reach 3 times the temperature of the surface of the sun in milliseconds. It's a really -- it's a catastrophic event when one of these things happen.

Two technologies that deal with it. First one on the top, we have a whole series; in fact, every one of our switchgear products that we offer, we have what's called arc resistant versions. Basically that allows, when the arc happens we basically contain the arc and vent it to a place where it can't hurt anybody that's sitting in front of the equipment. The latest version of that is our medium voltage drive, as you can see.

Completely different technology, typically used in Europe: I call it the airbag for switchgear, because it works exactly like an airbag, okay? Just like in your car, when you hit, you have an accident. There is a sensor in your bumper that says: aha, you're having an accident; I better activate the airbag.

Same exact thing happens here, except we do it with light. So light, arc flash -- an arc flash is a light event. It has a very characteristic waveform.

What we do is we take the -- we sense the light through a fiber optic cable that's running through a switchgear. Once we see that light, we say: aha, this is an arc flash. We wait a few milliseconds to make sure, and as soon as we understand that it is an arc flash we explode an airbag.

It's the device in the bottom. It literally explodes like an airbag.

What it does is it puts a short circuit across the incoming lines; and I won't go into all the technical reasons for it. But basically what it does is it just clamps the event. It doesn't allow the source to feed the fault.

What you end up with is a little bit of damage in the cubicle that that little device sits in. You've got to replace it, just like you got to replace the airbag in your car.

The good news, though is your car, you've got to take it to the body shop. This one, you just replace that little device and the busbar it's attached to, and you're done. So it's a very innovative technology around reducing -- instead I say managing the arc, it actually eliminates it, which is really unique.

So, six examples. I think I made the point that depending on how you apply them, obviously we're solving really important issues for customers. I could have showed you probably 60 more of these. So just really, I think, really good examples about how we're adding value for our customers.

In closing, I think two main points. First, the opportunity. If you take one thing away from this it's there is an almost limitless supply of opportunities to solve big customer problems in our business. We are not going to run out of ideas and we are not we to run out of problems to solve anytime soon.

You saw the issues with electricity. You know what's going on with demand. And just the variable diversity of the customers we serve is enormous. So great opportunity.

Clearly we think we have great capabilities in the business around customer engagement and technical capabilities. Hopefully those examples have demonstrated that to you.

We started this by saying innovation is critical, and it really is critical. I think we can create tremendous value for our customers, real opportunity for us, as we're creating tremendous value for Eaton in terms of both growth and margin expansion by being able to do this. So it's really a great opportunity.

With that, I'm going to welcome Mark Eubanks.

MARK EUBANKS, PRESIDENT, COOPER LIGHTING DIVISION, EATON CORPORATIONPLC: Good morning. My name is Mark Eubanks. I've been with our lighting business since 2006 and came over to Eaton via the Cooper acquisition. The DOE in the United States here projects that almost 75% of all lighting by the year 2030 will be LED. We don't think that's the case. We probably think it's a conservative estimate and likely a higher number going forward.

But even if you take that, think about the efficiency gain that's possible. This represents the equivalency of taking out 50 1,000-megawatt power plants. That's a staggering fact.

Think about the greenhouse gas emissions reduction: 38 million passenger cars coming off the road. This is a huge opportunity for our industry to really lead in sustainability and efficiency.

Our business is a large and diverse business relative to our peer group. If you think about the end markets we serve, the products we have, and really the geographic coverage, our reach is both global as well as very high in technology.

The most exciting part of our business, though, today, really is the third line here, is the growth rates. We've demonstrated since 2011 the ability to generate double-digit CAGRs over that time period. This is a great platform for us to continue to move forward and lead the industry.

Eaton as an entity really is a complete product solution for us to deliver the efficiency gains and the promise that our industry holds.

All customers can't travel to these trade shows; all customers can't see our experience centers; and all customers don't come to our headquarters. So we're also willing to come see our customers directly, take our show on the road.

This is likely the most exciting -- one of the most exciting opportunities we have in the business.

If you look on the right here, these are the comparisons of LED penetration rates of these same competitors relative to ours. More than 50% of our revenue today comes from LED-based lighting and luminaire systems, and this continues to grow. This is a figure that many are starting to report very publicly and so are we, and we are proud of where our portfolio has evolved.

I want to refer you back to one of the slides that Sandy used just after the Cooper acquisition to really think about strategic rationale of why the acquisition. I want to apply it really to our lighting business.

If you think about the real tenets around safety, efficiency, and reliability, lighting fits the bill in all three of those. Whether it's the LED efficiency that we talked about and the real gains that are out there, or really just the emergency and general illumination that creates productivity and safety environments for our customers in their facilities, this certainly fits the bill and is in alignment with this downstream power management vision.

Here's an image that can really highlight the breadth and depth of the portfolio to address customer needs. This happens to be a hospital campus, but could very easily be a refinery or a manufacturing facility or a university or a high-rise hotel like we're in today.

We've got solutions for almost every application here -- in fact, ran out of space to put more. From roadway LED-based lighting with wireless controls, to daylight harvesting, patient room controls, patient room lighting, and even a full campus digitally addressable solution that allows us to monitor, manage, and maintain and control every luminaire in a facility.

This is something that's very powerful, that can be managed through software, that gives customers the kind of granularity and optionality that they've never had in the past. This is a key opportunity for us, or a key building block for the future opportunity for our business.

Here's a look at the outlook of where we think the business can go and where we think it's going to grow. There are some really key fundamental tenets around the industry that are tailwinds for our business.

Energy costs are continuing to increase. We've got more people who need more power with a finite amount of resources. This will continue to be the case going forward.

Legislation will continue to increase and intensify, and I'll talk specifically about that in a second as well. But this is something that also drives adoption in many of these technologies; and really LED and controls is the way to accomplish it.

And then the increasing social responsibility, social responsibility around sustainability. Sandy mentioned it earlier. We have customers like Eaton that are electing to build buildings to certain standards like LEED that really require our products and technology to get there.

Up until the front end of this chart, if you see the before 2013, for five years, really the last five years, we've been working on the real -- just the conversion of LED -- to LED from traditional light sources, whether that be fluorescent, incandescent, or HID. But that story I wouldn't say has played out, because we've still got half our portfolio to go.

But the product roadmaps and the technology roadmaps really are coming into pretty sharp focus for us. It's about now executing and commercializing the rest of those ideas.

But today, we're focused disproportionately on this physical and functional integration of controls and solid-state lighting. This is the opportunity to do more than just light up rooms and light up buildings. We think there is a optionality that will exist with this kind of convergence that many other industries have seen in the technology space.

If you look here, you can see where our traditional sources -- these are the red region on the chart. These are non-LED-based sources.

These have continued to decline as a percentage of our portfolio, as I mentioned, and will continue to decline. If history is any judge of the future, we likely are being conservative here and think that the technology advances even faster, as I mentioned.

The top half of the graph really is the green and the purple zone, are both LED-based sources. The differentiation here is the green zone is standalone devices that are solid-state in nature, but are dumb. They are connected to outside systems or utilize outside peripherals to control them.

Whereas the purple region is where we think all the growth is going to come in the industry. This is really leveraging the converged platforms of both solid-state lighting and controls, both sensors and actuators. This will be where we think the optionality for our business and for our customers' solutions will really accelerate into the future.

It's worth noting here that -- if you don't have your calipers out on this -- but the purple region really is the controlled converged solution. We think this will be 50% or better of our portfolio by 2018. That likely, like the other predictions, is likely a light prediction going forward.

Let's talk about this convergence and really break down where we are and where we focus in the value chain. If you think back in the conventional days, and let's -- the bad old days, not the good old days. Back prior to 2008, this is how -- the top half of the chart is where we would have focused, on the right side in conventional luminaires.

We would be thinking about the luminaire applications, really investing in our brands, in our channel, and in our customer applications. We spent an inordinate amount of time developing salesforces focused on architects, engineers, lighting designers, EPCs, contractors, distributors, as well as end-users.

This is where all of our investment was because the light source technology for us was really about selecting components from one of the two or three large global OEMs that were vertically integrated, all the way from glass and silica all the way up to light bulbs and ballasts. This was the business model and really offered very little opportunity for differentiation from our other luminaire competitors.

We all differentiated around fit and finish. But for the most part, our products were very similar and really forced us to compete more on price and scale in the marketplace.

Fast forward to today and you can see that this shift really has changed. We're still investing heavily in the channel, as Revathi said.

We have the biggest salesforce that we've ever had. We've got the most technical salesforce that we've ever had, really focused on delivering these solutions and delivering value to our customers and understanding these customer-backed applications.

But at the same time we've taken the opportunity to also double down, thinking about research and development, thinking about new product development, further back upstream. Not only to take advantage of the value-add in the hardware and the parts and pieces, but really to be able to take advantage of an integrated solution that lets us leverage the proprietary solutions and control methodologies as well as the form factors of the products to deliver a better solution for our customers.

We still have a great supply chain, still have great suppliers that help us in the technology world. But this is where we are focused.

If you walked around Light Fair or Light and Build in the last couple years, specifically this year, you walked in our booth and see our products, and then walked to two or three other manufacturers, you would not have seen similar-looking products. I think this is a great thing for our industry.

10 years ago you walked in our booths, we all had the same-looking products, same core technologies, same lamp and ballast solutions. That's not the case today and won't be the case in the future. And we think it's a great opportunity to really differentiate our business not only from our competitors, but really from the rest of our history.

I mentioned I'd talk about the codes a little bit. This is a clear driver of some of the government-mandated and regulatory-legislated environment that really is helping move the efficiency story.

If you see the map on the top left here there is a color coding of where all the active code legislation is in the United States, state-by-state. One of the early leaders of all energy code progression and energy efficiency technology is California.

California passed the latest version of Title 24 last year, midyear. That code mandated mandatory requirements for more granular-level control. This is individual control, auto-on and manual-on and -off for individual rooms, demand-response inside of lighting control solutions, all adding more technology and rich features to a required solution.

That's forced manufacturers and suppliers like ourselves to really develop leading technology to be able to accomplish these goals. We're in the early innings of this as well. We think this will continue to intensify, and we've got a great opportunity to really be able to be a trusted partner for our customers.

Green programs. I mentioned the sustainability, the voluntary programs. This does continue as well.

LED lighting and controls is one of the best ways to accomplish lots of credit for qualifying for one of these classifications. We've seen it, and the trend increased dramatically over the past few years.

Another example of a public customer, the GSA has mandated -- since 2010 has mandated that all buildings have digitally addressable light fixtures. That means whether it's LED or not, requirements are that each fixture can be addressed and controlled individually.

Conventional techniques with analog devices make this virtually impossible or very expensive to do. Digital luminaires, converged electronics, converged sensors and actuators give us a great opportunity to not only achieve those goals but also deliver a more significant solution.

Here is a real-world example of how the energy codes have advanced and how our technologies have changed to get there. If you look at the top left, the box with the grid is actually a ceiling plan for a 25,000 square foot typical office floorplate. Back in the 1970s when the first energy codes came out, zones of control were 5,000 square feet or larger. Can you imagine a large home was the zone of control?

Really 20% to 30% saving was achieved by using really crude techniques, time clocks and relay panels that would sweep entire areas of a floor off. In fact, businesses basically because of these codes trained employees to not come to work early and to not work late, because the lights were going off. This is the kind of trade-off that we had to give up to get this kind of energy savings.

Fast-forward to the turn of the century, the most recent century, and codes changed. Codes changed to a smaller space, 2,000 square feet or smaller; and really the advancement of occupancy sensor technology was helpful in doing this. We were able to accomplish more savings, 30% to 50% energy savings, over traditional uncontrolled areas; but still a very inflexible system relative to large spaces.

Then till today, now codes have even advanced further, as I've mentioned. Customer requirements are advancing further, even absent of codes, to really get down to 150 square foot control zones. That's effectively personal space.

The only way to do that would be to individually control every light fixture. As I mentioned, conventional technologies, analog devices will not be the way that gets done. Advanced sources, software, communication protocols, as well as converged electronics are the answer to solving these smart lighting solutions.

Here's another look at the pervasive nature of lighting. We used to think about our business as light bulbs with sheet metal wrapped around them and differentiate over very small aesthetic details.

This is not the case anymore. We've got the opportunity today to deploy solid-state LED lighting luminaires that just by their installation on their own generate drastic energy savings, anywhere from 30% to 90% depending on the light source that they are replacing. As well, you get lifetime benefits, and certainly controllability is part of that.

Going forward, we're thinking about this in a whole different way. We're thinking about we're deploying microprocessor-based, high-density sensor networks that happen to be giving off light. And by the way, the opportunity to control and measure and monitor the space that this equipment and the real estate that it occupies -- whether it be a ceiling, a wall, or a street lighting pole -- gives us the opportunity to be the hub for data and building information and collection, and also extend optionality and control capabilities out to our customers.

This is where customers are continuing to look for a more sophisticated solution from a more sophisticated supplier. There's only a few companies in the world capable of doing this; Eaton is one of them, and we are excited about the opportunity to really take our business to the future.

So if you think about all that I've talked about today, we've got a great business with a great platform. Growing, diverse, really positioned to win.

We're not spending -- all the money we're spending is going forward. We're not spending any money restructuring. We're not spending any money going backwards trying to close down factories with old technology. Everything we are doing is about playing offense, both on the technology side as well as on the channel side.

This expansion of light points will continue because of the technology. But it will continue because of the optionality and the focus that we think we'll give customers going forward. The embedded intelligence and communications and the pervasive nature of the real estate we occupy really do set our business up and our customers for Big Data optionality that they didn't have certainly with traditional sources, and they don't have today without these converged integrated control solutions.

The industry and the future is bright, to use a pun. But the industry is part of something that we take as a steward of the industry, and think that we're positioned to win, and look forward to showing you that in the years to come. Thanks.

DON BULLOCK: Now I think Tom, Revathi, and Frank will come up for Q&A. Don't go anywhere. I'll just leave this up here to jog your thoughts.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: This question is for Revathi. What is the opportunity from a cost perspective with your distributor strategy?

REVATHI ADVAITHI: Okay, so I will start with the first one. How we think about distribution and which distributors to partner with, it's a complex story just like I said in my presentation. So we pick and choose the best distributors based on the segment, based on the investments they are making in that segment and based on what geography they are covering and whether we need that presence or not.

And typically profit margins with distributors are more focused around what they are doing in the marketplace and we are usually able to help them in terms of positioning them in the right segment with the right product, so it's a win-win for both. So we don't pick and choose distributors based on what the profit margins are between us and them. We are able to position that fairly well based on the segment they are participating and the geography. And we have been doing that for a while, so we have woven that web fairly well.

I would say the second part would be there is distributor consolidation happening. It is a fragmented industry and we continue to see that. We continue to see that within the super regionals and we continue to see that between the super regionals and the nationals. We expect that to continue and as that happens, we look at our footprint, see what that means to us and move forward with our existing strategy, but defined for growth with those distributors. But we expect that consolidation to continue to some extent.

DEANE DRAY, ANALYST, RBC CAPITAL MARKETS: Tom, I would be interested in hearing more commentary about the state of the data center market. You sounded a bit more optimistic than one of your bigger peers in that space and in your commentary, I would love you to touch on the segmentation, the go-to-market, especially given the hyperscale customers having very unique enterprise-specific type of requirements, less UPS, but still a faster growth rate. So a lot to touch on there, but be interested in hearing your comments.

TOM GROSS: Okay, sure. I would be happy to start, but I want to make an announcement that Revathi is now the official data center expert given her last two years battling with some of the biggies, the big tech folks. We feel very good about data centers. Now the CapEx spending or the data center construction market we kind of characterize as flat. But what is occurring in that, Deane, is -- and we've outlined this before -- is the UPS is getting a bit thinner and there's a lot of reasons for that, but probably the biggest reason is the mix of data centers. There's not a fundamental change in how UPS works, but the reality is some data centers don't need the same level of backup as others. So hyperscale is a good example.

At the end of the day, if that data center is for Web surfing, if you have to reenter your www address, it's not the end of the world. So the mix has definitely been around dotcom infrastructure and that has thinned out the UPS a bit because they don't need triple redundancy and so on. But the offset of that and then some by the way and then quite a bit is data centers have evolved -- I remember a big one was 4 megawatts. We are now selling 60 megawatts data centers and so the power distribution side of this equation is 4X, 5X times the UPS.

And I'm just warming up. Lighting, cable infrastructure systems, variable frequency drives, the electrical package is accelerating and the terrific news is the UPS is still the most important and we like our product lineup. We like our service lineup. But the real game here is an electrical supplier regardless. The bigger your package, the more you like data centers. Hyperscale is a little different. I don't know if you have any comments around changes as you look forward in that segment?

REVATHI ADVAITHI: I think the hyperscale segment is growing well. It is growing strongly and as Tom said, the key there is that if you look at the overall electrical portfolio in hyperscale, it is very significant for us. So when you are building these 60 megawatt data centers, you have to think about it as UPS is a great place for us to start pulling through our product, but it positions the rest of our portfolio and we are really well-positioned to take advantage of the growth there. It's all about good innovative products, strong lead times, being quick to market and we are well-positioned from those areas in the hyperscale market.

TOM GROSS: And just one addition because I'm sure it is going to get asked, so I'm going to try to cut off the question and ask. If you look at the software side of data center, which gets a lot of play from tons of people, including some of our competitors, we love our position there, Deane. Our capability we put under the banner of Foreseer and Foreseer is a power analytics monitoring and control system for data centers. Many of you saw that in Kentucky when you visited us and since power is going up as the number one cost of a data center, even beyond depreciation of the equipment, managing that power grid is really important and we love our position and you can see it in the wins we've had in hyperscale, colo, across the board. We have tended to stay away from the high end let's say supervisory control of a data center, including management of servers and software and networks and stayed to our knitting. That strategy is really paying off as we become the software provider of choice of managing that ever-increasing power network.
