It's all focused around optics, around thermals, around applications and around mechanical solutions, as well as our control methodology, as well as control integration. And that really is the value add and the IP that we are developing versus the real fundamental epitaxial growth process.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: One of your main competitors last week talked about US pricing starting last year bad and then improving. China on the other hand got worse over the last six months. Maybe talk if you are seeing the same trends. And then within power quality, I just wasn't sure. You said the market (technical difficulty). Within that, what is the three-phase power doing? How much is it down?

REVATHI ADVAITHI: Our pricing processes in terms of project pricing, we have good discipline around it, how we review projects and we know our markets really well so we know how to price for value for our customers and we see the pricing market, pricing overall to be fairly stable at this point in time. And there's always room for that to move up and down based on how the segments go, but our view is that we are in the right position in terms of our capability to price and we always do this fairly well and we may move with the market up and down, but we think that it is stable at this point in time.

TOM GROSS: Relative to China, I would say a very similar situation, pretty stable pricing. You always find pockets of highly competitive things, but overall a pretty stable environment.

The third part of your question relative to data centers, when I was referring to data center, I was generally referring to big data centers that take the big three-phase kinds of things. That market has been driven largely by big technology company investments and then also colos. And that's what I refer to as flat. Now when you get to the middle of the market, we see actually a healthier environment, not dramatically, but it is up a bit and so there's quite a few investments there that we are participating in. So if you net all that out to three phases, you end up just sort of seeing a flattish kind of environment.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: So you've addressed pricing in the large power assemblies. Can you just maybe comment on pricing across the electrical portfolio, generally speaking? And specifically, is the deflation in raw materials like copper, etc., is that creating some additional pricing pressure more broadly across the portfolio?

TOM GROSS: Okay, let me handle the copper question first. Obviously copper, silver and others conspiring to this. It is creating some discussions with our customers for sure. We have a very large amount of contracts that we negotiate on an annual basis with our larger customers where pricing gets set. And so the way this tends to play out is not 1000 phone calls when copper drops below a certain point. It's as those contracts come up for renegotiation, you have the discussion. So it is putting the discussion back on us of -- so you're seeing favorable economics, what are we going to do about this. We will have to manage that very well.

Price is not a huge windfall for us. That's the way we are looking at it this year. We believe it will be positive net, but not of huge magnitude, but we do not see a scenario frankly in any of the three regions and certainly therefore in total where we are going backwards in price in 2015. We don't see that at all.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Okay. And just a quick follow-on. Has there been any change in the dropthrough that you realized on your sales synergies? I am just thinking here about the -- if you look at the different buckets of sale synergy, the incentive program, service mix, etc., is there a difference in dropthrough and I guess I'm trying to hone in here on does the incentive program -- is that a more volume for less margin type of sale?

REVATHI ADVAITHI: No, I mean each one is fairly comparable to our margins we have. The incentive program really whether it was Cooper or Eaton already was doing some sort of an incentive program. So it's not as though overall you reduce your margins just because you are getting growth from channel. Channel growth is usually very profitable for us. So we see that as consistent or positive. The same on -- even if you think about services and services growth in terms of synergy, that gives us good pullthrough in terms of our products that come through and with a larger portfolio, we have larger pullthrough like the transformer service I talked about. So really each bucket doesn't drive a huge significant difference from our base portfolio margin. So we find that it is fairly consistent with that.

TOM GROSS: I think a good way to just think about it in simplistic terms is the rebates are a problem of prosperity because the big realignment was more towards the Cooper formula. We pay for growth. So if you grow, the rebates grow somewhat. But growth through the channel regardless of where it is in the world has a favorable impact on our margins and basically we are giving a bit of it back to continue to encourage growth. And although we spent hundreds of hours, maybe thousands of hours on [EDEP] at the end of the day, that's the way it works. And it's kind of a safeguarded, if you know what I mean, formula from a margin perspective.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: I had a question in regards to the pace at which you are likely to be able to enhance your margins after we conclude the majority of the period for restructuring synergy from Cooper. It looks as though that the restructuring will account for about 89% of your profit improvement between 2014 and 2016 and somewheres near 63% of the total Company. And what kind of assumptions would we have to look for or opportunities we will have to look for for you to pursue to be able to assume that you could sustain the same type of onward profit margin improvement and overall earnings contribution growth post 2016?

TOM GROSS: Sure. That's a perfect question to end on, by the way. So I think maybe a way to start is go back to the chart -- I think it was Rick's chart -- of our margin improvement history. We have demonstrated we can consistently grow margins. There were some acquisitions in there. There are lots of years where there were no significant acquisitions. And I think we feel very positive about our ability to continue to grow margins and the reason for that is not to make it too general, but I think Frank summarized it perfectly. When you look at this opportunity set within electrical to innovate, it's not just innovation for innovation. These are really real-world problems. It's complex. It's unsafe. It's regulated. It needs to be more efficient.

By the way, from generation to consumption, a lump of coal to lightout an LED, less than 35% of the energy gets to the LED. You think about the hundreds of billions of dollars of power generated to do that, 65% gone. So these are big megatrends and I would just characterize it this way. That gives us so many opportunities to stay focused on innovation, to solve some of these problems. I haven't even added what happens when the lights go out today. It's a pretty scary world. That's just a great margin capture environment, whether it's a big acquisition year or not a big acquisition year. I don't know how to say it other than I think all of us believe that kind of the world is our oyster. There's just so much to be done and we have an opportunity to do something about it. Okay, with that, Don. Thank you.

DON BULLOCK: Thank you all very much for spending time with us today. We're going to move at this point to the lunch session of our meeting. That will be directly behind us. (Conference Instructions). For those of you joining us via webcast, we will resume the question and answers in about 30 minutes. At that point in time, thank you very much and we look forward to you joining us at lunch.

SANDY CUTLER: If I could just call everybody's attention for a moment. Please continue your lunch, but we wanted to be respectful of your time here. Once again thanks for joining us for this morning. I hope you found that we shared with you a number of additional profiles and insights about our various different businesses and why we think we've got some really exciting years out ahead of us as well. I don't have any kind of preface this afternoon, so we will open the floor and if I can't answer the question, which is highly likely, I'm going to reference it to some of our experts who are here with me today. So who wants to lead us off this afternoon?

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Thanks, Sandy. So the first question is on your capital deployment plans. You had referenced about $1.5 billion, $1.6 billion by the end of 2016. I guess when I think about your strategy, how are you thinking about the M&A strategy from potentially a transformative acquisition versus both on acquisitions versus the decision to return it to shareholders in the near term?

SANDY CUTLER: Yes, thanks for the question. Because I think it is really one of the big steps for Eaton and we ought to be in position, as we said, by sometime this midyear to talk about it. We will continue our strong dividend policy and I think you know that our practice there has been to increase our dividends in line with our forward earnings expectations. And then it's going to come down to I would guess a mixture of repurchase and M&A. We have not tried to put a qualifier on it, that it would be a potential big deal if we did a deal, or a small deal or a collection of deals.

I think if you look at our history and we were chatting a little bit at my table at lunch is that our history has been to do a series of smaller transactions. There just are more of them available. But having said that, we simply don't know it this year. We have not withdrawn from the M&A appraisal process during this last several years, nor the courting process, so we knew a time would come when our management capacity and our financial capacity would come back into focus where we could go back on that offense and wanted to have that string of opportunities available, but a little early for us to specifically qualify that.

We are also not at a point where we can share with you that X percent would be spent on M&A or X percent would be spent on share repurchase. But I think you get an indication about a little bit of our bias from what we did in the second half of this past year when we bought back $650 million of our shares. And we, as I think you would expect us to say, feel that our shares are still underpurchased. So Don does have order cards here with us for any of you who are looking for opportunities.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Wondering if you could comment or maybe somebody else on your team could comment about you stand on the succession plans?

SANDY CUTLER: Yes, I'm sure we've got a lot of people on our team who would like to comment on that. We don't have the benefit of our Board of Directors here and obviously that's a decision they will make. I think you all know because it is our policy that our elected officers retire at age 65 and that for me occurs in May of 2016. Our Board historically has not had a practice of announcing succession way in advance of any given date, so they will make that call obviously and I think they've had a lot of experience on our Board, a number of our Board members have been through a couple different successions within Eaton. So I've got a lot of confidence they will make the right choices. They will choose their time, so can't give you any particular one. There may be lotteries running in the room that I'm not aware of, but that is usually the case.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Thanks. I had a tax question, so I didn't ask it while you were sitting here. I thought maybe you would want to toss it to Rick, but there's been a large difference between cash and GAAP taxes the last couple years that now seems to be narrowing. And just wonder if you could give us some context on what is driving the narrowing and ostensibly as your headline tax rate does go up with mix, as I think it will, do those two stay tight and maybe some -- if there's any updated color on where you think the tax rate is in fact going in the next year or two?

SANDY CUTLER: Great. Rick, here is the question you were looking for.

RICK FEARON: (inaudible) we do think the gap between cash tax and book taxes will likely (inaudible) start to narrow. Certainly will narrow this year and probably next year as well. A lot of it has to do with we're getting through some of the unsual (inaudible) that had to be (inaudible) legal entities (inaudible) with (inaudible) tax impacts. So we will be much more in a steady-state operating mode by the end of this year.

SANDY CUTLER: Rick, why don't you grab a microphone because they can't hear you on the broadcast by the way?

RICK FEARON: And that -- getting back into a steady state operating mode will narrow that difference between cash and book taxes. We think the rate this year will be between 9% and 11%. To get to 9%, you would have to have reimplementation of the R&E tax credit. We are not betting on that. It might happen, but the 10% midpoint of the range assumes that that is not reimplemented. And over the next few years, it is hard to know, there are a lot of things going on in the tax world, as I am sure you have noticed. The biggest of which I would say is not even what has been proposed here in the states, but it is all these OECD BEPS initiatives, which are 15 different policy papers on how international corporate taxation can change. It's very hard to know what will come out of those simply because they are complex and certainly not all agreed amongst the members of the OECD. But absent any major changes there, our rate likely to perhaps go up 1% to 2% over the next few years, but not dramatically based on everything that I see right now.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Rick, don't sit down yet, please. I've got another question for you. It's on FX, the 4 percentage points of headwind. Maybe just walk us through the hedging, what kind of hedging you are doing in terms of transaction hedging, not translation hedging. Maybe an update on how naturally hedged are you today. And then probably for Sandy, any color on the storm impact, storms plural, this season just in terms on the electrical side and just help us understand how it benefits and maybe or net given business interruptions. Thanks.

RICK FEARON: You're right, we have had a policy of not hedging our translation because we have regarded that as more just reporting as opposed to substantive. But we have had also a policy of hedging to the extent we can all of what I would call items on balance sheets that are in other than the functional currency. We hedge those completely and generally achieve that even though there is some complexity in managing 700 odd balance sheets.

In terms of transactional flows, meaning that you produce the product in one currency and sell it in another currency, any flows of significant magnitude we try to hedge out and so we don't have significant transaction exposure. We have a little bit because there are some flows that just don't merit hedging or some flows where the hedging costs are really quite high and so you may elect to hedge less than you might otherwise. But for the most part, our real exposure is just translation and that is really what the 4% is.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: (inaudible - microphone inaccessible).

RICK FEARON: From a natural hedge standpoint, our manufacturing philosophy has been to manufacture and sell in the same region and we do that for several reasons. One, we provide better service to customers by doing that. We are much closer to customers. But two, you naturally take away most of the FX exposure because generally regions tend to have currencies that it's either one currency or the currencies are closely aligned, so you generally don't have a lot of FX exposure by doing that and that's why, with all the actions we have taken, it really is mainly a translational issue for us.

SANDY CUTLER: We made that big change you may recall back in 2000, 2001 where we spent a lot of time trying to get our sourcing and manufacturing assets lined up in the zone of currency, so it's really been the same since then.

On the storm issue, we've given a lot of thought to moving additional resources to Boston. We have not yet, but there's no question this has been a harsh winter around the United States and there's also the port strike issue on the West Coast, and I would say nothing material really to report at this point. They make it more difficult but that's really sort of ours to overcome at this point.

NIGEL COE, ANALYST, MORGAN STANLEY: So Sandy, obviously, you financed the Cooper acquisition at very attractive interest rates and since that time rates have come down even more. Two times levered by the end of this year or thereabouts. How are you thinking about this unusual situation where we've got negative bond yields in Europe? Do you see an opportunity here to do something meaningful again?

SANDY CUTLER: I think again, Nigel, there is no question, I think if we had looked five years ago at this period of time, none of us would have anticipated seeing these different relationships, let me call it that way, that exist at this point. And we do think they create some opportunities. It's all part of what we're going to be looking at as we get toward the middle of this year. We feel we've got important commitments at this point in terms of what we said we would repay and that's been important for us as kind of a hallmark of our credibility with so many of the institutions that have provided us liquidity over the years and so we want to continue to, obviously, fulfill that. But as we get to the middle of this year, I think as we look at issues of capital structure and how we're going to return dollars to shareholders, that's all in the mix at this point. It is a very unusual period of time and we think it is one that needs to be noted and capitalized upon.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: When you think about Eaton as a power management company and you look at a couple of different paths to -- and adjacencies such as automation or other building systems that you are not already largely present in, what is your view competitively or opportunity -- forget M&A -- it could be organic, lots of ways of doing it, but just the opportunity set for Eaton in those areas? Is that something that is so far afield that you feel like you've already got what you need in those spaces to grow, or in fact those areas you really need to look at more aggressively over time?

SANDY CUTLER: Well, I think you heard about two cuts at that this morning. The titles may not have tied it right to you, but first let's just take what Tom talked to you about Foreseer this morning. Clearly the ability to do power distribution, asset management and inventory in a data center is one that we have right now and it's a very powerful capability. The second one you heard about was from Mark Eubanks in terms of the space that exists above you whether it's in a building or a parking lot or on a highway, obviously provides you with a really unique opportunity in that area as well.

So Eaton is not without its opportunities in these areas just from an internal organic growth point of view. We don't really ever comment on the M&A or specific verticals, but I think you can see us in a number of these businesses moving into areas where it's not just the physical presence of the product, but it's also our software capability to perform in a supervisory way, if you will, and we think there are real opportunities to grow in that regard.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: There was a lot of stuff in the prepared remarks about how the Cooper acquisition has reduced the volatility in the earnings and significantly through the cycle and more predictability, etc. Internally there had to be thoughts that that would help the valuation of the Company just given that you have less volatility in earnings. I think you could argue actually now that the discount on Eaton stock to multi-industry peers in general maybe has even gotten bigger kind of relative to the beginning when you guys maybe would think it would do the opposite. So just wondering if you have any comments on why that hasn't improved or just anything along those lines?

SANDY CUTLER: Yes, I think the discount is really an issue of whether you look at it on a pretax basis, adjusted basis, or whether you look at it on a full after-tax basis and different owners and investors have different perspectives about how long our tax rate may continue to be a significant discount to others. One of the reasons we think our Irish structure gives us a really great continuity or sustainability over time is we actually are in a place that has a very significant different tax rate by statute in this regard.

I think when we -- and I'll ask Rick to comment on this in a minute as well -- we do think our tax rate will tick up as Rick mentioned, but I know a number of you are using 15% tax rates in your models. That is not what we run. That's not what drives our cash and we think that is really an undervalued recognition at this point. I understood when we ran lower tax rates and we were a US-based company that people had concerns about it. I think that concern should be significantly less now that they were incorporated as an Irish company. Rick, do you want to add anything to that?

RICK FEARON: Yes, I would agree with you, Sandy. I think what has happened is that while we have created more stability in earnings, I think at the same time the world's in a time period where there is more discussion and uncertainty around tax rates. So I think that you've had those two factors that have impacted our valuation, but I think what has been missed is that because of our Irish domicile and because of the various actions we have taken to capitalize on that, we are not nearly as subject to exposure as a US company would be. But it will take -- I can understand how some people would like to see this over some period of time to get comfortable with that.

SANDY CUTLER: I would say that the second issue, which I think is a very material one and very well understood, is that Cooper was a very exciting acquisition when it was announced, but it was announced, it wasn't concluded. And if you think about out of the savings we said we got, we said we'd get $115 million the first year, we'd get $95 million the second. That's exciting, but the next big piece is $150 million this year. It's not done yet and then there's another $115 million next year. So for those who believe the acquisition is going well and that we are doing well against all of our commitments, it makes the $150 million and the $115 million a lot more probable than if you were sitting back in the late part of 2012 and early 2013 saying I wonder how they will do with this.

I think the other aspect, for those of you who have had a chance to talk to our channel partners or any customers, you hear from them the level of success we are creating in the marketplace and that's the real enduring strength over time. So I would call that not as much of a future as it was a couple years ago and I hope you got a sense from that today that this isn't exactly what I would say in the realm of "book it, Danno" yet, but it's getting particularly close and we think we can see the end of this integration and it creates a very attractive stream for us.

The last item I would mention is that if you went back just a couple years ago, I think there were significant questions in terms of would the heavy-duty truck cycle ever come back. And there was a lot written about that. There has certainly been a confirmation last year and again this year, we are seeing a very important end market that is a very handsome one in terms of profit and revenue stream for the Company come on quite strongly as well. So we are doubtful to have every one of those 20-some end markets ever operating all up at the same time, but it's a pretty good time for us when you look at that balance of the overall markets right now.

ANN DUIGNAN, ANALYST, JPMORGAN CHASE: Just following up on a similar theme. We don't see deep cyclical companies change their dividend policy in the good times because they always know the bad times are going to come. Have you thought at all about structurally changing your dividend as a way of expressing your confidence in the volatility in earnings going forward?

SANDY CUTLER: We think we did. When you think about we are talking about 5% -- our mid-point of our guidance this year is a 5% increase in our operating earnings per share and we just increased our dividend by 12%. And so we do think that our practice of not having either a yield or a payout methodology in terms of trying to have that dictate our dividend, but we look at it as a -- in regard to what we think our future earnings growth is going to be and clearly when you peel off the FX and the tax impact this year, we told you it would be about a 13% increase and so that 12% is -- and of course, you always end up in interesting rounding issues when you are trying to work with a cent. It's a pretty close approximation for what we think our rate going forward is.

So I think it's a message of confidence. We never cut our dividend in the 2008, 2009 time period, which I think is a reflection again of the cash flow characteristics of our Company that it's very strong through the cycle. So I think for investors who are looking to secure a portion of their return through a handsome dividend, that obviously makes Eaton a very attractive stock and Rick mentioned today we are up just a little bit over $3. We are at the high end of our peers and that's where we want to position the Company.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Maybe just one other final point on tax. So just looking at my coverage universe, I have three other Irish domiciles -- [IR], Allegion, Tyco. Their tax rate is really 20%-ish and Tyco arguably is the most sophisticated and experienced of those three I rattled off in terms of being foreign domiciled for a long time and knowing how to work it and they are at 18%. So I think some of us still struggle with why even going to 15% seems like it wouldn't happen at Eaton and maybe understanding what else might be going on there that would differentiate you from the other call them foreign domiciled US companies.

SANDY CUTLER: And again, it is no different, Jeff, than what we've talked about for maybe eight or nine years. Remember there were four key elements that number one, when Eaton acquired Westinghouse, they had a very large manufacturing platform in Puerto Rico. Most of you know the statutory rate there is 10% or below. That continues today. Some of those other companies you mentioned never have had that tax rate. That's why when we were incorporated in the US our rate was lower.

Second, very importantly and you could ask each of our executives here today, we pay our executives on an after-tax basis. There are a few companies that actually do that. And so people's sensitivity and appreciation for making tax-intelligent decisions has been part of our Company for a very long time, way low in the organization.

Third, we moved internationally after many of our competitors and so we moved post the international tax revolution when you found that many of these countries had dropped to 15% tax rates and many other people had made their investments at much higher times and so that's an important piece. That will burn off over time because other companies will make lapsing schedules in those higher areas.

And last but not least, obviously our move now to Ireland in 2012, which really helps us most fundamentally with the ability to move cash around the world and not end up with trapped cash, which obviously is really good news for our investors in that regard. So it's sort of those four items.

Well, we thank you all for joining us today. Appreciate your support and obviously Don and team are available for follow-up questions. Have a good afternoon. Thanks. Good to see you all.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:59FD-8D51-JCMN-Y2YS-00000-00Ebay buys payments startup Braintree for $800M, yet another win for PayPal2013-09-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:41ZLexisNexisEbay buys payments startup Braintree for $800M, yet another win for PayPal

Sep 26, 2013 (VentureBeat:http://venturebeat.com/ Delivered by Newstex)
BraintreeBrainTree's office
Big news in the payments world this morning, as eBay just announced that it has snapped up popular e-commerce payments processor Braintree[1] for $800 million in cash.

Braintree's[2] technology gives companies a complete solution to accept payments, including credit cards, without worrying about extensive payments infrastructure. The company competes with the likes of Stripe and credit card companies, and it was also one of the biggest threats to PayPalover the past few years. The deal is expected to close by the end of the year. 'As a separate service offered by PayPal, Braintree will be able to scale its platform at a rate that is just not possible for a startup,' wrote PayPalCEO David Marcus[3] in a blog post today. 'PayPal's already solved many of the regulatory and logistical hurdles that will help to extend Braintree's reach to more customers in more markets even faster. Our resources will enable them to push the boundaries of innovation with ambition and confidence for consumers, merchants and developers around the world. It's business as usual for Braintree. Braintree will continue to maintain its best-in-class service for its customers and developers for the foreseeable future.' Braintree announced in July that it's now processing more than $10 billion in payments[4], and it just recently released its Venmo Touch product to the public[5], a digital 'unwallet' that other apps can access to make payments. Braintree bought Venmo last year[6] for around $26 million. The company offers payments for 4,000 merchants, covering a potential 40 million customers, and operates in 40 countries. Its current customers including big tech firms like Uber, AirBnB, LivingSocial, and Rovio. All of those items likely made Braintree an enticing buy for PayPal(and something that it wouldn't want competitors to snap up). PayPalsays it expects to handle $20 billion in mobile payments this year, and that Venmo will 'help to contribute' to its mobile payments prowess. 'The consumer side and the merchant side have to come together for the next generation of e-commerce,' Ready told us when Venmo Touch launched. 'Payments will become a network effect play about who can make it easiest for merchants and consumers to connect with one another with context-driven experiences. To do that, you need to have thousands of merchants and millions of consumers. We are thinking that this platform, if we do this right, will be as important for next decade of commerce as PayPalwas for the last decade.' Founded in 2007, Chicago-based Braintree raised $69 million in funding from investors including New Enterprise Associates, Accel Partners, RRE Ventures, and Greycroft Partners.

urn:contentItem:5WGF-0KP1-JCMN-Y02Y-00000-00EBay is trolling Amazon over last year's Prime Day outage with a 'crash sale' (EBAY, AMZN)2019-07-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:41ZLexisNexisEBay is trolling Amazon over last year's Prime Day outage with a 'crash sale' (EBAY, AMZN)Rebecca Aydin

Jul 02, 2019( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) eBay / AmazonEBay[1] has announced a "Crash Sale," trolling Amazon's outage[2] during its 2018 Prime Day[3] sales. EBay's biggest troll is announcing[4] "a fresh batch of too-good-to-be-true deals that will drop if Amazon crashes." Meaning, eBay's sale will roll out additional deals if Amazon crashes again this year. But eBay isn't the only retailer stepping up to compete with Amazon in July — Walmart, Target, and Nordstrom are holding sales, too.

This confluence of major online retailer sales is turning mid-July into a summer Cyber Monday. Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories[5]. EBay[6] has announced a "Crash Sale" to rival Amazon's Prime Day[7], with the promise of extra deals if Amazon[8] crashes again like last year. Amazon crashed for over an hour[9] at the beginning of its 2018 Prime Day: error messages appeared on web pages, and customers encountered issues with placing items in their carts. Despite this, Amazon had record sales of $4.2 billion in the 36 hours of Prime Day, according to Wedbush Securities Inc. analyst Michael Pachter[10]. This was the company's highest single sales day until Cyber Monday[11] a few months later in November 2018. Read more: Amazon Prime Day, the made-up holiday that rivals Black Friday, is coming soon. Here's why it's such a big deal.[12] The eBay Crash Sale will run on July 15, overlapping with the first day of Amazon's now 48-hour[13] Prime Day. EBay's biggest troll is announcing[14] "a fresh batch of too-good-to-be-true deals that will drop if Amazon crashes." Meaning, eBay's sale will roll out additional deals if, and only if, Amazon has a similar outage to last year. EBay is also positioning itself as competitive to Amazon Prime in its free shipping, no membership, and "best price guarantee" that ensures that shoppers who find their eBay Deal item being sold at a competitor for a lower price within 48 hours of their purchase will be paid 110% of the price difference back by eBay. But eBay isn't the only retailer stepping up to compete with Amazon in July. Nordstrom's annual anniversary sale begins early access for members on July 12 and public access on July 19. Walmart[15] will be running sales July 14 through 17, and Target's Deal Days is the exact timeframe of Prime Day. This confluence of major online retailer sales is turning mid-July into a summer Cyber Monday. "July has become a massive shopping season," said eBay COO Jay Hanson in the Crash Sale press release.NOW WATCH: Apple just launched a $6,000 Mac Pro, available this fall[16]See Also: Facebook, Google, and Apple are going on the defense as the battle cry to break up 'big tech' gets louder than ever[17]Walmart and giant US retailers turn up heat on Amazon and Google by calling for blockbuster antitrust investigation[18]I tried the new $250 wireless earbuds from Beats, and they're officially the best AirPods alternative for iPhone users[19] SEE ALSO:OnePlus accidentally sent a push notification that said 'hahahaha' in Chinese to OnePlus 7 Pro users around the world[20] [ 1]: urn:contentItem:5CB6-HTB1-F03R-N44G-00000-00eBay Shrugged: Pierre Omidyar believes there should be no philanthropy without profit2014-05-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:41ZLexisNexiseBay Shrugged: Pierre Omidyar believes there should be no philanthropy without profitMark Ames

May 31, 2014 (PandoDaily:http://pandodaily.com Delivered by Newstex)
'I had a long debate with Pierre,' [Nobel Peace Prize winner] Yunus told me, referring to Omidyar. 'He says people should make money. I said, Let them make money—but why do you want to make money off the poor people?'

— The New Yorker[1] This week, India's newly-elected ultranationalist leader Narendra Modi unveiled his cabinet, three-quarters[2] of whom come from a fascist [3]paramilitary outfit, the RSS (Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh) — including one minister accused by police last year of inciting deadly Hindu-Muslim violence that left over 50 dead. The RSS was founded in 1925 by open admirers[4] of Mussolini and Hitler; in 1948, an RSS member[5] assassinated pacifist Mahatma Gandhi. In 1992, it was the RSS that organized[6] the destruction of the Ayodha Mosque, leaving 2000 dead[7], mostly Muslims; and in 2002, the RSS played a key role in the mass-murders of minority Muslims in Gujarat, according to Human Rights Watch[8], when the state of Gujarat was ruled by Narendra Modi — himself a product of the RSS[9]. Earlier this week, Pando reported[10] that Modi's election received help from unlikely sources in Silicon Valley including Google, and to a much more serious extent, Omidyar Network[11], the philanthropy fund of eBay billionaire and First Look publisher Pierre Omidyar. From 2009 through February of this year, Omidyar NetworkIndia Advisers was headed[12] by Jayant Sinha[13], a longtime Modi adviser and newly-elected MP[14] in Modi's ultranationalist BJP party[15] ticket. The Omidyar Networkpartner and managing director played a double role, investing funds in Indian nonprofits and for-profits, some with distinctly political agendas; while privately, the Omidyar man 'worked in Modi's team'[16] in 2012-13, and served as director[17] in the ultranationalist BJP party's main think tank on security and economic policy, the India Foundation. This week, Modi appointed the head of the India Foundation[18], former intelligence chief Ajit Doval[19], as his National Security Advisor[20]. Modi was the 'hi-tech populist' [21]candidate: London techies[22] managed Modi's 3-D hologram[23] campaign, beaming 10-feet-tall Modi holograms to rallies across India. And India's techies played a key role both in campaigning for Modi and voting for Modi. Despite the sunny progressive Silicon Valley gloss we've been fed these past few decades, Modi's appeal shows that the tech industry is as prone to far-right authoritarian politics as any other industry. And that is what makes the Omidyar Networkstory so revealing: Perhaps no other figure embodies the disconnect between his progressive anti-state image, and his factual collaboration with the American national security state and the global neoliberal agenda, than Pierre Omidyar. The role of Omidyar Networkin so many major events of the past week — helping elect India's ultranationalist leader Narendra Modi; co-funding Ukraine regime-change NGOs[24] with USAID, resulting in a deadly civil war and Monday's election of Ukrainian billionaire oligarch[25] Petro Poroshenko; and now, this week's first-ever sit-down TV interview with Edward Snowden, through an arrangement[26] between NBC News and Pierre Omidyar's First Look Media — shows how these contradictions are coming to the fore, and shaping our world. Omidyar's central role in the US national security state's global agenda may still come as a shock to outsiders and fans of First Look media's roster of once-independent journalists. But to White House foreign policy hawks, Pierre Omidyar represents the new face of an old imperial tradition. Liberal Hawks: Samantha Power, Omidyar USAID 'For Washington, NGOs are nothing less than 'America's invisible sector' of influence.' —James Peck, Ideal Illusions[27] In November 2013, UN Ambassador and neocon favorite [28]Samantha Power gave a speech at the Freedom Award[29] ceremony, honoring George Soros' role in advancing America's foreign policy strategy through the Open Society-USAID private-public partnership. The Freedom Award is one of the Cold War[30] establishment's top honors; past honorees[31] include George H. W. Bush, Bill Clinton, Winston Churchill, and OSS spy agency founder 'Wild' Bill Donovan. This is Soros' second Freedom Award, and for good reason, as Ambassador Power explained[32]: Soros' vision for the world — a world of free markets and 'open government' — perfectly synched[33] with President Obama's vision: A couple of years ago, I had the privilege of listening from the gallery of the United Nations General Assembly when President Barack Obama addressed the heads of state of the world and built an entire affirmative agenda around Karl Popper's vision, which is George's vision and which George popularized and resourced: open economy, open government, open society. After noting that 'private donations now equal more than two-thirds of the amount that the U.S. government gives in foreign aid,' Ambassador Power praised Soros' contributions and singled out his Silicon Valley heir, Intercept publisher Pierre Omidyar[34]: The new philanthropists—the Soros-modeled philanthropists — donate money, but they do so while they're still in the prime of their lives… And through his example, George [Soros] has given definition to what it means to be a modern philanthropist, to be a doer, paving the way for Bill and Melinda Gates, Warren Buffet, Pam and Pierre Omidyar, and others. George was first. Samantha Power would know: In November 2010, while serving in Obama's National Security Council[35], she posted on the White House website[36] a glowing description of President Obama's meeting with an Omidyar-funded Indian NGO, Janaagraha, just one month after the organization received a $3 million grant[37] from Omidyar Networkto launch its iPaidABribe anti-corruption campaign. The $3 million grant was Omidyar's first to an Indian NGO under managing director Jayant Sinha - who, as Pando reported, had a second job as advisor to ultranationalist Narendra Modi. Curiously, before receiving Omidyar's money and Obama's personal blessing, the NGO's co-founder, Ramesh Ramanathran[38], expressed his support for Obama's counter-insurgency strategy[39] in Afghanistan. With one caveat: even more NGOs: …for all its celebration of local services, the counter-insurgency strategy doesn't go far enough to realize the full potential of this approach. Specifically, two key aspects need to be added: first, having local governments be at the centre of civic service improvements; and second, well-defined participatory decision-making processes that empower citizens. …In other words, counter-insurgency could be thought of as 'bottom-up nation-building', not just asymmetric war strategy. Ramanathran[40] is a former Citibank executive and a Yale MBA. Besides fighting corruption in India through his NGO, Ramanathran also runs a microfinance company[41] that targets India's urban poor[42] borrowers — 'maids, vegetable sellers, security guards' according to one description[43]. His microfinance company suffered early on from high default rates[44] and alleged underworld pressures, but has since expanded lately thanks to large private equity investors like Morgan Stanley [45]and KKR. By taking a closer look at Omidyar Network's investments in India, we gain insight into where the common interests between Big Tech, the US national security state, and neoliberalism align — and Omidyar's strategic thinking aligning eBay/PayPal with Omidyar Networkand First Look media. Let's start with Omidyar Network's investments in the Rural Development Institute, founded by one of the godfathers of American counterinsurgency strategy: Roy Prosterman. 'Property Rights': Omidyar and 'Phoenix Program' guru Roy Prosterman Omidyar Networkidentifies 'property rights'[46] (or 'property titling') as one of its five areas of focus. One of Omidyar's personal heroes and largest grant recipients is neoliberal economist Hernando de Soto, the former right-hand[47] man to jailed dictator[48] Alberto Fujimori[49]. De Soto is the world's leading peddler of 'property titling' as the answer to global poverty: rather than giving aid, De Soto says we should give the world's poor private property titles, which slum dwellers can presumably collateralize into microloans for their slum-based startups. The results[50] have often been catastrophic[51] — but that hasn't stopped De Soto from being admired by the world's ruling elite, ranging from Bill Clinton[52], to the Koch brothers[53] — to Pierre Omidyar, who gave $5 million[54] to De Soto's neoliberal think tank[55], and gushes on Twitter[56]: Brilliant dinner with Hernando de Soto. Property rights underlie and enable everything. — Pierre Omidyar (@pierre) September 23, 2009[57] India, like many developing countries around the world, has what Anglo-Americans consider a weak legal structure on property rights. In particular, local indigenous peoples lay ancient claims to lands they live on, and have resisted state attempts to forcibly evict them to make way for industry, mining, and other powerful interests. The Naxal Maoist insurgencies raging in parts of India are fueled in part by displaced, landless peoples. Since Modi's election landslide, global investors[58] have been hopeful that India's land will now be made easier to buy and sell. Omidyar Network's longtime top man in India, Jayant Sinha—now an MP in Modi's far-right ruling party — told CNBC[59] that Modi's first job should be making land acquisition easier: We have to start with land acquisition. We have to make land acquisition a lot better in terms of both the people that are acquiring the land from the farmer's and so on as well as for industry. So perhaps it's little surprise that Omidyar's first major India grant[60], in 2008, went to the Rural Development Institute's (renamed 'Landesa') program 'to help secure land rights for the rural poor' in India's Andhra Pradesh state. By 2009, Omidyar Networkhad committed $9 million[61] to the RDI land rights program, the largest grant in the outfit's history. And what a history: The Rural Development Institute was founded in 1967 by Roy Prosterman, whose land reform programs were a key element[62] in the Vietnam War counterinsurgency strategy, the 'Phoenix' assassination program[63]. The Phoenix program became the template for modern American counterinsurgency[64] — violent terror, combined with soft-power land 'reforms' cooked up by Prosterman's Institute. During the Vietnam War, Prosterman teamed up with USAID[65] to implement his 'land-to-the-tillers' reforms, granting land to peasants as the carrot, while at the same time CIA death squads assassinated tens of thousands of Vietnamese village leaders and terrorized restive regions into submission. The result, Prosterman later boasted, was that Viet Cong recruitment dropped 80 percent[66]. A decade later, Prosterman sold the same land reform program to El Salvador's junta[67], just as the junta was ramping up its deadly attacks on rural civilians that left 75,000 killed[68] by US-backed government forces. Prosterman also served as 'land reform' advisor to Philippines dictator Ferdinand Marcos[69]. And in the 1990s, Prosterman was contracted by Booz Allen to advise land reforms in Moldova, according to journalist Tim Shorrock[70]. Former Wall Street Lawyer Works to Defend Poorest Farmers in China | Lovely tribute to Roy Prosterman @Landesa_Global[71] http://t.co/PMcCCD2b[72] — Omidyar Network(@OmidyarNetwork) October 25, 2012[73] A few years ago, Prosterman's Rural Development Institute changed its name to Landesa. But Prosterman's Cold War outfit hasn't changed its close cooperation with USAID[74], or its core strategic mission, tying land ownership to security (and counterinsurgency) — neatly summed by Landesa's India director's article: 'Connecting the Dots Between Security and Land Rights in India.'[75] Leaving aside the alleged benefits to India's poor of giving them land title to the commons — 400,000,000 Indians live on less than $1.25 a day [76]— for the more powerful interests funding land titling programs, there are endless advantages. It helps create a mass tax base for governments that want to shift more taxes onto the masses; it formalizes and legalizes transfer of property from the commons to the strongest and richest; it makes foreign investors happy; it helps the government and businesses track and keep data on its citizens; and, to quote Omidyar Networkmanaging partner Matt Bannick — recently appointed by the Obama White House[77] to a special taskforce — Prosterman's land reforms made Omidyar[78] 'excited about how micro-land ownership can empower women and help them to pull themselves out of poverty.' That's because micro-land ownership helps create the real focus of Omidyar Networkinvestments in India: Microfinance. 'Financial Inclusion': Omidyar, Microfinance Suicide-By-Pesticide Omidyar Network's ugliest disaster — besides co-funding Ukraine regime-change groups with USAID — was its role in funding SKS Microfinance, whose predatory lending and debt collecting practices led to a rash of gruesome suicides in rural Andhra Pradesh. First, a quick word on the theory and practice of microlending. In theory, the original microfinance concept — a nonprofit extending micro-loans to the poor, under favorable terms, below market rates — could be beneficial, and under the right circumstances, it often was. But to the neoliberals, the original microfinance concept smacked of do-gooder state socialism — so microfinance floundered in the margins of the development community until 1992. That year, USAID commercialized a Bolivian microfinance nonprofit called Prodem, creating a new for-profit micro-lender, BancoSol in its place. BancoSol ballooned overnight — both in loans and in profits, making millionaires of the former nonprofit directors before BancoSol nearly collapsed at the end of the decade. USAID liked the for-profit neoliberal model for microfinance, and it persuaded the World Bank and other global financial institutions to load in and sing its praises. That brought microfinance to the attention of Wall Street funds, eventually pushing out 'old' 'unsustainable' nonprofit microfinance institutions, and seducing the likes of Nobel Peace Prize winner and microfinance industry guru Muhammad Yunus into the for-profit[79] sector as well. As we now know, it ended in disaster[80] — particularly in India's Andhar Pradesh[81] state, where Omidyar-funded land title programs had been busy creating legions of rural poor 'micro-land owners' now ready to load up on Omidyar-funded microfinance loans. The result would be scores of women driven to grisly suicides[82], forced prostitution, and despair. It's hard to overstate just how central the for-profit microfinance model is to Pierre Omidyar's 'vision.' In a 2006 New Yorker article detailing Omidyar's near-religious zeal for commercializing microfinance, we learn that the eBay billionaire not only rejected the Nobel Peace Prize winner's appeals to soften his monomaniac focus on profiting off the world's poor — we also learn that Omidyar was committed to wiping out whatever remained of charitable non-profit microlending, so as not to 'distort the market.' Omidyar rejected on principle entreaties from his fellow billionaires to invest in a nonprofit microfinance fund. Because on principle, Omidyar refused to believe that good could come from anything but the self-interested profit motive. Here's the New Yorker[83]: [Omidyar] often cites Adam Smith's doctrine that unrestrained market forces and self-interest drive the most efficient—and socially beneficial—use of resources. Omidyar sees Smith's principles at work in eBay; he believes that eBay's commercial success was linked to a profound social good. Omidyar's faith in the eBay model is so great that he is convinced that it can be applied to solving humanity's problems, including poverty — and that is why Omidyar singled out for-profit microfinance as his life's mission. After rejecting Yunus as an 'old thinker' wedded to old do-gooderism non-profit thinking, Omidyar announced a $100 million donation to Tufts University, the largest in school history, with the stipulation that the Omidyar-Tufts Microfinance Fund[84] went 'specifically' into 'investments that would promote microfinance's commercialization.' To manage the fund, Omidyar hired a Senior Credit Officer from USAID — the agency that originally commercialized microfinance in 1992 — who channeled Joseph Schumpeter to the New Yorker[85]: 'One of the things we need and we will get is a cycle of creative destruction,' said Tryfan Evans, the director of investments at the Omidyar-Tufts fund, who previously worked at U.S.A.I.D. 'If you're inefficient, you will get overtaken by competitors.' What is rather shocking in hindsight is how fanatical Omidyar's faith is in the free market, to the point that he's willing to risk exploiting the most vulnerable poor on earth to prove that Adam Smith is right. The dangers of for-profit microfinance lending to India's poor were no secret: the New Yorker article[86] references a string of microfinance related suicides[87] in Andhra Pradesh back in 2006, before Omidyar's millions pour oil on that fire. Yunus failed to dissuade Omidyar: 'Let them make money—but why do you want to make money off the poor people?' To Omidyar's mind, Yunus just didn't get it. This was about something far more important— Omidyar was proving a theory. To the New Yorker reporter, the eBay billionaire explained: 'Omidyar views the fund as a way of testing his theories about commercializing the sector. 'It's really the demonstration impact I'm looking for, primarily,' he said.' And so Omidyar tested his theory: plowing millions into India's SKS Microfinance via investments into murky microfinance outfit Unitus. In 2010, SKS Microfinance listed a $350 million IPO[88] that netted insiders and early investors like Unitus obscene profits. The murky, interlocking nonprofit/for-profit[89] structures ensured that only those on the inside knew whether Omidyar made money on his investment. The only sure thing was that the explosion of microfinance lending in the state of Andrah Pradesh, led by SKS Microfinance, wound up saddling the world's poorest and most vulnerable village women with debts they could not pay, causing a wave of suicides. An AP investigation[90] directly implicated Omidyar-funded SKS Microfinance agents in several suicides: One woman drank pesticide and died a day after an SKS loan agent told her to prostitute her daughters to pay off her debt. She had been given 150,000 rupees ($3,000) in loans but only made 600 rupees ($12) a week. Another SKS debt collector told a delinquent borrower to drown herself in a pond if she wanted her loan waived. The next day, she did. She left behind four children. One agent blocked a woman from bringing her young son, weak with diarrhea, to the hospital, demanding payment first. Other borrowers, who could not get any new loans until she paid, told her that if she wanted to die, they would bring her pesticide. An SKS staff member was there when she drank the poison. She survived. An 18-year-old girl, pressured until she handed over 150 rupees ($3) - meant for a school examination fee - also drank pesticide. She left a suicide note: 'Work hard and earn money. Do not take loans.' In all these cases, the report commissioned by SKS concluded that the company's staff was either directly or indirectly responsible. After the report, Omidyar Networkscrubbed SKS Microfinance from its website. An old cached webpage[91] shows Omidyar hailing SKS Microfinance for 'serving the rural poor in India' and claiming that the murky Unitus private equity fund's IPO 'exit strategy' will 'attract more capital to the market.' Instead, Unitus dissolved its microfinance NGO, a wave of resignations and murky millions moved hands, SKS Microfinance became a pariah, and Andhra Pradesh passed laws regulating microfinance institutions. A tiny handful of insiders and investors pocketed obscene millions, over 200 killed themselves, and entire Indian rural communities were devastated. Self-interest and profit motive did not create the greatest social good that Omidyar believed in; and yet, Omidyar Networkcontinues to expand its portfolio[92] of microfinance — or 'financial inclusion' — investments. eBay Shrugged 'Omidyar stopped talking about microfinance as a way to end world poverty, and instead described its mission in a way congruent with the eBay experience.' —New Yorker The key to understanding the enigmatic eBay billionaire and his many contradictions — an active participant in Washington's global empire on a scale unrivaled in publishing, while also founder of a quarter-billion dollar 'adversarial journalism' startup and privatizer of the Snowden NSA files, the largest cache of leaked national security secrets in US history — is understanding Omidyar's eBay-centric vision. Omidyar is a vision man[93], as his star employee Jeremy Scahill[94] constantly reminds us. And his vision was shaped, for understandable reasons, by his experience making ten billion dollars overnight off of eBay, which Omidyar believes is proof of a larger philosophical and moral structure at work, rather than a combination of smarts, luck, privilege… and other less savory factors. In 2000, Omidyar confided to his New York Times biographer, Adam Cohen, that he founded eBay to create a 'perfect market' after feeling cheated by the way tech IPOs in the early 1990s let insiders 'spin' IPOs for a quick profits before dumping them onto the market to regular investors — like the pre-eBayOmidyar. Cohen writes[95]: When 3DO announced plans to go public in May 1993, Omidyar placed an order for stock through his Charles Schwab brokerage account…. 3DO went public at $15 a share, but when Omidyar checked his account, he learned that the stock had soared 50 percent before his order had been filled…. it struck him that this was not how a free market was supposed to operate—favored buyers paying one price, and ordinary people getting the same stock moments later at a sizeable markup. Omidyar's solution was an online auction. Cohen, a member of the New York Times editorial board, found Omidyar's story convincing. There was only one problem: At the very time Omidyar spun this yarn to Cohen, Omidyar was under investigation[96] in the largest IPO stock spinning scandal in history. According to a House investigation, in return for giving Goldman Sachs the lucrative eBay IPO, the 'vampire squid'[97] bank set up private secret accounts for Omidyar and CEO Meg Whitman letting them spin dozens of tech IPOs before they went to market — ripping off both retail investors and startup investors. Omidyar settled a shareholder fraud lawsuit[98] in 2005 without admitting wrongdoing, ironic for a visionary who believes so deeply in accountability. More recently, Omidyar was subpoenaed[99] by a federal grand jury[100] criminal investigation[101] into his and other eBay executives' alleged roles in stealing Craigslist's 'secret sauce'[102] for eBay's profit. As grubby as Omidyar's might sound, it is in perfect keeping with his radical free-market ideology, an ideology that prioritizes self-interest[103] and the profit motive as the greatest engines for good in the world. Of course, the real Omidyar has little in common with the Omidyar of journalistic fairytales — the 'civic minded billionaire' and 'the billionaire exception' (Columbia Journalism Review[104]), whose 'commitment to the investigative form and an open society ' is so great, we 'should pray he lives a long and lucid life' (Reuters[105]) — or, the Omidyar that Pulitizer Prize winner Glenn Greenwald described to Amy Goodman[106]: '…if you look at Pierre's record of advocacy over the last several years….He would not start a new business in order to make money. He would only start a new business for some goal, some civic-minded goal.' Actually, the real Omidyar would never, on principle, start a new business, or pursue a civic-minded goal, without putting profit at the very center of the project. On principle — because in Omidyar's mind, no good could possibly come from defying the free markets. That is why he fought with Yunus over the principle of getting rich of the world's poorest people through microfinance. As the New Yorker explained it: 'EBay would be his template for the future. In 2004, he founded Omidyar Network, which makes for-profit investments as well as philanthropic donations, and as he began to search for vehicles with eBay-like properties he decided that microfinance was an amazing fit. Both eBay and microfinance allow people to discover that they can be entrepreneurs…. Both can be viewed as demonstrations of free-market principles. Both can be seen as businesses whose profitability is linked to their social impact. Omidyar stopped talking about microfinance as a way to end world poverty, and instead described its mission in a way congruent with the eBay experience.' It is impossible for us non-billionaires to grasp how profoundly Omidyar Network's 'philanthropy' is shaped by eBay/PayPal's corporate interests: his enthusiasm for microfinance to the world's poor is shaped by eBay, and even First Look media — which structurally[107] resembles Omidyar Network's murky profit/nonprofit pretzel — is turning out to be an eBay-vision-in-progress[108]. As with Omidyar's vision for self-supported microfinance as the best means for 'social impact,' Omidyar has made it clear he wants First Look to be 'self-supported' from the profits of First Look's 'technology company' that will 'develop new media tools for First Look properties.' Ebay — which gives people 'tools to pursue their goals,'[109] and whose 'vast scale' demonstrates 'business could also be an effective tool for social good' — is the model for Omidyar Network's philanthropy; and finally, the circle is closing as eBay transforms itself into a 'digital magazine of all things,' according to a former Omidyar[110] employee writing in the Atlantic[111]: eBay is hiring editors and long-form writers to help turn its site into a 'digital magazine,' according to president of eBay Marketplaces Devin Wenig[112]…. He wants eBay to be a retail-publisher, not a social network. 'We're now in the content business,' Wenig said. 'So, for the first time, eBay has a voice. We're telling stories. We have an editor. We have curators. And we have writers on-staff. You'll see that evolve to some longer-form stories, some really beautiful pictures… It's media-like.' Viewed through Omidyar's own lens, and through Omidyar's own words, the contradictions between the White House insider-Omidyar who works hand in glove with the national security state, and maverick publisher-Omidyar pledging to fight the national security state, aren't really contradictions. Because there is always one right answer whenever those two interests collide, one synthesis to that alleged dialectic: The interest of the shareholders is always right. Omidyar himself explained[113], in his own words, his eBaysian vision in the case of WikiLeaks, when he chose the self-interest of eBay/PayPal[114]'s shareholders — Omidyar being the number one shareholder — over everything, including the principle of protecting free speech and resisting government repression of WikiLeaks. In his PayPal-WikiLeaks editorial, Omidyar wrote[115]: Today, it appears, notification of a criminal investigation is enough to force businesses whose cause is not the First Amendment to cut off a publisher the way Amazon, PayPal, Visa and Mastercard each have done WikiLeaks. (Disclosure: Civil Beat Publisher Pierre Omidyar is chairman of eBay, which owns PayPal.) Unlike the press barons of old, the executives of these businesses cannot tell their shareholders that it will hurt their company more to cave on a matter of principle than to drop a customer. It is their right and common practice to shut a customer down when they receive complaints from criminal investigators, even without a court order. This even though the existence of a criminal investigation is no indication of guilt. The executives have a fiduciary duty to do what's best for their shareholders. And if they didn't respond to government warnings, they very well could risk their own business being shut down. There is no doubt, and no difference between the Omidyar who argued with Nobel Peace Prize winner Yunnus about the need to profit off the world's poorest borrowers; or the Omidyar who pursued the self-interest of eBay's shareholders over less valuable principles like freedom of expression; or the Omidyar who chooses to collaborate with USAID in Ukraine, or violent ultranationalists in India whose policies could help eBay's bottom line. The contradictions exist only in the minds of those who hope and dream of a different Omidyar, an Omidyar of liberal fairytales.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5X81-BV41-JCMN-Y4YC-00000-00eBay, Stripe, Mastercard, and Visa leave Facebook's Libra Association2019-10-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:41ZLexisNexiseBay, Stripe, Mastercard, and Visa leave Facebook's Libra AssociationReuters

Oct 12, 2019( VentureBeat: http://venturebeat.com/ Delivered by Newstex) (Reuters) — Facebook's ambitious efforts to establish a global digital currency called Libra[1] suffered severe setbacks on Friday, as major payment companies including Mastercard and Visa quit the group behind the project. The two companies announced they would leave the association Friday afternoon, as did eBay, Stripe, and Latin American payments company Mercado Pago. They join PayPal which exited the group a week ago[2], as global regulators continue to air concerns about the project[3]. The latest exodus leaves the Libra Association without any remaining major payments companies as members, meaning it can no longer count on a global player to help consumers turn their currency into Libra and facilitate transactions.

The remaining association members, including Lyft and Vodafone, consist mainly of venture capital, telecommunications, blockchain and technology companies, as well as nonprofit groups. 'Visa has decided not to join the Libra Association at this time,' the company said in a statement. 'We will continue to evaluate and our ultimate decision will be determined by a number of factors, including the Association's ability to fully satisfy all requisite regulatory expectations.' Facebook's head of the project, former PayPal executive David Marcus, cautioned on Twitter against 'reading the fate of Libra into this update,' although he acknowledged 'it's not great news in the short term.' Libra will press ahead with plans to formally charter the association in three days despite the setbacks, Dante Disparte, its head of policy and communication, said in a statement. 'We are focused on moving forward and continuing to build a strong association of some of the world's leading enterprises, social impact organizations and other stakeholders,' he said. 'Although the makeup of the Association members may grow and change over time, the design principle of Libra's governance and technology, along with the open nature of this project ensures the Libra payment network will remain resilient.' Facebook announced plans to launch the digital currency in June 2020 in partnership with other Libra Association members. Almost immediately afterwards, the project faced relentless scrutiny from global regulators, who said it raised a host of serious questions that the group had yet to answer. France and Germany last month pledged to block Libra[4] from operating in Europe and backed the development of a public cryptocurrency instead. And U.S. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell suggested the project could not advance before addressing serious privacy, money laundering, consumer protection and financial stability concerns that must be addressed. The rapid succession of exits by major financial companies Friday afternoon suggested that scrutiny was taking its toll. Three days earlier, a pair of senior Democratic senators wrote to Visa, Mastercard, and Stripe, telling them to be wary of 'a project that will forseeably fuel the growth in global criminal activity.' 'If you take this on, you can expect a high level of scrutiny from regulators not only on Libra-related payment activities, but on all activities,' Senator Sherrod Brown and fellow Democratic Senator Brian Schatz wrote in the letters. Brown said in a statement after the announcements on Friday that the companies had been 'wise to avoid legitimizing Facebook's private, global currency.' Facebook Chief Executive Mark Zuckerberg is scheduled to discuss the project when he testifies before the U.S. House Financial Services Committee on October 23. U.S. Representative Maxine Waters, who chairs the panel, has repeatedly called on Facebook to shelve the project. [ 1]: https://venturebeat.com/2019/06/18/facebook-announces-libra-cryptocurrency-and-calibra-digital-wallet/ [ 2]:   https://venturebeat.com/2019/10/04/paypal-becomes-first-member-to-leave-facebooks-libra-association/ [ 3]:   https://venturebeat.com/2019/07/15/u-s-proposes-barring-facebook-and-other-big-tech-firms-from-offering-financial-services/ [ 4]:   https://venturebeat.com/2019/09/12/france-seeks-facebook-libra-cryptocurrency-ban-europe/

urn:contentItem:5SH4-FPC1-J9XT-P2S8-00000-00EBF CEO Wim Mijs: â€œEurope needs banking technologyâ€2018-06-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:41ZLexisNexisEBF CEO Wim Mijs: â€œEurope needs banking technologyâ€


Brussels: European Banking Federation has issued the following press release:
At the EBF Fintech Cocktail organised on Monday 4 June in the context of Money 2020, European fintech innovators gathered for an informal evening in the centre of Amsterdam. In a brief welcome word, EBF CEO Wim Mijs emphasised the need for European reinforcement in the fintech space.


[CHECK AGAINST DELIVERY]
Good evening ladies & gentlemen,
Welcome in Amsterdam, welcome to the EBF Fintech Cocktail.
My name is Wim Mijs and I am the CEO of the European Banking Federation.
Many of you already know what the EBF does. But for those who don’t;
The EBF represents the interests of the European banking sector, trying to keep financial regulation fresh, efficient and above all: We need regulation that is future-proof.
We do this from Brussels, where most EU policy & regulation is being produced and many EU institutions are seated. And Frankfurt, home of the European Central Bank and the centre of the Single Supervisory Mechanism and the Euro system.
The technology revolution makes our work really exciting, because not only business is undergoing enormous change, the regulatory mindset is also shifting. This year alone, Europe gave birth to two major rules, PSD2 and GDPR.
And this is only the beginning, policy makers and regulators are finally sinking their teeth into technology and acknowledging the importance of the financial sector to innovate and grow.
In March, the European Commission came up with the European Fintech Action Plan. I like the word Action in this context. Because that is exactly what we need, with an overclock speed.
In the Action Plan there is a clear focus on strengthening cybersecurity and technologies like blockchain and artificial intelligence have got their own observatories. The European Central Bank has made its guidelines for new bank licenses and the European Banking Authority is assessing closely the interactions between fintech activity and national regulators in its Fintech Roadmap. But we need more than just observation.
Time for action indeed. We are a long-time supporter of an EU-wide framework of experimentation, also know as a fintech sandbox. This will not only benefit the market knowledge of authorities but eventually accelerate the cross-border nature of fintech business cases.
But fintech as we see it, is not the first innovation that is disrupting the world of money and certainly not the last. This time though, the speed of it all is incredible.
What we really are talking about here, at Money 2020 during the Amsterdam Fintech Week, is banking technology.
And also, we are within a stone’s throw, a few hundred meters in that direction, from the very first public stock exchange in the world, where traders gathered to sell their stocks of the East India Company.
Due diligence was done from door to door. Compliance was handwritten and required several pair of eyes. Transparency and trust were as important back then as they are now.
The tools of the trade just look a bit different.
There was no MiFiD 2 back then, but financial activity never was unregulated. Rules were increased every time someone tried out a trick and changed when it did not work. Tricks that still tend to happen, leading to losses and even crises.
It all has led to the current rules that are in place. Rules that will always require thorough review, by government and by the market.
Now regulation needs to be applicable in the digital age. Since banks will not the only ones doing banking.
Big tech and big data companies are emerging and leaving their marks in many industries, even in our social doings. Data awareness is growing, GPDR is a good start.
But when playing the same game, you stick to the same rules. The sector needs competition, banks even like competition. But it must be fair. Banks exchange data with third parties, but not the other way around.
Neither finance was a one man’s job, there was always a need to broaden horizons, looking at new ways of working together, merging, consolidating.
It is what led to the capital markets and banking unions of this world. It is what is happening between banks and start-ups. The models of collaboration are endless.
Are you wondering how the bank of the future looks like? Ask yourself how the human behind that bank will look like. Because it also makes sense to think about the people interacting with financial services; employees, consumers, clients. They are the ones feeling the impact, they have to make the decisions in a complex environment. That’s why education, financial literacy and consumer protection has become more so important in the digital age and cannot be ignored. That’s why it has become part of our work as well.
In a politically challenged Europe, the need to strengthen the single market is crucial to stay ahead.
And as we all know, technology is a big part of the answer.
Digitally driven and cross-border financial services are essential to keep up trade and economic growth.
While accelerating the digital transformation, we should continue to pursue true European goals, because the world around us has not stopped to move forward.
Let’s do this together. Thank you for coming, and don’t forget to stay in touch with the EBF.
Media contact:
Nahuel Mercedes, Communications Officer, +32 2 508 37 48, n.mercedes@ebf.eu
About the EBF:
The European Banking Federation is the voice of the European banking sector, brining together 32 national banking associations in Europe that together represent some 3,500 banks – large and small, wholesale and retail, local and international – employing approximately two million people. EBF members represent banks that make available loans to the European economy in excess of €20 trillion and that securely handle more than 400 million payment transactions per day. Launched in 1960, the EBF is committed to creating a single market for financial services in the European Union and to supporting policies that foster economic growth.
