Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XCX-5PV1-JB20-G429-00000-00Economic Data out Today; Boeing CEO before Congress; The American Economy; General Electric Releases Q3 Numbers; Fires Rage in California; U.S.-China Trade2019-10-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:41ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA6:00 AM ESTLee Carter, Omeed Malik, Kevin O'Leary, Peter Andersen, Lee Smith, Lauren Stephens, Kaki McGrathNEWSInternational103001cb.231Economic Data out Today; Boeing CEO before Congress; The American Economy; General Electric Releases Q3 Numbers; Fires Rage in California; U.S.-China TradeMaria Bartiromo, Lauren Simonetti, Claudia Cowan

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN ANCHOR: A lot today. All of that coming up.

Markets this morning look like this ahead of all of that. We are looking at a fractional move this morning. Dow Industrial down about 11 points, the S&P down one and the Nasdaq down just a fraction.

Then this, the World Series headed to a decisive game seven. Washington pulling out another win last night on the road. The game full of excitement and controversy. We've got all the highlights right here.

MORNINGS WITH MARIA begins right now.

We've got a big show this morning. Joining the conversation, Farvahar Partners founder and CEO Omeed Malik back with us, pollster and the president of Maslansky and Partners Lee Carter is here, and the chairman of O'Shares ETF's and entrepreneur Kevin O'Leary.

Great to have everybody this morning. Welcome.

KEVIN O'LEARY, CHAIRMAN AND ENTREPRENEUR, O'SHARES ETF'S: Thank you very much.

BARTIROMO: Good to see you. A lot to talk about.

We've got a lot of economic data out this morning. We have GDP. You've got, of course, the ADP. A whole alphabet of numbers. And, of course, it's the economy that is front and center in the 2020 election, right, Lee?

LEE CARTER, POLLSTER AND PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY AND PARTNERS: Yes, there's no question about it. I think that a lot of people are talking about how the economy is what's giving and the president so much cover right now with everything that, you know, is going on. And I think that Democrats really have to be careful about how they treat this because this is an issue that the American people find dear to their hearts. It's their pocketbooks. People are feeling good. A lot of economic data that is in favor of the president right now.

BARTIROMO: I'll tell you, if there's one person that is coming across, as well as anybody opposite the president, would be Tulsi Gabbard. And I know you are a big supporter of Tulsi Gabbard, Omeed. Does she look at the economy as a driving force? Is that part of her platform as well?

OMEED MALIK, FOUNDER AND CEO, FARVAHAR PARTNERS: There's no doubt about it. But the way he get -- she gets there is a little different. She starts with foreign policy and says the premise is, we've wasted $6 trillion over 18 years on regime change wars, we've got a trillion dollar deficit, but six times that have gone to wars that haven't made us safer. So what can we do with money like that to put in the pockets of the American people and do some of the programs people say we don't have the money for. So she absolutely thinks the economy's important, but she's starting from foreign policy and backing into it.

BARTIROMO: Yes, and she comes across really well in that. I'll tell you, it's hard for the group of Democrats to even touch the economy because it's so vibrant right now. They don't -- they don't want to go there, Kevin. I mean look at the start-up situation, look at the valuations in the private market.

O'LEARY: I try and, you know, forget about the circus in Washington because I look at it through the lens of an investors, and I simply look at this. In the history of modern times in politics, there's never been a president that loses their mandate when you're at full employment. Regardless of impeachment or circus or anything else, this president's policies have driven the economy through dynamics I haven't seen in my whole investment like.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

O'LEARY: And so I'm looking at it through the lens of an investment in private companies and foreign. While we're under 4 percent unemployment, the chance that he loses a second mandate, in my view, is zero. Whether you like him or you don't.

BARTIROMO: Yes, because of the economic story.

MALIK: Yes, I --

BARTIROMO: And, of course, you're also in the private market all the time.

MALIK: Absolutely. And I -- and I echo Kevin. We know each other. And so I couldn't agree more.

What I would say is, the Democrats are going to try to make this about Trump the individual, not the economy.

BARTIROMO: That's right.

MALIK: They tried that in 2016. It failed. Let's see if they try it again.

CARTER: I think Elizabeth Warren is trying to do something a little bit different with the economic story, though. She's trying to exploit this idea of wealth inequality. She's not saying the economy's not good, she's saying that the economy's not working for everyone. And that's the story that she's really -- you know, and she's tried a number of different messages a long time, but that is the one that she's going with right now.

BARTIROMO: Meanwhile, GE is just hitting the tape. General Electric earnings looks like it's beating estimates on the top line. The stock is at $9.37. Bottom line right here -- beating on the bottom line, pardon me, beating on the bottom line here. Earnings are better than expected at 15 cents a share.

We're going to Lauren right here. The stock is already trading up, up two and a third percent on GE. We've got the earnings at 15 cents a share versus an estimate of 11 cents a share. We are just getting the revenue out as well, which also actually looks better than expected. But we're watching the stock move as these numbers are hitting the tape.

And this, of course, is -- is one of the -- at one point was the metric to look at for the overall economy. It's just not the case anymore, is it?

O'LEARY: I think GE is actually a crime scene, that's the way I look at it. I don't think the equity has any value. I know that's controversial to say that. If I was going to buy this thing, I'd buy the debt because I can never figure out the balance sheet. I'm a balance sheet guy. It's so confusing. That's why it's been dead money for so long.

And, look, I admire the new admin to come through and try and fix it, but the balance sheet is horrific. You can't understand it. And so if you're going to take a chance, buy some debt. It will probably convert to equity before this whole horror story is over.

BARTIROMO: Even -- even after all the asset sales, you still feel that the balance sheet is confusing for you?

O'LEARY: Very. And I can't find an analyst who can really drill into it and say, let's go long this equity. There's so many opportunities in the market. And $8 to $9 is where it's been forever. It's dead money.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

Omeed.

MALIK: It's a capital structure issue, I agree. I think the debt is something to look at. They are pretty high levered as well. More than they'd like to be. So this is a company, if you're not comfortable going in and analyzing the capital structure, you should stay away from it as a retail investor.

BARTIROMO: And yet the stock is trading up on this beat. I mean are the expectations so low in terms of what they can achieve right now that, you know, that any win is going to be bid up?

O'LEARY: You know, I don't know. They beat. And you're getting 2 percent. You're being rewarded 2 percent. And the stock has never moved much past here during this whole controversy.

I just look at it and say, you know, it's really an option. The equity's an option that this management team can fix it over the next three years. But why take that risk when there's so many other companies doing so well with free cash flows you can actually look at, analyze their income statement and their balance sheet. This is -- this is like going to Las Vegas, buying this equity.

BARTIROMO: All right. The company is also raising -- raising some guidance here. And maybe that's what's pumping up the stock. We'll keep watching GE shares on this beat and its pretty active this morning and moving up 2.5 percent on General Electric.

Meanwhile, Boeing is on the hot seat once again this morning. CEO Dennis Muilenburg facing critical questions from lawmakers yesterday over the 737 Max jet. Concerns that employees had had about the now grounded aircraft. Muilenburg apologizing to the families of the crash victims before being slammed by members of the Senate Commerce Committee yesterday. Most notably Texas Senator Ted Cruz.

Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. TED CRUZ (R-TX): Look, I practiced law a lot of years. You had your lawyers look over this document and they read a senior leader after these crashes had occurred saying they lied to the regulators.

Mr. Muilenburg, how in the hell did nobody bring this to your attention in February when you produced this to the Department of Justice? How did you just read this a couple of weeks ago?

You're the CEO. The buck stops with you. Did you read this document and how did your team not put it in front of you, run in with their hair on fire, saying we've got a real problem here? How did that not happen and what does that say about the culture at Boeing if they didn't give it to you and you didn't read it and if you didn't say, I want to read and see what happened.

Your testimony here earlier here today is, well, we're not sure what they were talking about because he's not at Boeing anymore. How did you not, in February, set out a nine alarm fire to say, we need to figure out exactly what happened, not after all the hearings, not after the pressure, but because 346 people have died and we don't want another person to die.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: All right, Lee Carter, your reaction.

CARTER: Yes, you know, I think one of the most important things when a CEO is in this position and they apologize is that they really address the issue at hand. I think his apology was weak at best. I think Ted Cruz really got the best of him. And everything that he responded from that point forward seemed like it was so over wrought with legalese. There wasn't emotion. He didn't really seem to get what was at stake. He didn't really seem to acknowledge the concerns that we all have.

People are afraid. And the buck does stop with him. And I don't think he did -- I don't think he did the best job that he could have going in there. I mean it was an impossible situation for him to face, but you've got to go in there, acknowledge concerns, and talk about all of the actions, all of the things that you're doing to make sure that people are safe now, because there's -- people are afraid.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

CARTER: And this is his business. This is his future. This is -- I think he did not do a good job.

BARTIROMO: You know, I tell you, they are being really adamant about getting the 737 back in the air in the fourth quarter. So in order to do that by year-end, you're going to need some conviction here and probably more pushback if, you know, you know, if, in fact, they are going to get that plane back up in the air.

What do you think, Omeed?

MALIK: I definitely don't see it coming back this year.

BARTIROMO: You don't?

MALIK: I think first quarter is their best case.

BARTIROMO: But the company did say year end, right?

MALIK: Yes, they have said that, but a lot of the people that follow it don't think that's going to happen because it's a regulatory issue. The FAA and other regulatory lawyers are going to have to approve that. It's not up to just them.

I would say there's a human tragedy here. He failed the test, as you suggested.

CARTER: Yes, absolutely.

MALIK: He's also worried about his personal liability when he goes out there. So he has to balance that.

BARTIROMO: That's true.

CARTER: Well, this is --

MALIK: With that said, this is a duopoly, so it's either Airbus or them. So I think ultimately analysts are thinking this -- this stock will make a comeback.

CARTER: I mean I think that everybody looks out there and says there's a legal risk, right, and so I have to be so careful because that's a financial risk to the company. What they don't understand is that there's a communication risk for the company when you don't get this right, when he doesn't go out there and really show the emotion, that he doesn't really say that I get the tragedy, I get the lives impacted and this will never happened.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

CARTER: And here's what we're doing to address it. He just failed that test. And I think that's going to have a financial impact on him and the company.

BARTIROMO: Real quick, we want to get to earnings.

O'LEARY: The market just wants the answer to one question, is this a structural fix or a software fix? The reason the stock is so bullet proof is everybody assumes that it's a software fix and it will be resolved in Q1. If it's a structural change that's required, the stock's 250 (ph). So it's going to be a really interesting -- and right now 99 percent of people that look at this say oh it's a software fix.

BARTIROMO: OK.

O'LEARY: But, if, at the end of the day it's structural, yikes.

BARTIROMO: A lot of other earnings that we need to talk about rolling on this morning in the third quarter. We've got FaceBook and Apple reporting after the bell tonight. As you see, those stocks are fractionally up this morning.

Other big names. You just heard General Electric. You've got Lyft and Starbucks releasing their quarterly numbers this morning. So far it feels like to third quarter, Kevin, has been better than feared? Would you agree with that?

O'LEARY: Yes. I'm loving these earnings. You know, we have a fantastic economy going on here. Domestically it's on fire and internationally it's starting to look like it could be in a recovery mode. And if there's a trade deal, this market will not stop. And that's why it's been bullet proof. People are thinking phase one looks good. If it gets signed in the next 60 days it will mean phase two will be sometime next year.

BARTIROMO: Yes, we'll see about that China deal. We feel -- feel like we're following the bouncing ball, but there definitely is optimism on both sides in terms of wanting to get a deal done. It's supposed to be signed at APEC on November 17th.

Check futures this morning. We've got a market that is searching for direction a bit this morning, but in the negative column. Dow Industrials down 9 points. We've got the S&P down one point and the Nasdaq down three quarters of a point.

Of course, we are wrapping up a two-day Federal Reserve meeting today. It is day two of the Central Bank's meeting where we are expecting a cut in interest rates for the third time this year, 25 basis points.

We are also waiting on the GDP. This is the third quarter GDP out. It is out in two hours' time. Estimates call for growth in the GDP of 1.6 percent. Now that is way down from what we saw earlier in the year, of course, on GDP. What's your expectation?

I know this is sometimes a backward looking number, Omeed, but I feel like the GDP is an important barometer.

MALIK: It is also for confidence. I mean it's starting to come in a bit. I mean we did have the tax reform that obviously juiced the economy, but now you've got issues that are being weighed down that the Fed acknowledges on a global scale, mostly based on manufacturing.

I still think the growth is there. I tend to agree with Kevin, I think the economy is generally strong. Let's wait a few more quarters before we run to any extreme conclusions. But by in large, I still think it's a positive story, but things are coming in a bit amongst almost every metric. So, yes.

BARTIROMO: Do you worry, Kevin, that CapEx has slowed down quite a bit? I mean it's the consumer that's showing real strength with this uncertainty, whether it be USMCA, China deal. Managers have begun to sit on cash. Maybe not for technology spending, but for other spending.

O'LEARY: Yes, no, there has been a slowdown in manufacturing. That's evident. But, you know, it's the consumer carrying the economy, 70 percent of it.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

O'LEARY: This number, this data set on a single basis is not enough to be concerned about. I think we'll still end up somewhere in the 1.8, 1.9, maybe 2, averaging out over 12 months. But it's not a slowdown -- it's not a signal of recession yet, which is why the market remains bullet proof.

BARTIROMO: All right, we will take a look at the GE numbers.

Let's dig deeper into this report because it is better than expected, both on the earnings and revenue line, and the stock is on the move.

Lauren Simonetti with the numbers and the analysis now.

Lauren.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Yes. On the move big time, jumping 5.4 percent right here in the premarket. For perspective, for the quarter that just wrapped for GE, the stock is down 15 percent. But we've got a double beat, as you noted, Maria, beating on the bottom line by three cents a share, earnings coming in at 15 cents. Revenue just shy of $23.4 billion. Also stronger than expected.

Larry Culp now at the helm of GE for a year and he said this in the press release and this might be what's moving the stock. We are raising our industrial free cash flow outlook again, even with external headwinds from the 737 Max and tariffs. (INAUDIBLE) second quarter GE burned through a billion dollars in cash. It looks better going forward. He made those comments.

And also GE makes the engine for this troubled 737 Max jet. So the company is saying that they're optimistic with the negative news in the backdrop.

One other piece of negative news is, it's an industrial company and you have two quarters of contracting manufacturing sector, Maria.

BARTIROMO: All right, Lauren, thank you.

The stock still, nonetheless, is up this morning.

We're going to take a short break.

When we come back, California in flames. Crews are scrambling on contain this massive Getty Fire, as officials determine the cause this morning. We are taking a look there and we will take you there live.

Plus, down to the wire. The Washington Nationals forcing a game seven in the World Series. We're back with some details on that.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

The massive Getty Fire in Los Angeles sparked by a tree branch falling on power lines. The area now under its first ever extreme red flag warning. Fierce winds intensifying up and down the state threatening new power outages in the north.

That's where we find Fox News senior correspondent Claudia Cowan. She's live in Santa Rosa this morning.

Claudia, good morning to you.

CLAUDIA COWAN, FOX NEWS SENIOR CORRESPONDENT: Good morning to you, Maria.

That's right, we are in a critical window right now with this latest wind event. The winds really have not picked up yet but expected gusts of 60, 70 miles an hour will challenge firefighters on the line working to hold the containment number and keep hot embers from flying, speaking new fires.

As you mentioned, extreme fire dangers consist -- continue to exist down in Los Angeles where crews on the 650 acre Getty Fire are mopping up hot spots and making sure that smoldering blaze doesn't roar back to life.

Surveillance video shows the moment it started early Monday morning when high winds blew a branch into a power line.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: This was, simply put, in plain parlance, an act of God, that the wind broke off a tree branch, threw that tree branch because of these strong winds far enough to cause a spark off a line that is still intact there, but you can see a little bit of the damage on it. Most likely caused those sparks to fall and begin this fire. And then we were off to the races.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

COWAN: Utility companies have been turning off the power to prevent these kinds of fires. But in northern California, another round of blackouts has people fed up. Some have been without electricity since Saturday and are having to search for places to charge their phones, get gas, buy food and ice. Many businesses without generators have had to close, creating hardships across the board.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Everybody's losing money. The companies are losing money. The employees are losing money. And so it's not a good situation for anybody.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

COWAN: Yes, and it's a safety issue too because some cell towers are out of power and that has many residents' concerns that they might not get their text messages warning them that they need to evacuate if this fire continues to grow. It has now grown to more than 76,000 acres and is just 15 percent contained one week after it started, Maria. And in the meantime, hundreds of thousands of people are still under mandatory evacuation orders, both here and in southern California as well.

Back to you.

BARTIROMO: What a shame really.

Claudia, thank you. We will get back to you as more news develops.

Coming up, ridesharing rivals teaming up. Uber and Lyft banning together, fighting California's new labor laws. Wait until you hear this.

And then Fed in focus. Investors are waiting on the Central Bank's decision today as new uncertainty over China trade moves markets this morning. We're going to preview the Fed meeting when we come right back.

Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: All right, we've got a busy day for markets this morning. We're looking at earnings. We've got the Federal Reserve decision on interest rates, which we'll get at 2:00 this afternoon. And this morning we get the first look at third quarter GDP.

Futures this morning ahead of all of that are negative, fractionally speaking. Dow Industrials down just 7 points. The S&P is flat, down 1 point. And the Nasdaq down three quarters of one point.

We're getting new reports that the trade agreement between the U.S. and China might not be completed in time for next month's meeting between President Trump and President Xi Jinping in Chile (ph).

Joining us right now is Andersen Capital Management Peter Andersen.

Good to see you, Peter. Thanks very much for being here.

PETER ANDERSEN, ANDERSEN CAPITAL MANAGEMENT: You're welcome.

BARTIROMO: So with all of that as your backdrop in terms of the economic story, we'll get another look at GDP today and this China story that seems to change by the day, how do you want to allocate capital?

ANDERSEN: Well, you know, I think that the China trade situation will eventually resolve. And when it does, the market, I think, is acting like a coiled spring right now, Maria. I think that when that gets resolved, we will have earnings growth, tremendous earnings growth, frankly, and continued hiring. You know, we have full employment now, but imagine if we do have a resolved China dispute how much more enthusiastic U.S. companies can become.

MALIK: Yes, just turning for a moment to USMCA that Maria had mentioned in passing, what do you think that impact is going to have on the markets if that does, in fact, get passed? I was on The Hill yesterday and most Democrats I spoke to said, while their farmers in their constituencies love it, the unions are against it. So, one, how do you kind of handicap the passage of the USMCA and, two, what impact, if any, does it have if it does get passed or doesn't get passed?

ANDERSEN: Well, I'm on the side of, I think it will get passed because even though the unions do have power, I think the logical thing to do is to pass that bill. And when that does pass, I think, as I was saying before, employment, more capital expenditures that will fuel even more growth in this country, as unbelievable as it seems, because right now I think we're doing exceptionally well and, you know, the Fed is wrestling, frankly, with, can we do any better? And I think many companies are on hold because they're just waiting for that coiled spring to unleash, which will be when the China trade situation does get resolved.

O'LEARY: Peter, let me ask you a question about that coiled spring. What matters most for S&P companies, and certainly small companies doing businesses in China is two things, IP (ph) protection, which we don't have in phase one, and access to their growing middle class market, which we don't have in phase one.

What's your handicap on when we actually get the meat of the deal? How long is it going to take to get those two things, because that's where I'm going to get growth explosion in earnings?

ANDERSEN: Right. Right. And, you know, when this was first announced, this whole issue with China trade, I think we were all to optimistic thinking it was going to be solved, frankly, overnight. But, you know, negotiating with China, it takes more than just jumping on an airplane, right, and reading the brochure about their culture. So I'm actually handicapping this to go well into 2020. But I'm not losing the optimism because it makes logical sense for both sides to work out a mutually agreeable arrangement.

BARTIROMO: Yes, we'll see if they can get that enforcement mechanism in there. That's the key right now. They need to have some kind of an enforcement mechanism to ensure that China doesn't break all its promises, like it's done umpteen times in the past.

And I understand that is what they're negotiating right now. And they are negotiating in for phase one in terms of getting that enforcement action in there.

On USMCA, increasingly I'm hearing positive things. Even -- even Democrats -- we had Henry Culler (ph) on the other day who said we will -- this is his quote, we will pass it this year. So we'll see.

Earnings, meanwhile, grow long this morning. Apple and FaceBook will report earnings after the bell today. Analysts expect Apple to report earnings of $2.84 a share, revenue of more than $62 billion in the fiscal fourth quarter.

FaceBook, meanwhile, expected to report earnings of $1.91, revenue of more than $17 billion.

Peter, what would you do with these stocks right here, given the valuations, given the expectations of potential more scrutiny from Washington on big tech? How do you want to invest around these stocks?

ANDERSEN: Well, you know, Maria, I have never owned either one of those stocks and I continue to stay away from them. I think there are more opportunities.

But let me just say a couple of things about Apple, for instance.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ANDERSEN: I mean I jokingly say that, you know, they haven't created 11 phones, they've created the same phone 11 times. And the reason I joke about that is, you know, the details, they're just add-ons.

BARTIROMO: Oh, I see. Yes, OK.

ANDERSEN: And I think it's a mature market. I think it's a mature market and I think that they really do have to come up with something very creative and I'm on the sidelines particularly because of the TV elements that they're watching. I mean that's very, very high risk.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ANDERSEN: Who knows how that -- how can you even model the success of something like that? So I stay away from Apple.

And, FaceBook, as you said, I think the regulatory actions are very, very scary and who knows how those are going to turn out. And those, again, they're difficult to model. As a portfolio manager, you like to pick stocks that you can have a pretty good sense --

BARTIROMO: Right.

ANDERSEN: Of the handicap of whether or not it's going to go up or down. And those two stocks, I think at best, are going to move sideways.

BARTIROMO: Well, tell that to the investors who bid up Apple to above a trillion dollars in market value.

ANDERSEN: I know.

BARTIROMO: Look, we've got the October job's report due out on Friday. The economy is expected to have added 85,000 jobs to the economy in the month of October with the unemployment rate rising to 3.6 percent.

But I think you'd all agree that this has some -- lots of noise in it because you've got the GM strike, the Boeing situation in terms of the Airbus -- I'm sorry, the Boeing situation in terms of the 737.

Is it -- is this a concern that job growth is slowing to this number or do you think there's too much noise in it.

Real quick.

O'LEARY: Single data set. Too much noise. Doesn't change the outlook. We're still going to go into next year well under 4 percent unemployment. The economy's on fire. There's no other way to describe it.

BARTIROMO: All right, Peter, it's great to get your insights this morning. Thank you so much, sir.

ANDERSEN: You're welcome.

BARTIROMO: Peter Anderson.

Fox Business will carry today's Federal Reserve decision live at 2:00 p.m. Eastern. Join us for that.

Make sure you join us Friday, starting at 8:00 a.m. Our coverage of the October job's report. All hands on deck. Job's Friday. We love job's Friday.

All right, a quick break, though.

Meanwhile, setting the scope. House Democrats unveiling a resolution on the impeachment inquiry, giving Congressman Adam Schiff the power to make key decisions. We're taking a closer look at that.

Plus, the origins of the Russia probe. We are talking with the author Lee Smith coming up.

Then, the World Series going to game seven, not without controversy. We're taking a look at what happened last night straight ahead. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Good Wednesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining me. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Wednesday, October 30th.

Your top stories right now, 6:33 a.m. on the East Coast.

Countdown to the Federal Reserve decision. Investors are expecting a rate cut today from the Central Bank. That would be the third cut this year. We're also getting a look at the state of the economy when we get the GDP number for the third quarter at 8:30 a.m. Eastern. Join us for that. We've got a lot going on.

Meanwhile, in the face of all of that, earning season rolling on this morning. General Electric out with a double beat. CEO Larry Culp says that he remains confident it will unlock value for GE stakeholders as their transformation accelerates. Look at this stock, accelerating as we speak. It is up better than 7 percent right now on GE.

Markets, though, look like this. More of a flat situation for the broader averages. Dow Industrials down 10 points, the S&P 500 down one and the Nasdaq down 3 quarters of 1 percent.

The S&P hit a new intraday high yesterday before retreating and snapping a four-day winning streak. The Dow and the Nasdaq also finished slightly lower yesterday. The DowIndustrials were down 19 points at the close yesterday. The S&P was down two and the Nasdaq down 49.

Global markets this morning look like this. The European indices are mixed. The FT 100 down five, CAC quarante in Paris up 12, and the DAX index in Germany lower by 24.

In Asia overnight, markets were lower across the board. It was really on some reports that the U.S.-China trade deal might not be read to actually be signed in Chile next month. We'll see about that. There are wide expectations that the two get together on November 17th, but we are following the bouncing ball of what happens with this China deal. Obviously the two sides are in talks and there are more talks scheduled for this week.

Our top story this half an hour, the impeachment inquiry and the origins of the Russia probe. House Democrats are outlining the next steps for impeachment as House Intel Committee Chairman Adam Schiff is being accused of blocking an impeachment witness from answering questions from Republicans. Congressman Devin Nunes and House Minority Whip Steve Scalise were inside the hearing on Capitol Hill. Here's what they had to say?

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. DEVIN NUNES (R-CA): To coach the witness to decide whether or not what -- what we're going to be able to ask the witness. I mean we don't even get any witnesses at this point and it doesn't like -- look like we're going to get any ever. But to not let us ask questions, I've -- I've never ever had that. And to see someone coach a witness, you know, this isn't the first time that Schiff -- you know, Schiff's very good at coaching witnesses. Remember, he also met with the whistleblower. So this is -- this is just unprecedented.

STEVE SCALISE (R-LA): Joe Biden himself bragged about it. He said he flew over there and he told them that in six hours he's leaving with the billion dollars of our money, taxpayer money, if they don't fire the guy that's looking into his son. I mean, my goodness, if that's not a quid pro quo, I don't know what is. But, of course, that's why the Democrats want to throw up all these smoke screens. They don't want you to look over there.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The House plans to hold a vote tomorrow, not on impeachment but on the resolution and the parameters for moving the impeachment process forward.

Joining me right now is the author of the new book on the best seller list, "The Plot Against the President: The True Story of How Congressman Devin Nunes Uncovered the Biggest Political Scandal in U.S. History," the author, Lee Smith, is joining us right now.

Lee, it's great to have you. Congratulations on the book.

LEE SMITH, AUTHOR, "THE PLOT AGAINST THE PRESIDENT": Thank you. Thanks very much, Maria.

BARTIROMO: So let me start with the impeachment process.

SMITH: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Because I think our audience knows how I feel about what went on in 2016 --

SMITH: Yes.

BARTIROMO: As I've talked about it a lot in these last three years.

SMITH: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Do you connect any dots with the fact that they are trying hard to come up with something against President Trump right now --

SMITH: Yes.

BARTIROMO: And completely ignoring what we already know was some wrongdoing by some key players in our intel agencies back in the election year in 2016?

SMITH: Absolutely. Here's how I see what we're calling the impeachment process, inquiry. I see it as a secret ritual conducted by a cult. I mean they're doing most of this in secret. And -- and I think it's worthwhile thinking that Speaker Pelosi, as the high priestess of the cult, and Adam Schiff as a high priest of the cult, and the purpose of the cult is to protect the swamp. The swamp and what the swamp has done. And President Trump was sent by the American voter to drain the swamp yet it's the role of Madame Pelosi and Mr. Schiff to protect the swamp. The -- what they're talk about impeachment is ridiculous. It has no -- bears no connection to reality, just as Russia-gate. There's no connection to reality.

BARTIROMO: So just like Steve Scalise just said, you know, look over here, nothing to see over here --

SMITH: Right.

BARTIROMO: Because we know that William Barr is now conducting a serious investigation into the origins of the Russia probe --

SMITH: Right.

BARTIROMO: As is John Durham. Former National Security Adviser Michael Flynn now says that the FBI manipulated his 2017 interview.

SMITH: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Your new book, "The Plot Against the President," says that this was part of a, quote, multifaceted criminal conspiracy to destroy Flynn even before he joined the president's legal team.

Take us back to what happened with General Flynn because he was actually the first person of anybody tied to Donald Trump to be surveilled.

SMITH: Right.

BARTIROMO: I mean we've talked a lot on this program about George Papadopoulos, about Carter Page --

SMITH: Right.

BARTIROMO: But it was Michael Flynn who was the first person who was surveilled, correct?

SMITH: Right. That's absolutely correct, Maria. You've had Congressman Nunes on the show often and you've been covering this story since well before the election. You and I have spoken about this. So you know the details of this story very well.

It started in late 2015, early 2016 when they started targeting General Flynn. Then this rolled into a larger operation against the president, that started to include or at that time candidate Trump and it started to include other Trump advisers, including the gentlemen you named before, Carter Page and George Papadopoulos. And if you look at the specifics of the operation they waged against Trump, we see Ukraine in the middle of that. That's why I believe it's important to look at what's happening now regarding Ukraine and this farcical procedure taking place on The Hill as a continuation. It's not just -- it's not Russia 2.0, it's the same thing. They're continuing the operation. It has an offensive purpose to take down Trump, to protect the swamp, but they're also defending against what they did.

As you say, I entirely agree, they're quite concerned about what U.S. Attorney John Durham is doing. They're very concerned about what General Flynn's lawyer Sidney Powell has turned up and they've been worried all along about what Congressman Nunes and his team have dug up.

BARTIROMO: They really tried to attack Congressman Nunes from the get-go --

SMITH: Oh, yes.

BARTIROMO: When he started sniffing around in terms of what's going on --

SMITH: Right.

BARTIROMO: What went on here.

For those people who may not be so closely, you know, watching this and like you are, like I have been as well, in very simple, practical terms, tell us what this cabal of people did and whey they did it, beginning at the end of 2015 late (ph)?

SMITH: Yes. Well, I mean they targeted -- they targeted the Trump team. I mean I think the -- I think the essential point and one of the important points my book makes is looking at newly acquired documents. The point that I make, we've talked about the FBI and we've talked about the DOJ and the bad things that people did in law enforcement and the intelligence community. And that's absolutely true.

One of the most important things to keep in mind, though, however, is that the prime beneficiary, primary beneficiary of spying on the Trump campaign, which is what the FBI and DOJ did, they spied on the Trump campaign to try to find an October surprise. The primary beneficiary of that was not the FBI, was not the Department of Justice, it was the Clinton campaign. And, in fact, the Clinton campaign got the FBI to break into the Trump campaign, to find an October surprise, to destroy Trump's candidacy. After the election, that's when they rolled it into a coup.

BARTIROMO: So this was very simply one political campaign trying to destroy the competitor political campaign.

SMITH: Yes. Right.

BARTIROMO: Hillary Clinton trying to destroy Donald Trump and Hillary had incredible sources and partners because obviously her husband was president and they have the Clinton machine.

How far up the lines do you think this goes because every time I ask people, and I do this all the time, who do you think the mastermind is --

SMITH: Right.

BARTIROMO: All the attention goes to the CIA, because we know it was really the CIA that would be able to get all of these international diplomats --

SMITH: Right.

BARTIROMO: Quote/unquote, like Alexander Downer and Joseph Mifsud and, of course, Stefan Halper to run into Trump campaign people.

SMITH: Yes.

BARTIROMO: How far up the ladder do you think it goes? Is it John Brennan? Is it President Obama?

SMITH: Well, I mean, we certainly -- we know, we know that U.S. Attorney Durham is certainly looking at the CIA. I imagine we've heard former CIA Director John Brennan say that he's supposed to be interviewed. I make the case in my book certainly in a chapter that Congressman Nunes, he titled the chapter Obama's dossier, which is what he calls the intelligence community assessment of January 2017. I mean Obama asked for this and Brennan used it as the Steele dossier to set up Donald Trump by claiming that Donald Trump won the presidency, won the election, not by -- not by virtue of the vote of the American public but rather thanks to Vladimir Putin. This has created a tremendous amount of problem and we even heard former director of national intelligence, James Clapper, saying that that intelligence community assessment has led to all of the different things that we've had today. And that was ordered by Barack Obama.

BARTIROMO: It's pretty extraordinary that this big lie of coordination with Russia is still going on in Hillary Clinton's head.

SMITH: Yes.

BARTIROMO: She just called Tulsi Gabbard a Russian asset.

SMITH: It's terrible.

BARTIROMO: So she's still trying to sort of -- meanwhile, is it fair to say that she actually did collude because she -- her campaign paid for the dossier and the dossier came from Russia?

SMITH: I mean certainly one of the scandals is, is that they got -- they got law enforcement, a certain section of law enforcement, to help them spy on the Trump campaign. I think the real lasting damage that's been done here is, is that Hillary Clinton paid for a conspiracy theory that has been injected into the American public's sphere. We've been living with this for more than three years. We've been living in the sick mind of the Clinton campaign and Clinton operatives. And that's what the impeachment process is about, it's a continuation of the sickness that the Clintons put into the American public sphere starting in late 2015, early 2016.

BARTIROMO: Lee, it's great to have you on the show today. Thanks very much.

SMITH: Thank you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: And congrats on the book.

SMITH: Thanks very much. Thanks.

BARTIROMO: Lee Smith joining us there. Check out the book, "The Plot Against the President."

Coming up, down to the wire. The World Series taking all the way to game seven. Now without controversy, though. That's next.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

FiatChrysler in merger talks again.

Cheryl Casone with the details in headlines now.

Cheryl.

CASONE: That's right, Maria. Good morning.

This time FiatChrysler is in talks with Peugeot owner PSA Group. The combination would create an auto giant with 50 billion. This is FiatChrysler's second attempt at a merger this year after it pulled out of an agreement with Renault back in June.

Well, Johnson and Johnson is disputing an FDA finding that its baby powder had traces of asbestos in it. The company says 15 new tests from the same bottle that was tested by the FDA found no asbestos. The FDA's finding prompted Johnson and Johnson to recall 33,000 bottles, but J and J says an additional 48 new lab tests of the recalled bottles also confirmed the product doesn't contain asbestos.

The stock was halted at the end of trading yesterday. It started trading in the aftermarket. Right now it's up 3 percent in the premarket. A sock to watch.

And then we're all going to be watching tonight, I am sure, because the World Series is headed to game seven after an emotional Nationals win last night in Houston, their home turf. The Nationals pulling off a commanding performance. They scored seven runs, setting up ailing ace Max Scherzer to take the mound against Zack Greinke for the Astros.

The game was not without controversy, we should add. When shortstop Trae Turner was called out after interfering with a catch at first base, whoo, it got real emotional and heated on the field last night.

You can catch game seven, guys, tonight, 8:00 p.m. on Fox.

You've got to hand it -- no matter what happens tonight, you've got to hand it to the Nationals.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

CASONE: The Astros were favorites going into the series. They have rocked it. And they've done it on the Astros home turf. You've got to say pretty amazing stuff.

BARTIROMO: Yes, it's amazing. Fun.

Cheryl, thank you.

CASONE: You bet.

BARTIROMO: Coming up, "Made in America." A fleece company keeping customers cozy all year round. The source of this unique apparel may surprise you. we're going to check it out. "Made in America," next.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

OK, we are celebrating "Made in America," as we always do. My next guest turns family inspiration into a sustainable direct to consumer fleece wear business that keeps customers warm year round. Joining me right now is Dudley Stephens, chief executive officer, Lauren Stephens, and chief operating officer Kaki McGrath.

Ladies, great to see you. Thanks so much for being here.

LAUREN STEPHENS, CEO, DUDLEY STEPHENS: Good to see you.

KAKI MCGRATH, COO, DUDLEY STEPHENS: Thanks for having us. We're really excited to be here.

BARTIROMO: Congratulations on this company.

Before we get to these product that you brought, tell us how you did it. How did you start this company? Was it your own money? Tell us how you did it.

STEPHENS: Yes, so we're self-funded from the start. We thought there was a gap in the market for fleece clothing and we're active women, we're moms, we're career women and so we thought, we need to elevate this fabric and make it stylish.

BARTIROMO: How fantastic. You opened a pop-up in downtown New York City earlier this year. You were also part of a rotating pop-up store at the Hudson Yard's Mall.

Is it going to be just pop-ups or should -- do you just get this online?

MCGRATH: Yes, right now we're all direct to consumer. We do pop-ups, as you mentioned, in Brooklyn -- I'm sorry, in New York, and we have one in Boston as well. We're really progressing online right now, so we're going to maintain that. But, at some point, there might -- down the road there might be an opportunity to touch and feel our stuff that's a little bit more permanent.

STEPHENS: (INAUDIBLE) store, yes.

BARTIROMO: OK. So brick and mortar store maybe on the horizon.

MCGRATH: Maybe down the line, yes.

STEPHENS: Maybe down the line.

BARTIROMO: OK.

STEPHENS: Yes, we've been really successful direct to consumers so far and we've built our company through Instagram and the community on social media and it's just -- the power of Instagram is truly amazing. And the women that follow us, they're super dialed in. They're loyal. We love them. We almost have developed friendships with some of them and it's been -- allowed us to grow our company. And they've been just so supportive of us as female business founders.

BARTIROMO: I love the fact that you produce in Brooklyn.

MCGRATH: Yes.

BARTIROMO: You are women owned and operated and you've got a product that we all love.

STEPHENS: Yes.

BARTIROMO: So you're right about Instagram. I love Instagram.

STEPHENS: Yes, it's addictive.

BARTIROMO: I can't believe how many things you can buy on Instagram.

STEPHENS: Yes.

MCGRATH: Yes.

BARTIROMO: So, touching it -- this is one of your best sellers. This is called the park slope (ph).

STEPHENS: Yes.

MCGRATH: Yes. That's right.

BARTIROMO: Everything is named after a town in Brooklyn.

STEPHENS: Yes.

MCGRATH: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Which I love.

STEPHENS: Neighborhoods and streets in Brooklyn, exactly, yes.

BARTIROMO: OK, so just tell me about the park slope. This feels really cozy right here.

STEPHENS: Yes.

MCGRATH: Yes.

STEPHENS: So that's one of our best sellers. It has a high funnel neck. Our fabric allows it to stand up really well, which differentiates us from other fleeces, I think. And the funnel neck has just become our flagship look. When people see friends that are wearing it or people they don't even know, we hear our customers saying, is that a Dudley Stephens?

BARTIROMO: How great.

STEPHENS: And it's starting to pick up that we're, you know, hearing that from a lot of people.

BARTIROMO: So what's the difference between something flat like this to something like this, which is also one of your best sellers. And this is called the cobble hill (ph). This is --

STEPHENS: Yes. So the turtle neck underneath is our cobble hill turtleneck. This is our marine-hooded vest, which is a new style for this fall. And it's, you know, this is a little bit more soft, cozy. It's like a teddy fleece kind of in a -- we call it a caramel color with a nice oversize hood and easy to throw on over pretty much anything.

BARTIROMO: Pricing. What do we know about pricing in terms of how much these retail for?

MCGRATH: Yes, so our best sellers are each 158. Our prices range from 78 to just about 200 for some of the outerwear.

BARTIROMO: OK. And have you -- had gotten a lot of -- what's been the response from customers so far?

MCGRATH: Great.

STEPHENS: Customers are loving that they can wear this from morning to noon to night no matter what the day entails. And we find ourselves that we'll put stuff on. I mean I'm wearing this now and then I'm going to my kid's Halloween parade and I'm not going to change.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

STEPHENS: You know, you just feel like --

BARTIROMO: That's beautiful.

STEPHENS: Thanks. I -- this is one of our new sales also. No, you just feel as if you can go from all these different situations in life and you don't need to change and you can still feel polished and put together.

BARTIROMO: We talk about the tariffs all the time and the fight with China. How hard it is or expensive is it for you to be producing in Brooklyn and not having to deal with, you know, a having a cheaper manufacturing plant in Mexico or in China?

STEPHENS: Yes, we've seen a small impact on our cost of goods due to the tariffs, but we are determined to continue to scale (ph) in the U.S. That's a big -- that's very important to our brand.

BARTIROMO: All right, the company's Dudley Stephens. Check it out.

Lauren Stephens, Kaki McGrath, thank you so much, ladies.

MCGRATH: Thank you.

STEPHENS: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: We'll see you.

We'll be right back.

urn:contentItem:5YNW-13D1-JB77-K00X-00000-00Economic hammer blows chip away at risk appetite2020-04-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:41ZLexisNexisEconomic hammer blows chip away at risk appetiteMichael Mackenzie

Deflationary winds are blowing and unlike past recessions, cheap oil provides far less of a stimulus kick for consumers who have lost their ... Deflationary winds are blowing and unlike past recessions, cheap oil provides far less of a stimulus kick for consumers who have lost their jobs or suffering pay cuts while stuck at home. US...

Deflationary winds are blowing and unlike past recessions, cheap oil provides far less of a stimulus kick for consumers who have lost their ... Deflationary winds are blowing and unlike past recessions, cheap oil provides far less of a stimulus kick for consumers who have lost their jobs or suffering pay cuts while stuck at home. US...

Deflationary winds are blowing and unlike past recessions, cheap oil provides far less of a stimulus kick for consumers who have lost their ...

Deflationary winds are blowing and unlike past recessions, cheap oil provides far less of a stimulus kick for consumers who have lost their jobs or suffering pay cuts while stuck at home.

US oil futures hit fresh lows on Wednesday, at $19.20 a barrel, a new nadir since 2002. This reflects the sheer scale of the global demand shock courtesy of the Great Lockdown, and one that overwhelms the recent production cuts from Opec and major oil countries. The International Energy Agency forecast a 9.3m barrel a day decline in demand for 2020, with April seen suffering a 29m b/d drop alone. The agency said:

“There is no feasible agreement that could cut supply by enough to offset such near-term demand losses.”

This news of a deflationary breeze arrived after the IMF forecast a cumulative output gap of $9tn in the event of the global economy bouncing back next year. That suggests low interest rates and plenty of central bank support for some time. In conjunction with a flattening curve of pandemic infections across major economies, this helps explain the powerful rebound in asset prices from their March lows. 

But as more companies shed staff and enact pay cuts, the outlook for consumer spending casts a lengthy shadow over any future recovery. Advance US retail sales data for March recorded the biggest monthly drop since records began in 1992, down 8.7 per cent. The one bright spot was a rise of 25.6 per cent in sales at food and beverage stores from stockpiling ahead of self-isolation. 

This all means that the return of the consumer may well take a lot longer than some in the equity and credit markets reckon. That hardly bodes well for the global economy and companies’ bottom lines. The latest US industrial figures were dire, showing the biggest drop since 1946, while Bank of America, Citi and Goldman Sachs followed JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo in preparing for   large credit losses. 

The Federal Reserve’s Beige Book highlighted a sharp contraction in business activity, job losses in the retail, leisure and hospitality sectors, and no upward wage pressure. That led the Fed to signal deflationary pressure:

“The general direction of price inflation was down for both selling prices and non-labour input prices,” with the central bank adding that “the outlook calls for further downward pressure on prices on average”.

At least on Wednesday this grim economic toll registered across global equities and risk assets (although a pullback was hardly a surprise given the scale of their recent bounce). Another market barometer, the two-year Treasury yield, fell below 0.2 per cent, its lowest level since September of 2011.

Here’s the take on the consumer from Joshua Shapiro at MFR, an economic consultancy in New York:

“Government support efforts notwithstanding, large increases in unemployment and a lack of clarity about the future will cause consumers to continue to pull back. This will be reinforced by precautionary savings from those whose income stream may so far remain intact but who’s continued employment prospects are shakier and investment portfolio is likely smaller.”

The equity market riposte is that the lack of inflation and a protracted recovery means extended central bank support. A view that earnings expectations are about to rebound in 2021, in contrast to the pain of 2020, has certainly flavoured renewed bullish outlooks from Wall Street strategists, led by JPMorgan and Goldman Sachs.

Over at Unigestion, its analysts beg to differ:

“Despite all the policy support and the positive health-related news, we believe that most investors are underestimating the consequences of the Covid-19 recession and its impact on earnings in a highly leveraged financial environment.”

Markets duly run ahead of outcomes. But the pandemic recession, for all the alacrity of central bank support, is still going to hammer the global economy and threaten a very leveraged global financial system. Faith in the central bank put option of open-ended support awaits the ultimate test as investors keep a close eye on how hard a landing Main Street endures.

Quick Hits — What’s on the markets radar?

Further pressure on Italian government bonds reminds us that the eurozone has work to do after the recent meeting of finance ministers. Italy’s 10-year yield has risen to a four-week high of more than 1.8 per cent, writes the FT’s Tommy Stubbington. Debt for Greece, Portugal and Spain are also weaker as bond investors sense that indebted countries within the common currency are on their own. 

The impressive bounce in the S&P 500 from its March nadir has been led by big tech and, in particular, Apple, Amazon and Microsoft. The big three alone have increased their S&P 500 weights by 3.3 percentage points during the past two months notes DataTrek, exceeding the current sector weights for real estate (3.1 per cent), energy (2.9 per cent) and materials (2.5 per cent). 

This suggests that investors are betting on tech disruption from companies with the cash to exploit a post-pandemic economy. Here’s the FT’s Richard Waters with a look at how cloud computing has outpaced the market of late.

Also of note is the growing divergence between two important S&P 500 service sectors: healthcare and financials. Since early February, healthcare’s weighting has risen to 15.2 per cent from 13.9 per cent, while financials has dropped to 11 per cent from 12.6 per cent. I’ll leave the summary to DataTrek:

“Covid-19 has reminded investors that healthcare is both an essential service and a potential source of disruption (in this case, a vaccine) in its own right while financials bear the brunt of the current deep recession with no offsetting upside.”

Those who think equity markets have hit their Covid-19 lows should be mindful of history, argues Henry Colvin at Longview Economics:

“In almost all pullbacks, equity indices retest their lows from the initial ‘wave’ of selling.”

The data highlight that 15 pullbacks in the S&P 500 of more than 10 per cent since 1978 resulted in 13 of these corrections seeing the index retest its low.

Henry adds:

“On the other two occasions that the S&P 500 did not retest its lows, both were small pullbacks (of 11 per cent and 12 per cent) and neither were associated with a direct macro shock to the US economy.”

Nearly a third of UK blue-chips have suspended, deferred or cut their dividends leaving the FTSE 100 providing a forecast income of £64bn in 2020 (implying a yield of 4.1 per cent), down from £85bn in 2018 and £75bn in 2019. But the key factor for income seekers is that 10 FTSE members are forecast to pay out £42bn in dividends in 2020, or two-thirds of the expected total according to AJ Bell’s Russ Mould. Expand that list to 20 companies, and the forecast payout rises to £54bn in dividends in 2020, or 84 per cent of the expected amount.

AJ Bell estimates that at least seven of the 20 companies, led by BP, Shell and Diageo, are maintaining their payouts. As investor analysis references “earnings cover, cash flow, the debt and pension and lease obligations on balance sheets and the maturity timeline of any borrowings” for UK blue-chips, AJ Bell also notes the importance of “any assistance received during the current crisis and how front-line staff are being rewarded for helping to keep the show on the road”.

Russ adds: 

“Regulators are already bringing banks and insurers to heel in the UK and the US bailout package for airlines expressly forbids dividends and buybacks until autumn 2021, after all.”

Finally, as a former resident of New York’s East Village and where the fire escape was my balcony (East Third street above the Edge Bar and down from the   Hells Angels clubhouse — both gone), here’s a very special   musical tribute as residents saluted the city’s health workers:

urn:contentItem:60J5-5W81-F03R-N4NH-00000-00Economic Kickstart; Rocket Man IPO; Uber Eaten2020-08-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:41ZLexisNexisEconomic Kickstart; Rocket Man IPO; Uber EatenJoseph Hargett

Aug 07, 2020( Banyan Hill: http://banyanhill.com Delivered by Newstex) ;; Friday Four Play: The 'Shout at Wall Street' EditionWhen I get gains, I trade Robinhood free. Market investing is a drug for me. My heart, my heart. Kickstart my economic heart. But we've already had one kickstart this year with the CARES Act.

So, what about a second kickstart? Looks like we'll have to wait a bit longer for Stimulus 2: COVID-19 Boogaloo[1]. While talks between Democrats and the White House have progressed, the two sides remain relatively far apart on several key issues — including federal unemployment benefits, reopening schools and state and local government aid during the pandemic. And, in case you wondered if the economy really needs a second round of stimulus, the latest employment report should help clarify things a bit. The U.S. economy added just 1.76 million jobs in July[2], only about a third of the 4.79 million added in June. Clearly, the pandemic's resurgence slowed hiring considerably. Since this whole thing started back in March, the U.S. lost 22 million jobs. The past two months saw less than half of those — about 9.3 million — return. Now, they say we've got trouble, trouble in our eyes. But Wall Street's just looking for another good time. To that end, the Federal Reserve still has investors covered with 'unlimited' stimulus, at least. They don't call Fed Chairman Jerome Powell 'Dr. Feelgood' for nothing — he's the one that makes investors feel alright. I've got one more thing you'll understand. President Trump enacted a China ban[3]. It's sweeping but not easily understood, and it could cause trouble for the one they call Feelgood erm, Jerome Powell. When we started Great Stuff, all we needed needed was a laugh. A year's gone by, I'd say we've kicked some gains. When I'm enraged, or hittin' the trades, gains are rushing through my veins. And I'd say we're still kickin' stock picks. But not as much as rocket surgeon Michael Carr Volatility like today's is exactly why Mike Carr developed his 'One Trade' strategy. With the One Trade strategy, you can make one trade on one single investment every week, targeting 100% returns every time you trade it — in just two days, on average. Click here to see Mike's research in action.[4] (Today's poor attempt at a Mötley Crüe tribute goes out to Sgt. Christopher C. Ret. — aka Crit — who wrote in to Great Stuff yesterday. Keep rocking, you crazy metalhead! We'll catch up more next week in Reader Feedback.) And now for something completely different it's time for your Friday Four Play.No. 1: Rocket Man A successful initial public offering (IPO)? In this market? It's more likely than you think. Rocket Companies Inc. (NYSE: RKT[5]) finally completed its IPO yesterday, and the stock skyrocketed[6]. RKT jumped more than 19% in its first trading day. Today, it's up another 14.5%. I know what you're thinking: 'Finally, another space stock to invest in!' Wrong! And I think it won't be a long, long time before some Robinhoodlums confuse Rocket Companies with an actual space company. Or Virgin Galactic Holdings Inc. (NYSE: SPCE[7]) with an actual space company. Despite its starry-eyed name, the company runs Rocket Mortgage — formerly known as Quicken Loans. Yes, Rocket Companies specializes in mortgage banking. For better or worse (for those of us who remember the 2008 financial crisis), Rocket flipped the mortgage loan business on its head, turning the process into an assembly line of sorts. Analysts call Rocket the 'Amazon of financial services,' which I guess is a good thing. The company raised more than $1.8 billion in its IPO, making it the largest mortgage lender by market capitalization. Rocket reportedly closes more than 100,000 mortgages a month and has plans to scale up to 200,000 per month. That's a lot of houses — and a lot of loans. With mortgage rates at lows not seen in decades, Rocket's IPO couldn't have come at a better time. But the stock's success for investors remains to be seen. Great Stuff is keeping an eye on RKT for now. Stay tuned.No. 2: Uber Eats $1.78 Billion Loss Some things are eternal. Time passes. The sun rises and sets. Seasons change. Uber Technologies Inc. (NYSE: UBER[8]) loses billions. Once again, ride-hailing specialist Uber reported a massive loss[9] of $1.78 billion, or $1.02 per share. The results were worse than even Wall Street expected — a loss of $1.27 billion, or $0.76 per share. But Uber has two contributing factors this time around: the pandemic and the $2.65 billion acquisition of food delivery company Postmates. Still, investors don't appear to cut Uber much slack. The stock fell by nearly 6% on the news. There were a couple of bright spots, however. First, revenue rose to $2.24 billion, blowing away the consensus estimate for $1.82 billion. Second, Uber Eats now brings in more revenue than the company's ride-hailing business. 'We are fortunate to have both a global footprint and such a natural hedge across our two core segments' CEO Dara Khosrowshahi said in a press release. A natural hedge? That's one way to look at it. Rides go down, Eats goes up. I expect we'll see the inverse occur once COVID-19 is no longer a problem.No. 3: On the Bright Side First Solar Inc. (Nasdaq: FSLR[10]) is doing just fine during the pandemic, keeping its factories open to crank out those sick solar panels and solar panel accessories. No stranger to the biz of keeping places lit, First Solar scorched the earnings confessional[11] last night. Earnings per share: $0.35. Estimate: $0.23. Revenue: $642.41 million. Estimate: $493.34 million. Even better than a double beat, the company also reported that a profitable second quarter income wise, compared to last year's net and operating income losses. Facts and figures aside, now we can get into the real meat of the matter[12]: First Solar also took the opportunity to sell off its once-stellar operations and management (O&M) business. Essentially, the company wants to pare down its plate-spinning and focus on what it does best: making solar equipment. See, when First Solar started out, the solar sector was still getting its feelers out, and companies entering the game had to hit clients with the all-in-one package: complete solar setup from development and manufacturing to installation and upkeep. But now it's time for change: First Solar is doing the rattlesnake shake and shedding its dead skin. Its O&M division, which saw margins fall from a reasonable 30% just three years ago to just 10%, came under immense competitive pressure. (More on that whole 'healthy competition' issue in a sec.) With the sale, First Solar pretty much leaves North America for the laid-back comfort of its production lines, and the market has so far cheered the streamlining. FSLR is up 15% today, and up 145% since its March lows. The thing is, this isn't even the hottest news in the energy market today. The real potential for your investment dollar lies in a crucial piece of tech developed by one tiny, pioneering American company. It ain't solar or wind, but an energy revolution that could create more millionaires than pot stocks, cryptos and Big Tech combined! Click here to learn what's going on.[13]No. 4: Buzz Brewing in Big Tech Big Tech has a soap opera in the works that I think would give our beloved EV Days[14] a run for its primetime slot. Enter, Antitrust Issues[15]. Everybody on the tech block played nice (well, as nice as usual) as they stood in the U.S. regulatory lineup[16] last week, claiming their businesses were all fair, dandy and competitive. That's when I set my watch for the real antitrust issues to start coming out. You see, Apple Inc. (Nasdaq: AAPL[17]) has built up its walled garden for, well, decades now, with its closed-in ecosystem marketed as squeaky-clean exclusivity. This time, Apple won't let a slew of new cloud gaming apps make it to the App Store without passing the company's increasingly strict guidelines. Cloud gaming is Big Tech's next big deal (to some folks), letting people play games that run entirely from remote servers and stream straight to the user's device. Apple Arcade and Alphabet Inc.'s (Nasdaq: GOOG[18]) Google Stadia were two first contenders, but you bet that Apple won't let Google's gaming service run on iOS. Chipmaker Nvidia Corp. (Nasdaq: NVDA[19]) was also unable to launch an iOS app. Facebook Inc. (Nasdaq: FB[20]) actually brought its gaming app to Apple's ecosystem but had to essentially neuter the instant-gaming part of its platform, i.e., the whole selling point of it. But someone's missing from the fray where's Microsoft Corp. (Nasdaq: MSFT[21])? Still arguing with Apple about bringing the xCloud gaming service to Apple devices. A spokesperson for Microsoft stated: 'Apple stands alone as the only general purpose platform to deny consumers from cloud gaming and game subscription services like Xbox Game Pass. And it consistently treats gaming apps differently' Really, all this does is show how intertwined Big Tech's competitive talons are — and how far down the 'you can't play with us' rabbit hole Apple wants to go. If Google, Nvidia, Microsoft and Facebook all turn against Apple, that's some serious scratch that Apple stands to lose. But Apple's big enough to basically ignore any legal pressure the rest of Big Tech would push at it. Microsoft is the only one that truly needs this win. Facebook and Google both get enough revenue from their main gigs that gaming is an afterthought for them and you know how long side projects (don't) last in the Google world. Xbox cloud gaming is the only real edge that Microsoft has in the next console season. Does it absolutely need Apple for its plans to work? Or can Microsoft afford to ignore Apple and have Xbox service users make the push for them? And will Apple keep blocking out the haters? Probably.Great Stuff: Friday Night, and I Need a FightOK, so we're not really looking for a fight here, but I do want to order up another slice of that Reader Feedback pie, if you've got it! We had an email blowout from your fellow readers this week — and we've got even more chitter chatter on the docket for next week. But we can't get to that if you don't get to scribblin' out a few lines to GreatStuffToday@banyanhill.com [22]. When you've got your mind on the market (and the market on your mind), feel free to share your thoughts with us.; Seriously, rant away. The best rambles we get, we can't even publish. (Thanks, Alex F!) In the meantime, you can check us out on Facebook[23], Instagram[24] and Twitter[25]. Until next time, stay Great!Joseph Hargett Editor, Great Stuff [ 1]:
