Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WVX-X331-DYTM-91S2-00000-00ECONOMIC R0UNDTABLE.2019-07-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:41ZLexisNexisPg. 64ECONOMIC R0UNDTABLE.Bicknell, Lindsay

Every month, Utah Business partners with Holland & Hart and Big-D Construction to host roundtable events featuring industry insiders. This month we invited mergers, acquisitions, and deals specialists to discuss national local economies, the availability of capital, and market outlook. Moderated by Cheri Waldron, executive director at MountainWest Capital Network, here are a few highlights from the event.

WHAT HAS THE LANDSCAPE BEEN LIKE IN UTAH OVER THE PAST YEAR?

PAUL SKEEN | PARTNER | EIDE BAILLY

You're starting to see a late entrance approach to this M&A cycle. You're seeing some companies looking for funding they maybe shouldn't be looking for and that creates a flood of deals that aren't ready to go to market. I don't envy the private equity investment groups who have to sort through the flood of deals and decide what's good and what's not.

TODD REECE | PARTNER | BALLARD SPAHR

There were a lot of smaller deals in the state, and that's been consistent over the last few years. But we have two IPOs with Pluralsight and Domo. You have German tech giant SAP acquiring a local company for $8 billion. It puts us on the map as a real player.

BARRY LUTZ | MANAGING DIRECTOR | WELLS FARGO

Q1 is down 18 percent globally year-over-year. If you look at the US, Q1 is up seven percent year-over-year. If you think about Utah 2015, $10 billion in transaction value, 524 transactions. In 2018, $14 billion in transaction value, 483 transactions. So think about the global backdrop down seven percent, US down 10 percent, Utah up 40 percent. The number of transactions actually is down about eight percent but the volume is up 40 percent, which is fantastic.

DREW YERGENSEN | SENIOR VICE PRESIDENT | KEYBANK

KeyBank publishes a sentiment report for middle market companies. And 70 percent of companies think there is a real downturn [coming] in 2019 or 2020. A lot of business owners feel like they're prepared for it. The follow up question was, how do you feel like you'll do in this next downturn? And there was over 20 percent that want a downturn. You hear that a lot from business owners, as we'd like a correction and feel like valuations are too high, it's too frothy, we feel more capitalized for it and prepared for it.

MATT BARTHOLOMEW | DIRECTOR | BDO

70 to 80 percent believe that there will be a correction within the next few years. I would term it as a lot of cautious optimism where private equities are just taking their time, being very discerning, and closely managing their portfolio to be able to weather a downturn.

ANDY DEREN | PARTNER | ERNST & YOUNG

Through the lens of the private equity clients I serve, they're looking for specific highgrowth assets that are going to generate a return for them during a specified period of time. And what's attractive about Utah is when you look at the technology landscape, when you look at the people that are creative, and it can be accretive to and compete directly with some of the companies not only in Silicon Valley, but also abroad.

CURTIS ROBERTS | PARTNER | KICKSTART SEED FUND

We've seen the relatively recent development of the private IPO. There is so much capital available to fund tech companies and they're still equally, if not more attractive than they ever were, that many times the founders that wish to take some of their ownership in cash can do so without selling the company and can stay in charge. And companies are staying private and founder-controlled for a longer period of time. The result that we're seeing may be a temporary reduction in deal volume, but ultimately full exit through a strategic sale or an IPO will still happen. There are just more ways for founders to get liquidity now because of so much capital chasing.

HOW DO THE NATIONAL LOCAL ECONOMIES IMPACT M&A ACTIVITY IN UTAH?

BARRY LUTZ | MANAGING DIRECTOR | WELLS FARGO

The ecosystem is growing. When you think about the actual macro environment and where we are today, you have the Dow, the S&P, the Russell, and NASDAQ all up double digits. You have volatility which is back down into deal territory. And you have very attractive valuations when you think about the macro environment. April jobs hit, they were positive. Unemployment is at 3.6 percent, the lowest in 49 years. Labor force participation nationally is about 60 percent, Utah is 68 percent. And so you have these really positive macro indicators somewhat offset by trade concerns. We're 119 months into this expansion, the longest ever is 120 months in 1990 and yet, you see that we had a 3.2 percent GDP growth rate in Ql. We're forecasting very positive growth rates throughout the rest of the year.

ANDREW WAN | PARTNER | LARSON & COMPANY

What's very unique in Utah is that not only are we able to attract deals to come here, but we're able to attract them to stay here in Utah and expand. But one factor that Utah has to overcome is the culture. We have this negative connotation that Utah is very close-minded, and so companies are attracted to select Utah as a potential, but ultimately, they lose because they think all the great outdoors and everything does not overcome some of the cultural aspect. But it's that image that Utah has as being closed-minded that may be preventing more deals from coming to Utah.

VAL HALE | EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR | GOVERNOR'S OFFICE OF ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT

One area where the state is struggling and trying to seek answers is in the area of deep tech. They've eliminated the TC1P grant. It was a couple of million dollars that we gave to early companies that were coming out or just ready to commercialize and move forward. And now they've also eliminated the USTAR grants for the early early-stage technology companies.

Most states have something there to try to help early-stage companies get over that valley of death. Our legislators said that's not the role of government but these companies need funding, they need access to help them get through that process.

BRADLEY BERTOCH | PRESIDENT | VENTURECAPITAL

A lot of us here remember special grant expense. We remember when we had a whole bunch of startups and one or two big companies and there was nothing in the middle. Well that gap got filled and we've got a nice continuous flow of great deals that grow up. And we're going through a real harvest. But if you harvest until there's nothing else left to harvest, then you wonder what happened. And either, you play catch up real fast and to try and revive things, or you move on and move someplace else.

SPENCE HOOLE | CEO | DIVERSIFIED INSURANCE GROUP

I think we've done really well with startup and emerging-growth and middle-market but we've not done well on the anchor tenants. Think of it like a shopping mall, we don't have the Nordstrom's here, the big tech companies. I think some of these [companies] celebrate the harvest and the exit a lot. I think it's awesome for shareholders. And 1 would think it's much better for our ecosystem as a whole if we can encourage companies to scale, sustain, be the acquirers not the acquired, and look to build those anchor tenants.

REED CHASE | PARTNER | TANNER

It's easy and really good at times to be thinking, "Hey, this is great. Let's just keep doing what we're doing." But things won't always be the way they are and you have to look ahead and invest. And so it is good to see that the state is having these discussions and thoughts around how we create new sectors that don't currently exist. That doesn't happen overnight. And those aren't investments that you make, that you see a return in one, two, three, or five years. Take very long-term and significant investments now.

HOW MUCH COMPETITION EXISTS BETWEEN LOCAL AND OUTSIDE INVESTORS?

CURTIS ROBERTS | PARTNER | KICKSTART SEED FUND

The competition continues to increase, it keeps local investors on our toes, it keeps us motivated to keep our funds going, to continue to raise the funds needed to support the local companies.

It does have an effect on valuations, but it creates that much more robust of an environment for local founders to say, "Look, I don't have to put all my eggs in one small basket to be able to raise money for my company. If I've got a good opportunity here, I'll have a number of options." And that just means we're going to have more and more funding available.

VAL HALE | EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR | GOVERNOR'S OFFICE OF ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT

We're seeing a lot more interest from international investors in Utah now. At least once a month we get these international people coming here saying, "We have money, we want to invest, point us to good deals." And I don't know if we had that type of interest in the past.

BRADEN MOORE | PROJECT DEVELOPMENT | BIG-D CONSTRUCTION

For the last 20 years, investors on projects and infrastructure have been locally-based in Utah. And now we're getting a tremendous amount of capital from out of the state and out of the country, which we've never seen before. It has a lot to do with people wanting to be here in Utah, but also just how successful we're being, it's a huge spotlight and we've never seen investors like this before.

DARIN GILSON | MANAGING DIRECTOR | BANYAN VENTURES

The number of investment firms, or entities out there has grown significantly. It always felt like there were plenty of deals to go around and share. There's actually a good collegiality amongst the investment community here. I don't know if we consider ourselves competitors as much as colleagues. But I would just say maybe in the lower tech sectors that it doesn't seem like it's as competitive between the firms for deals.

IS CAPITAL AVAILABLE TO FUND GROWTH IN UTAH? HOW CAN WE INCREASE THE AMOUNT OF CAPITAL AVAILABLE?

CURTIS ROBERTS | PARTNER | KICKSTART SEED FUND

There is more than enough. And what has made tech attractive as a sector is the fact that the costs to start a company have plummeted. And it is shockingly easy--not that I want to minimize the odds of success, because there are still a lot of failures--but it's easier than it's ever been to get a technology company. Many get to first revenue with no outside capital because they're so capital efficient.

BRADLEY BERTOCH | PRESIDENT | VENTURECAPITAL

There has been a movement in the venture community since the end of the 90's through 2000, you can flip a deal like you can flip a house. And that has lent the accelerator model and the seed models and a lot of venture models into the SaaS and apps mentality. Well, what about those businesses that are capital intensive? Like sciences, medical devices, clean tech, or advanced materials? I mean, they're just left to struggle, right? And it's not only here, it's happening everywhere.

If you're an entrepreneur and you need money, there's never enough money. It's just the way it is. We can all sit here and say "Oh, they have more money than they can think of,"-and in many respects, that's true-but if you're an entrepreneur and you need money, there's never enough money, so it just depends on which side of the table you're on.

WHAT IS TO COME?

REED CHASE | PARTNER | TANNER

IPOs get a lot of attention and they're very exciting. Last year was an excellent year for Utah IPOs and there were almost two. And then 100+ other companies got their money to the private markets and strategic buyers. But over the last 20 years, the public markets have gotten oppressive and difficult and full of regulation and the market innovated and found a better way for both companies to get financing. So while we'll probably have some exciting IPOs and public transactions this year, it'll be a fraction of the overall deal volume and continue in real terms to be a pretty minor part of the equation.

SPENCE HOOLE | CEO | DIVERSIFIED INSURANCE GROUP

There's significant headwinds in the IPO market right now in terms of litigation, and if you look at last year, there was a landmark ruling that allowed companies to bring federal class-action lawsuits in state courts, which is totally different than just bringing in a federal court in terms of pleading standards and dismissal rate. That's created a lot of consternation.

And just the cost of insurance for an IPO company has doubled. Retention rates are going up three or four times. It's the hardest market we've ever seen in the insurance industry in my career.

CURTIS ROBERTS | PARTNER | KICKSTART SEED FUND

As a country, we are facing significant policy questions relating to public markets that should be somebody's priority. And there are other countries in the world that have figured out regulatory schemes for relatively small companies to go public. We have to have a circumstance where smaller companies can get access to public markets. If we don't, the wealth concentration issues that we're having in the US will just continue to be reinforced by the fact that they're not available.

GREG LINDLEY | PARTNER | HOLLAND & HART

I agree that something should be done for smaller companies, but there has to be some significant changes to make it work. The cost of compliance is just so high that it prices people out of even thinking about it. And then you have the aftermarket issues and trying to have a market for it. There'd have to be a radical change in our system to make that work and I'm not sure who's got the political will to carry that water.

HOW DO WE ATTRACT MORE DIVERSE TALENT?

BRADLEY BERTOCH I PRESIDENT | VENTURECAPITAL

There are a lot of people that need to be brought to the table. And it's a critical thing that we need to embrace because by 2030,70 percent of the wealth in this country is going to be in the hands of women. The number of women who are actively involved as angel investors is almost zero. Husbands are not bringing their wives to the angel meetings. They're not bringing their kids. By 2030, you're going to see the demise of angels unless things start to change and unless we co-opt people into the investment community.

ANDY DEREN | PARTNER | ERNST & YOUNG

People are attracted to good assets, whether that's business, or people, or whatever that might be. It's important to acknowledge the fact that there is a shortfall in women in other demographics that are present not only as employees, but in the boardroom and participating in these deals. In some of the private equity funds, it's encouraging to see those boards and the decision makers change and shift balance because we're seeing them be incredibly accretive to value. When you set a platform like that, it truly is magical, because you can see great things come in a very short period of time.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5W0M-M5F1-DYDW-74MB-00000-00Economist Agustin Carstens praises Aadhaar, Jan-Dhan Yojana and UPI2019-04-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:41ZLexisNexisEconomist Agustin Carstens praises Aadhaar, Jan-Dhan Yojana and UPIApril 29

April 29 -- India's Aadhaar is a huge asset, according to renowned economist Agustin Carstens (pictured), who also praised the Unified Payments Interface (UPI), which has lowered entry barrier for smaller firms, thus levelling the playing field.


Carstens, who is general manager of the Bank for International Settlements (BIS), is former finance minister of Mexico and former governor of its central bank.
Carstens lost out to Christine Lagarde, who was French finance minister, for the post of managing director of the International Monetary Fund (IMF).
Carstens, considered one of the most influential voices in economics, came to the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) to deliver the 17th C D Deshmukh Memorial Lecture on Thursday.
The lecture, focused on financial inclusion, said protecting the stability of the financial system encouraged financial inclusion, but globally the central banks should do more, such as embracing technology, while safeguarding the users' interests against the flipside of technology. India, in this context, has done pretty well, according to Carstens.
He praised the Pradhan Mantri Jan-Dhan Yojana for introducing households to basic transaction accounts, while companies such as Paytm expanded the scope of banking through digital offer.
"India's Aadhaar programme is a huge asset and one that is delivering benefits," said Carstens.
Using the Aadhaar-enabled payments system, people in rural areas can make deposits, withdrawals, and transfers. The system allows banking correspondents to visit rural areas with a micro ATM, which can verify customers' identities digitally and operate their accounts, he noted.
However, Carstens was cautious about unmitigated access of data by large technology firms, which don't share the data with anyone but raises the bar so much that no other firm can compete with them.
"Data ownership is severely concentrated among a few big firms, giving them an excessive degree of market power. And, in many cases, customers are blissfully unaware of how their data is being used. Dealing with these issues is complicated by the inadequacy of existing rules," said Carstens.
Big firms can use data to assess a potential borrower's creditworthiness, and even a person's reservation rate, or the highest interest rate at which a borrower would be willing to take a loan. Based on this, a big tech firm can charge higher lending rates, up to the individual reservation rates, extracting a larger share of the surplus from its customers.
"Proprietary control of data thus amplifies big techs' market power," Carstens said in his speech.
In this context, India and the RBI have done a commendable job in developing the UPI.
"When the market fails to provide for the public good, central banks and financial authorities can act as catalysts. Take India's Unified Payments Interface: This facility allows both domestic and global players to develop mobile payment applications. As such, it lowers the barriers to entry, especially for smaller firms, thus levelling the playing field," he said.
"Defining standards and deciding who should have access to data and how best to manage them are important aspects to consider. Getting the answers right could lessen the scope for regulatory arbitrage and adverse spillovers, keep markets competitive, and channel more of the benefits of innovation towards financial inclusion," Carstens said, adding that international cooperation would be vital to ensuring that technology reshapes financial intermediation for the better.
In his opening remarks, RBI Governor Shaktikanta Das said the recent developments in fintech had given a fresh impetus to financial inclusion in the country. Exponential growth in digitisation and online commerce in India has forced policymakers to put in place a state-of-the-art national payments infrastructure and technology platform.
"The RBI is continuously aligning its regulatory and supervisory framework so that the evolution of fintech can be leveraged to widen and ease the financial access by the excluded population," Das said.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5W3T-FXT1-JCJY-G1B6-00000-00Economist Sir Angus Deaton warns inequality will damage UK progress2019-05-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:41ZLexisNexisBUSINESSVersion:1Economist Sir Angus Deaton warns inequality will damage UK progressGurpreet Narwan, Economics Correspondent

Economic inequality in Britain could lead to higher rates of suicide and drug and alcohol related deaths on a similar scale to the opioid crisis in the US, according to a report by the Institute of Fiscal Studies.

Sir Angus Deaton, the Scottish-born Nobel laureate economist who has examined the links between inequality and the opioid crisis in the US, warned in the report that deaths from suicide, drug overdoses and alcohol-related liver disease have been rising among middle-aged people in England, bringing to an end decades of continual improvement.

He outlined the risks of the UK following the US, where wages for non-college-educated men have not risen for five decades, and where rising mortality for less-educated white men and women in middle age has caused average life expectancy in America to fall for the last three years.

The report, which is the first in a series of publications, is part of a five-year project between the IFS, one of the UK's leading economic tanks, and the Nuffield Foundation, the charity, that attempts to understand the causes of inequality and considers policies for tackling it. The review, which is being chaired by Sir Angus, will bring together world-leading experts in sociology, demography, epidemiology, political science, philosophy and economics.

In a statement alongside the release of the report, the IFS said: "We have not experienced anything similar in the UK but we have now had a decade of stagnant wages and there is recent evidence that 'deaths of despair' - deaths from suicide and drug and alcohol abuse."

Sir Angus, 73, said: "In much of the rich world, where one or more of politics, economics and health are changing in worrisome ways. If working people are losing out because corporate governance is set up to favour shareholders over workers, or because the decline in unions has favoured capital over labour and is undermining the wages of workers at the expense of shareholders and corporate executives, then we need to change the rules."

Paul Johnson, director of IFS, added: "I can't think of anything more important than understanding what drives the inequalities we see today and working out what we might do to influence them. Everything from early childhood education to the regulation of "big tech", from the design of the benefit system to the effects of globalisation, from the role of men and women in the home to the design of corporate governance, matters for producing the outcomes we see. We will be examining them all."

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XX5-3NM1-DY19-C2W8-00000-00Economists warn tech is disrupting economic data, too2020-01-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:41ZLexisNexisEconomists warn tech is disrupting economic data, tooTom Richardson

Economists claim big tech's rapid rise has left regulators behind the eight ball and led to problems measuring productivity.

Economists are worried the rapid rate of technological change is hurting the quality of key measurements of national economic growth and productivity.

The concern is that tech's deepening reach and the ongoing growth of the services sector may mean quarterly gross domestic product (GDP) numbers are being distorted.

"This is probably one of the most important yet least discussed topics in markets," said Yarra Capital Management economist Tim Toohey.

"It's clear that as economies evolved ... towards a digital economic structure that defies national borders, the basic methods we have used to measure and assess economic growth have not kept pace."

The question economists are struggling to reconcile is why the productivity gains made from tech are seemingly not reflected in stronger GDP as defined by the sum of all goods and services produced over a quarter.

Mr Toohey argues that part of the problem is efficiency advances delivered by tech are being underestimated in the services sector as output is generally measured on the basis of hours worked.

"The established measurement approach struggles to identify and measure intangible assets such as intellectual capital and the value of networks, let alone the technological delivery of existing services that enhance the utility and efficiency of other businesses and consumers," he said.

According to Mr Toohey, everyday examples of productivity gains not properly captured are in the mobile banking, shopping and gaming spaces. The economist also argues tech or science-based productivity advances in the large healthcare sector are not adequately recorded.

"Procedures that previously required days of hospital stay are now done in a few hours in outpatient facilities. Instead, the statistician largely just captures the hours worked by the hospital staff."

How technology is affecting human productivity also has other side effects not captured by the statisticians responsible for compiling GDP data.

"A different way to think about the effects of technological change is that the benefits are potentially making our leisure time more efficient - for example, knowing when buses will turn up rather than just waiting and hoping," said Macquarie economist Justin Fabo.

However, Mr Fabo argues the dramatic impact of tech on industrial and human productivity has positive and negative effects with the net outcome uncertain.

"The proliferation of some technology, particularly social media and the ability to work outside the office, is probably making some workers less efficient. Some people just spend more leisure time on social media or playing games."

Big tech's global influence on productivity is an important question not just because social media leads more people to waste time at work.

Stephen Anthony of Industry Super thinks a lack of government intervention means the unprecedented power of big tech is stopping smaller nations like Australia from benefiting from the technological advancements.

"Productivity gains are being captured within firms rather than shared with consumers in the form of much lower prices which help to drive purchasing power," he said.

"Tech producers such as the FANGS have been able to capture the 'rents' from their software services and platforms and use them to further concentrate gains by disrupting and sometimes deregulating broader industries."

In referencing the 2019 research of NYU finance professor Thomas Phillipon, Mr Anthony suggests US politicians advocating for a break-up of big tech may be on the money.

"It is clear that concentration is a major issue to faster growth in the United States and that US policy makers have dropped the ball in terms of driving greater competitive pressure in their economy," he said.

"To the extent that the US is a driver of global productivity this has helped to stifle outcomes."

Mr Anthony also points out how US tech businesses have regularly caused controversy overseas by employing transfer pricing mechanisms to minimise taxes paid in countries including Australia.

In the US itself a politically controversial issue is the widespread use of giant share buybacks by blue-chip multinationals where profits are simply reinvested to buy back shares. The net effect is just to return more capital to its owners, all arguably at the cost of productivity.

The rise of the sharing economy

Alex Joiner, an economist at IFM Investors, thinks the rise of the US tech-based sharing economy has also revolutionised the services sector globally.

"Technology has been opening up different forms of growth and unlocking productivity in existing capital," he said.

"Just think, Uber is the largest taxi company in the world and has no taxis and Airbnb is the biggest hotel chain with no hotels. The existing capital in these sectors has been opened up via technology."

In Australia, an Uber driver should be more productive than an old-fashioned taxi driver, as they'd spend less time looking for rides. Or according to economic theory, they'd produce a greater output with less input.

However, GDP growth in many advanced economies is historically low and commonly only marginally positive.

In its last statement on monetary policy, the RBA forecast GDP growth to hit 2.75 per cent over 2020, but leading economists believe that's optimistic and are tipping a median rate of just 2.25 per cent.

No easy answers

These rates are below longer-term historical averages that remain tied to commodity prices and global demand.

For economists, central bankers and governments, what's behind the tepid growth rates and associated low inflation has been harder than expected to explain.

Adding to the problems is the unknown impact of technological disruption and how, for example, productivity formulas should be adjusted to account for the rise of software in automating tasks.

"Precisely because technological diffusion is leading to measurement problems it is difficult to calibrate the size of the problem," said independent economist Saul Eslake.

"Most of the academic research I've seen suggests that measurement problems don't 'explain away' the slowdown in productivity growth in 'advanced' economies since the turn of the century and especially since the financial crisis."

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5RWB-NK81-JC5R-21XT-00000-00Economy Focused2018-03-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:41ZLexisNexisEconomy Focused

　　Key points from the Two Sessions and what they mean for China and the world



Liu Zihong, CEO of Chinese tech company Royole, shows off a wearable device that can automatically identify human thought on November 14, 2017 at the company's headquarters in Shenzhen, south China’s Guangdong Province (XINHUA)


At a time when the United States seems to be retreating from the principles of free trade and globalization, Brexit inches toward reality, the rumblings of trade wars begin to rock the stability of the international order and leadership in technology is seen as a path to prosperity, China is faced with unprecedented opportunities to consolidate its position as a global leader in trade, diplomacy and global commerce and generate wealth for its citizens.

This is the context in which thousands of party leaders, business people and innovators from across China gather at Beijing's Great Hall of the People for the annual sessions of the National People's Congress (NPC) and the National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, collectively known as the Two Sessions.

This year's meetings are of particular significance as they follow the five-yearly National Congress of the Communist Party of China, the 19th installment of which was held in October 2017.

The gathering marks the start of President Xi Jinping's second term in office, the official inclusion of Xi Jinping Thought on Socialism with Chinese Characteristics for a New Era into China's Constitution, the election of the government for the next five years and the launch of institutional reform of the State Council. Despite these momentous changes, the primary focus is still on China's economy and government plans for growth and expansion.

A wide range of topics are being discussed, everything from new growth targets to the role of technology such as blockchain and artificial intelligence in the future of the Chinese economy.

Growth targets

In delivering the annual Report on the Work of the Government at the opening of the First Session of the 13th NPC, Premier Li Keqiang announced the government's economic growth target of 6.5 percent for 2018, the same as the projection made for 2017, despite China's economy growing at a reported 6.9 percent last year.

This target serves several purposes, ensuring continued and well-managed growth, high employment rates, and high-quality growth among them.

The work report included a consumer price index (inflation rate) of 3-3.5 percent, 3 percent less energy consumption, 11 million new urban jobs and an urban unemployment rate of 4.5 percent. Also unveiled were an expected government expenditure of 21 trillion yuan ($3.32 trillion) and a prudent and neutral monetary policy, with easing or tightening only as appropriate.

China's drive for high-quality development means steady progress in the direction the country has been moving for several years: toward an economy that is driven by technology and services, consumer-focused, green, and healthcare-oriented.

The previous break-neck speed growth is being replaced by high-value-added, intelligent and services-focused growth. This requires a fundamental shift in psychology in terms of a greater tolerance and understanding at the central, provincial and municipal levels of government that the "new normal" is a slower, more sustainable and more value-added form of growth, which is not as easy as it sounds. There may be some difficulties and obstacles along the way toward high-quality development, but the temptation to fall back on short term, fast growth attitudes, fixes and initiatives must be avoided.

The discussion and official implementation of a plan for achieving high-quality development is one of the most important outcomes of the Two Sessions.

Globalization leader

China is committed to providing leadership in globalization. This will take the form of free trade agreements with individual countries as well as multilateral trade pacts, further investment in and support for new global economic governance and institutions, and through continued expansion of and investment in the Belt and Road Initiative.

The Belt and Road Initiative will connect the Chinese heartland with Central Asia, Western Asia and Europe by land, and India, Indonesia, Africa, Pakistan and the South Pacific by sea.

There have been and will be investments in ports, railways, the extraction of natural resources and technology. Another seldom discussed aspect of the Belt and Road Initiative is the role it will play in cross-border e-commerce for China.

There has been a great deal of hype around the Belt and Road Initiative as a "trillion-dollar investment" and there being trillions of dollars of potential advantages. In the long term, investment may not reach those numbers, but the initiative is nonetheless real and the symbolism is as important as the infrastructure. The Two Sessions endorse the idea that the Belt and Road Initiative is representative of China's ambitions in global trade and diplomacy.

Technological innovation

The Two Sessions are also serving as a platform for China to showcase its ambition in innovation and technology. Many of the CEOs of China's leading tech companies are present at the Great Hall of the People, working on strategies and plans to help China solidify its place as one of the two most important technology and innovation hubs in the world.

Premier Li identified extending preferential tax policies for venture capital and angel investments, encouraging overseas Chinese students to return to China after their studies to pursue "innovative" business ventures, expediting the recruitment of highly-skilled overseas talent in China, cutting rates for mobile Internet services by at least 30 percent and pushing for ubiquitous high-speed broadband Internet services in urban and rural areas as priorities for the development of China's technology.

Tencent CEO Pony Ma, Xiaomi CEO Lei Jun, JD.com founder Richard Liu and Baidu founder Robin Li are all in attendance and talked in detail about everything from AI, to blockchain, to cryptocurrencies. This is a clear sign that technology and innovation are a joint private/public endeavor in a way reminiscent of the Apollo missions and the development of the Internet in the U.S. crescendo has been reached in the debate as to whether Chinese companies listed on foreign stock exchanges should return to China and be listed on domestic bourses. The detail and plan for changes in Chinese laws and regulations that will fast track this process are taking place at the Two Sessions.

According to the Financial Times, "China's tech companies have faced regulatory barriers to listings on the country's more stringent stock markets. Those barriers are being lifted to increase fundraising for tech companies as part of the government's push to become a global tech power, as well as to improve the quality of investments available to local traders."

Alibaba, Baidu, Netease and other big tech firms have voiced support for the change.

Chinese businesspeople are adept at identifying opportunities and making the most of them. In much the same way the country itself has identified key opportunities for stable and secure domestic growth, for going global and for making adjustments that promote quality, value-added growth.

Foreign companies, governments, governing bodies, brands and tech firms would do well to ensure they fully comprehend the policies, initiatives and growth and development targets codified at the Two Sessions in order to make informed decisions about their engagements with China and Chinese companies, and their own "five-year" plans for a globalized world.

The author is vice president of China/Asia Pacific and Global eCommerce Practices at Tompkins International

This will get intense <xhtml:span class="hit">regulatory</xhtml:span> scrutiny.  If <xhtml:span class="hit">regulators</xhtml:span> nix this thing, Monsanto gets a $2 billion check. Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5KRT-5F31-JBHT-D55R-00000-00Economy in the Focus on the Campaign Trail; Trump Says Clinton Lacks the Judgment, Temperament and Moral Character to Lead the United States;;[1]2016-09-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:41ZLexisNexisEconomy in the Focus on the Campaign Trail; Trump Says Clinton Lacks the Judgment, Temperament and Moral Character to Lead the United States;[1]LanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN ANCHOR: E-mail server looming large, and they did loom large yesterday during a congressional hearing.

Donald Trump immediately went on the attack.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP (R), PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE: This is far bigger, and a far bigger scandal than Watergate ever was. Hillary Clinton lacks the judgment, temperament and moral character to lead this country. She does, you know it, everybody knows it.

(APPLAUSE)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Plus, another Obamacare drop out, the latest roadblock for President Obama's signature legislation. Why so many insurance companies will not participate. On to the war on police, disturbing new video this morning of a man plowing his car into three officers at a gas station in Arizona.

That driver now facing attempted murder charges, we've got the latest on the police officers' condition. The deal of the day, Bayer acquires Monsanto, this is a done deal. The deal valued at $66 billion.

Well, they're confirming the deal. Now, we need to hear from regulators, that's $128 a share, interesting that the stock is at 106 when this is $128 deal. Somebody is not believing that the regulators are going to go with this.

The fast-food wars are heating up, we are taking a closer look at what companies are doing to bring customers into restaurants in a slow economy.

And markets this morning edging higher, we are expecting the markets to open a fractionally better on the session, extending a big move yesterday.

And in Europe, the tone was set higher, stocks edged higher and continue to be on the upside, the FT 100 up two-thirds of 1 percent. A big rebound in oil prices, one of the supports for stock prices this morning.

In Asia overnight, declines across the board, as you can see, the Korean market is closed for a holiday. Four-legged friends on a baseball diamond, a record night with more than 1,000 dogs showing up at last night's White Sox game.

We will tell you about that, all those stories coming up this hour. And joining me to talk about it, Maverick PAC National Co-Chair Morgan Ortagus, Kingsview Asset Management Scott Martin.

And former CIA operative and Diligence President Mike Baker. Good to see everybody --

SCOTT MARTIN, KINGSVIEW ASSET MANAGEMENT: Thank you --

BARTIROMO: Great show so far. So, do you still have on your -- continue on carry vest?

MORGAN ORTAGUS, NATIONAL CO-CHAIR, MAVERICK PAC: But today is my favorite show ever. I had Cheetos-covered chicken finger, and I've modeled Shapewear for concealed carry, so, I think like -- God bless America today, this has been a great show --

MARTIN: It's been a good day for you --

ORTAGUS: It has --

MIKE BAKER, FORMER OPERATIVE, CENTRAL INTELLIGENCE AGENCY & PRESIDENT, DILIGENCE: Scott and I are still waiting to model the Shapewear.

ORTAGUS: Yes --

MARTIN: I'm just so upset --

BARTIROMO: You want to --

BAKER: Yes --

BARTIROMO: Try it on.

BAKER: It depends on the concealed carry --

MARTIN: I'm just upset I missed the White Sox thing, you know, I'm from Chicago, it looks like they had some dogs, and I guess the --

BARTIROMO: Yes --

BAKER: Yes --

MARTIN: It's been a rough season --

BARTIROMO: Yes --

MARTIN: For the White Sox --

BAKER: Yes, but not for the Cubs.

MARTIN: Rough, seasoned dogs, the day I call --

BARTIROMO: Oh, got it, got it --

BAKER: That might have been --

BARTIROMO: Good for -- except you get choke ever.

BAKER: He's appearing here twice nightly --

BARTIROMO: We have a can't-miss lineup coming up, stay with us this hour. Former Hillary Clinton presidential campaign senior adviser Mark Penn with us this morning.

And the former Chairman and CEO of Yum! Brands David Novak joining us. Plus, the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY" Stuart Varney will be along, so, you don't want to miss a moment of it, do stay us.

We kick it off this hour on the campaign trail. President Obama steps into the campaign for Hillary Clinton who plans to return to the campaign tomorrow. Our own Blake Burman has the latest now in Washington, Blake, good morning to you.

BLAKE BURMAN, FOX BUSINESS: To you as well. For the third day in a row, Hillary Clinton will be off the campaign trail as she recovers from pneumonia. That hasn't stopped though, the Clinton team from rolling out some high profile help.

Later today in Las Vegas, Bill Clinton will step in for his wife. It was yesterday in Pennsylvania standing behind a podium with Clinton slogan that the president repeatedly launched attacks against the Republican nominee.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARACK OBAMA, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: You want to debate who is more fit to be our president, one candidate who's traveled to more countries than any Secretary of State ever has, and the other who isn't fit in any way, shape or form to represent this country abroad and be its commander-in-chief.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: Donald Trump with daughter Ivanka standing by his side unveiled his plan Tuesday to reduce the financial burdens of childcare.

Throughout the day though, he also continued to keep the focus on Clinton's basket of deplorables comment.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: While my opponent slanders you as deplorable and irredeemable, I call you hardworking American patriots who love your country, love your families, and want a better future for all Americans.

(CHEERS)

(APPLAUSE)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: Meantime, Maria, take a look at this. The polling surge appears to be continuing this morning for Trump, a new reading out from "Bloomberg" has Trump over Clinton in the state of Ohio up by 5 points.

Now there's two things to point out here with this poll. When it's head- to-head, it's 5 points, when they bring in the third-party candidates, it still remains 5 points.

And secondly, Maria, this is the largest lead for Trump over Clinton in Ohio for the entire election cycle, primary and general. Some might say he is peaking here at the right time.

BARTIROMO: Wow --

BURMAN: Maria --

BARTIROMO: That's an incredible number, Blake, I wonder what John Kasich has to say about that, given his stance throughout the convention --

BURMAN: That he hasn't endorsed him --

BARTIROMO: And this entire --

BURMAN: Yes, exactly --

BARTIROMO: Election season. Blake, thank you, Blake Burman. Joining me right now is former Hillary Clinton presidential campaign senior adviser Mark Penn. Mark, good to see you, thanks so much for joining us.

MARK PENN, POLITICAL STRATEGIST: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Well, what do you think? I mean, obviously, it's been a tough couple of weeks, we hope Hillary is well and is feeling better obviously, that was a very scary video to see her collapse the way she did.

Do you think it was wise for her to take a few days off and rest, or does this feed into Trump's narrative that she is not healthy to be the next president?

PENN: Well, I think it was unquestionably the right decision given all the circumstances here for her to take a couple of days off.

Who hasn't taken a couple of days off and you know, nursed an illness in bed and then -- and then come back and bounce back.

I think this will be a blip here, once she gets back on the campaign trail, and I think she's going to get a tremendous welcome when she comes back out.

BARTIROMO: Yes, probably so, from her supporters, there's no doubt. But let's talk about these last couple of weeks when she made this -- the comments about deplorables, you know, criticizing half of the supporters of Donald Trump.

And then of course, we're watching this video of her stumbling into the van. Can she recoup what has occurred?

PENN: I think she can, I think the American people have seen her be a first lady, a senator, a Secretary of State, who as the president pointed out, traveled to an unbelievable number of countries and they've seen her run through this campaign with enormous stamina and always able to carry out whatever job she was doing to the absolute fullest.

So, I think this is just going to pass pretty quickly.

BAKER: Good morning Mark, this is Mike Baker. You've been responsible for some very successful campaign messaging over the years.

What do you think is the one message that during the course of these next final two months, she needs to really focus on.

PENN: Well, look, I think unquestionably, there's a big difference between qualifications and competence.

And I think -- I think that's a huge gap, I think you saw the president hit that issue. I think also you saw some great economic numbers, you know, come out yesterday in terms of rising incomes, better wages.

And I think that from her perspective, she's got to say that she's got a vision for America, she's going to carry it out, she's not going to take America down the wrong track. Down a track of division which Donald Trump would represent.

BARTIROMO: Yes, we've been talking this morning, Mark, about who to trust, and why you know, all of these agencies becoming politicized have just enraged people.

And then you've got the mainstream media, it seems that they are protecting Hillary Clinton. I mean, "Cbs Evening News" edited the Bill Clinton slip- up about his wife's health.

We want to show you the original interview, this is not what aired broadly, but here's the original interview, look at this, Mark.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BILL CLINTON, FORMER PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Well, if it is, it's a mystery to me, and all of her doctors rarely, but on more than one occasion over the last many years, the same sort of thing has happened to her when she just got severely dehydrated.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: OK, so, that's what was edited. Now, we want to listen to the entire piece of it so that you could see what "Cbs" edited out. Listen to this, Mark.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CLINTON: Rarely, but on more than one occasion over the last many years, the same sort of thing has happened to her when she just got severely dehydrated.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: So, initially, Mark, Bill Clinton said it happens frequently, and then he said, well, it happens rarely. So, they took out the first frequently. "Cbs" released a statement defending its editing of those Clinton's response.

It said the clip in question from former President Bill Clinton's interview with Charlie Rose ran in its entirety on "Cbs" this morning", "Cbsnews.com" and on "Cbs News" 24/7 digital streaming service.

One clip that ran on "Cbs Evening News" was edited purely for time while our deadline for the live broadcast.

What do you think about this, Mark? I mean, "Cbs" editing out Bill saying Hillary frequently has health issues.

PENN: Well, look, I think they sort of ran the whole clip, I'm glad they did ran the whole clip. I think a slip of the tongue was a slip of the tongue.

I don't think frequently would be an accurate characterization. I worked night and day with the Clintons for 13 years, and I never saw her anything but fully able to carry out whatever job, and you know, in a very strong and vibrant manner.

So, I think frequently was just a slip of the tongue and let's let President Clinton make some slips of the tongue, he has before.

BARTIROMO: So, you're saying you've never seen her or heard that she does faint?

PENN: No.

BARTIROMO: OK, Morgan Ortagus.

ORTAGUS: Yes, on the health issue, Mark, just close us out on Obamacare. We're seeing another -- big change, and we're seeing in October, we're expecting premiums to rise dramatically for the American people.

How is Hillary Clinton going to address a very bad environment for Obamacare heading into the election, what's going to be a rough October.

PENN: Look, I think healthcare is an issue that the American people trust Hillary Clinton to really fix.

I think if you look at every poll, she has a significant lead on the healthcare issue, and that she's going to take a look at the problems, and I think this is a case of obviously going back and mending some problems that are emerging.

And I think that's what's going to happen.

BARTIROMO: Mike Baker --

BAKER: Yes, Mark, if you don't mind me asking. When was the last time you worked closely with Hillary?

PENN: Well, you know, I was really chief strategist through 2008 and worked with her in 2000 and 2006, and so that's when I worked very closely with her.

BAKER: OK, Mark, in light of these latest polls, you worried about Ohio?

PENN: Look, I think it's a very close race, I think the upcoming debate is going to be a really decisive event because the American public has really not seen the two of them face-to-face and seen the contrast.

I think you saw in the primaries when people saw the contrast between Hillary and Bernie Sanders in the first debate, it was pretty stark. I'm expecting they'll see a very stark contrast and that will make a decisive difference in this race.

BARTIROMO: So, yes, the debates are going to be critical, Mark. What does Hillary Clinton need to do to ensure that she wins that debate from your standpoint, that first debate?

PENN: Again, from my standpoint, I hope the first debate won't evolve into, you know, negative personal exchanges, but will be on a higher level, the American people deserve a good debate.

I think she's just going to get out there and show that she's got a program for the future of America, that she's qualified, that she's ready to serve, that she's going to bring people together rather than divide them apart.

And I think if she shows that she will beat Donald Trump. I'm not convinced he's got a strategy where he can win a debate using performances that worked in the Republican primary.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's a very good point, Mark, great to see you as always, thanks so much.

PENN: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Mark Penn joining us there. Governor Mike Pence will join me tomorrow at 8:30 a.m. Eastern right here on MORNINGS WITH MARIA, don't miss it, do stay with us for that special interview tomorrow.

Still to come, a $66 billion mega deal, the details behind Bayer, $66 billion deal for Monsanto. Plus, Edward Snowden wants to come home, why he's calling on President Obama to pardon him on moral grounds, next.

(MUSIC)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. A driver plowing into police officers outside a gas station in Phoenix, we've got the latest, Cheryl Casone with that story and headlines now, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS: Yes, Maria, and we've got the video, take a look at this. This suspect slamming a 41-year-old sergeant and a 33-year- old officer working his first day on the job, obviously this looks intentional.

A third police managing to get out of the way. That policeman arrested the attacker.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Our officers is hit by the vehicle, flies about 8 feet in the air, smashes into the front glass of the QT and goes down. Not only did the suspect try to run over us, but then he fought with us after that.

These officers could have easily been killed, and I thank God that we're not planning three funerals right now.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: But they were seriously injured, those two. The suspect expected to face three counts of attempted first degree murder and two counts of aggravated assault.

Well, you know, presidents traditionally issue a lot of pardon during their final months in office. And Edward Snowden wants to get in on the action. The national security agency whistleblower has been living in exile in Russia for more than 3 years.

Well, now, he says that President Obama should pardon him before he leaves office next year. Last month, Obama commuted the sentences of more than 200 federal inmates.

Snowden says that he deserves clemency because the information that he leaked about U.S. in British surveillance programs was morally correct, he says and benefited the public. Why don't you decide on that one.

And it is official, Germany's Bayer buying Monsanto for $66 billion, that does include debt, and this deal that our Charlie Gasparino said was imminent this morning did in fact get confirmed. The all cash transaction working out to $128 a share, that's 6 percent more than Bayer's original offer back in May.

This also includes a $2 billion break up fee, Maria, here's some pre-market action 106.10. But, you know, like you pointed out, deals for 128 a share, we shall see the acquisition creating one of the world's largest agrochemical firms.

It could face though antitrust concerns, Maria, and again, as you pointed out earlier, that might be why the stock isn't moving any higher right now.

BARTIROMO: Right, all right, Cheryl, we'll be watching that, thank you so much. Mike Baker, quick comments on Snowden, will he be getting a pardon?

BAKER: Good God, no. This could make my head explode if I thought about it too long. Look, clearly, Edward Snowden's life in Russia, the bastion of free speech and openness is wearing thin on Mr. Snowden.

(CROSSTALK)

And shocking he doesn't like it, but if he comes back to the U.S. -- and I don't mind, I hate -- great, bring him back to the U.S.

But you know what he should do, he should face justice for what he did. I don't stand in that group who say, he should be hanged for treason.

No, he should face justice. And he skipped the country, he essentially handed over an enormous amount of data to the Chinese and to the Russian Intel services and others.

And to say that didn't happen, to say that somehow he was, you know, this I.T. administrator --

MARTIN: Yes --

BAKER: Was -- who, you know, we're going to all see glorified in the Oliver Stone movie.

To say that he was smarter than Chinese Intel service or the Russian Intel service and others is naive at best.

ORTAGUS: I'm as passionate as Mike is about this issue. I mean, we -- I was in Saudi Arabia as a diplomat when this happened. I saw it directly affect the meetings we were in. We know that we've lost people, most lives because of it.

We've lost people who were aspiring for us. There are proper ways in which to blow the whistle without blowing our classified information, without blowing Intel message, mean sources. There're proper ways to do this.

You can go to the Congress, you can go to the chain of command, you can do without spilling American secrets to the world.

BARTIROMO: Yes --

ORTAGUS: And debilitating our -- and preventing our ability to go after terrorists.

BARTIROMO: All right, it's fair point, you know, some people debate --

ORTAGUS: Were fired up about that --

BARTIROMO: Some people debate on whether or not --

(CROSSTALK)

Hero or a criminal. We'll take a short break, we've got more debating coming up. President Obama giving himself a pat on the back, why he's taking credit for less pain at the pump.

He's attributing the move in oil to his administration. Then the latest addition to the fast food wars, Cheetos, the crazy combos companies are betting on to beat the competition, back in a minute.

(MUSIC)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. The fast-food wars taking a cheesy twist. Burger King is unveiling its Cheetos Chicken Fries today. The nine piece order is covered in the cheese crust snack broiled(ph).

This is the latest marketing cook-off in the fast food industry. Joining me right now is the co-founder and former CEO of Yum! Brands, the parent company of KFC, Pizza Hut and Taco Bell. David Novak is with us, David, great to see you.

DAVID NOVAK, FORMER CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, YUM! BRANDS: Nice to see you, Maria --

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us. And I know you are out with a new book which we're going to talk about.

NOVAK: Right --

BARTIROMO: But you're a real insider in the business. And we -- you know, we try all of these new products on the set and we talk about what's new coming out of these fast-food restaurants.

What's your take on this newest food items, fast food comes -- are these companies going to any lengths to get people in the doors?

NOVAK: Well, I'll tell you. One of the things that drives our category is news. People are looking for -- to try new things.

So, all of us are always trying to come up with good innovation. But you really want to have the innovation that sticks.

I personally prefer Doritos Locos Tacos --

(LAUGHTER)

The nacho piece tacos and the cornichons(ph), tacos that we have at Taco Bell. The Burger King has had the chicken fries for a number of years. So, this is their effort to bring a unique image to known quantity and we'll see what it does.

But I don't think it's a huge idea.

BARTIROMO: OK, so, give me the status-check on the industry right now.

NOVAK: Yes --

BARTIROMO: What's driving business and what are you seeing --

NOVAK: Yes --

BARTIROMO: Out there?

NOVAK: Well, I think what always drives business is innovation and news and brands that are well positioned and outstanding operations. In our business, if you don't have the core operations right, making customers happy.

You don't have a chance, but I think what -- the brands that are winning are the brands that bring a steady stream of news to our customers and they're well advertised and well positioned.

I think Taco Bell for example is leading our industry on that front, great marketing, great products that people look forward to and solid operations, that's the winning equation.

BARTIROMO: Yes, and you're also all about teamwork --

NOVAK: Right --

BARTIROMO: And showing appreciation --

NOVAK: Right --

BARTIROMO: For people you wrote this book, "O Great One!: A Little Story About the Awesome Power of Recognition". Tell us what you're trying to do with this book.

NOVAK: Well, basically, what I learned is I was running Yum! Brands, recognition is one of the most powerful things you can do. I call it the secret weapon of every leader. And it's really an awesome thing to do for people.

I mean, the last thing you want to have happen is to go to work every day and not being recognized for what you do.

In fact, 82 percent of employees feel they're not recognized by their supervisors. So, basically, what I'm trying to do is spread the good word on recognition.

And get leaders in the world to recognize people more and get great results. And this is a parable about a guy named Jeff Jenkins who run Happy Face toy company, finds out they're not getting great results because nobody is happy.

And it's based on experiences I had running Yum! Brands and running KFC and Pizza Hut and Taco Bell.

BARTIROMO: And you did such an incredible job. I remember when the company went public and it was incredible euphoria and the growth story was -- the runway was incredible at Yum! Brands. So, congratulations --

NOVAK: Oh, thank you --

BARTIROMO: But isn't it funny that it's just a little thing makes people feel good, which is a huge motivator --

NOVAK: Yes --

BARTIROMO: For people, and it's --

NOVAK: Right --

BARTIROMO: Not done as --

NOVAK: Yes --

BARTIROMO: Much as you would expect.

NOVAK: Sixty percent, we did some national research for my new company which is called Ogo Enterprises. And I'm building a brand, the first recognition inspiration brand for the amazing people in your life.

And we did some research and we found that 60 percent of people say they're -- is motivated by recognition is money, and 40 percent --

BARTIROMO: Wow --

NOVAK: Say they'll put more energy into work if they get recognized. Yet, it just really doesn't happen.

BARTIROMO: Yes --

NOVAK: And this is just a shame. And you know, I hate it when you see people hardworking, people in the world, really doing a great job, and what they do isn't noticed.

BARTIROMO: People really want to get recognized --

NOVAK: Absolutely --

BARTIROMO: They want to know that you know that they're doing, you know -- they're working hard. So, you are a motivational leader as well. What do you make of the 2016 presidential election and the skills that are required to run this country.

NOVAK: Yes, well, I think what we really need is a leader that can take people with them and bring the country together.

I think what's going to happen this year is, you're basically going to go into the voting booth and hold your nose and make your vote.

BARTIROMO: Yes --

NOVAK: So, it's a -- it's a sad time for our history but I hope someone, someday can step up and really get this country moving in the direction it needs to go. And that needs to be united.

BARTIROMO: What do you think the most important issue is for customers? Customers of the fast food business and who are ultimately voters.

NOVAK: Yes, well, I think you know, in terms of the election --

BARTIROMO: Yes --

NOVAK: You know, I think what people want is like anything else. You want to be -- in our industry, you want to be proud of the brand you go into, you want to be proud of the -- proud of the food that you make --

BARTIROMO: Right --

NOVAK: I think, you know, what people want to have happen is, people want to have our country be great, and be proud of what we are and what our leaders are.

And I think we have the ways to go in that front, but I have -- there's no doubt in my mind that this is the greatest country in the world and we will -- we will prevail in the end.

BARTIROMO: Isn't it extraordinary that we haven't seen 3 percent economic growth in a lot of years at this point? How would you --

NOVAK: Yes --

BARTIROMO: Characterize the back drop out there right now?

NOVAK: Yes, I think it's a cautious backdrop.

BARTIROMO: Yes --

NOVAK: You know, I think there's cautious -- cautiousness is everywhere you look, and there's cautious optimism, but it's -- nobody is really ready to jump in that pool and say hey, you know we're there yet.

BARTIROMO: Yes, it's really important, that's why this book is so important, "O Great One!: A Little Story about the Awesome Power of Recognition", congratulations on the book, David, and it's great to see you.

NOVAK: Nice to see you, too, Maria --

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much --

NOVAK: OK --

BARTIROMO: David Novak there. Up next, the PR nightmare continues for Samsung, the outrage over the company's handling of its faulty Galaxy 7 phones.

Then this homerun is leaving baseball fans weak in the knees, check it out. The incredible hit from one big league slugger, back in a minute.

(MUSIC)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Happy Wednesday, everybody. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Wednesday, September 14. Your top stories right now, 8:30 AM on the East Coast, the economy in focus on the campaign trail, both President Obama and Donald Trump touting their policies, how they have and will help the American people.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARACK OBAMA, U.S. PRESIDENT: America is stronger and more prosperous than when we started out. And gas is $2 a gallon.

(CHEERING AND APPLAUSE)

OBAMA: That is even -- thank you for reminding me. Thanks Obama.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: We're taking a closer look at the numbers straight ahead, thanks Obama. Mylan labs under pressure over soaring Epipen prices, and the Wall Street Journal has new details this morning on the company's sky- high executive pay, how the company compares to the rest of the pharmaceutical sector when it comes to compensation. Fears over exploding batteries, Samsung now telling users to limit charging the Galaxy Note 7, why this is fast becoming the worst P.R. disaster since Chipotle food crisis.

Markets this morning, little changed but higher, as you can see, markets are expected to extend the rally that we've been seeing, the Dow Jones Industrial average up about 20 points right here, fractional moves but higher. In Europe, the tone was set positive and that is being led by a rebound in the price of oil, the FT 100 is up a half of a percent, the CAC quarante in Paris was higher has since reversed course. In Asia, overnight, declines across the board, fractional moves nonetheless but lower, rather. And the Korean markets closed today for a holiday.

Bark at the park, the record night in Chicago, as more than 1,000 dogs showed up for last night's White Sox game, we will tell you about it. The economy a key concern for voters this election and Donald Trump gave his supporters a preview of an economic speech he will deliver tomorrow.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: On Thursday, I will outline my full economic plan which is completely paid for, through economic growth and proposed Federal budget savings. It's going to be something special like this country hasn't seen in many, many decades.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: I want bring in right now, Steve Moore, Trump economic advisor and distinguished fellow -- visiting fellow at the Heritage Foundation. Steve, good to see you.

STEVE MOORE, TRUMP ECONOMIC ADVISOR: Hi, Maria.

BARTIROMO: So, we've spoken a lot about his corporate tax rate at 15 percent. Tell us what we should expect from the speech tomorrow.

BARTIROMO: General Jack Keane joining us there.

Coming up, parents of students in Detroit giving the city schools a poor report card, they are suing Governor Rick Snider and education officials for the failing states of the public schools in Detroit.

And then Oprah's portfolio taking a hit as shares of Weight Watchers have plummeted. Straight ahead, what is next for the talk show queen's role and the company's quest for a new CEO? We will check it out. Stay with MORNINGS WITH MARIA. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Stocks are looking higher this morning. Take a look at futures indicating a fractionally better opening for the broader averages this morning.

A handful of names on the move this morning, Weight Watchers shares taking a hit after CEO, James Chambers resigned. The stock fell over 8 percent following that news yesterday reportedly cost investor, Oprah Winfrey, nearly $120 million just on that move.

We are also watching shares of Ford Motor, the company holding its Annual Investor Day today where it will present its financial outlook for 2017. It's also discussing future business and product strategy, could include more insight on Ford's ride sharing business as well. The stock finished fractionally lower yesterday.

Russian hackers at it again. Now confidential medical information from U.S. female athletes who competed at the Rio Olympics has been posted online. Cheryl Casone with the story and headlines now. Cheryl, good morning to you.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS: Yes, good morning, Maria. Well, the athletes include gymnast, Simone Biles, tennis players, Serena and Venus Williams and basketball player, Alena Deladon (ph). The World Doping Agency said a Russian cyber espionage group called "Fancy Bears" hacked its database and revealed records of exemptions, which allowed athletes to use banned substances because of a verified medical need.

Here is what Simone Biles tweeted. She said that she is taking drugs to treat ADHD since she was a kid. Her tweet says, "Please know I believe in clean sport and have always followed the rules and will continue to do so. This fair play is critical to sport and very important to me." She has a very good attitude about all of this, we should say.

Parents of Detroit school children are suing Michigan Governor Rick Snyder saying their kids lack a fighting chance. The lawsuit claims the state deliberately has failed to provide necessary tools to provide a good education.

Lawyer for the students say that it's the country's first federal case that pushes for literacy as a right under the U.S. Constitution. The suit seeks a number of remedies including evidence-based literacy programs and a system to monitor conditions that deny access to literacy.

And finally this, a new study finds credit card agreements are just too hard for most Americans to read. Creditcards.com says they're typically written at the 11th grade reading level and half of Americans read at of ninth grade level or below.

Creditcards.com analysed more than 2,000 credit card agreements about 45 percent of cardholders surveyed, Maria, said they never, hardly ever read their credit card agreement. And I bet if you ask most of them, they would have no clue what their interest rate is on those cards. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: You're right. Well, it's all the fine print, Scott Martin?

SCOTT MARTIN, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Well, by all the debt, they've been ranking up. I think Cheryl is right. They don't understand the APR because clearly a credit card debt being on the rise here and a lot of folks unfortunately over leveraging and making minimum payments, but still carrying balances and therefore getting charged on interest.

BARTIROMO: I want to get back to another story that Cheryl brought us and that is this doping scandal and this hacking. Mike Baker, I mean, it happens all over and now we have another e-mail dump, what's your take on this? Should we be worried?

MIKE BAKER, FORMER CIA COVERT OPERATIONS OFFICER: Well, we should be worried, but you know, what we also have to realize is this is not something new. We are talking about it now, but this has been going on for years. We are a little bit slow on getting to the game.

I mean, Congress is still trying to sort out some legislation. The Pentagon still doesn't really have a protocol for what is a cyber warfare.

So in a sense the horse has left the barn, we lost a lot of information through economic espionage, to state sponsored, and China is the number one sponsor of this sort of activity in cyberspace. Russia being number two.

BARTIROMO: It keeps coming from Russia, though, it feels like.

BAKER: Well, I does. I mean, because Russia's got a lot of what they call persistent threats. They are not necessarily state sponsored, but they are sudo state sponsored so there's a cut out there and there is claim of disconnect between the government and these various hacking groups.

So this one that went after the doping federation is an example, "Fancy Bears," which has no connection to Carebears which is a great --

MARTIN:: I guess that "Fancy Bears" is like a rogue part of like the Carebears --

BAKER: That would make a great --

MARTIN: Is there any collaboration between Russia and China with all of these hacks? I mean, it's hard to track these guys sometimes.

BARTIROMO: Well, that's a fine question because actually at the end of the day they all hate each other. I mean, I don't --

BAKER: We sometimes forget that here. Each country acts in its own best interest. General Keane is fantastic in talking about Iran, and he was very clear about this. Iran is emboldened by this nuke deal.

We looked at the nuke deal or the administration did as if somehow we were going to be on the same agenda and what the current administration seems to forget is that each nation acts in its own best interest.

So Russia acts in its own best interest. There is no cooperation between them and China. Is there a cooperation between China and North Korea? There is to some degree. The North Koreans have been trained into high level by Chinese agents. And so there is a connection there to some degree --

MARTIN: Similar interests and geographical area.

BAKER: But what we're seeing from the Russians, this "Fancy Bears" group that went after the doping federation is the same that went after the DNC. But there are a number of these groups and to say that somehow they're completely separate from the Russian government would be naive.

BARTIROMO: OK, all right, we want to talk more about that this morning. I have to get your take on the increasing expectations of numbers of refugees coming into the country.

Take a short break, more from our panel coming up and then Google helps you complete your search request, right, but also may be influencing your vote, how the search engine could be favoring one candidate. Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Google's auto complete is bias in favor of Hillary Clinton. That is what recent research from Sputnik News suggest. Google reportedly suggest only positive search results for the Democratic presidential candidate.

Joining me right now the man behind the article, senior research psychologist at the American Institute for Behavioral Research and Technology, Dr. Robert Epstein. Dr. Epstein, good to see you. Thanks so much for joining us.

DR. ROBERT EPSTEIN, AIBRT SENIOR RESEARCH PSYCHOLOGIST: Well, thank you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: You know, most people when they use Google they are not expecting it to get political. So tell us what your findings suggest?

EPSTEIN: Well, there are a little shocking, we did an experiment to see what happens when you show people negative search suggestions like something about Hillary's health or Donald Trump's flip-flops or things like that.

And what we found is that negative search suggestions attract a tremendous number of clicks especially for undecided voters, undecided voters will click on a negative search suggestion about 15 times as often as they will click on a neutral search suggestion.

So a simple way to kind of rig an election is suppress negative search suggestions for your favorite candidate, but to allow negative search suggestions for the other candidate. And there's a lot of evidence that, in fact, Google has been doing exactly that for Hillary Clinton.

BARTIROMO: Wow. We know that the founders and senior leadership are fans of Hillary, I mean, Eric Schmidt, and the founders of the company as well, but they -- they have said, look, this is auto complete and this is not -- this is not something that we can control, so what's the answer to that?

EPSTEIN: Well, we looked at that carefully and what we found is in fact their suppressing all negatives for Hillary Clinton, but they're not doing that for other people, prominent people including Donald Trump.

So there does seem to be bias there, not only that, the numbers are big because we estimate that this manipulation alone will shift somewhere between 800,000 and 3.2 million votes in November.

BARTIROMO: Wow, Mike Baker, this is pretty extraordinary.

BAKER: It is extraordinary. When you talk in light of the previous story about Russian hacking, and you talk about what's the game plan behind the Russian hacking of the DNC in the electoral infrastructure, in part it's possibly to damage the trust in the system.

You see something about this that the doctor is talking about Google and it has in the sense same impact once it becomes public, once people are aware of it.

BARTIROMO: Who do you trust?

BAKER: Right, exactly, who do you trust?

BARTIROMO: Yes. So, Dr. Epstein, what should we be doing about this? Obviously we want to make sure people understand that there's a capability to do this.

EPSTEIN: The problem is that our research also show that generally speaking, people can't see this kind of manipulation. You know, they are just -- you know, they are acting very smoothly. They are getting some suggestions, they are clicking on something.

Basically people are unaware and especially in search rankings people are entirely unaware of any kind of manipulations there. And if you manipulate search rankings to favor one candidate that can shift 2.6 million and 10.4 million votes with no one being aware and no paper trail.

MARTIN: Because it comes to the top page. You not only get the autocorrect, but you get the story at the top. How many times you Googled something and you go to the top five and pick the story out of the top.

BARTIROMO: Right. Well, we know that Google is denying this, Dr. Epstein, but we also know when it comes to like Facebook, the founder just gave money $20 million to Hillary. So I mean, some are being clear about who their candidate is.

EPSTEIN: Well, there's no question that there's favoritism here.

BARTIROMO: Dr. Epstein, thank you so much for joining us. We appreciate it. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Good Wednesday morning, everybody. Welcome back. I'm Maria Bartiromo.

END
