urn:contentItem:5KRT-5F31-JBHT-D560-00000-00Economy in the Focus on the Campaign Trail; Trump Says Clinton Lacks the Judgment, Temperament and Moral Character to Lead the United States;;[1]2016-09-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:41ZLexisNexisEconomy in the Focus on the Campaign Trail; Trump Says Clinton Lacks the Judgment, Temperament and Moral Character to Lead the United States;[1]LanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN ANCHOR: E-mail server looming large, and they did loom large yesterday during a congressional hearing.

Donald Trump immediately went on the attack.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP (R), PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE: This is far bigger, and a far bigger scandal than Watergate ever was. Hillary Clinton lacks the judgment, temperament and moral character to lead this country. She does, you know it, everybody knows it.

(APPLAUSE)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Plus, another Obamacare drop out, the latest roadblock for President Obama's signature legislation. Why so many insurance companies will not participate. On to the war on police, disturbing new video this morning of a man plowing his car into three officers at a gas station in Arizona.

That driver now facing attempted murder charges, we've got the latest on the police officers' condition. The deal of the day, Bayer acquires Monsanto, this is a done deal. The deal valued at $66 billion.

Well, they're confirming the deal. Now, we need to hear from regulators, that's $128 a share, interesting that the stock is at 106 when this is $128 deal. Somebody is not believing that the regulators are going to go with this.

The fast-food wars are heating up, we are taking a closer look at what companies are doing to bring customers into restaurants in a slow economy.

And markets this morning edging higher, we are expecting the markets to open a fractionally better on the session, extending a big move yesterday.

And in Europe, the tone was set higher, stocks edged higher and continue to be on the upside, the FT 100 up two-thirds of 1 percent. A big rebound in oil prices, one of the supports for stock prices this morning.

In Asia overnight, declines across the board, as you can see, the Korean market is closed for a holiday. Four-legged friends on a baseball diamond, a record night with more than 1,000 dogs showing up at last night's White Sox game.

We will tell you about that, all those stories coming up this hour. And joining me to talk about it, Maverick PAC National Co-Chair Morgan Ortagus, Kingsview Asset Management Scott Martin.

And former CIA operative and Diligence President Mike Baker. Good to see everybody --

SCOTT MARTIN, KINGSVIEW ASSET MANAGEMENT: Thank you --

BARTIROMO: Great show so far. So, do you still have on your -- continue on carry vest?

MORGAN ORTAGUS, NATIONAL CO-CHAIR, MAVERICK PAC: But today is my favorite show ever. I had Cheetos-covered chicken finger, and I've modeled Shapewear for concealed carry, so, I think like -- God bless America today, this has been a great show --

MARTIN: It's been a good day for you --

ORTAGUS: It has --

MIKE BAKER, FORMER OPERATIVE, CENTRAL INTELLIGENCE AGENCY & PRESIDENT, DILIGENCE: Scott and I are still waiting to model the Shapewear.

ORTAGUS: Yes --

MARTIN: I'm just so upset --

BARTIROMO: You want to --

BAKER: Yes --

BARTIROMO: Try it on.

BAKER: It depends on the concealed carry --

MARTIN: I'm just upset I missed the White Sox thing, you know, I'm from Chicago, it looks like they had some dogs, and I guess the --

BARTIROMO: Yes --

BAKER: Yes --

MARTIN: It's been a rough season --

BARTIROMO: Yes --

MARTIN: For the White Sox --

BAKER: Yes, but not for the Cubs.

MARTIN: Rough, seasoned dogs, the day I call --

BARTIROMO: Oh, got it, got it --

BAKER: That might have been --

BARTIROMO: Good for -- except you get choke ever.

BAKER: He's appearing here twice nightly --

BARTIROMO: We have a can't-miss lineup coming up, stay with us this hour. Former Hillary Clinton presidential campaign senior adviser Mark Penn with us this morning.

And the former Chairman and CEO of Yum! Brands David Novak joining us. Plus, the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY" Stuart Varney will be along, so, you don't want to miss a moment of it, do stay us.

We kick it off this hour on the campaign trail. President Obama steps into the campaign for Hillary Clinton who plans to return to the campaign tomorrow. Our own Blake Burman has the latest now in Washington, Blake, good morning to you.

BLAKE BURMAN, FOX BUSINESS: To you as well. For the third day in a row, Hillary Clinton will be off the campaign trail as she recovers from pneumonia. That hasn't stopped though, the Clinton team from rolling out some high profile help.

Later today in Las Vegas, Bill Clinton will step in for his wife. It was yesterday in Pennsylvania standing behind a podium with Clinton slogan that the president repeatedly launched attacks against the Republican nominee.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARACK OBAMA, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: You want to debate who is more fit to be our president, one candidate who's traveled to more countries than any Secretary of State ever has, and the other who isn't fit in any way, shape or form to represent this country abroad and be its commander-in-chief.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: Donald Trump with daughter Ivanka standing by his side unveiled his plan Tuesday to reduce the financial burdens of childcare.

Throughout the day though, he also continued to keep the focus on Clinton's basket of deplorables comment.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: While my opponent slanders you as deplorable and irredeemable, I call you hardworking American patriots who love your country, love your families, and want a better future for all Americans.

(CHEERS)

(APPLAUSE)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: Meantime, Maria, take a look at this. The polling surge appears to be continuing this morning for Trump, a new reading out from "Bloomberg" has Trump over Clinton in the state of Ohio up by 5 points.

Now there's two things to point out here with this poll. When it's head- to-head, it's 5 points, when they bring in the third-party candidates, it still remains 5 points.

And secondly, Maria, this is the largest lead for Trump over Clinton in Ohio for the entire election cycle, primary and general. Some might say he is peaking here at the right time.

BARTIROMO: Wow --

BURMAN: Maria --

BARTIROMO: That's an incredible number, Blake, I wonder what John Kasich has to say about that, given his stance throughout the convention --

BURMAN: That he hasn't endorsed him --

BARTIROMO: And this entire --

BURMAN: Yes, exactly --

BARTIROMO: Election season. Blake, thank you, Blake Burman. Joining me right now is former Hillary Clinton presidential campaign senior adviser Mark Penn. Mark, good to see you, thanks so much for joining us.

MARK PENN, POLITICAL STRATEGIST: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Well, what do you think? I mean, obviously, it's been a tough couple of weeks, we hope Hillary is well and is feeling better obviously, that was a very scary video to see her collapse the way she did.

Do you think it was wise for her to take a few days off and rest, or does this feed into Trump's narrative that she is not healthy to be the next president?

PENN: Well, I think it was unquestionably the right decision given all the circumstances here for her to take a couple of days off.

Who hasn't taken a couple of days off and you know, nursed an illness in bed and then -- and then come back and bounce back.

I think this will be a blip here, once she gets back on the campaign trail, and I think she's going to get a tremendous welcome when she comes back out.

BARTIROMO: Yes, probably so, from her supporters, there's no doubt. But let's talk about these last couple of weeks when she made this -- the comments about deplorables, you know, criticizing half of the supporters of Donald Trump.

And then of course, we're watching this video of her stumbling into the van. Can she recoup what has occurred?

PENN: I think she can, I think the American people have seen her be a first lady, a senator, a Secretary of State, who as the president pointed out, traveled to an unbelievable number of countries and they've seen her run through this campaign with enormous stamina and always able to carry out whatever job she was doing to the absolute fullest.

So, I think this is just going to pass pretty quickly.

BAKER: Good morning Mark, this is Mike Baker. You've been responsible for some very successful campaign messaging over the years.

What do you think is the one message that during the course of these next final two months, she needs to really focus on.

PENN: Well, look, I think unquestionably, there's a big difference between qualifications and competence.

And I think -- I think that's a huge gap, I think you saw the president hit that issue. I think also you saw some great economic numbers, you know, come out yesterday in terms of rising incomes, better wages.

And I think that from her perspective, she's got to say that she's got a vision for America, she's going to carry it out, she's not going to take America down the wrong track. Down a track of division which Donald Trump would represent.

BARTIROMO: Yes, we've been talking this morning, Mark, about who to trust, and why you know, all of these agencies becoming politicized have just enraged people.

And then you've got the mainstream media, it seems that they are protecting Hillary Clinton. I mean, "Cbs Evening News" edited the Bill Clinton slip- up about his wife's health.

We want to show you the original interview, this is not what aired broadly, but here's the original interview, look at this, Mark.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BILL CLINTON, FORMER PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Well, if it is, it's a mystery to me, and all of her doctors rarely, but on more than one occasion over the last many years, the same sort of thing has happened to her when she just got severely dehydrated.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: OK, so, that's what was edited. Now, we want to listen to the entire piece of it so that you could see what "Cbs" edited out. Listen to this, Mark.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CLINTON: Rarely, but on more than one occasion over the last many years, the same sort of thing has happened to her when she just got severely dehydrated.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: So, initially, Mark, Bill Clinton said it happens frequently, and then he said, well, it happens rarely. So, they took out the first frequently. "Cbs" released a statement defending its editing of those Clinton's response.

It said the clip in question from former President Bill Clinton's interview with Charlie Rose ran in its entirety on "Cbs" this morning", "Cbsnews.com" and on "Cbs News" 24/7 digital streaming service.

One clip that ran on "Cbs Evening News" was edited purely for time while our deadline for the live broadcast.

What do you think about this, Mark? I mean, "Cbs" editing out Bill saying Hillary frequently has health issues.

PENN: Well, look, I think they sort of ran the whole clip, I'm glad they did ran the whole clip. I think a slip of the tongue was a slip of the tongue.

I don't think frequently would be an accurate characterization. I worked night and day with the Clintons for 13 years, and I never saw her anything but fully able to carry out whatever job, and you know, in a very strong and vibrant manner.

So, I think frequently was just a slip of the tongue and let's let President Clinton make some slips of the tongue, he has before.

BARTIROMO: So, you're saying you've never seen her or heard that she does faint?

PENN: No.

BARTIROMO: OK, Morgan Ortagus.

ORTAGUS: Yes, on the health issue, Mark, just close us out on Obamacare. We're seeing another -- big change, and we're seeing in October, we're expecting premiums to rise dramatically for the American people.

How is Hillary Clinton going to address a very bad environment for Obamacare heading into the election, what's going to be a rough October.

PENN: Look, I think healthcare is an issue that the American people trust Hillary Clinton to really fix.

I think if you look at every poll, she has a significant lead on the healthcare issue, and that she's going to take a look at the problems, and I think this is a case of obviously going back and mending some problems that are emerging.

And I think that's what's going to happen.

BARTIROMO: Mike Baker --

BAKER: Yes, Mark, if you don't mind me asking. When was the last time you worked closely with Hillary?

PENN: Well, you know, I was really chief strategist through 2008 and worked with her in 2000 and 2006, and so that's when I worked very closely with her.

BAKER: OK, Mark, in light of these latest polls, you worried about Ohio?

PENN: Look, I think it's a very close race, I think the upcoming debate is going to be a really decisive event because the American public has really not seen the two of them face-to-face and seen the contrast.

I think you saw in the primaries when people saw the contrast between Hillary and Bernie Sanders in the first debate, it was pretty stark. I'm expecting they'll see a very stark contrast and that will make a decisive difference in this race.

BARTIROMO: So, yes, the debates are going to be critical, Mark. What does Hillary Clinton need to do to ensure that she wins that debate from your standpoint, that first debate?

PENN: Again, from my standpoint, I hope the first debate won't evolve into, you know, negative personal exchanges, but will be on a higher level, the American people deserve a good debate.

Next, we will tell you how much more Mylan executives were paid than their peers at much larger pharmaceutical companies; back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back, an Arizona man reportedly drives his car into three police officers at a gas station on purpose. Cheryl Casone with the details and headlines now. Cheryl?

CHERYL CASONE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Yes, on purpose; that's the key phrase in this story, Maria. (HEADLINES)

BARTIROMO: Wow, really interesting numbers there, Cheryl. Thanks so much. Coming up next, the State Department now admitting that the Iran Nuclear Deal may be to blame for the worsening tensions with the country; more on the consequences coming next. Then, Bayer set to acquire Monsanto, $65 billion deal. We are looking for the confirmation any minute now. Take a look at who benefits from this tie-up, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. An imminent deal on the horizon; Bayer closing in on a $66 billion deal to acquire Monsanto. That was first reported by FOX Business Network's Charlie Gasparino. The merger expected to be made official this morning. After months of wrangling, the deal would be the largest of 2016, in terms of M&A.

Joining us right now on the phone is FOX Business Senior Correspondent Charlie Gasparino. Charlie thanks for calling in. Break down what we know so far.

CHARLIE GASPARINO, FBN CORRESPONDENT, via telephone: $128 a share; a lot of people thought it would be about $130. It's not. It's right below that. It's an all-cash deal, which was very enticing to Monsanto board members, and I think this is like what got it over the hump. As you know, they've been wrangling about this since March. We actually broke when it first became public that Bayer was interested and that they had made an official bid back in May, so this tells how long it's been going on.

But this was the clincher, I believe, a $2 billion breakup fee. So that means if regulators, and I will tell you, there's a lot of regulatory talk about this. This will get intense regulatory scrutiny. If regulators nix this thing, Monsanto gets a $2 billion check. I think that's what put it over the top.

Now, if you look at the share price this morning, even - you know, the deal hasn't been announced but I mean, I guess we are pretty much -- we know what's going on. It's six hours difference between here and Germany. So you can expect this thing to be announced, officially, very soon.

If you notice, the price is not - is nowhere near $128. I think that reflects two things: (1) the deal hasn't been announced, and, you know, it's never a deal until you see the press release; but I think the even bigger concern is the regulatory scrutiny. You've got E.U. regulators, U.S. Justice Department Antitrust are going to be all over this. This deal, as you said, is the biggest deal of the year but, you know, to just think about all of the various chemical and agricultural products that both companies bring to the table. I mean, this is going to be a huge undertaking, taking these two companies and putting them together.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

GASPARINO: So that's why the deal is not trading, that plus it's never a done deal until you see it in writing but I think the regulatory concerns have investors a little freaked out right now.

MARTIN: Charlie, on that note, what do you make of the regulatory environment that's out there now. I mean, you mentioned the Department of Justice and some of the other regulators got in the way of the Office Depo and Staples issue, or at least the merger there. I mean, what do you -

BARTIROMO: Pfizer-Allergan.

MARTIN: You can go on. I mean, Charlie, what do you think about some of these deals going forward, not just this one but other ones that may come out here, where companies may talk to each other but not go through with things? What do you make of how things are, regulatorily, with regard to some of these deals that are out there?

GASPARINO: Well, I mean, if you notice the E.U. has been pushing back on some of these cross-border agriculture deals. I mean, there's a few of them that are out there right now. DuPont, I believe, has one that's being held up and, you know, this is a big concern. Listen, there are two complicating matters here: (1) it's two huge companies. I mean, Monsanto is one of the biggest U.S. companies out there. Bayer is this huge conglomerate in Germany. So you have two sets of regulators, not just one. You have U.S. Antitrust. You have E.U. regulators.

You know, that's what the markets say, and I can tell you that when this thing is done and you start talking to investment bankers, you know, they think that they got this covered. They are going to share some noncore assets, meaning Bayer will, and they think they are going to be able to appease the -- appease the people. But I will just tell you this, that's what the New York Stock Exchange and the Deutsche (Inaudible) thought a couple of years ago when they were looking to merge and, as you know, it didn't happen.

So, you know, one thing as being a journalist, I get paid no matter what happens with this deal. My job is just to break the deal.

BARTIROMO: All right, Charlie. We'll wait for the announcement. You know what's interesting, I think, the E.U. looks at deal-making differently than the U.S. does. The E.U. is trying to protect competitors. So if this deal is too big to take market share from competitors, it actually -

MARTIN: Exactly, and that's the whole issue and I think that's what's dangerous about this deal and some of the other ones that have been rumored to be in the works, it's how the E.U. comes into play here, given that they're --

BARTIROMO: We will see about that. We're going to take a short break. Still to come, President Obama wants to admit 25,000 more refugees into the country now, more than the 85,000 who have already arrived this year. The national security concerns front and center when we come right back. Mike Baker is going to weigh in on that. Then, America's top athletes are the targets of a Russian hack attack; hackers releasing the medical records of Simone Biles and the Williams Sisters. The details next; stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Good Wednesday morning, everybody. Welcome back. I'm Maria Bartiromo. It is Wednesday, September 14th. Here are your top stories at 6:30 a.m. on the east coast.

The role of technology in the race for the White House. New questions this morning over how Google could be affecting the vote.

Tensions rising with Iran and the State Department admitting that the nuclear deal may be the reason.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: We have seen disturbing trends makes significance of the nuclear agreement much more important because the last thing anyone would want to see a nuclear armed Iran, but it also shows that Iran has a choice to make.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Ramping up the refugee levels meanwhile, Secretary of State, John Kerry, reveals how many more people the Obama administration says it wants to bring into this country now. The details coming up.

A failing grade for Detroit schools, students are suing the governor, the latest coming up.

And America's top athletes have become the latest target of a cyber threat. Medical records of Simone Biles and the Williams sisters released by Russian hackers.

Credit cards, we use them every day, but a new study says most Americans probably do not understand their contracts because there are too hard to read. What you need to know to protect yourself.

Markets this morning looking higher. Futures indicating a fractionally better opening this morning for the broader averages. The Nasdaq up a quarter of a percent right now.

In Europe stocks are edging higher as well as. We got a rebound in the price of oil this morning and that is boosting stocks in Europe. The FT 100 up, three quarters of 1 percent.

Different story in Asia overnight, declines across the board, take a look, the markets in Korea, by the way, are closed today for a holiday.

Well, the Obama administration admitting now that the Iran nuclear deal may be to blame for Iran's increased aggressions, this coming just three days after Iran's military threatened to shoot down a pair of U.S. Navy planes operating in international air space.

State Department spokesperson, Mark Toner, said this yesterday. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARK TONER, STATE DEPARTMENT SPOKESPERSON: As much as we would like to see Iran's behavior change in the region, we've not seen a significant shift.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: But you can't rule out that, in fact, this deal has served as a cause for this more aggressive posture?

TONER: I mean, I can't rule that out.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: This marking the first time any senior U.S. official has acknowledged Iran's behavior is actually worsening.

Joining me right is Fox News military analyst, General Jack Keane. General Keane, good to see you. Thanks so much for joining us.

GENERAL JACK KEANE, FOX NEWS MILITARY ANALYST: Good to be here, Maria.

BARTIROMO: The last time we were together, we spoke about Iran testing the limits, testing Islam. It's provoking the United States in the wake of this Iran deal.

Now we hear from the administration, are they finally realizing this deal was a mistake or what do you think is going on now given what we have seen from Iran against our military in the last several months?

KEANE: Well, they'll never admit that the nuclear deal was a mistake because it was seminal objective of the Obama administration's foreign policy. So that's going to stay on the table.

They're going to claim that this is a good deal. They were incredibly naive because they also believed that the deal somehow in terms of a strategic objective would motivate and inspire the Iranians to join the international community of nations and behave reasonably like other nations in the region do.

That was always nonsense. No one believed that that would happen. The Iranians have been since 1980, Maria. The strategic objective is not a nuclear weapon. The strategic objectives is domination of the Middle East and they have never come off of that.

To do that, drive the United States out, weaken the relationship between the United States and the Sunni Arabs and that's what bullying the United States is about and trying to humiliate us is to weaken our relationship here with the Sunni Arabs.

Are they emboldened by the nuclear deal? You bet you they are, they got what they wanted. You know, the deal, Maria, legitimizes them within their own country among their own people.

It's doubtful we will ever see July 2009 repeated again with that movements in the streets of Tehran trying to overthrow that regime.

BARTIROMO: Wow. So OK, we've got obviously a few more months of President Obama's presidency where he's not going to do anything. What do you want to see in the next administration regardless of who it is, General, in terms of the Iran relationship? What should be done? Are we supposed to just take this taunting and bullying from the Iranians on our military men and women?

KEANE: I think things will change almost dramatically regardless of who is president because I believe for a long time and I think you see it in the behavior of the Iranians, Russians, Chinese that we have a weak president and this empty rhetoric and they can take advantage of this president.

Clearly what must happen is the United States has to reengage in the Middle East. We have to get back involved with our Sunni Arabs. We have to have a strategic alliance and recognize that Iran is the number one adversary from a nation's states perspective in the Middle East.

And they are threatening the stability and security of the Middle East and therefore threatening the economic and prosperity and well-being of the global marketplace.

BARTIROMO: Yes, it's really extraordinary, actually. The Obama administration, now this, General, it's announcing new plans to raise the number of refugees admitted to the United States in 2017 by 30 percent.

So we are talking about 110,000 refugees in 2017. The administration already called for 85,000 and they're already here. Some of these refugees will be coming through Syria, does an increase in migrants correlate to an increase in terror threats?

KEANE: Not necessarily but it certainly is an increase in the level of security that we have to have. We -- so our viewers understand, we traditionally take in 70,000 to 80,000 refugees. Now refugees are not part of the normal immigration process.

These are people who are seeking asylum largely because of political oppression and when it comes to Syria, Iraq and Afghanistan, some are literally coming because of survivability particularly out of Syria.

What I think we should do if we are going to increase the numbers coming out of Syria, bring in the Homeland Security immigration folks, we just brought in ten thousand of them.

I think it has gone largely better than most expected, but I would still like to see those officials come before the Congress and explain this program and how they have strengthened it. And make certain that if we are going to increase those numbers out of Syria that we are not going to have any concerns.

What they have taken in as I've been told by people involved in the process is largely families, some who have been tortured, some who have been displaced and some have illnesses, et cetera, if that is going to continue, we should be OK.

But I think that Congress deserves as representatives of the American people to see the details of that so we are clear that we are going to be able to protect the American people.

BARTIROMO: So, I mean, do you have confidence in the vetting process? You know, over the last six, eight months we have been talking about the fact that ISIS has been very clear, they have a passport-making machine, they're going infiltrate the refugee flow, they have done it in Europe. What's your confidence level when it comes to the vetting process in the U.S. right now?

KEANE: That's a great question. Well, first of all, there is a problem in Europe and because there is no process there. Second, ISIS has said that they will infiltrate. I do believe, Maria, take some credit here.

I think the attention that the media has placed on this issue particularly Fox in reporting this and getting the Congress heavily engaged in this has forced the administration to get into the details of this maybe a little bit more than what they would have for these Syrian refugees.

And I think they're sort of all in on this thing to be frank about it. So I don't have the concerns now that I had months ago because I believe anecdotally the feedback is this has gone pretty well.

Look at, this refugee program in general which have been going on for years, we have never had a single one of them that I'm aware of them ever commit a terrorist act.

BARTIROMO: No, I think you make a great point and obviously the media, certainly, Fox has been reacting to viewers, OK, I mean, that's why we are focused on it because we are hearing from viewers.

In the face of all of this, General, we have North Korea. So I want to get your take on the weapons there. Experts are saying that the country will have enough nuclear material for 20 bombs by the end of this year, 20 bombs.

North Korea just conducted its fifth and largest nuclear test, as you know that was last week, what responsibility does the U.S. have in relation to North Korea's nuclear program? What should be the response?

KEANE: Yes. This is a Soviet challenge. We credited North Korea somewhere around six to seven bombs. Now they are going to be up to 20 because of their enhanced enrichment capabilities that they have.

They've got a couple of facilities to do that and we have classified ways to sort of monitor that activity. That's how we can come up this with number, so to speak.

Nuclear weapons, what is North Korea up to with these nuclear weapons? Clearly they want to build a missile capable of having a nuclear weapon on that they can reach the United States. Are they really going to attack the United States? I doubt that.

So what is going on? Nuclear weapons have always been about regime preservation, this regime, third generation, that's all they care about. They suck this country dry just to take care of themselves.

It's a brutal repressive regime and that's all they care about. They look at Saddam Hussein, if he had nuclear weapon, he would never been deposed.

They looked at Gaddafi, if he had a nuclear weapon, she would have never been deposed and that's why they want this nuclear. Now they threatened the use of these nuclear weapons offensively I believe mostly for geopolitical and economic leverage.

And to make certain that South Korea is never ever going to think about unifying that peninsula and making a one Korea out of that peninsula. I think largely what scares us or concerns us, this guy is a nut.

He's not a rational actor like the Soviet Union was, who had dangerous nuclear weapons for years and was an adversary. So that's why we've got so much concern. We don't have rational actors here.

BARTIROMO: Right. That's very interesting. I did not realize it was largely about staying in power. General, thanks so much. Such great insight always from you. We appreciate your time this morning, sir.

KEANE: Good talking to you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: General Jack Keane joining us there.

Coming up, parents of students in Detroit giving the city schools a poor report card, they are suing Governor Rick Snider and education officials for the failing states of the public schools in Detroit.

And then Oprah's portfolio taking a hit as shares of Weight Watchers have plummeted. Straight ahead, what is next for the talk show queen's role and the company's quest for a new CEO? We will check it out. Stay with MORNINGS WITH MARIA. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Stocks are looking higher this morning. Take a look at futures indicating a fractionally better opening for the broader averages this morning.

A handful of names on the move this morning, Weight Watchers shares taking a hit after CEO, James Chambers resigned. The stock fell over 8 percent following that news yesterday reportedly cost investor, Oprah Winfrey, nearly $120 million just on that move.

We are also watching shares of Ford Motor, the company holding its Annual Investor Day today where it will present its financial outlook for 2017. It's also discussing future business and product strategy, could include more insight on Ford's ride sharing business as well. The stock finished fractionally lower yesterday.

Russian hackers at it again. Now confidential medical information from U.S. female athletes who competed at the Rio Olympics has been posted online. Cheryl Casone with the story and headlines now. Cheryl, good morning to you.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS: Yes, good morning, Maria. Well, the athletes include gymnast, Simone Biles, tennis players, Serena and Venus Williams and basketball player, Alena Deladon (ph). The World Doping Agency said a Russian cyber espionage group called "Fancy Bears" hacked its database and revealed records of exemptions, which allowed athletes to use banned substances because of a verified medical need.

Here is what Simone Biles tweeted. She said that she is taking drugs to treat ADHD since she was a kid. Her tweet says, "Please know I believe in clean sport and have always followed the rules and will continue to do so. This fair play is critical to sport and very important to me." She has a very good attitude about all of this, we should say.

Parents of Detroit school children are suing Michigan Governor Rick Snyder saying their kids lack a fighting chance. The lawsuit claims the state deliberately has failed to provide necessary tools to provide a good education.

Lawyer for the students say that it's the country's first federal case that pushes for literacy as a right under the U.S. Constitution. The suit seeks a number of remedies including evidence-based literacy programs and a system to monitor conditions that deny access to literacy.

And finally this, a new study finds credit card agreements are just too hard for most Americans to read. Creditcards.com says they're typically written at the 11th grade reading level and half of Americans read at of ninth grade level or below.

Creditcards.com analysed more than 2,000 credit card agreements about 45 percent of cardholders surveyed, Maria, said they never, hardly ever read their credit card agreement. And I bet if you ask most of them, they would have no clue what their interest rate is on those cards. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: You're right. Well, it's all the fine print, Scott Martin?

SCOTT MARTIN, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Well, by all the debt, they've been ranking up. I think Cheryl is right. They don't understand the APR because clearly a credit card debt being on the rise here and a lot of folks unfortunately over leveraging and making minimum payments, but still carrying balances and therefore getting charged on interest.

BARTIROMO: I want to get back to another story that Cheryl brought us and that is this doping scandal and this hacking. Mike Baker, I mean, it happens all over and now we have another e-mail dump, what's your take on this? Should we be worried?

MIKE BAKER, FORMER CIA COVERT OPERATIONS OFFICER: Well, we should be worried, but you know, what we also have to realize is this is not something new. We are talking about it now, but this has been going on for years. We are a little bit slow on getting to the game.

I mean, Congress is still trying to sort out some legislation. The Pentagon still doesn't really have a protocol for what is a cyber warfare.

So in a sense the horse has left the barn, we lost a lot of information through economic espionage, to state sponsored, and China is the number one sponsor of this sort of activity in cyberspace. Russia being number two.

BARTIROMO: It keeps coming from Russia, though, it feels like.

BAKER: Well, I does. I mean, because Russia's got a lot of what they call persistent threats. They are not necessarily state sponsored, but they are sudo state sponsored so there's a cut out there and there is claim of disconnect between the government and these various hacking groups.

So this one that went after the doping federation is an example, "Fancy Bears," which has no connection to Carebears which is a great --

MARTIN:: I guess that "Fancy Bears" is like a rogue part of like the Carebears --

BAKER: That would make a great --

MARTIN: Is there any collaboration between Russia and China with all of these hacks? I mean, it's hard to track these guys sometimes.

BARTIROMO: Well, that's a fine question because actually at the end of the day they all hate each other. I mean, I don't --

BAKER: We sometimes forget that here. Each country acts in its own best interest. General Keane is fantastic in talking about Iran, and he was very clear about this. Iran is emboldened by this nuke deal.

We looked at the nuke deal or the administration did as if somehow we were going to be on the same agenda and what the current administration seems to forget is that each nation acts in its own best interest.

So Russia acts in its own best interest. There is no cooperation between them and China. Is there a cooperation between China and North Korea? There is to some degree. The North Koreans have been trained into high level by Chinese agents. And so there is a connection there to some degree --

MARTIN: Similar interests and geographical area.

BAKER: But what we're seeing from the Russians, this "Fancy Bears" group that went after the doping federation is the same that went after the DNC. But there are a number of these groups and to say that somehow they're completely separate from the Russian government would be naive.

BARTIROMO: OK, all right, we want to talk more about that this morning. I have to get your take on the increasing expectations of numbers of refugees coming into the country.

Take a short break, more from our panel coming up and then Google helps you complete your search request, right, but also may be influencing your vote, how the search engine could be favoring one candidate. Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Google's auto complete is bias in favor of Hillary Clinton. That is what recent research from Sputnik News suggest. Google reportedly suggest only positive search results for the Democratic presidential candidate.

Joining me right now the man behind the article, senior research psychologist at the American Institute for Behavioral Research and Technology, Dr. Robert Epstein. Dr. Epstein, good to see you. Thanks so much for joining us.

DR. ROBERT EPSTEIN, AIBRT SENIOR RESEARCH PSYCHOLOGIST: Well, thank you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: You know, most people when they use Google they are not expecting it to get political. So tell us what your findings suggest?

EPSTEIN: Well, there are a little shocking, we did an experiment to see what happens when you show people negative search suggestions like something about Hillary's health or Donald Trump's flip-flops or things like that.

And what we found is that negative search suggestions attract a tremendous number of clicks especially for undecided voters, undecided voters will click on a negative search suggestion about 15 times as often as they will click on a neutral search suggestion.

So a simple way to kind of rig an election is suppress negative search suggestions for your favorite candidate, but to allow negative search suggestions for the other candidate. And there's a lot of evidence that, in fact, Google has been doing exactly that for Hillary Clinton.

BARTIROMO: Wow. We know that the founders and senior leadership are fans of Hillary, I mean, Eric Schmidt, and the founders of the company as well, but they -- they have said, look, this is auto complete and this is not -- this is not something that we can control, so what's the answer to that?

EPSTEIN: Well, we looked at that carefully and what we found is in fact their suppressing all negatives for Hillary Clinton, but they're not doing that for other people, prominent people including Donald Trump.

So there does seem to be bias there, not only that, the numbers are big because we estimate that this manipulation alone will shift somewhere between 800,000 and 3.2 million votes in November.

BARTIROMO: Wow, Mike Baker, this is pretty extraordinary.

BAKER: It is extraordinary. When you talk in light of the previous story about Russian hacking, and you talk about what's the game plan behind the Russian hacking of the DNC in the electoral infrastructure, in part it's possibly to damage the trust in the system.

You see something about this that the doctor is talking about Google and it has in the sense same impact once it becomes public, once people are aware of it.

BARTIROMO: Who do you trust?

BAKER: Right, exactly, who do you trust?

BARTIROMO: Yes. So, Dr. Epstein, what should we be doing about this? Obviously we want to make sure people understand that there's a capability to do this.

EPSTEIN: The problem is that our research also show that generally speaking, people can't see this kind of manipulation. You know, they are just -- you know, they are acting very smoothly. They are getting some suggestions, they are clicking on something.

Basically people are unaware and especially in search rankings people are entirely unaware of any kind of manipulations there. And if you manipulate search rankings to favor one candidate that can shift 2.6 million and 10.4 million votes with no one being aware and no paper trail.

MARTIN: Because it comes to the top page. You not only get the autocorrect, but you get the story at the top. How many times you Googled something and you go to the top five and pick the story out of the top.

BARTIROMO: Right. Well, we know that Google is denying this, Dr. Epstein, but we also know when it comes to like Facebook, the founder just gave money $20 million to Hillary. So I mean, some are being clear about who their candidate is.

EPSTEIN: Well, there's no question that there's favoritism here.

BARTIROMO: Dr. Epstein, thank you so much for joining us. We appreciate it. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Good Wednesday morning, everybody. Welcome back. I'm Maria Bartiromo.

END

But mostly it's companies that are developing technologies like drones and driverless vehicles and those that ...

urn:contentItem:5TVC-B881-DYTB-K0C1-00000-00Economy is booming, so why are we so afraid of a bust?2018-11-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:41ZLexisNexisAopinion/commentaryPg. 13Economy is booming, so why are we so afraid of a bust?PETER MORICI ;

The Trump economy is sizzling, but the stock market is behaving like a recession is just around the corner. Equity prices have swooned then recovered many times, and whether the economy collapses depends mostly on Washington policymakers wrecking things.

The Trump economy is sizzling, but the stock market is behaving like a recession is just around the corner. Equity prices have swooned then recovered many times, and whether the economy collapses depends mostly on Washington policymakers wrecking things.

Americans emerged from World War II with worn-out cars and appliances, and the rush to replace them sent the economy surging. Once consumers were satiated, the collapse in demand that followed precipitated a slowdown, and such boom-bust cycles repeated for several decades.

Beginning in the 1980s, an economy more based on services and technology became less vulnerable to such cyclical swings. And nascent artificial intelligence and logistics software helped businesses better anticipate demand to avoid overproduction and layoffs.

Until the financial crisis - which was precipitated by the disastrous decisions to repeal Glass-Steagall and ignore reckless mortgage lending and securities trading by banks, insurance companies and other, shadowy financial institutions - growth and unemployment became much less variable. Economists call these decades the Great Moderation.

Now with the financial crisis behind us, Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell is optimistic the economy can continue expanding and unemployment in check, but both the Fed chairman and president are giving stock investors a bad case of nerves.

Trade with China and our allies needs fixing. Everything from global trade rules to international postal rates has been rigged to give America a whopping trade deficit. Despite being the most competitive economy on the planet, we are racking up foreign debt to finance our deficits like pre-crisis Greece.

The broad tariffs on Chinese imports may be essential to resetting our trading relationship, but the administration has them substantially wrong.

From bicycles to pleasure boats, the administration has levied tariffs on imported components but not on the final products. That is driving manufacturers to move production or source more outside the United States - and basic product design, software, logistics and a multitude of other supporting service activities will follow.

The Fed is correct to gradually move up interest rates, because permanently low interest rates overinflate land and other asset values. However, Fed policy statements indicate its target federal funds rate is about 3.4 percent by early 2020, and that's well above what economists estimate is the neutral rate of interest that neither slows nor overheats the economy.

The boom for big tech appears over as Facebook, Apple, Amazon, Netflix and Google are nearing market saturation and all face tough regulatory challenges. But where technology takes away, it also gives.

Artificial intelligence and robotics are spreading through the economy. Businesses are investing heavily in these and worker training, and investors need to seek out the next round of stars. Some will be among old line, dull companies like Walmart, which is learning to use the web to compete effectively with Amazon. But mostly it's companies that are developing technologies like drones and driverless vehicles and those that build robots and write software that multiply the productivity of ordinary workers.

The rotation out of big tech and the difficulty of finding these new stars - especially, when startups are staying private longer - makes stocks more volatile and equity investing more difficult. In the fullness of time, markets work these things out.

For now, the two most critical events are the December meeting of the Fed policymaking committee, when it is set to raise federal funds rate to nearly 2.5 percent and give new guidance about how much further it intends to push that rate next year, and Mr. Trump's decision to further raise tariffs on Chinese imports if no new progress is achieved at the Dec. 1 conclusion of the G20 Summit. Watch closely for whether he broadens tariffs to include more final goods that are disadvantaged by duties on their imported components.

A crisis in the Middle East is always possible, but for now oil prices don't appear headed for $100 a barrel and whatever else can happen is beyond even the much storied forecasting abilities of economists.

Peter Morici is an economist and business professor at the University of Maryland, and a national columnist.

urn:contentItem:5SK0-9F11-F03R-N2M9-00000-00Economy Thriving on Trump's Reforms ~ VIDEO2018-06-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:41ZLexisNexisEconomy Thriving on Trump's Reforms ~ VIDEONewt Gingrich

Jun 16, 2018( AmmoLand.com: http://www.ammoland.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Opinion Economy Thriving on Trump's Reforms USA - -(Ammoland.com)- [1] President Trump's positive impact on the U.S. economy and markets is unassailable.Except for a short disruption in February, the major stock market indices have been on a steady ascent since Donald Trump's formal selection as the Republican nominee for president. The Nasdaq Composite Index has sailed from 5036.37 on July 19, 2016 to 7761.04.86 at the closing bell on Thursday - continuously meeting and exceeding record highs along the way.We have seen similar market trends in the Dow Jones Industrial Average and the S...00, which have climbed from 18559.01 and 2163.78 on the day Trump was nominated to 25175.31 and 2782.49 by Thursday, respectively.This market strength (especially the Nasdaq's) is a really big deal. We are in an age of massive technological advancement and innovation that could potentially catapult our society into a new era of global leadership. Advancements in driverless cars, artificial intelligence, computing power, and helpful uses for big data will bring about changes in virtually every aspect of our lives, including health care, transportation, communication, and commerce.

The Nasdaq tracks almost 3,000 mostly technology-focused companies which are working on these dramatic innovations. This includes America's five largest big tech companies - Amazon (AMZN), Alphabet (GOOG, GOOGL), Apple (AAPL), Facebook (FB), and Microsoft (MSFT).I had a great FacebookLive conversation last week with Terry Campbell, Nasdaq's vice president and head of government relations. We talked about the amazing comeback that the American economy has been seeing under President Trump and the Republican leadership.Newt Live at Nasdaqhttps://www.facebook.com/plugins/video.php?href=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fnewtgingrich%2Fvideos%2F10156322339027429%2F...w;_text=0...th;=560[2]As I wrote in my new book, Trump's America: The Truth About Our Nation's Great Comeback, our Gross Domestic Product (GDP) has been on the rise. Despite a summer of devastating hurricanes that caused billions of dollars in damage and job losses in at least three states, Puerto Rico, and the U.S. Virgin Islands, the U.S. GDP grew by 2.6 percent in the last quarter of 2017. This is lower than the 3-to-4 percent growth for which President Trump has aimed, but as I wrote in the book, 2.6 percent was still a welcome change from nearly a decade of slow growth.'These growth numbers were still astounding considering President Trump inherited Obama's lethargic economy. In fact, the first quarter's weak growth was the last holdover from the Obama years because Trump's policies were just beginning to go into effect. In fact, the average growth for the last three quarters in 2017 was 2.97. Even with the first quarter included, Trump's first year ended less than half a percentage point away from his goal, which the media had declared impossible.'And as I mentioned to Terry last week, some economists are anticipating second quarter GDP growth this year to exceed 4 percent. In fact, the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta is estimating more than 4.5 percent growth in the second quarter.The remarkable success in our markets and economy are directly related to the Trump agenda. As I said at Nasdaq, the three major drivers are deregulation, the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, and innovation.First, President Trump's massive effort to cut government red tape has allow companies to focus on their businesses rather than paperwork and federal rules. As I wrote in Trump's America, the Competitive Enterprise Institute estimates that the total economic impact of federal regulatory compliance is about $1.9 trillion a year. Between the Trump administration's ability to repeal 22 rules every one it has created and the Republican Congress's ability to scrap 15 expensive Obama-era regulations through the Congressional Review Act, American companies have saved billions.These businesses have been using these savings to expand their companies, increase hiring, and boost wages. This has helped lead us to the lowest unemployment rate in 18 years. In fact, the latest Bureau of Labor statistics indicate there are more open jobs than there are people looking for work in America. This is a wonderful problem to have.Similarly, the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act significantly lowered the corporate tax rate (as well as personal income taxes for most Americans), and this has led nearly 600 companies to give bonuses, raises, and better retirement benefits to their employees. In fact, the tax cuts have made the United States so competitive, more and more international companies are seeking to move into the United States.In addition to boosting employment and wages, the Trump agenda has allowed companies - especially the ones Nasdaq tracks - to focus on innovations that will further grow the economy and help make life better for Americans.Finally, along with creating more jobs, higher wages, and greater productivity, our strong economy has allowed us to use our economic strength to influence countries such as North Korea and China. This is exactly why President Trump integrated the economy and trade into his National Security Strategy.As I mentioned to Terry at Nasdaq, the continued success of the economy and markets under the Trump-Republican agenda will be a decisive issue in the 2018 elections - and I believe it will start a 'red wave' in the Senate and allow Republicans to keep control of the House of Representatives.The reason is simple: The number one thing you can say about President Trump and Republicans is that their agenda works.Your Friend, Newt Newt Gingrich P.S. My new book, Trump's America: The Truth About Our Nation's Great Comeback[3] is out and available for order.About Newt GingrichNewt Gingrich is well-known as the architect of the 'Contract with America' that led the Republican Party to victory in 1994 by capturing the majority in the U.S. House of Representatives for the first time in forty years. After he was elected Speaker, he disrupted the status quo by moving power out of Washington and back to the American people.Gingrich Productions is a performance and production company featuring the work of Newt Gingrich and Callista Gingrich. Visit :   www.gingrichproductions.com[4]The post Economy Thriving on Trump's Reforms ~ VIDEO[5] appeared first on AmmoLand.com[6]. Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5X6H-DR11-DYFF-817S-00000-00Eco-pledges not ending big tech ties to oil, gas Work with fossil fuel companies grows for Amazon, Microsoft, Google2019-10-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:41ZLexisNexisAPg. 006Eco-pledges not ending big tech ties to oil, gas Work with fossil fuel companies grows for Amazon, Microsoft, GoogleMatt O'Brien Associated Press

Employee activism and outside pressure have pushed big tech companies like Amazon, Microsoft and Google to promise to slash their carbon emissions. But there's another thing these tech giants aren't cutting: their growing business ties to the oil and gas industry.

When Microsoft held an all-staff meeting in September, an employee asked CEO Satya Nadella if it was ethical for the company to be selling its cloud computing services to fossil fuel companies, according to two other Microsoft employees who described the exchange on condition they not be named. Such partnerships, the worker told Nadella, were accelerating the oil companies' greenhouse gas emissions.

Microsoft and other tech giants have been competing with one another to strike lucrative partnerships with ExxonMobil, Chevron, Shell, BP and other energy firms, in many cases supplying them not just with remote data storage but also artificial intelligence tools for pinpointing better drilling spots or speeding up refinery production.

The oil and gas industry is spending roughly $20 billion each year on cloud services, which accounts for about 10% of the total cloud market, according to Vivek Chidambaram, a managing director of Accenture's energy consultancy. It's not yet clear whether the extraction industry is getting its money's worth, although experts remain bullish about the application of advanced technology to oil and gas exploration.

Nadella sought to assuage employee concerns at the Sept. 12 meeting, first by reiterating Microsoft's internal efforts on environmental sustainability, according to the workers, who asked for anonymity because they feared retaliation for speaking about an internal meeting. The employees said Nadella also defended Microsoft's energy partners, pointing out their investments in researching and developing more sustainable energy production methods.

"There's no fossil fuel CEO who sits there and says, 'You know, I'm just gonna deny climate change,'" Nadella said, according to the employees' transcript of his remarks. "If anything, they're all saying, 'Let us have, in fact, the regulation, the pricing mechanisms that get us to this future.' "

Microsoft said in an emailed statement Tuesday that it is "focused on helping companies of all kinds become more efficient, including energy companies." It declined to comment on Nadella's remarks, which were part of a regularly scheduled "all-hands" gathering in which the CEO welcomes questions on a range of topics.

Less than a week after that exchange and days before a planned worldwide protest over climate change, Microsoft announced yet another major deal for its Azure cloud computing platform - this time with Chevron and oilfield services giant Schlumberger. The timing of the announcement ahead of the climate protest and United Nations climate action meetings angered some environmentally minded Microsoft workers and caught the attention of outsiders.

"It is unconscionable that amid global climate protests, tech giants like Microsoft are announcing major partnerships with Big Oil," said Democratic presidential candidate and Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, in a tweet that coincided with the Sept. 20 global climate strike. "We must hold them accountable, demand they break ties with the fossil fuel industry, and move rapidly to sustainable energy."

After months of employee activism, Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos said he was pushing his company to the forefront on sustainability, committing it to have 100% of its energy use come from solar panels and other renewable energy by 2030. But he also defended Amazon's work with the oil and gas industry, arguing that "we need to help them instead of vilify them."

Some experts say AI and cloud services could actually play a role in curbing emissions.

Denying cloud computing services to the oil and gas industry would do little to address the bigger problem of the world's ongoing dependence on fossil fuels, said Aseem Prakash, director of the Center for Environmental Politics at the University of Washington.

"We would not want to collapse the fossil fuel industry," Prakash said. "We would want a soft landing."

Big Tech

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:607R-P361-JC8G-818F-00000-00EC Review Finds GDPR Successful, in Need of Improvement2020-06-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:41ZLexisNexisINTERNETEC Review Finds GDPR Successful, in Need of Improvement

The EU general data protection regulation is generally a success but needs more work, European Values and Transparency Commissioner Vera Jourova said at a Wednesday briefing. The European Commission's two-year assessment found that fears the privacy framework would be "the end of the world" didn't materialize, she said. Seventy percent of Europeans have heard of the regulation but more awareness is needed, she said. The review found the EC approach was correct, with more companies using privacy by design as a competitive advantage, and the one-continent, one-law philosophy enabling more businesses, particularly small and mid-sized ones, to operate in Europe's single market. It included a "serious to-do list," Jourova noted. One key issue is the resources available to national data protection authorities (DPAs). There was a 42% increase in staff and a 49% hike in budgets between 2016 and 2019, but the European Data Protection Board (EDPB) and DPAs must boost cooperation to provide a pan-EU data protection culture, Jourova said. The EC is monitoring DPA resources, said Justice Commissioner Didier Reynders. It's possible some national authorities, such as Ireland and Luxembourg, that handle complex cases involving big tech companies might need more capacity and cross-border cooperation, he said. "Consistent and efficient enforcement of the GDPR remains a priority," said European Data Protection Supervisor Wojciech Wiewiorowski. He proposed creating a shared pool of experts in the EDPB to help DPAs in complex and resource-heavy cases. The EC review was "thorough but critical," said Computer and Communications Industry Association Europe Senior Policy Manager Alex Roure: Two years after becoming law, companies and consumers still "lack clear guidance from enforcers which too often take diverging, national actions." The GDPR "has failed to live up to its promise," proving to be a "complicated, burdensome drain on Europe's digital economy," said Center for Data Innovation Senior Policy Analyst Eline Chivot. The review shines an "unflattering lights" on many shortcomings, yet the EC "seems determined to double down by layering on even more rules."

urn:contentItem:6083-0F01-F19Y-C2B7-00000-00EC to rule on TV production mega-deal between Banijay, Endemol Shine2020-06-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:41ZLexisNexisExclusiveEC to rule on TV production mega-deal between Banijay, Endemol ShineSaqib Shah

The $2.2 billion takeover by Banijay will create the world's largest independent production studio.

The European Commission is to issue its merger control decision June 30 on French TV producer Banijay Group's $2.2 billion takeover of Endemol Shine Group Ltd., a deal that would create the world's biggest independent production studio.

Having secured funding for the deal in February, regulatory clearance is the final hurdle Banijay faces in its bid to acquire its U.K.-based counterpart from The Walt Disney Co. and private equity firm Apollo Global Management Inc.

The combined entity's programming lineup will include long-running reality shows "Keeping Up With The Kardashians," "Big Brother," and "Survivor;" quiz shows "Deal or No Deal" and "Pointless;" and Netflix Inc. scripted series "Black Mirror."

While a number of deals have collapsed due to the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic, Banijay said it intends to complete the transaction.

Once the deal is closed, the combined group will be owned by French duo LDH (67.1%) and Vivendi (32.9%). LDH is a holding company controlled by Financière LOV (52%), the investment firm controlled by Banijay Chairman Stéphane Courbit. Italian group De Agostini (36%) and French finance group Fimalac are also investors in LOV.

Europe

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5YY6-SW51-DYRJ-00M2-00000-00EC Urged to Retain Safe Harbor Liability Exemptions for Online Intermediaries2020-05-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:41ZLexisNexisTOP NEWSEC Urged to Retain Safe Harbor Liability Exemptions for Online Intermediaries

EU rules on liability of online intermediaries shouldn't change under upcoming draft legislation, some stakeholders said. The Digital Services Act (DSA) is intended to update the 2000 EU e-commerce directive, which set minimum liability standards for internet intermediaries and established "safe harbor" exemptions. Although work on the proposal is in an early stage, digital rights activists and some European Parliament members urge retaining the safe harbor provisions. The European Commission told us it intends to unveil a proposal for consultation in coming weeks, and a draft measure "later this year."

The DSA is part of EC President Ursula von der Leyen's agenda to make Europe "fit for the digital age." It calls for upgrading liability and safety rules for digital platforms, services and products to complete the digital single market.

The European Parliament analyzed the current intermediary liability regime, implementation gaps and main proposals for revising the system. The April 30 paper said the e-commerce directive isn't uniformly applied across the EU, and many areas are unclear, such as to what extent new online services such as social media companies fall within the definition of information society service providers that can benefit from safe harbor. The paper said academics and stakeholders want new clarification of whether digital services providers such as social networks and online marketplaces could benefit from safe harbor; there may be an opportunity to enshrine a "Good Samaritan" clause to motivate online intermediaries to better control the content they host.

EU lawmakers are setting out positions in own-initiative reports. COVID-19 "exposed serious shortcomings in the ways platforms such as Google, Facebook, and Amazon are regulated in Europe," said Internal Market and Consumer Protection Committee (IMCO) rapporteur Alex Agius Saliba, of the Socialists and Democrats and Malta. His draft report for the lead committee called for retaining safe harbor, and expanding the DSA to digital services, not just online platforms.

Illegal content should go through notice and action procedures based on intermediaries' duty of care, responded the Legal Affairs Committee. The current "limited liability" regime, where intermediaries are deemed liable and can be asked to remove content only when they have actual knowledge of the illegal activity, should be retained, wrote Patrick Breyer, of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance and Germany. The idea is to have parliamentary reports adopted by September, he said.

Intermediary liability provisions should remain intact, emailed European Digital Rights Senior Policy Adviser Jan Penfrat. "No matter how well-intentioned, threatening hosting intermediaries with legal liability for user-uploaded content will inevitably lead platforms for remove or block any content that could potentially be considered illegal anywhere in the EU to avoid the legal uncertainty and risk," with negative effects on free speech. EDRi expects opposition to the proposal from those who believe that big tech platforms "should do more" to fight hate speech and disinformation but aren't sure how to achieve that, he said. EDRi wants large commercial platforms to be required to be more transparent about how they manage online content. Google and Facebook didn't comment this week.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5PJS-Y921-JC8G-80S1-00000-00Edge, Tech Giants Facing Increased Scrutiny, but Regulatory Risk Seen More Long Term2017-09-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:41ZLexisNexisTOP NEWSEdge, Tech Giants Facing Increased Scrutiny, but Regulatory Risk Seen More Long Term

Edge and tech heavyweights face growing policymaker scrutiny and regulatory risk, analysts and others said Monday, but most doubted there's a near-term threat of major U.S. government intervention that would realign the internet marketplace. "It is remarkable how quickly the discussion has changed, putting large tech companies on the defensive," emailed Doug Brake, telecom policy senior analyst at the Information Technology and Innovation Foundation.

"It does seem that big tech has gone from being darlings to the doghouse pretty quickly," said Washington Analysis senior telecom, media and tech analyst Thomas Seitz. "The progressive wing of the Democrat Party seems to have become skeptical of their power, and Republicans were never really good friends of big tech. But does that mean anything?" He said the FCC lacks jurisdiction; the FTC lacks three of its five commissioners, complicating major action; and Congress seems unlikely to act for now.

News reports indicate the political environment for "big digital platform companies, particularly Facebook and Google, has suddenly turned negative and the companies for the first time face real threats of regulation and antitrust action, similar to those they already face in Europe and other countries," said New Street Research (NSR) analysts in an investor note Sunday, which cited their adviser Blair Levin. "The reports are accurate in noting the voices of criticism span a broad political spectrum, which often is the precursor to a significant government action. Nonetheless, we don't see the volume or breadth of the commentary leading to action."

"For investors, the discussion to date is more noise than signal," the NSR analysts said. "The threats are far more likely to arise in other countries or through private antitrust action. Further, we see no signs that governments in the United States are likely to act in ways that provide potential competitors to the data platforms advantages that improve their own prospects for competing with such platforms."

Brake agreed. "Despite all the noise, we are unlikely to see a historic shift in antitrust thinking or serious regulation any time soon," he said. "Demagoguery and the magic wand of 'gatekeeper' went a long way in the net neutrality debate, but I don't see those tactics carrying as well against the consumer welfare standard. This doesn't mean all is well. This new narrative poses a major threat to the advancement of pro-innovation, pro-growth policies around the world. Continued denigration of the most successful U.S. companies will feed the headwinds, especially with growing nationalism and increasingly protectionist policies gaining traction abroad."

Open Society Foundations Fellow Gigi Sohn said she generally agrees "there's not going to be much action in the near term," though she called the Stop Enabling Sex Traffickers Act (SESTA) a possible exception. "It's got bipartisan support, sympathetic victims, horrific crimes" and "the tech companies have gone from 'No and Hell No,' to 'let's work together,'" she said. "So it's a near-term possibility."

Longer term, Sohn said momentum is building for antitrust changes to constrain market consolidation and harmful practices across industry. "Something needs to be done to antitrust laws to reflect reality," said Sohn, a former aide to then-FCC Chairman Tom Wheeler. She also said privacy remains a big concern. "People really do care about their privacy; they just don't know what to do about it." She backs a "level playing field" for both broadband and edge providers, an approach she said wouldn't put edge providers out of business despite their regulatory fears.

"Google and Facebook face more serious government accountability risk than most appreciate," emailed Scott Cleland, chairman of NetCompetition, which is backed by broadband interests. "They are too big to be unaccountable. Big is not bad, but big unchecked power is bad. This obvious bad problem has rapidly crystalized, but solutions remain embryonic. ... The single biggest solution and accountability risk would involve antitrust cartel enforcement of Google and Facebook for apparently dividing up the digital advertising market in 2014, when they abruptly stopping fiercely competing directly with each other in social and search advertising, and then they rapidly benefited from expanding their joint share of digital advertising revenue growth to over 95% in a little over two years." Google and Facebook didn't comment.

Sohn suggested vested interests may be helping fuel the edge regulation speculation. "I'm suspicious that certain opponents of net neutrality have been very eager to push this meme, while at the same time avoiding scrutiny for their own actions," she said. NSR offered a similar view: "Google, Facebook, Amazon, as well as Microsoft and Apple are among the largest companies in the world and their rise has led to the decline of others, some of whom might wish to use government to stem the tide."

Cleland said edge providers largely have themselves to blame. "Consider: their reported election role in Russian fake news, fake ads and fake objectivity; their reported societal role in enabling hate speech and hate ads; their reported political role in opposing bipartisan SESTA legislation that would tweak their Section 230 immunity from liability to not apply to enabling child sex trafficking; Facebook's reported live broadcasts of rape, torture, murder; Google and Facebook's enablement of terrorist recruitment, while opposing being subject to [Communications Assistance for Law Enforcement Act]; their lack of ownership or cross-ownership limits; and their lack of any FCC public interest obligations for national security, public safety, law enforcement, emergency preparedness, emergency services, universal service, non-discrimination, privacy, indecency, [equal employment opportunity], consumer protection, etc."

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5RYG-J251-F10T-02D0-00000-00Ed Gets Caught Up in The Data Leak Scandal2018-03-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:41ZLexisNexisEd Gets Caught Up in The Data Leak ScandalDavid Manners

I can tell you it’s a darn nasty feeling when the PM fixes you with those hawkish eyes across the Cabinet table and demands: “What are you doing about it?” Especially when there’s damn all you can do it about it, Ed confides to his diary. It was, of course, this Big-Tech data leak thing. ...

I can tell you it’s a darn nasty feeling when the PM fixes you with those hawkish eyes across the Cabinet table and demands: “What are you doing about it?”

Especially when there’s damn all you can do it about it, Ed confides to his diary.

It was, of course, this Big-Tech data leak thing.

Naturally I huffed, puffed and bluffed: “. . . .tighter regulation for social media companies . . . .haul Zuckerberg before a Treasury Select Committee . , . . .raid the Cambridge outfit’s office . . . . . . . . .,”  but I knew it was all fluff and piss. Most uncomfortable.

Back in the office I call in the Permanent Secretary.

“The PM wants us to act on these data leaks,” I tell him.

“Very good, Secretary of State, how?”

“I’d hoped you’d tell me,” I reply, “of course it’s more a question of appearing to do something than actually changing anything.”

The PS looked relieved. “It’s a tricky one Secretary of State, these companies have more committed customers than most countries have populations, they are worth more than medium-sized countries’ GDP, and they’re foreign. We have neither jurisdiction nor leverage.”

“But the PM must be appeased.”

“Perhaps, Secretary of State, I could get one of the Department’s contacts at a Californian digital company to issue a statement that owing to pressure from HMG they’re tightening up their customer data auditing procedures.”

“Ah, that might do the trick.”

“I’ll get on to it right away, Secretary of State,”

“One other thing.”

“Yes, Secretary of State?”

“Could you get the statement to say ‘intense pressure from HMG’?”

“Certainly, Secretary of State.”

This story continues at Ed Gets Caught Up in The Data Leak Scandal

Or just read more coverage at Electronics Weekly

urn:contentItem:606V-J8M1-F022-H0DN-00000-00Edison Inv Research Limited: Edison issues report on the small satellite market: A New Paradigm for Space2020-06-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:41ZLexisNexisEdison Inv Research Limited: Edison issues report on the small satellite market: A New Paradigm for SpaceEdison Investment Research Limited Edison Inv Research Limited: Edison issues report on the small satellite market: A New Paradigm for Space 25-Jun-2020 / 14:59 GMT/BST  London, UK, 25 June 2020Edison issues report on the small satellite market: A New Paradigm for SpaceSmall is beautiful, especially when it comes to fulfilling the needs of consumers and Big Tech companies the world over. With half of the world still without access to the internet, the likes of Amazon, Facebook and Google cannot monetise them. So small satellites are being launched to rapidly fill this chasm.  In their new report Edison analysts Anne Margaret Crow and Andy Chambers survey the corporate launch landscape from Elon Musk's Space X and Jeff Bezos's Amazon to lesser-known - but still pivotal players - including AAC Clyde Space and Mynaric. "Mega-constellations of smallsats are emerging." says Anne Margaret. "Frost & Sullivan predicts nearly 10,000 will be launched in the next 10 years - 90% of them by entities that have already started launching them. Our analysis helps investors see which companies are well placed to benefit. "We have no doubt the trends in the industry are set to continue. During the coronavirus pandemic broadband connectivity has become a lifeline for many. Video-conferencing is up 350%, Netflix streaming by 38%. With half the world still not being able to access these services, the smallsat sector is set to be a dynamic business of increasing importance for years to come." to view the full report. All reports published by Edison are available to download free of charge from its websiteAbout Edison: Edison is an investment research and advisory company, with offices in North America, Europe, the Middle East and AsiaPac. The heart of Edison is our world-renowned equity research platform and deep multi-sector expertise. At Edison Investment Research, our research is widely read by international investors, advisers and stakeholders. Edison Advisors leverages our core research platform to provide differentiated services including investor relations and strategic consulting.Edison is authorised and regulated by the .Edison is not an adviser or broker-dealer and does not provide investment advice. Edison's reports are not solicitations to buy or sell any securities.
